content.title: Serving (1)
content.introtext:
‘Unless I wash you, you have no part with Me.’ John 13:8 NIV

Feet are generally a bit smelly. And in the first century AD, they were most certainly grotty. Imagine living in a town without slabs of concrete pavement to keep your feet from the dirt and grime beneath. Then imagine wearing only sandals, all day, every day. Dust, dung and dirt all got on people’s feet.

On the last night of His life, Jesus did a job that was normally done by the lowest rank of servants. It would have definitely been one of the worst jobs in the house. After His last dinner with the disciples, Jesus got down on His knees and washed their feet.

‘Why?’ you might ask. You wouldn’t be alone in wondering. The disciples must have been looking at each other with raised eyebrows, trying to figure out what was going on. Jesus said to them: ‘Do you understand what I have just done to you?... I, your Lord and Teacher, have just washed your feet. You, then, should wash one another’s feet.’ (John 13:12–14 GNT)

In other words, in order to serve God in a Jesus–like manner, we need to serve each other. Jesus made Himself the lowest by washing feet, so nothing should be seen as being beneath us when it comes to serving others.

SoulFood: Gen 10–12, John 18:12–24, Ps 150, Pr 29:22–27

content.title: The Waiting Game (3)
content.introtext:
‘I delight to do Your will, O my God.’ Psalm 40:8 NKJ

Imagine if the French had settled for an ‘Eiffel Chimney’. Or Michelangelo had just painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel a nice blue. Or Alexander Graham Bell had decided to just write a letter. The world would be a lot less colourful, wouldn’t it? These entrepreneurs didn’t throw in the towel the moment the headaches started. They saw the potential, pictured the dream and persevered with the vision.

To keep your dream alive, you need to keep on dreaming. Don’t let the waiting fester into frustration. Don’t sell the dream short. Don’t settle for a bargain bin sort of hope.

George Lucas had a vision to set new benchmarks for sci-fi movies. If the technology wasn’t there, he’d invent it. When the impossible started knocking on the door, he and his colleagues would return to the vision: ‘We were always dreaming of how it was going to be,’ he said.

If he can keep believing in the name of Star Wars, surely you can keep believing in the name of Jesus. The Bible’s number one dream-boy, Joseph, didn’t let knockbacks steal his destiny. Disowned, trafficked, betrayed and left to rot in a dungeon… he still believed in his initial dream. Read Joseph’s waiting game in Genesis 37-45. Take note of the obstacles Joseph overcomes in order to see his dreams turn to reality. Guess what? You might have to do some overcoming too before your dreams turn into reality.

SoulFood: Lev 11:1-13:37, Matt 5:27-37, Ps 42:6-11, Pr 1:24-28

content.title: Launch Out
content.introtext:
‘Launch out into the deep.’ Luke 5:4 KJV

Heard the saying about someone ‘being a big fish in a little pond’? Well when it comes to goldfish it isn’t true. Goldfish grow to the size of the container they’re kept in. Put one in a small glass container and it’ll grow to about eight centimetres but if you put it in a huge lake it’ll grow anywhere up to a metre long! The size of the pond determines the size of the fish. Similarly, little ideas in little-thinking minds produce little achievements. But little ideas in people with big-thinking minds produce enormous achievements. Jesus said, ‘According to your faith let it be to you.’ (Matthew 9:29 NKJ) If you reached the age of 25 and still weren’t at your full height, you’d probably get an appointment with the doctor. It’s the same with every other part of our lives: ‘Let us not go back over the beginning lessons we learned about Christ. We should not again start teaching about faith in God and about turning away from those acts that lead to death.’ (Hebrews 6:1 NCV) And what else were you were put on earth for, but to grow in God and live in His ways? So what’s holding you back? If you embrace His purpose, you’ll have a good head–start in life. Jesus said, ‘If you have faith and do not doubt, you will...be able to say to this mountain, “Go, fall into the sea.” And if you have faith, it will happen.’ (Matthew 21:21 NCV) The size of your faith shapes how you’ll do. Don’t stay small. Launch out into the deep.

SoulFood: Gen 7–9, John 18:1–11, Ps 148:7–14, Pr 29:16–21

content.title: Second Fiddle
content.introtext:
‘Love each other with genuine affection...’ Romans 12:10 NLT

Putting others first is a basic pillar of Christian community. It’s an instruction that’s written time and time again in the New Testament. For example, ‘Be devoted to each other like a loving family. Excel in showing respect for each other.’ (Romans 12:10 GWT) Loving those who buy you presents and laugh at your jokes is easy, but Jesus actually tells us to love those who look down on us and would scorn our attempts at friendship, too. It’s there in Matthew 5:44 — ‘love your enemies’!

So before you start casting derogatory remarks, look at life from their point of view. You may need to simply accept that people come in all shapes and sizes, from all sorts of backgrounds, with all sorts of baggage. Again and again, Jesus met people that His fellow religious types had written off, but He didn’t brush them aside — He had compassion on them. And it’s His design for us as the Body of Christ that we do the same — with God’s love planted deep in our soul, we trust that He will activate compassion within us, even for those we wouldn’t otherwise give a second thought. We’re not saying that this will be easy. In fact, you’ll probably need some assistance — but, remember, God’s help is only a prayer away!

SoulFood: Matt 14:22–33, 1 Kings 3:4–28

content.title: Look Up, Look Sharp (1)
content.introtext:
'Everything in me will celebrate when you speak what is right.' Proverbs 23:16 NLT

We're not going to get through life without facing some kind of criticism. So we might as well learn to recognise the value of it. Whether you're a pastor, a plumber or a pilot, it's true that the people who do well are usually those who are humble enough to take criticism on board and use it to their benefit.

Ever noticed how humility isn't actually mentioned in the Galatians 5 passage on the Fruit of the Spirit? Maybe that's because humility is the kind of soil that good fruit can grow in. We all make mistakes (and if you think you don't, then ask the person next to you what they reckon - they'll probably give you a different answer!) and we need to learn from them.

When you receive criticism, before you reach for the Kleenex or start getting defensive, work out what's behind it. If it's coming from someone you respect, take the time (and the head space) to be honest with yourself, chew it over and if they've hit on something, do something about it. Jesus said, 'The truth will set you free.' (John 8:32 NLT)

content.title: Look Up, Look Sharp (2)
content.introtext:
'He did not retaliate when He was insulted.' 1 Peter 2:23 NLT

'Sticks and stones will break my bones but words will never hurt me,' must be the most meaningless nursery rhyme of all-time. We all know it isn't true. Words can hurt. But with God on our side, we can have a confidence that makes us secure. Secure in who we are in Him, secure as a child of the living God, secure because we are made in His image, secure because we are a branch in the Vine of Jesus, secure because there is a plan and a purpose for our lives.

Sometimes you'll get criticised and the words will be just plain wrong. In that instance, take a deep breath, recognise it for what it is and move on. If Jesus had let every discouragement and put-down soak in, He might never have gone through with His master plan.

You're not responsible for the criticism you receive, but you do have the power over how it affects you. A smart, sarcastic response might be the most instinctive comeback. Turning the other cheek might sound like an old fashioned way to respond, but it could be the way to make God smile. Keep looking to Jesus as your example: 'He did not retaliate when He was insulted. When He suffered, He did not threaten to get even. He left His case in the hands of God, who always judges fairly.' (1 Peter 2:23 NLT)



SoulFood: Rom 3:21-6:23, John 14:1-14, Ps 118:10-18, Pr 28:1-4

content.title: Look Up, Look Sharp (3)
content.introtext:
'It is to one's honour to avoid strife.' Proverbs 20:3 NIV

Oops. You've made a mistake. A hash of it all. Fact is, it's not an innocent error. You've gone and done it. You've sinned. You can't hide and there are no fig leaves to wear. What do you do? Sit around and mope?

When Formula 1 cars have got a problem, the drivers don't just let the car grind to a halt, make a cup of tea and feel sorry for themselves. They get in the pit lane, correct the problem and get back on the track. There's a race to be won! The only real mistake is...to not learn from a mistake. Regain your focus, and put right what went wrong.

Proverbs says, 'As iron sharpens iron, so a friend sharpens a friend.' (Proverbs 27:17 NLT) That's a good way to get right back on track. But with metal work, sparks can fly. A mate pulling you up might be hard in the short term, but it will help you to look up and look sharp. So don't fight fire with fire, because 'only fools insist on quarrelling.' (Proverbs 20:3 NLT) Instead, rise above the conflict, regain your clear sight and remember who God says you are, in Christ. The Bible says 'Confess your sins to each other and pray for each other so that you may be healed.' (James 5:16 NIV) Who can you take your sins to? Ask God for His strength as you walk forward again.



SoulFood: Rom 7:1-9:16, John 14:15-25, Ps 118:19-29, Pr 28:5-8

content.title: Look Up, Look Sharp (4)
content.introtext:
'If God is for us, who can be against us?' Romans 8:31 NKJ

As humans we love 'having a go' at other people. We love a bit of 'critical analysis'. Whether it's sharing our take on why the latest pop star wannabe failed, or taking part in a post football match discussion to slaughter the ref, we can't help ourselves. We like to dress it up, but usually it's nothing more than plain old nasty.

Jesus received a good share of 'critical analysis', sometimes for nothing more than where He was from. 'Nazareth! exclaimed Nathanael. Can anything good come from there? Just come and see for yourself, Philip said.' (John 1:46 NLT) And Nathanael did see, as over time Jesus showed him He was who He said He was.

Jesus had faith that His Father was for Him. If you've been criticised by another Christian, that faithfulness test is one of the things that shows how trustworthy you are, and it may prove to critics that they got you wrong. 'And if our God is with us, then what could stand against' is more than a line from a worship song. It's a deep-rooted mind-set that can empower you to do what God has called you to do, no matter how tough the criticism.

Judges 5:21 NIV says, 'March on, my soul; be strong.' Is there a dream you once had that you've given up on because of discouragement? Get on your knees, and pray life back in to that dream.



SoulFood: Rom 9:17-11:36, John 14:26-15:4, Ps 146, Pr 28:9-12

content.title: Decisions, Decisions...
content.introtext:
'Lord, point out the road for me to follow.' Psalm 25:4 NLT

The decisions we make are important. Standing in front of a non-Christian crowd to tell them that your life revolves around Jesus might take real guts... but ask yourself this: would they be able to tell how important Jesus is to you if you didn't? The decisions we make in our life should reflect who our God is. If we're going through life making woeful choices and continually picking our way out of a crisis situation, it won't reflect well on the holy and perfect God who we claim is in control of our lives.

Albert Camus said, 'Life is a sum of all your choices.' Are your choices different because of Jesus, or are they still focused on looking after number one?

'Don't copy the behaviour and customs of this world, but be a new and different person with a new freshness in all you do and think. Then you will learn from your own experience how His ways will really satisfy you.' (Romans 12:2 TLB)

This isn't about Jesus saving us, and then instantly trusting us to spontaneously make the right choices all the time. That's the end goal, but we don't get there overnight. He tells us to be a new and different person. We can only do that with His strength, but it takes work. It's only when we train ourselves (in His grace and by His Spirit) by making a thousand little right choices that we can be trusted, when decision one-thousand-and-one arrives, to make the holy one. So decide now to put a plan in place that will enable you to follow Jesus more easily when the next big crunch comes along.



SoulFood: Rom 12-14, John 15:5-17, Ps 14, Pr 28:13-16

content.title: Working for God - His Way
content.introtext:
'...Created in Christ Jesus to do good works...' Ephesians 2:10 NIV

God has made you a particular way for particular purposes, complete with specific gifts and talents. Being busy for the sake of it wasn't the plan. Lamborghini manufactures both tractors and sports cars. Although the badge is the same, their tractors aren't lightning fast and their sports cars can't tow a plough through a muddy field. So, turn to God, and let Him tell you what you're here for.

Henri Nouwen wrote: 'Many voices ask for our attention... But underneath all these often very noisy voices is a still, small voice that says, You are My Beloved, My favour rests on you. That's the voice we need most of all to hear. To hear that voice, however, requires special effort; it requires solitude, silence, and a strong determination to listen.'

You need to listen to God before you can start working for God. Sitting by God's feet is where you'll end up one day, and it's the only sure foundation for success in this life. It's difficult to find what He wants for your life until you can hear His voice above anyone else's - then, and only then, can you '...let God transform you into a new person by changing the way you think. Then you will learn to know God's will for you, which is good and pleasing and perfect.' (Romans 12:2 NLT)

If you want God to tell you what you're here for, try finding a quiet place to spend time listening to Him. Ask Him to protect you from mishearing Him, or being deceived - read a chunk of the Bible first and ask Him what He'd like to share with you.



SoulFood: Rom 15-16, John 15:18-27, Ps 65, Pr 28:17-20

content.title: Bad-Mouthing
content.introtext:
'You will know how people must conduct themselves in the household of God.' 1 Timothy 3:15 NLT

Just imagine your five fingers sitting down together for a good gossip-and-gripe session about how uppity the elbow has got. The idea that one part of the body could think itself superior to another part is pretty silly! They all have their own contribution to make. It's just like that in the Body of Christ - the Church - in your local area.

If you're at a good church, thank God, but watch out you don't damage the rest of the Body by bad-mouthing another group of Christians down the road. And, if there's one person that feels isolated in your own church... that's one person too many. But the answer to that problem might be you! There are always ways to help. Why not take them a cup of coffee, ask them how they are and start taking a heartfelt interest in their life. After all, 'God places the lonely in families' (Psalm 68:6 NLT), which means you may have some brothers and sisters at church you need to get acquainted with.

As well as isolation, gossip can ruin things, and needs to be dealt with - by you! Don't engage with it, even if it's dressed up as Christian concern. 'Do not criticise one another, my friends.' (James 4:11 GNT) Unless you are willing to talk directly to the person concerning something specific, don't talk about them. And don't let anybody else talk about them either. It might not be easy, but it is that straightforward. Be a good influence in your church.



SoulFood: 2 Chron 7:12-16, Matt 6:5-15

content.title: Going It Alone? (1)
content.introtext:
'It is too much for me.' Numbers 11:14 NCV

Moses was having a bad day. There he was, out in the desert with all the people God had called out of Egypt and, no matter which way he turned, there was moaning and complaining. 'No meat,' the people whined. 'No garlic. No melons. No cucumber. We were better off as slaves.'

No wonder Moses was fed up. These people were willing to give up their freedom for a cucumber! He started on his own moan to God. It might not seem an appropriate attitude from a servant of the Most High God, the man chosen to receive the Ten Commandments, but Moses had had enough. He was ready to toss in the towel.

But God had some advice: 'Gather for Me seventy men... and let them take their stand there with you. I will take some of the Spirit that is on you and put it on them, and they shall bear the burden of the people with you, so that you may not bear it yourself alone.' (Numbers 11:16-17 ESV)

Being a lone ranger can make you easy pickings for the enemy. So look around, pray, and share your load.

Belonging to a small group of Christians who can support you when life gets rough (and when it's just everyday up-and-downs) can be very helpful. If you're not already a member of a small group, ask your church about joining one.



SoulFood: Ecc 1-4, John 16:1-11, Ps 130, Pr 28:21-24

content.title: Going It Alone? (2)
content.introtext:
'They shall bear the burden...with you.' Numbers 11:17 NKJ

'I have a dream!' said Martin Luther King Jr. 'My lord, I have a cunning plan,' said Baldrick. You may be a visionary, but you will not succeed until you learn to inspire others with your vision and have them take it up for themselves. Top Tip Time: inspiring others requires credibility and conviction. People will only get involved if they can see that you're fully behind it yourself.

Psychologist Dr. Larry Crabb describes what it's like when the right message, spoken by the right messenger, is spoken to the right people: 'A vision we give to others of who and what they could become, has power when it echoes what the spirit has already spoken into their souls.' That power can convince people to join you in the pursuit of your vision, and greatly enhances your chances of success.

The Bible isn't a maths text book, but still here's an equation to ponder: one person can put a thousand others to flight, but two people can put ten thousand others to flight (Deuteronomy 32:30). The Scriptures teach us the power of working alongside each other. Take a group of people united in one vision, and the anointing of the Lord, and you'll accomplish more than you ever dreamed possible.



SoulFood: Ecc 5-8, John 16:12-18, Ps 2, Pr 28:25-28

content.title: Is Christ Credible? (1)
content.introtext:
'...the Scripture would be fulfilled...' John 19:28 NIV

We're taking a different tack with these next two days' readings. Lots of people today shrug off Jesus by pointing to what they call the 'historical inaccuracy' of His resurrection. So we're going to try and look at a simple way of looking at Christ's resurrection that might not be so easy to write off.

Today we'll start by asking, 'What's the problem?' Well, even as far back as 50 AD or thereabouts, Paul said that the message of Christ was 'a stumbling block to Jews and foolishness to Gentiles.' (1 Corinthians 1:23 NIV) This meant that Jews thought His death and resurrection was blasphemy ('God dying?! How dare you suggest it!'), and the Gentiles (people who didn't believe in Israel's God) thought coming back from the dead just didn't make sense!

The Gentiles were like many non-believers today: resurrection seems plain ridiculous to them. And perhaps they have a point. After all, people don't tend to come back to life after they die. And it's not scientifically provable that it actually happened, because in order for something to be scientifically provable, you need to be able to repeat it to test it... which we can't do either.

So what gives it that all-important credibility? That's something we'll look at tomorrow. But today, think about why you believe in Jesus. What makes you accept the Bible's story that He died and came back again? Are you able to give a reason for 'the hope that is within you'?

content.title: Is Christ Credible? (2)
content.introtext:
'...the Scripture would be fulfilled...' John 19:28 NIV

Yesterday we asked you to think about why you believe in Jesus. Today, we'll take a quick look at what we think gives His message, death and resurrection believability.

Ever heard the phrase, 'There's no smoke without fire?' Think about that big oil rig explosion off the coast of America a couple of years ago. Even fifty kilometres away from the fire, the smoke kept on going and going.

It's like that with the disciples in the early church. They were incredibly passionate, some would have said insanely so, about their real life relationship experience with the risen Jesus. Smoke without fire? Mass hallucination? Sure, it's been claimed. But all the sceptics needed to do to quiet the Christians' commotion was produce Jesus' dead body. So why didn't they?

Maybe the disciples stole it? But would so many have gone to their deaths (pretty gory ones too) for what they knew to be a lie, for no earthly gain?

Or maybe they were all honest fools, duped by a crazy idea. But, unlike followers of other religions, they didn't die for an idea, they died for what they had seen and experienced - Christ's resurrection - and His real life relationship with them, post-resurrection.

There's more - the Jewish historian Josephus mentioned the disciples' testimony, and was alive at their time. Heaps of Old Testament prophecies point to Jesus - you don't have to believe the Bible is holy to see that these historical predictions came true, even about things Jesus couldn't have invented (like where He was born!)

These points just can't be brushed away - they're a powerful testimony to a real-life God!

content.title: Stone in Focus
content.introtext:
'Roll the stone aside, Jesus told them.' John 11:39 NLT

Lazarus was dead. There was no hiding it. It had been three days. But nothing's impossible with God, right? A heavy stone stood between Lazarus and new life. Then Jesus gave the command, 'Remove the stone.'

God knows how our hearts can become stone-hard. People hurt us. We hurt ourselves. We hurt other people. It's called sin, and it's more lethal than a terminal illness. Simply being a Christian doesn't make you immune. It subtly creeps in like cancer and causes us to die spiritually - and ultimately physically. All of this puts a solid wall between us and the fullness of life God wants for us.

But He is God, He is good and He hasn't left us alone. 'And I will give you a new heart with new and right desires, and I will put a new spirit in you. I will take out your stony heart of sin and give you a new, obedient heart.' (Ezekiel 36:26 NLT) That's what Jesus can do - His power is strong enough to shift any stony heart, restore what you've lost and bring new life from certain death. Jesus enables you to be right with Him and others. But change only begins when you're willing to 'take away the stone' and allow God to deal with what's behind it. Are you willing to do that?



SoulFood: Gen 4-6, John 17:13-26, Ps 148:1-6, Pr 29:11-15

content.title: Hungry for His Word (3)
content.introtext:
'The grass withers...but the Word of our God stands forever.' Isaiah 40:8 NLT

The third and main reason for reading your Bible is because it's all about Jesus! Everything in the Bible in some way points towards the Son of GodHe is the most significant man who ever walked the earth. Other faiths talk about Jesus as a good man, a prophet or a moral teacher but that just doesn't get close to the truth. The Bible shows Jesus to be God Himself! And there's loads of historical and archaeological proof that the Bible holds its own as a piece of true historical literature.

This is what historian Philip Schaff had to say, 'This Jesus of Nazareth, without money and arms, conquered more millions than...Napoleon; without science and learning, He shed more light on things human and divine than all philosophers and scholars combined... He spoke such words of life as were never spoken before or since... without writing a single line, He set more pens in motion...than the whole army of great men of ancient and modern times.' And Napoleon Bonaparte himself said, 'I know men and I tell you that Jesus Christ is no mere man. Between Him and every other person in the world there is no possible term of comparison... Jesus Christ founded His empire upon love.'

The Bible. Don't miss out. Find your love for Jesus, and from that place, get stuck into reading about Him!



SoulFood: Ex 22-24, John 7:14-24, Ps 104:1-23, Pr 24:26-27

content.title: When People Leave the Church (3)
content.introtext:
‘Let us not…judge one another anymore ...’ Romans 14:13 KJV

‘It’s not God I’ve got a problem with, it’s those so–called Christians!’
You might have heard some people say this kind of thing, but have they got a point? Judgmental, holier–than–thou types can drive people round the bend — and right out of Church! When Jesus first told the story of the prodigal son, His intended audience was the Pharisees: the religious do–gooders of the time; and in classic Jesus–style, He used a simple story to get under their skin. The older brother in the story may have known how to be a dutiful son, but he certainly didn’t know how to be a brother. Maybe it’s no surprise the younger son walked out the door.
The apostle Paul says, ‘Don’t condemn each other any more...’ (Romans 14:13 NLT) Power and status over other people can be a serious temptation and when you find yourself feeling you’re ‘better’ than someone else — whether they’ve left the Church, or are just struggling with things you’ve got sorted — it can give you a serious ego boost. He goes on: ‘Decide instead to live in such a way that you will not put an obstacle in another Christian’s path.’ (Romans 14:13 NLT) Don’t let your heart get poisoned with pride. Make sure your Heavenly Father can say you’ve been a good sibling, as well as a good son or daughter. And when we’re tempted to sneer down on those who have left the Church, just think — that may well be the attitude that drove them away in the first place.


SoulFood: Is 63–66, John 13:18–30, Ps 114, Pr 27:20–22

content.title: Put Your Foot Down (1)
content.introtext:
'...Joshua...summoned all the men of Israel and said..."Put your feet on the necks of these kings..."' Joshua 10:24 NIV

After literally years of waiting, Joshua got to live in the land God has promised the Israelites. It was amazing. After nearly four decades, he was finally there but then he found everyone was out to do him over! Five kings with armies, each with their own weird name: AdoniZedek king of Jerusalem, Hoham king of Hebron, Piram king of Jarmuth, Japhia king of Lachish and Debir king of Eglon. They all combined against Joshua for one massive scrap, but God was on Joshua's side. What followed is a rather unpleasant death for each of them.

But what's in a name? The meaning of each king's name might be significant, by warning us about certain attitudes that can rob us of all that we can be. The first king's name is all about 'robbing our peace'. With no peace, doing the simplest thing is a nightmare. The second warns us about 'being religious'. The third means 'like a wild ass'-enough said?! But also, this 'wildness' could refer to being isolated from other Christians. The fourth means 'shining'. This isn't bad in itself. However, if you reckon you're God's gift to the world and are lapping up the glory, you're just idolising yourself. Finally: Debir, the last king: his warns us about bad mouthing other Christians. Whatever stinking attitude you've got: put your foot down and kill it!

You can read the story for yourself in Joshua 10:16-27.



SoulFood: Num 9:15-23, Gal 5:13-26

content.title: Put Your Foot Down (2)
content.introtext:
'...So they came forward and placed their feet on their necks.' Joshua 10:24 NIV

Sometimes life's a battle. Just when you feel you're making advances, a hand grenade comes at you from round the corner. Great! Joshua probably felt pretty overwhelmed himself. Taking on one army's one thing, but to have five come at you is a bit much. And without God, it would be far too much. But this is WITH God.

Can't multitask? God can! Is life piling on the pressure? God wants you to stand solid in Him. The Bible says 'We live by faith, not by sight.' (2 Corinthians 5:7 NIV) This means that we're not going to know how it's all going to pan out, or how God's going to provide. We can't be sure certain things will turn out the way we hope or expect. But God is with us through it all. In fact, He promises He will 'never leave you...never abandon you.' (Hebrews 13:5 GNT) And He never goes back on a promise!

Looking at our life with our own tiny human perspective only reveals part of God's big picture. The grand old duke of York had ten thousand men, but they were up, down and all over the place! Emotions are no different. If you allow your emotions to rule your life you will be up one minute and down the next. Do you think life is supposed to be an up and down experience? Wrong! God's plan for you is to get down on your knees to pray, then get up in faith and do what He's told you to do.



SoulFood: Ex 25-27, John 7:25-44, Ps 104:24-35, Pr 24:28-29

content.title: The Most Important Relationship
content.introtext:
'...I never knew you, go away...' Matthew 7:23 NLT

The most important relationship you will ever have for the rest of your life is the one you have with God Himself. It's one you will be in for all eternity and it's the very reason you were created in the first place. So the question is: on a busy day when your mum wants to chat about your studies and your friend calls to invite you round, but your youth club is about to start, which do you drop first? Would it even cross your mind that you've spent no time with God lately?

For centuries Bible experts have argued about the point when someone is 'saved' and whether you can lose your place in Heaven once you've got it. The truth of the matter is, on the final day when you're standing face to face with Jesus, the simple question will be: 'Do you know me?' You see it doesn't matter what we've done and what we've said. The question is: do you have a real relationship with Jesus? When you look into someone's eyes, you both know whether or not you have a relationship. There's only two of you, you can't fake it or pretend you have if you've not. Nothing needs to be said, you both know exactly where you stand.

So remember, although you can look like a fantastic Christian on paper, it's really all about you and Jesus-nothing else matters.



SoulFood: Ex 28-29, John 7:45-53, Ps 9, Pr 24:30-34

content.title: Hello!
content.introtext:
'On the third day, He shall rise again.' Luke 18:33 NIV

Halloween Night is an annual bit of so-called 'fun' when parents dress their children up as Satan's little helpers and demand treats from neighbours 'or else'!

It's true that Christians are known for being a bit sensitive when it comes to the subject of 'Halloween', but everyone with a braincell between their ears ought to see that there are better things to throw a party over! And anyway, if it's out-of-this-world supernatural stuff you're looking for then crack open the party-poppers for Jesus; He's King of the supernatural:

(1) Demons shrieked when He walked down the street-and ran from Him fearing His power to bind them in eternal chains with a single Word (2) The forces of nature obeyed His command, water turned to wine, crashing waves became gentle ripples and fish even coughed up coins! (3) He died, and then rose from the dead! He didn't return from the grave as a moaning, groaning half-dead shadow of His former self; His resurrected body was now fit for eternity, like ours will be when we're raised to reign with Him on the final day.

The most supernatural thing of all is that Jesus is here right now with you by His Holy Spirit. Say, 'Hello,' right now; ask Jesus to say, 'Hello,' right back in your life.

There's a prayer at the back of this magazine to introduce you to Jesus and make today just Hello not Halloween.



SoulFood: Deut 18:9-18, Dan 2, Isa 47:5-15, Acts 16:16-34

content.title: Translated
content.introtext:
'Whatever the Father does, the Son also does.' John 5:19 NLT

Gandhi once said, 'You Christians look after a document containing enough dynamite to blow all civilisation to pieces, turn the world upside down and bring peace to a battle-torn planet. But you treat it as if it is nothing more than a piece of literature.' The Bible is the Word of God, it's deep, earthshaking truth on paper, it's the keys to transformed living; but it's hard to ignore the fact Gandhi's right about our attitudes. How can those of your mates who won't go near a Bible discover God for themselves?

Well, your friends may read the Bible 1% of the time, but they read you 99% of the time. That means you and I have a job on our hands. We're called to be Bible 'translators', of a sort. Our words and attitudes should 'translate' the Bible from words on a page to life, and communicate some of the truth about God to those around us. 'If my friends were only to open the Bible,' we think, 'they'd find themselves face-to-face with God's truth!' Here's the thing. If they look at us, they should really be able to see the same deep, earthshaking truth of God, in the flesh! That sort of a light-up-the-world life is promised for us, but it's not guaranteed. It's only when we've spent time in God's presence - when we've seen and heard - that we will be able to 'translate' God's truth in a way that compels others to listen.

content.title: No Place Like Home
content.introtext:
'Lord, through all the generations You have been our home!' Psalm 90:1 NLT

At the end of a hard day it feels good to come home to a place you know - a place where you can kick off your shoes, be yourself, and not worry about what anybody thinks. And reverently speaking, God's presence can become equally comfortable to you too. With time, you can learn to go to Him for strength, for protection, and for guidance. God wants you to be at home in His presence and aware of His nearness at all times. We think of God as a deity to talk about instead of a place to dwell, but God wants us to see Him as the One in whom '...we live and move and have our being...' (Acts 17:28 NIV) When God led the children of Israel through the wilderness, He didn't just show up once a day and then disappear. No, the pillar of fire was there with them all night and the cloud of smoke was with them all day. God never leaves us. Jesus promised, '...I am with you always...' (Matthew 28:20 NIV) The Psalmist said, 'The one thing I ask of the Lord - the thing I seek most - is to live in the house of the Lord all the days of my life...' (Psalm 27:4 NLT) You might be thinking... 'I'd love to live in God's house too, but I'm stuck in the real world.' Actually; you are just one decision away from your Father's presence. You don't need to change your address - just your perception. Wherever you go today, whatever you face today, remind yourself: 'He is with me!'



SoulFood: Ex 30-32, John 8:1-20, Ps 96, Pr 25:1-7

content.title: Valiant Warriors (1)
content.introtext:
'All these men of war...were of one mind to make David king.' 1 Chronicles 12:38 NKJ

Read a bit about King David's soldiers in 1 & 2 Chronicles and a band of hulking warriors might come to mind. Sword-toting, arrow-slinging, 'they looked like lions and were as fast as gazelles on the hills.' (1 Chronicles 12:8 GWT) These guys sound like merciless killing machines! But read between the lines, and you'll see that underneath their leather hides and thick skins was something more than brute force. What made David's warriors valiant?

There are three basic things that made them the cream of the crop. They never gave up when the going got tough. They worked together as a team. And they always stayed faithful to their commander. You're probably not enlisted in a regiment like David's, but you could still learn a thing or two from these guys! The spirit of a valiant warrior - God's kind, anyway - goes deeper.

Just as they trained to be persistent in hard times, so should we. 2 Timothy 2:3 NIV says, 'Endure hardship...like a good soldier of Christ Jesus.' In the same spirit of unity that they had, Philippians 2:2 NLT asks us to '[agree] wholeheartedly with each other, loving one another, and working together with one mind and purpose.' And just as they are to stay close to their commander, Hebrews 3:1 NIV talks straight to us: 'Holy brothers and sisters, God chose you... So keep thinking about Jesus... We believe in Him.'

content.title: Valiant Warriors (2)
content.introtext:
'All these men of war...were of one mind to make David king.' 1 Chronicles 12:38 NKJ

Joining the army is no ordinary career - it's more than just a job. Not everyone can join: there's a process to go through and requirements to be met. It's a way of life filled with great benefits, but also harsh uncertainty. The life of a soldier is not easy. Being a Christian is no ordinary way to live either. It too is a life filled with benefits but it's also not easy. It can be a struggle living as a Christian, especially as we're not given a get-out-of-jail-free card to exempt us from difficulties and doubts that others go through.

In much of the world, being a Christian can be as life-threatening as being a soldier. In over fifty countries Christians are persecuted: actively sought out and punished for standing up for Jesus. There must be a very strong temptation to go AWOL.

Perhaps what made David's men stay strong as valiant warriors was that they were united and determined. We need to be united with those suffering for being Christians: standing together, upholding one another in prayer and showing support for one another. And we need to be determined: never giving up on them.

Visit www.opendoors.org.au and make an effort to find out more about our persecuted sisters and brothers and what you can do to show unity and determination on their behalf.

content.title: Valiant Warriors (3)
content.introtext:
'All these men of war...were of one mind to make David king.' 1 Chronicles 12:38 NKJ

Have you ever thought to yourself: 'It must be ok. After all, I'm doing it for God.' We may have good intentions, but just because we think we're doing something for God doesn't necessarily mean it's ok!

King David wanted to do something special for God. He laid down plans to bring God's Ark back to Jerusalem (nothing to do with Noah - this was the Ark of the Covenant, a holy container housing the original stones engraved with the Ten Commandments.)

As the leader of an army of united and determined warriors, the whole nation was behind David. But, caught up in eagerness, he had not paid attention to God's instructions. He chose a convenient way to get the job done, ignoring the obedient way. The consequences were fatal for a man called Uzzah (you can read about it in 1 Chronicles 13.)

David had the right motives but the wrong methods. In trying to be sincere, he got things sincerely wrong. David learned the hard way that God's will must be done in God's way. Learn from David's mistake, don't repeat it. Remember: both your motives and your methods matter to God.

content.title: Costly Business
content.introtext:
'If you do not carry your own cross and follow Me, you cannot be My disciple.' Luke 14:27 NLT

This is tough talk from Jesus. He's asking his listeners to take a position: are you in or out? Are you with Me or not? And the way He said He knows you're serious about being His disciple comes down to actions, not just words.

Discipleship counts the cost: are you willing to take the responsibilities as well as the rewards of following Jesus? There are countless benefits in being a Christian but there's also a high cost.

Many people wear a cross as jewellery. Jesus' first followers wouldn't have thought that there's anything pretty about identifying yourself as a Christian this way - after all the cross was an instrument of torture and death. So when Jesus talks about carrying our crosses, He's talking about being willing to sacrifice our own agendas.

And that's the heart of the matter: if it comes to it, are you willing to let your own goals, glory and gain 'die' for the sake of following the Master? If your answer is 'no', Jesus is clear: you cannot be His disciple. Ouch.

Brother Lawrence of the Resurrection said: 'Let us think often, that our only business in this life is to please God.' Practice asking yourself this question before each action, word or thought: 'Will this please the Lord?'

content.title: Sparrows and You
content.introtext:
'Martha...you are worried and upset about many things...' Luke 10:41 NIV

In Matthew 10:29 NIV, Jesus says 'Are not two sparrows sold for a penny? Yet not one of them will fall to the ground apart from the will of your Father.' The sparrows that were common at the time Jesus said this were noisy little nuisances, and they were everywhere. Market traders would catch a handful to sell for a penny, but they weren't much of a meal. Worse than that, they would nestle in any place they could find. King David noticed that they even settled near God's altars (Psalm 84:3)!

And yet, God grants the sparrow - an everyday, insignificant creature - His attention. His eyes are on every creature, no matter how small. So how much more will He grant us His care?

If you were to pluck a single hair from your head, God would know the exact number left behind. (Luke 12:7) As you go outside today, notice the sky, flowers, trees, birds and clouds. Think about this - God ensures that every part of His creation can be provided for, from sweeping fields of corn and flowers, to the most miniature insect. (Luke 12:24-28) He sees every detail. Sometimes it's easy to get worked up about every little thing that comes up, just like Martha did when Jesus popped round for tea. Jesus helped Martha put her life in better perspective: 'Martha...only one thing is needed. Mary has chosen...it...' And what had Mary chosen? Sitting at the feet of Jesus! God provides daily, just enough, no more and no less. We can, and should, fix our eyes on that fact.

When you wake up each day, take time to find things you can think of to thank God for. Everything down to the breath in your lungs comes from Him, so there should be no shortage!



SoulFood: Is 1-3, John 9:1-12, Ps 15, Pr 25:21-2

content.title: Critics and Cheerleaders
content.introtext:
'Love one another: just as I have loved you.' John 13:34 ESV

When Jesus says, 'Love one another,' the word He uses has a sense of self-sacrificing nurture. Think of a mother and her child. He's saying that we should love one another like that - treating each other gently, affectionately, and always seeking the best for each other.

You might think of someone in your church or youth group and think the kind of love they need most is tough love. But beneath the mask, we all desperately need to be nurtured. God gives us the church, youth groups and friends so we can nurture and be nurtured.

The story is told of a little girl who came home from church one Sunday and announced, 'I want to be like the man who stood up in the pulpit today.' Delighted, her mum said, 'That's lovely, dear. So you want to go into the ministry?' 'No,' she replied, 'I want to tell people what to do!'

Some of us want to be authority figures so we can correct people and give them our so-called 'constructive criticism'. But most people don't need a critic, they need a cheerleader. When you nurture people they will welcome you to speak into their life - and they will listen. Paul wrote, 'Encourage each other and build each other up.' (1 Thessalonians 5:11 NLT) With a simple phone call, txt or email you could encourage someone today!

content.title: Forget Him Not
content.introtext:
'This I call to mind and therefore I have hope.' Lamentations 3:21 NIV

'I was twelve at the time,' recalled a woman in her forties, 'when...for the first time I spoke to God, knowing He was alive and listening. I asked Him if we could be best friends forever, and He said, Yes! I often look back and remember that day, especially on bad hair days - those days when I'm confused, full of doubt, disappointed, fearful, lonely, anxious, hurting, full of self-loathing, or plain disillusioned with life.'

It's said that 'we're not slow learners, just quick forgetters.' In the Bible, when God separated the Jordan River for His people to walk through, He told them to build a statue of stones there so that they would always remember the miracle He'd done for them. It was a physical object, anchoring God's trustworthiness in a constant presence. It was to help them call God's goodness to mind. Just like the lady in today's story has done, and just like God's people did, it's important for you to mark out some key moments when you knew God was there for you. Obviously it doesn't have to be a tower of stones, but what can you create to remind yourself of times God was there for you? A journal of collected prayers? Post-it notes of things God has done? It's up to you, but the important thing is to remember to remember... so that we don't forget in the dark what God has done for us in the light.



SoulFood: Is 8-11, John 9:24-41, Ps 99, Pr 25:26-28

content.title: Reasons to Believe
content.introtext:
'Only fools say in their hearts, There is no God.' Psalm 14:1 NLT

Here's something you don't need to be reminded of: being openly Christian in a mainstream school or a secular workplace is tough. It can feel like you're swimming upstream all the time - like everyone's going in the opposite direction to you. How do you cope with being Christian in a classroom full of (seeming) atheists?

1. Be informed. The Bible is a miraculous book - from the way it was written, handed down and translated, to its amazing unity. Jesus lived, and no credible historian will dispute the evidence of His life and ministry. And two billion believers worldwide and generations of men and women who changed the world claim to have met Him. Spend time reading good books and learning about the reasons why your faith makes complete sense.

2. Be gracious. Nobody is ever argued into the Kingdom of God: they are loved into it. Most people need to feel they belong before they could consider believing. So pray for your unbelieving friends and ask God for opportunities to show them His love. Be patient, but expect God to open doors for you. Remember: the majority of atheists out there aren't die-hards, rather they have never had a chance to get to know God yet.

Build up your faith by learning why the Christian faith makes sense (this is sometimes called 'apologetics'). There are great resources available by people like Ravi Zacharias and Chuck Missler. Check them out on YouTube.

content.title: Fooling Around (1)
content.introtext:
'You fool! You will die this very night. Then who will get it all?' Luke 12:20 NLT

Gimme, gimme, gimme, more, more, more! It's easy to become consumed with getting stuff, the latest, coolest, trendiest...things. Or our image: Let's spruce ourselves up and look the part, life's for living - now!

Life can easily become all about the here and now, with no thought about what's next. But what is next? What's happening when the party's over? Is there another one? Where are we going when this life ends?

It's said that the average body has enough phosphorus to make 2200 match heads, enough sugar to go into 60 cubes, enough salt to fill 20 spoons, and enough iron to make about $10 worth of nails. The rest is just dust and water. When we pamper the part of us that's on the surface and neglect the fact there's much more to us than skin and muscles, it's no wonder that God calls us 'fools'!

No one can guarantee when they will die, only that they definitely will. So take note, and take care of your whole being, because it's all intertwined - soul and body - and if you're part of God's family, it's destined for something much bigger and better than just this life.

content.title: Fooling Around (2)
content.introtext:
'Did Abner die like a fool?' 2 Samuel 3:33 NCV

Two opposing armies had come face to face. They had taken up daggers and swords, and both ended up beating the other to a pulp. The fighting just kept going from bad to worse. Abner came face to face with Asahel: 'Therefore Abner struck him in the stomach with the blunt end of the spear, so that the spear came out of his back; and he fell down there and died on the spot.' (2 Samuel 2:23 NKJ) Now Joab (Asahel's brother) was out to get him! But instead of staying inside the city of Hebron where he would be protected, Abner met with his enemy at the city gates. Joab took the opportunity to kill him. 'He drew his dagger and killed Abner in revenge.' (2 Samuel 3:27 NLT)

'Did Abner die like a fool?' He knew what to do - and didn't do it. There were no rivers to cross to get to freedom, no mountains to climb, no fees to be paid. Hebron was a city of sanctuary - a safe refuge for anyone pursued for a crime. All Abner had to do was stay inside. A life-saving decision he foolishly chose to ignore.

Jesus calls us to Him. It's sensible to go to Him. It's life-saving. It's life-changing. Most of all, it's the only proper response to the announcement that He is the true King of everything and everywhere.

Don't fool around with this life. Don't stop at the gates. Romans 10:9 NIV tells us that when you '... confess with your mouth Jesus is Lord and believe in your heart that God raised Him from the dead, you will be saved.' Isn't it time to make a choice for Him?

content.title: Word Seeds
content.introtext:
'Whatever you plant is what you'll harvest.' Galatians 6:7 GWT

The Bible is full of helpful hints and trustworthy tips that, when acted upon, move us towards real change for the better. Do you want to come up smelling of roses? Then take notice of this pretty piece of advice: '...whatever seed a man puts in, that will he get back as grain... He who puts in the seed of the flesh will...get the reward of death; but he who puts in the seed of the Spirit will...get the reward of eternal life.' (Galatians 2:7-8 BBE)

If you think of your words and actions like seeds and the person you speak them to as soil, then your words are about the harvest that you end up with. So, for example, if you speak lies to a friend, an untrustworthy relationship will grow. The only way to build good, solid relationships is to talk with words that are true, kind and generously spoken. Out of that grows faithful friendships.

What about how you talk to yourself? Someone once asked, 'If you had a friend who spoke to you in the same way that you sometimes speak to yourself, how long would you allow that person to be your friend?' Could it be that you are your harshest critic? Little words of criticism, telling yourself that you are not being pretty enough, thin enough, clever enough, good enough? Speak God's words of love, forgiveness, beauty and strength into your own life too, and see how they grow. Set yourself a challenge today: speak words that build people up, and don't say anything critical about anyone - and that includes yourself.

content.title: Love Your Leader
content.introtext:
'I will give you shepherds after my own heart. They will...feed you with knowledge and insight.' Jeremiah 3:15 GWT

Did you know that over 50% of those who enter full-time Christian ministry leave it within ten years because of discouragement? Ground down by the demands of unappreciative people, starved of positive words, they just give up and go back to something else. Isn't that tragic?

'Pastor' simply means shepherd - and God knows we need shepherds. In many ways we're just like sheep - often we're a bit thick, we don't know what's good for us, we follow the herd and we get ourselves into some real scrapes. But a pastor leads their sheep to safe places where they can feed and protects them from predators and other dangers.

Pastors need pastoring too. Of course, they need to look first of all to Jesus, who calls himself the Good Shepherd (see John 10: 1-17). But we have a part to play - and there's a good reason why.

Hebrews 13:17 NCV says God gives us leaders and spiritual mentors to '...watch over [our] souls...' and we are to give them reason to do this 'with joy, not sadness'. Interestingly, the writer finishes with a few extra words: 'That would certainly not be for your benefit.' (NLT) Loving the leaders God has given us is good for us too. We can do this in practical ways like praying for them, encourage them and thank them next time you see them.

content.title: Draw on God's power in you
content.introtext:
'God...is able...to accomplish infinitely more...' Ephesians 3:20 NLT

Being born wasn't your doing, and it's probably for the best that it wasn't! Imagine if everyone had control over what went into 'us'. We'd probably all turn out pretty similar, because our creativity is seriously limited compared to the Creator of the universe. 'God... is able... to accomplish infinitely more.'

He only made one you, with all the true individuality and uniqueness that comes from an infinitely creative God. You are an incredible masterpiece - the one and only you that ever has been or ever will be. How amazing! 'Thank You for making me so wonderfully complex! Your workmanship is marvellous.' (Psalm 139:14 NLT)

Sometimes being different can make you feel misunderstood, like no one sees the real you. But know this: God made you, so He 'gets' you. In fact God knows you better than you know yourself; He knows your thoughts, your comings and goings, how many hairs are on your head... He knows everything about you. More than that, He has put inside you heaps of potential; He says in Jeremiah 29:11 NLT: 'I know the plans I have for you, says the Lord. They are plans for good and not for disaster, to give you a future and a hope.'

Get to know your Creator. Then you'll truly be able to celebrate being you, enjoy being different, and be excited about what's ahead. Run hard. Eat up His words. Dream big dreams. God promises that 'through His mighty power at work within us, [we are able] to accomplish infinitely more than we might ask or think.'

content.title: Keep Going
content.introtext:
'...Don't give up.' Galatians 6:9 NLT

'If at first you don't succeed try, try, try again' is an expression that some believe dates back to Scotland in the fourteenth century. The legend says, after suffering a major defeat at the hands of the English, Scottish king Robert the Bruce went and hid in a cave. There he watched a spider trying to spin a web. Each time the spider failed, it simply started again. So inspired was Robert by the little creature that he returned to his troops and led a series of victories against the English.

Most of us underestimate the time it takes to achieve anything of lasting value. We have one diet drink and expect to lose a kilo in a day. We participate in one gym session and hope to be running the Sydney Marathon by the weekend. We lift a few weights and hope to see better muscle definition overnight.

In order to achieve great things, we have to put the hard work in. No cutting corners - that's a sign of impatience and lack of self-discipline. Whatever you're aiming for it's important you keep going. Paul wrote: 'Don't get discouraged and give up, for we will reap a harvest of blessing at the appropriate time.' (Galatians 6:9 NLT)

So, whatever it is that's worthwhile that you're working on, don't give up. Pray about it now, and ask God to help you stick at it.

content.title: The Branch and the Bride
content.introtext:
'I am the vine; you are the branches...' John 15:5 NIV

'There goes Jesus again with His fancy analogies,' some of the disciples no doubt thought. Maybe Peter wondered, 'Shouldn't we be doing something useful, like healing the sick?' But Jesus wanted them to understand how important just being with Him was. He didn't want them clocking in and clocking out. 'I am the vine; you are the branches. Those who remain in Me, and I in them, will produce much fruit.' (John 15:5 NLT)

But why go for vine as a picture? Wouldn't a palm tree have been better? They produce nice coconuts, and are tall and strong, which could surely represent Jesus. Oh, and the pretty branches too, they could be us! No, Jesus knew exactly what He was saying. The unique thing about the branches of a vine is that they're all interwoven with the vine, so you can't tell what is branch and what is vine.

That's our benchmark too. Our lives should channel His nature, so you can't tell what's 'God' and what's 'us'. He wants us close - as close as a marriage, in fact. Jesus wants us to keep giving every part of our lives to Him, holding nothing back, so that He can transform it. So let's do that! If a husband only spoke to his wife when he wanted something, it wouldn't be long before their marriage was in trouble. The more we go to Jesus, the more we'll grow like Jesus.

content.title: Secret Spaces
content.introtext:
'People did whatever seemed right in their own eyes...' Judges 17:6 NLT

We all need time to be alone - a safe place to just reflect and be ourselves. But we need to be careful that our 'me time' doesn't develop into 'secret space' time where we start doing things that we don't speak about to anyone. When we have no one to question our actions, we're in danger of becoming a law unto ourselves. The people in the book of Judges did that - just whatever they thought was right. And they ended up in over their heads in trouble.

The more we allow secret space time into our lives the more we open ourselves up to things that will damage and hold us back. Eating disorders, self-harming and porn addiction are a just a few of the harmful things that begin in secret spaces.

There is within us a natural tendency to sin, so we are called to 'walk in the light' where our motives and actions are transparent and we are encouraged to avoid sin. (1 John 1:7)

You don't need to go announcing to the world every last detail of your life. But you do need at least one person to be accountable to - someone mature, who knows God's Word and who will keep your confidence as well as love you enough to be honest with you. Ask someone today to be your accountability buddy. Someone who can give you the help you need, someone you can be open and honest with, and you can listen to with respect.

content.title: Against the Flow
content.introtext:
'People did whatever seemed right in their own eyes...' Judges 17:6 NLT

If everyone's doing it, it's ok, right? Wrong! When your mates swear, lie, are sexually active outside of marriage, get drunk, experiment with drugs, take a sickie or fight, it doesn't mean it's ok for you to do the same!

Sound familiar? You've probably heard that sort of advice a hundred times (and it is good advice, even if it's not always told in a helpful way!) But when you're tempted to do one of those things, right and wrong can feel a bit fuzzier...

Truth is, God doesn't disappear when people dispute His existence. God's ideas on living right don't lose their power just because people choose to ignore them. Lots of people around us have, willingly or not, bought into a very pretty lie - that they can follow every whim without consequence.

Don't live like that - Christians aren't going against the flow just for the sake of it. We're called to, 'remember the Lord in everything [we] do, and He will show [us] the right way.' (Proverbs 3:6 GNT) We catch a hold of His better life for us, one that is high above the world's, by listening for His voice.

In the book of Joshua, you'll discover a nation that hung onto every word God spoke. But one book later in Judges, you'll find a defeated nation who doesn't believe in God. The first is strong and law-abiding, the second weak and lawless. You'd think you were reading about two groups of people. But in a few short years, the people of Israel had gone from listening for God's voice to doing whatever they felt like. The fact is God never changes. But we can. So let's make sure we stay true!

content.title: Don't Give Up
content.introtext:
'You have great faith! Your request is granted.' Matthew 15:28 NIV

It's not the sort of response you'd expect from Jesus. A woman came up to Him, begging for help and He basically told her to go away. He may have been polite about it but that's hardly the point. It all started when a Canaanite woman came up to Him. The incident is told in Matthew 15:22-28 NIV: 'Lord...my daughter is suffering terribly from demon-possession,' and He said, 'I was sent only to...Israel...It is not right to take the children's bread and toss it to their dogs.' Most of us would have been put off by this putdown - but not this woman. 'Yes, Lord,' she said, 'but even the dogs eat the crumbs that fall from their masters' table.' Did Jesus have a twinkle in His eye then? 'Woman,' He said, 'you have great faith! Your request is granted.'

Talk about obstacles! Jesus isn't exactly welcoming her with open arms by saying she didn't belong to the right race. Most of us would have walked away offended. Not her! She stayed the distance. She didn't give up. She wasn't asking for what she deserved, she was crying out for what she needed! She stayed there long enough for Jesus to answer her prayer. In reality, she told Jesus, 'Let the children have the bread, all I need are the crumbs.' None of us are asking for what we deserve (if we got that, we'd be in deep trouble!) but, if we persist in asking for the blessing of the crumbs, we'll still have more than we ever need.

Do you ever feel like giving up on Jesus? If you're not seeing God's answer just yet, take a lesson from the Canaanite woman and don't give up!

content.title: Time Is Precious
content.introtext:
'The years...pass quickly, and then we are gone.' Psalm 90:10 NCV

There are a variety of ways to measure a year - days, weeks, months, sunsets, midnights... or cups of coffee. What most people agree on is that time is precious and has a habit of flying. We often think, 'I wish I had more time', but the reality is that we only have as much this week as we did last week: 168 hours precisely.

The real question is how you're spending your time. Some things demand our time - course commitments, work rosters or revising for exams. But what about all those other hours that you do get to decide about - your 'free' time? Are those hours dedicated to the couch while you impersonate a potato?

It's a question of worship, actually. Just as we can do with money, we can worship God with how we choose to spend our time - using it wisely to grow in love for Jesus and for others, or frittering it away on selfish pleasures.

We should offer our time to God in prayer, ask how He wants us to use it and be open to changing our plans. At the end of the day, one thing's sure: the best way to measure a year is in love.



SoulFood: Matt 5:1-12, Josh 10:5-14

content.title: When People Leave the Church (1)
content.introtext:
'The younger son...journeyed to a far country.' Luke 15:13 NKJ

It's easy to look around you, compare your life to your mate's next door and come to the conclusion that this Christianity business isn't everything it's cracked up to be. Over the next few days, we'll be looking at the story Jesus told of the Prodigal Son and asking why, two thousand years later, people are still leaving Church. (Side note: that's Church with a big C, aka the Body of Christ, aka being a part of Christianity. People leaving their local church and remaining in the faith is a different thing altogether, and not what we'll be looking at here.)

Blessings, a transformed life, a new spiritual family, God's unconditional love? Yes, please! But give it a little time and the shine can start to fade. Before you know it, the shops, the beach, your own bed, even homework can all seem more attractive than being at church on Sunday morning. In the story, it was the son's choice to leave his dad's home. There was no 'holding him hostage'. The father actually showed great respect for the son by letting him go. The point is that if you will not be held by the love of God, then He won't use His power to stop you.

But where did the son's choice get him in the end? Answer: a mess. A pig-stinking, hunger-panged, guilt-ridden mess. But none of that was any matter to the loving Father; that son would always be His son. As you take the time to re-read the story of the Prodigal Son in Luke 15:11-21, consider: do you need to come back?

content.title: Handling Criticism (2)
content.introtext:
'If you listen to correction, you grow in understanding.' Proverbs 15:32 NLT

Yesterday we looked at receiving criticism and today we're going to look at healthy ways to pull other people up. Imagine there's a scale of justice and mercy, with justice at one end and mercy at the other. Jesus was obviously perfect. John describes Him as being 'full of grace and truth'. (John 1:14 ESV) Jesus had justice and mercy meshed in perfect harmony. More often than not, we don't. Perhaps you've heard this illustrated with the quirky phrase, 'You can fall off a horse both ways.'

So, let's consider this minefield: 'Improving situations through constructively criticising others!' First, it's worth asking yourself whether you can handle criticism yourself. If you can't, but you still go round telling everyone else what they should be doing, you're making yourself look like a hypocrite. Secondly, ask yourself what your motives are for dishing it out. To make yourself look wise? For a bit of spiritual prestige? Then you may well be proud. Thirdly, are you fuelled by blame? Then you'll only come across as judgmental and you won't get taken seriously. Fourthly, have you got ideas of how to go forward? If not, is it even helpful to open your mouth? And finally, are you speaking the truth in love? Do they know you genuinely care about them? If you're not respecting them but just shovelling information down their throats, they'll see through it.

content.title: Keep Running
content.introtext:
'Run the race that lies ahead of us and never give up.' Hebrews 12:1 GWT

Look what Jesus endured: (1) Temptation. We imagine the wilderness temptation as three isolated events scattered over a forty-day period. No: 'The devil tempted Jesus for forty days...' (Luke 4:2 NCV) Every step, whispering in His ear; every turn of the path, sowing doubt; forty days of non-stop temptation! When it was over Satan would flee, angels would come and strengthen Him, and He would leave the wilderness to go out and minister as no one ever has. But first He had to get through the temptation. So do you. And the good news is, strengthened by God's grace, you can. (2) Accusation. '...Some said, "He is a good man." Others replied, "No, He deceives the people."' (John 7:12 NIV) 'The people retorted, "You...devil! Didn't we say all along that you were possessed by a demon?"' (John 8:48 NLT) They accused Him unfairly, but Jesus kept running. You must too. (3) Rejection. His family thought He was mad. The neighbours treated Him badly. When He returned to His home town they tried to throw Him off a cliff (Luke 4:29). But Jesus kept running. So must you. (4) Shame. At the cross He became 'sin' personified (2 Corinthians 5:21). Though He never stole, lied or lusted, He bore the shame of every thief, liar and adulterer. How did Jesus do it? What kept Him going? The Bible answers: '...Who for the joy set before Him endured...' (Hebrews 12:2 NIV) Jesus had already lived in Heaven, and knowing what awaited Him enabled Him to endure and finish the race. And the same joy awaits you too.

content.title: Wise Words
content.introtext:
'He who heeds counsel is wise.' Proverbs 12:15 NKJ

The old wooden door of the office creaked open. 'Hark, sister Sylvia, what seemeth to be thy ailment?' 'Well, sister Margaret, I no longer fit into my trousereth and wouldst therefore like thee to pray that the Lord wouldst miraculously remove this tyre from my waistline.' 'Ahh...sister Sylvia, could I asketh thee...Hast thou exerciseth and partaken of a diet of sound nutrition?' 'Sister Margaret! It is not for thee to guilt trip me regarding Big Macs and Doritos, but to pray!'

You might have come across people like this. They just expect prayer to be a magic wand that saves the day, while they do things that are obviously going to get them in a jam. Or maybe that's you? Prayer is important, but so is how you focus your time and energy. If someone comes to you with a problem, you might do well to ask some sensible questions.

Like: 'What do you think caused the problem...? What have you done about it? What do you feel God has said? What are you planning to do next?' If someone comes to you for advice, it can be tempting to bring all the memory verses you can think of in to play, but is it necessary?

And 'don't think you know it all.' (Romans 12:16 NLT) If you're not sure what to advise, be honest, and point people towards someone who's wiser than you.

content.title: Handling Criticism (1)
content.introtext:
'...A wise person stays calm when insulted.' Proverbs 12:16 NLT

Your teacher turns to you, stern as stone, and calmly says, 'Can I have a word...? In my office.' Your mind races. Your brain tries to figure what you've done wrong. Your heart's like a drum in your ears. They sit you down, and so it begins...

No one likes being criticised. It's like a slap in the face. Especially if you don't feel it's deserved. But criticism is a very necessary process to go through if you want to get better. The Bible uses the language of pruningthe trimming process trees are put through so they can keep growing healthily and produce fruit. Even word4U2day entries get pruned! We also need pruning.

When it happens, don't think you're getting chopped down! So here are a few safety tips as you head towards the pruning shears: (1) Cling to rational thinking. Don't lose the plot! (2) Check your conscience. Has God been prodding you about the same issue? (3) Consider the critic. Do you trust them? 'Better to be criticised by a wise person than...praised by a fool.' (Ecclesiastes 7:5 NLT) (4) Look for God's purposes in it, no matter what. '...the words of wise people bring healing.' (Proverbs 12:18 GWT)

If you've been left reeling from something someone's said to you ask God to shine light and truth in to your heart so you can step forward and grow healthily.



SoulFood: Isaiah 11:1-10, Luke 2:21-38

content.title: 'By My God I Can...'
content.introtext:
Saturday, 20 October 2012
'By My God I Can...'
'By my God I can leap over a wall.' 2 Samuel 22:30 ESV
Faith. It's a gift we ask for from God. However, don't be fooled into thinking it's a gadget on a utility belt, only to be brought out for times of healing at church. It's about having a bold and true understanding of who God is and who you are in Him. Looking at your situation might fill you with a tsunamisized sense of dread, but when you start looking to God, the waves won't come crashing over you. You might be facing a huge deadline and have no idea how you'll get there, when some bloke says, 'There's no such word as can't!'
You probably want to punch his lights out, but he's just getting you to stop looking at the size of your problem and start actually doing something about the problem.
Let's say you want to see your class or workmates become Christians: this will probably require getting other Christians onboard. Top four sensible questions: (1) Do you have a Christian group? (2) If you do, do you actually go to it? (3) Do you pray with other Christian friends? (4) Could you put on an event to make yourselves known? All these things could be part of scaling your wall. Bite the bullet and before you know it, you'll be hurdling for Jesus!
SoulFood: Ex 4-6, John 5:31-47, Ps 5, Pr 24:8-9

content.title: Share the Dream (2)
content.introtext:
'...You...became my partners...' Philippians 4:15 TLB

In order that you can turn your dreams into a reality, you're going to need to share it 'from the heart'. You need to tap in to everyone else's passions by first showing where your passions are at.

If people see that what's good for you is good for them too, they'll be champing at the bit. People will follow the dreamer, not necessarily the dream. But if they're sitting there like limp lettuce, it's pretty clear you haven't connected emotionally. When people see that what you've got is more than just a good idea, but could actually benefit them, they'll be well up for it. Frankly, most people do things for their own reasons, not yours. When they see they're on to a winner, you'll have a match made in Heaven.

It's no easy task and some people might still need convincing. This is where patience comes in. However, a word of warning: Don't go pelting ahead, so full of your own ideas and ego that you leave everyone else in meltdown. You'll need to adapt your pace to keep everyone on board. If you run too far ahead, you will lose your followers. Generally, people have to hear an idea at least seven times before they embrace it and call it their own. Ten percent of people are pioneers, 70 percent are settlers and 20 percent are antagonists. Make it your goal to win over the pioneers, to wait for the settlers and to leave the antagonists behind.



SoulFood: 1 Cor 10-11, John 4:27-38, Ps 32, Pr 23:29-35

content.title: Share the Dream (3)
content.introtext:
'...God's Kingdom consists of God's approval and peace...' Romans 14:17 GWT

You must share your dream visually because only when people 'see it' will they buy into it. People need to actually see what you're on about, or at least some semblance of it before they'll put their metaphorical money where their mouth is.

The thing about dreams is that they're not so great if that's all they ever are. Whether it's transforming a community or creating a new team, it's the impact of your dream that matters. Think about the person you're sharing your dream with, and look at things from their point of view. Are they going to improve themselves? Will they have the rewarding feeling of a job well done? Do they feel valued? Do they like being around you? All these questions matter to people, and if people feel like they don't matter to you, they'll soon be off. If you're already a living breathing example of what you're trying to sell, then a large part of the battle's won. Whether or not they choose to climb aboard will have to do with you-are you a person of integrity? Will you actually do what you say?

Remember that Jesus Christ was the expert in all these matters, so keep focusing on Him. Even when it's all clicked into place, you might never get a gold star. However you will have that sense of peace and joy that only comes through God's stamp of approval. Is God calling you to step out in faith? Believe Him for His power!



SoulFood: 1 Cor 12-14, John 4:39-54, Ps 87, Pr 24:1-4

content.title: The Hardest Nut to Crack
content.introtext:
'...We are God's children.' Romans 8:16 NLT

Relatives can sometimes be the hardest nut to crack. We can often get on really well with all sorts of people, but those who are the biggest challenge are often the people closest to us.

The Bible talks about all of us being God's kids. So, by default, that means that if you're a Christian, then you've got a whole load of brothers and sisters in Christ, as well as aunties and uncles, mums and dads and other folk you're related to (whether you like it or not!) If you don't want to end up alone and lonely, learning to get on with people is crucial. Everyone knows you're not perfect and you won't do this all of the time. But that doesn't mean it's ok to not bother.

But God says, 'Do your part to live in peace with everyone... never avenge yourselves. Leave that to God. For it is written, "I will take vengeance; I will repay those who deserve it," aasays the Lord... Don't let evil get the best of you, but conquer evil by doing good.' (Romans 12:18-21 NLT) 'Well that's easy for you, God, you're Perfect,' you might say. God knows everything we struggle with but He doesn't just leave us with the command and say, 'See ya later!' He offers us His power to actually make peaceful relationships a reality.

Spending time praying for someone who you don't naturally get on with is a good way to start building a healthy relationship.



SoulFood: 1 Cor 15-16, John 5:1-15, Ps 41, Pr 24:5-6

content.title: Steel or Play Doh?
content.introtext:
'...We are all formed by Your hand.' Isaiah 64:8 NLT

Superman or Morph the plasticine man-who would you rather be? The Man of Steel versus a lump of clay. Superman could do just about anything-everything bounced off him and he could stop anything in its tracks. Morph, on the other hand, kept getting remoulded and reshaped, and even splattered into a ball of clay again and again.

It might seem like the answer's obviously Superman, but what if we're wrong? If we look at it from God's point of view, God wants to make, create and shape us into men and women of God. So which is easier to work with: clay or steel? If you're a bit more like steel than playdoh, He'll still be patient with you to do what He has to do. However, it might take more time and effort. It will probably be more painful for you too. Once you're like clay, God can shape you and use you and work with you. When He's done, your desires will start to match up with His desires.

If you look inside yourself (metaphorically, of course) what are those things you desperately want? If you only want recognition, popularity and progress, then you're falling short. Take Jesus: most people thought Jesus came to rule the Jews and sort out the Romans, and yet He ended up dying on a cross. But in doing so He accomplished the will of God.

Being moulded into shape by God is a sign of strength not weakness.



SoulFood: Ex 1-3, John 5:16-30, Ps 15, Pr 24:7
