content.title: The Revival We Need (4)
content.introtext:
'Love never fails...' 1 Corinthians 13:8 NKJ

Golden oldies! Don't you just love 'em? You're at the park and there's a sweet little old couple walking hand in hand. He's as doddery as a toddler, and her hair's as grey as smoke. You can tell they've had more games of Scrabble than you've had cooked dinners.

Old couples who've stood the test of time are more than tired old clichés. They're a testimony to the true nature of love. You might think love is that racing feeling when the cutie you've had your eye on walks through the door. However love is really about hanging in there when you want to walk out, forgiving each other and keeping on keeping on. 1 Corinthians 13 might be the famous wedding passage, but we could all do with a reminder so that we can 'love our neighbour as ourselves'.

There are 16 aspects of love that don't bear any resemblance to anything lovey dovey, but are instead very practical. At the top of the list is patience. Could you imagine the difference it would make if you didn't just fly off the handle when your mum shows up late to pick you up. Then there's kindness, and we all love it when someone's done the washing up even when it's not their turn. The final aspect of love is that it never fails. It keeps going. A revival of love might only begin as a small deed, but it could bring on a revolution.



SoulFood: 1 Cor 1-3, John 3:22-36, Ps 89:15-37, Pr 23:15-18

content.title: Flour Power
content.introtext:
'There's poison in this stew!' 2 Kings 4:40 NLT

There's nothing like a bit of outdoor cooking. Trees all around, fire crackling away and a nice bit of stew for the youth group. All those tv masterchefs and kitchen kings would be so proud! Now all it needs are a few 'herbes de provence'...there we go...give it a stir and 'voila', a beautiful homemade stew à la Elisha! So, what do you think, guys? Impressed? Hey! Don't spit it out, it took me ages to make! Whaddya mean it's revolting? Err...hang about...I'll...add some...some... yes, eureka! I'll add some flour!

And it worked! This was how Elisha dealt with the problem of a poisonous stew. Read it for yourself in 2 Kings 4. By adding flour, it miraculously took away the effect of the poison. God's Word is like flour, because flour is the main ingredient in our number one staple: bread! Jesus said, 'I am the Bread of Life.' (John 6:48 NLT)

Jesus can help us from becoming spiritually ill when we find ourselves in poisonous situations. Don't let disappointments make you cynical. Go to the Word! Starting to feel the snake of resentment wrapping round your heart? Go to the Word! Wound up in a mess which wasn't your making? Go to the Word! And once you've added the Bread of Life, make sure you add seasoning too! 'Let your conversation be always full of grace, seasoned with salt, so that you may know how to answer everyone.' (Colossians 4:6 NIV)



SoulFood: 1 Cor 4-6, John 4:1-12, Ps 89:38-52, Pr 23:19-21

content.title: Share the Dream (1)
content.introtext:
'...Be of one mind, united in thought and purpose.' 1 Corinthians 1:10 NLT

'I have a dream!' These words have been made famous by Martin Luther King, Abba and even Westlife. Dreams are important to us, after all, 'who hopes for what he already has?' (Romans 8:24 NIV) But simply having a dream doesn't convert it in to reality. If we don't consider how we can share our dreams with other people, you might find yourself chomping on a big bar of regret by the time you hit retirement.

So let's think about some practical basics: (1) Have you thought it through? Bursting into your pastor's office with all your mates cheering at your back, probably won't sway it for him. Until he believes you've thought it all through, you won't get far. Have you proven yourself to him that you can stick things out when the going gets tough? Don't kid yourself that just because he's a Christian he's bound to say yes. (2) Do you have a plan in place to make it happen? Or are there more unanswered questions than answered? You may be able to recite the whole of Philippians but are you up to the job? Successfully sharing your dream takes skill, practice and God's help. Start ticking these boxes and you're well on your way to living the dream!



SoulFood: 1 Cor 7-9, John 4:13-26, Ps 100, Pr 23:22-28

content.title: Look for the Best in Them
content.introtext:
'...always pursue what is good both for yourselves and for all' 1 Thessalonians 5:15 NKJV

VJ Smith writes: 'I don't remember the exact date I met Marty. Like a lot of people...the line I was in wasn't moving as quickly as I wanted and I glanced towards the cashier...an affable-looking man in his seventies. ...For the next few minutes I watched him. He greeted every customer with the usual, "How's it going?" Then he did something different-he actually listened. ...he would respond to what they had said and engage them in brief conversation. I had grown accustomed to people asking me how I was doing simply out of robotic conversational habit...I could [reply], "I just found out I have six months to live," and someone would reply, "Have a great day!" Then...the old cashier walked round to the customers, extended his hand, looked them in the eye and said, "I want to thank you for shopping here today. Have a great day." The looks on their faces were priceless. There were smiles and sheepish grins. All had been touched by this simple gesture... Some walked away, paused...and looked back...they couldn't quite comprehend what had just happened...I wanted to take him home and feed him cookies!...I'd been in that store a hundred times and never walked away feeling like that.' A marriage counsellor asked a couple to list each other's good qualities. The husband listed twelve. His wife couldn't think of any! The Bible says, 'Look for the best in each other, and always do your best to bring it out.' That's hard to do when you're looking for perfection and focusing on the other person's shortcomings. The Bible says, 'Love...keeps no record of wrongs.' (1 Corinthians 13:4-5 NIV) In other words, look for the best in them!

SoulFood: Jonah 2, Luke 11:29-36

content.title: The Revival We Need (3)
content.introtext:
'...Where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty.' 2 Corinthians 3:17 NKJ

Bring it on! Your time has come! All those hours of cleaning the church toilets actually haven't gone unnoticed! Your youth worker has approached you with the opportunity to do a talk in a couple of month's time to the rest of your youth group! Your chest puffs out, ever so slightly, but not enough for anyone to notice. You borrow concordances, start prepping notes and up the ante in prayer. You cannot wait for the big night! Then, with only a day to go, your pastor calls a meeting saying that God has told him there's a different plan for that night and you're not gonna get to do your talk! You are seething! 'What?!!' What a waste! You feel like walking out! But before you blow a gasket, what might God be teaching you through this?

Well, the Bible says: 'Where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty.' But that liberty (there's the third 'L' and it basically means freedom) happens under Godapproved authority. Freedom doesn't mean doing whatever you want, whenever you want. Part of it means being open to God for a different plan, a different way of doing things. Liberty isn't feeling free enough to do what you want, it's about freeing you up to let God work through you. Take the humble choice, and allow God's Spirit to help you love the people around you. Spend time praying for those who have authority over you, especially church leaders. Ask God to give them wisdom in the decisions they make.



SoulFood: Malachi 1-4, John 3:1-21, Ps 89:1-14, Pr 23:10-14

content.title: Growing in God (5): Mission
content.introtext:
'The most important thing is that I complete my mission...' Acts 20:24 NCV

Jesus said, 'As You sent Me into the world, I have sent them into the world.' (John 17:18 NIV) Carrying out your mission on earth is vital for growing in God: 'Go to the people of all nations and make them My disciples. Baptise them in the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, and teach them to do everything I have told you.' (Matthew 28:19-20 CEV)

In church circles we call this speech, 'The Great Commission'. If you've put your initials next to Jesus you've also put your initials next to His Great Commission. And before you start with, 'Surely, He means ministers and missionaries and stuff,' take a look at Jesus. He was only in Year 7 when He said, 'I must be about My Father's business...' (Luke 2:49 NKJ) Even as a kid, Jesus understood He was on a mission from God. It's thought that many of the disciples were of high school age when they started their mission with Jesus.

Many great revivals can pinpoint young people at the hub of the happening. Mission is a must regardless of your maturity. As young people you're often asked to consider your future career, but your mission deserves far more attention. Making Jesus known will affect people's eternity; your job might not. So start opening your mouth for God.

SoulFood: Ezek 16:53-19:14, Matt 22:1-14, Ps 103:13-22, Pr 19:17

content.title: Chosen (3)
content.introtext:
'Unless the Lord builds a house, the work of the builders is wasted...' Psalm 127:1 NLT

The God-followers in Jeremiah's day thought that they could live however they wanted. With their egotistical, I'm-the-boss-of-me attitude, they thought God would never let them suffer the consequences of their actions. In fact, they thought they were untouchable because God was on their side! But in truth, they ignored God and never listened to Him. To them everything else was more important. Jeremiah cried his eyes out when he realised this. He broke down, seeing just how bad this attitude truly was.

What's important to you? What things have you achieved that you're most proud of? Do you know there is one thing that God wants you to revel in? Better than friendship, romance, perfect health, or even this week's iPhone? It's your relationship with Him. In Jeremiah 9:23-24 NLT, God says, 'Don't let the wise boast in their wisdom, or the powerful boast in their power, or the rich boast in their riches. But those who wish to boast should boast in this alone: that they truly know Me and understand that I am the Lord who demonstrates unfailing love and who brings justice and righteousness to the earth, and that I delight in these things.'

How's your relationship with Jesus? Do you boast that you truly know Him? If not, why not?



SoulFood: 2 Chron 16-18, Luke 20:9-19, Ps 20, Pr 19:24-29

content.title: Bitter Lemons and Dirty Ashes
content.introtext:
'...We stopped relying on ourselves and learned to rely only on God...' 2 Corinthians 1:9 NLT

Down in the dumps today? Feeling like the world is against you, and even God Himself has got it in for you? Life doesn't always turn out the way we plan or hope, does it? It would be great to have instant power to pass that exam, make that guy fancy us, grow a money tree, stop those bullies, take away the fear, stress, pain, unfairness. But we don't.

When life throws us bitter lemons and dirty ashes, thinking positively and relying on God is often at the bottom of our agenda. It's hard to look forward to tomorrow when everything is a raincloud of doom. How can we believe that God truly loves us when the mess we're in doesn't seem to change? How can we trust God is there for us when it doesn't even feel like He's listening to our prayers? How can we rely on Him to help? After all, He could have kept Joseph out of prison (but didn't), stopped Daniel being thrown into a den of lions (but never did), or made sure Paul wasn't shipwrecked (but it happened anyway).

Take a closer look as to what else happened. As a result of their painful near-death experiences, they got to know God more and the result was that they impacted the world around them. With God, your best moments will often follow the worst times.

Take strength from 1 Peter 4:12-13 and memorise God's promise to you: 'And we know that God causes everything to work together for the good of those who love God and are called according to his purpose for them.' (Romans 8:28 NIV)

content.title: Fire and Soap
content.introtext:
'...He is like a refiner's fire and like launderers' soap.' Malachi 3:2 NKJ

'It's all right, it's just a little bit of dirt. It's not a detergent ad! No one's expecting it to be whiter-than-white', are they?'

This may be your attitude towards your clothes, but is it also your attitude towards sin? Just like your mum can spot the tiniest of blemishes on your outfit, God sees everything. When you sin, own up to it. 'If we say openly that we have done wrong, He is upright and true to His word, giving us forgiveness of sins and making us clean from all evil.' (1 John 1:9 BBE)

'Yeah, but I keep doing it, I keep thinking it. Isn't God going to stop forgiving me?' When Jesus told Peter to forgive his brother seventy times seven, that's a picture of how God will deal with us. God won't even write us off after the four hundred and ninety-first time either!

When you stuff up, own up to it and turn again to Jesus. If your heart races at the thought of the wrong you've done, then give God thanks your conscience is still sensitive and responsive to His Spirit. Washing powder cleans your clothes but it's God's fire that cleans our insides. And when you've confessed your sin to Him, don't be down on yourself. Instead be confident that Jesus' sacrifice is enough for you to walk with God confidently once more.

You're not a loser, you're a learner.



SoulFood: Lev 23:33-44, Jn 7:1-40, Zech 14:16-21

content.title: The Rumour Mill
content.introtext:
'Troublemakers listen to troublemakers...' Proverbs 17:4 CEV

A conversation involving malicious chatter or rumours about other people-that's gossip. But, oh how tasty it can be! A quick status change here, a sneaky text there as well as lunchtime chatter and banter. Then of course there are the gossip columns, magazines and even TV and radio programmes spouting it out. It's hard to keep away from it.

A person who habitually spreads intimate or private rumours or facts-that's a gossiper. Not really something we'd want on our CV, is it? That's because deep down, we know gossip for what it is. A weapon of mass social destruction, designed to break and tear down an individual, friendship group or community. The moment somebody begins to gossip, stop them and ask, 'Why do I need to know this? Have you talked to the person you're talking about?' Wise up; people who gossip can't be trusted!

What does the Bible say about dealing with gossip? 'The words of a gossip are like tasty bits of food; people like to gobble them up.' (Proverbs 26:22 NCV) 'A gossip can never keep a secret. Stay away from people who talk too much.' (Proverbs 20:19 NIV) 'If a ruler listens to falsehood, all his officials will be wicked.' (Proverbs 29:12 ESV) 'Without wood a fire goes out, and without gossip a quarrel dies down.' (Proverbs 26:20 GWT)

God's Word speaks the truth, so get rid of gossip before it weaves itself into the fabric of your everyday speech. '...stop making false accusations and spreading vicious rumours! ...Then your light will shine out from the darkness, and the darkness around you will be as bright as day.' (Isaiah 58:9-10 NLT)



SoulFood: 2 Chron 22-24, Luke 20:27-40, Ps 27, Pr 20:5-6

content.title: Snubbed Out
content.introtext:
'He will not crush the weakest reed or put out a flickering candle...' Matthew 12:20 NLT

Back in Jesus' day, kids would make musical pipes to play with from reeds growing by the river. They'd hollow them out, bore in holes and make tunes. But just like toys today, over time they get battered, bruised and thrown away. Have you ever felt like that? Life was once fresh and good, but then hurtful words or your own failure left you battered and vulnerable.

Remember candles on a birthday cake when you were a kid. Fun for a moment, but once blown out, useless and quickly discarded. Maybe you once felt on fire for God, but then the chilly wind of unforgiveness or injustice extinguished it all.

What do all these people have in common: A woman trembling before an angry mob threatening to stone her to death? A house surrounded by people and a paralysed man on a stretcher; his friends not giving up until they get him through the crowd to Christ? A blind man crying out for his sight and disciples telling him to be quiet? They are all bruised reeds and smouldering wicks that Jesus reached out to restore. The world thinks it knows what to do with you-break you off and snuff you out! But not Jesus: 'He does not crush the weak, or quench the smallest hope.' (Matthew 12:20 TLB) No matter how spent or used you feel, God's still got you! Come, He will treat you gently and make you whole. He'll never chuck you out with the rubbish or snub you out. Talk to Him.



SoulFood: 2 Chron 25-28, Luke 20:41-47, Ps 78:1-8, Pr 20:7-10

content.title: Forgotten (1)
content.introtext:
'The Lord...will never leave you nor forsake you.' Deuteronomy 31:6 NIV

Loneliness is 'an unpleasant feeling in which a person experiences a strong sense of emptiness and solitude resulting from inadequate levels of social relationships' according to Wikipedia. Right back at the very beginning of creation God said, 'It is not good for the man to be alone...' (Genesis 2:18 NIV) That's true: God created us to enjoy friendship and community.

Being alone and being lonely are two different things. It's possible to be by yourself and not feel lonely and it's possible to feel lonely in a crowded room. This is because loneliness is a state of mind, an emotion brought on through relationship breakdown. If we become a forgotten friend, an ex, or the black sheep of the family, we can feel incredibly lonely. A lack of good relationships in our life can leave us in desperation feeling worthless, unwanted and not needed. There is no deeper sadness than the idea that we do not have a friend, that no one cares about us, that no one is concerned about anything that might happen to us, that no one would even care if we weren't around.

There is only one true cure for deep loneliness: understanding who God is. He calls Himself your 'Heavenly Father,' not just your creator and designer. When Jesus taught us to pray He didn't begin with 'O, omnipotent, omnipresent, omniscient God.' Yes, God is all of those, but when it comes to us, He wants to be recognised and called 'Father' (Matthew 6:9). That's how He thinks about us, and wants us to think and to feel about Him.

He's your loving, secure, accepting, concerned, compassionate, protecting, assuring, providing Father-when you grasp the truth of that you will begin to overcome the fear of loneliness.



SoulFood: 2 Chron 29-31, Luke 21:1-11, Ps 78:9-16, Pr 20:11-14

content.title: Forgotten (2)
content.introtext:
'...Nothing can ever separate [me] from God's love...' Romans 8:38 NLT

'Turn to me and be gracious to me, for I am lonely...' wrote David in Psalm 25:16. Loneliness, that awful feeling of desolation and emptiness, is something that mankind has been experiencing for millennia. When David felt it, he didn't hold back-he told God everything, 'Look to my right and see; no one is concerned for me. I have no refuge; no one cares for my life.' (Psalm 142:4 NIV) Job felt so misunderstood and rejected by his friends, he told God, 'I despise my life...my days have no meaning.' (Job 7:16 NIV) Elijah became consumed with loneliness and prayed that he might die, '...I have had enough, Lord...Take my life...' (1 Kings 19:4 NIV)

Because of his isolation, Jeremiah told God, 'Cursed be the day I was born...Why did I ever come out of the womb to see trouble and sorrow...?' (Jeremiah 20:14-18 NIV) Wrapped up in their isolated state, each of them prayed big bold real prayers, and get this: God never barked back at them to be quiet. He never told them off for being silly. He never shouted, 'Pull yourself together!' God loved them, understood them and listened to their emotional pain.

When we are overcome with loneliness, we too need to turn to the real cure. God is the only who truly gets us, understands what we're going through and can help us overcome feeling forgotten.

If you're feeling like this, express it in writing a song or poem, just like David did in the Psalms.

content.title: Lament
content.introtext:
'Then David got up...' 2 Samuel 12:20 NIV

David committed adultery with another man's wife, got her pregnant, then arranged to have her husband put to death in an attempt to cover it up. Then he married her and thought everything would be ok. But the child became critically ill. Desperately wanting to save the baby's life, David '...fasted and went into his house and spent the nights lying on the ground. The elders of his household stood beside him to get him up from the ground, but he refused, and he would not eat any food...' In spite of all his praying, the child died. Why did God let this happen? We don't have a clear answer. But this much we know: when you have repented of your sin and experienced God's forgiveness, you must get up and go on with your life. David made earthshaking mistakes but we can discover three important things in this story: (1) Until you are willing to make things right with God and those you've hurt, you can't go forward with confidence. (2) Until you process your emotions in a healthy way, whether guilt or grief, you will remain stuck and forfeit the joy of what God has for you next. (3) When you've done these two things, get up and get on with your life.



SoulFood: 2 Chron 32-34, Luke 21:12-24, Ps 78:17-31, Pr 20:15-19

content.title: Made It!
content.introtext:
'Follow Me, and I will make you...' Mark 1:17 NKJ

Every year thousands join the long lines queuing for their chance at stardom, each one hoping they have The X Factor. They're prepared to do whatever it takes to prove they're 'the next big thing' in the entertainment world. Each one nervously awaits the approval of the judges. They long to scream down the phone, 'I made it through to the next round!'

Many fall at the first hurdle, some having been laughed (others man-handled) off stage, feeling intense disappointment. The nearer the hopefuls get to the finishing line the harder they fall, knowing they never made it.

Jesus says, 'Follow Me, and I will make you...' We all want to be 'a somebody' and Jesus promises when you follow Him, 'He will make you.' But we wonder if He'll leave us standing in line, kick us off boot camp or turf us from His house. Listen: Following God is like stepping out on tissue paper and discovering solid rock underneath. But you'll never discover the rock unless you're willing to step onto the tissue paper!

Here's a promise to sustain you. '...do not be discouraged, for the Lord your God will be with you wherever you go.' (Joshua 1:9 NIV)

content.title: At His Name
content.introtext:
'Then Jesus...said, "All authority in Heaven and on earth has been given to Me."' Matthew 28:18 NIV

Whether you're into music or movies, you're sure to have your favourite celeb. When we hear that 'certain name' we get a buzz of excitement. We spend big bucks to check out their latest film or attend their next concert. We may even queue for hours to catch just a glimpse of them.

Some people can make us starry-eyed. But can you imagine someone's introduction leaving people horizontal? That's exactly what happened to a whole group of men. They went seeking out the 'man of the moment', the guy everybody wanted to meet. And when they finally caught up with him, the guy introduced himself and they all fell flat on their faces! The men were trained, tough soldiers and the man was Jesus. They were seeking to arrest Him-they were the best of the regiment, armed and dangerous but, by simply stating who He was, He sent these guys tumbling. Go check it out in John 18:2-6.

Philippians 2:10 NLT tells us; '...at the name of Jesus every knee should bow'-and if they don't today, they will someday soon.

Celebrities come and go but the bedrock of our faith is still Christ's virgin birth, His sinless life, His atoning death, His victorious resurrection, His work of mediation and His visible return as King of Kings. Christ-there's no one like Him!

content.title: Decisions (1)-Crisis!
content.introtext:
'...We do not know what to do, but we are looking to You for help.' 2 Chronicles 20:12 NLT

Every day we have millions of choices to make: what time to get up, what to have for breakfast, what to put on our Facebook status? Some choices are easier than others and we can make a quick decision without a thought. But other times they seem nothing less than a mini-crisis! Running around like a headless chook or burying your head in the sand, hoping it'll go away will ensure things get worse, not better.

King Jehoshaphat faced a crisis. The Moabites and Ammonites were massing their troops in preparation for an all-out assault on Judah. Jehoshaphat had every right to be afraid, withdrawn, worried and indecisive. But instead he led the way for us all in how to handle a crisis moment. Jehoshaphat called all the people together to ask God for help, a day of prayer for everyone: 'All the men of Judah stood before the Lord with their little ones, wives and children.' (2 Chronicles 20:13 NLT) It was a prayer meeting involving every member of the family. When stuck in a crisis, not knowing what to do, Jehoshaphat prayed, 'We do not know what to do, but we are looking to You for help.' And we need to do the same.

Meeting up with your friends or family to pray together about the things each of you need help with is still a good idea today.



SoulFood: Jos 1-4, Luke 22:14-23, Ps 78:56-64, Pr 20:25

content.title: Decisions (2)-Unknown Territory
content.introtext:
'...The Lord your God will be with you wherever you go...' Joshua 1:9 NIV

Starting a new school, heading off for college, moving to a university, beginning a new job-these are times when decisions get trickier. We're in new territory, covering unknown ground. Situations like these can make us anxious because fear of the unknown creeps into every choice we make.

Joshua knew exactly what that felt like. After living in the wilderness for forty years, God asked him to step out into a new place. His leader Moses had died and Joshua had no one around who knew how to help him or what to do. Every day brought a new unknown, a new experience, a new obstacle to overcome. How would he get through this?

God takes him aside for a chat and reminds him: '...Be strong and courageous, for you are the one who will lead these people to possess all the land I swore to their ancestors I would give them... Be careful to obey all the instructions Moses gave you... Study this Book of Instruction continually. Meditate on it day and night so you will be sure to obey everything written in it. Only then will you prosper and succeed in all you do... Do not be afraid or discouraged. For the Lord your God is with you wherever you go.' (Joshua 1:5-9 NLT) As a leader you will always be uncertain about many things, especially when you go into new territory. But you can never afford to be unclear or in doubt about your calling, your vision, and your ultimate victory. And where does such confidence come from? God's promise, 'I am with you.'



SoulFood: Jos 5:1-8:29, Luke 22:24-38, Ps 78:65-72, Pr 20:26-30

content.title: Decisions (3)-Call Upon the Author
content.introtext:
'I will instruct you...in the way you should go; I will guide you...' Psalm 32:8 NKJ

One reason we can find it difficult making a decision is because we're frightened of failure, scared we'll get it wrong and make a fool out of ourselves. We need to remember that just because we may fail sometimes; it doesn't make us a failure. Thomas Edison is believed to have had tried at least 50,000 experiments before he successfully invented the storage battery: that's at least 49,999 failed experiments! How did he keep on going without seeing any results? When he was asked about it, Edison said, 'Results? Why, I know 50,000 things that won't work.'

When the choices we make don't produce hoped-for results, we can learn from them to make better decisions in the future. This doesn't mean we don't need to put any thought or effort into decisions we make. Choices always come with consequences, so they matter! It's important we recognise that we won't make good decisions simply by flipping a coin.

The Bible contains the very thoughts of the One who created us and knows everything about us, everything about life. In order to make consistently right choices we need to know what it says and apply it in our life. Most of all we need to chat on a regular basis to the Author because, 'The Lord says, "I will guide you along the best pathway for your life. I will advise you and watch over you."' (Psalm 32:8 NLT)

How about buying a Bible commentary to use alongside your Bible study!

content.title: Gospel Truth
content.introtext:
'...We have seen His glory...' John 1:14 NIV

Gospel Truth. We hear that phrase loads of times, but what does it mean?

First up, let's look at Truth. Truth is not just the idea of fact over fiction; Truth is not just words or beliefs; Truth is not just an individual viewpoint. Truth can be seen from many angles, but Truth, in essence, is one Man-Jesus.

The four Gospels-Matthew, Mark, Luke and John-can be read individually, but to get an accurate picture of Jesus we should read all four in relation to each other. The beauty of this is that each Gospel looks at different aspects of Jesus, His works, His personality and His teachings. They all complement each other by looking at a different side of Truth. They do not argue against each other, but they build each other up. They do not fight against each other, but together they complete the story of God-in-the-form-of-man.

The ones who wrote the Gospels saw Jesus' glory when He came to earth, and they have written so we can also see His glory!

When did you last read all four Gospels? Now is a good time!



SoulFood: Ex 19:16-20:22, 2 Tim 3:14-4:8

content.title: Respect
content.introtext:
'...as though you were working for the Lord...' Colossians 3:23 NLT

Riots, looting and arson attacks happened on a mammoth scale across England in early August 2011. Holidaying politicians were called back to work and police annual leave was suspended until law and order was restored. In later news reports, approximately 3100 people had been arrested and a thousand charged; five people had died and 16 others were injured. The cost of damage to property was believed to be $300 million.

It all started out as a peaceful protest march after the tragic fatal shooting of a young man by police officers. The march was joined by a younger group of people, angry and armed. As the shouting escalated, violence broke out and the horrific scenes began.

When we don't respect our leaders we get anarchy, total chaos and everyone suffers. It is said, that until you learn to take orders you will never be qualified to give them. Jesus knew more than any other human being, yet even He respected the authority of the government in power. How much more then should we? Don't go talking down those who have authority over you. Ok, they're not perfect. But if you want to be treated with respect, you first have to respect others, even those you don't agree with or even like. Whatever you do or say, give it out '...as though you were working for the Lord...'

Even when you disagree with some of the opinions or actions of your leaders, you can find ways to encourage and show respect to them.



SoulFood: Num 29:1-6, Matt 24, Rev 11:15-19, 1 Cor 15:50-58

content.title: Life in a Rocking Chair
content.introtext:
'There is no condemnation for those who belong to Christ Jesus.' Romans 8:1 NLT

Are you spending too much time beating yourself up? If so, it's time to stop! In a series of talks entitled Beauty for Ashes, Christian speaker Joyce Meyer says: 'Don't waste time on things that produce nothing good in your life. Stop doing things that don't help you progress.' For many reasons we can think badly about ourselves. Guilt, anger and shame are just a few. Joyce compares them to living life in a rocking chair: 'The thoughts will keep you busy, tire you out, but get you nowhere! You'll go through life, simply rocking back and forth in your own misery.'

God doesn't want you to feel bad about yourself and confession deals with it. 1 John 1:9 NLT says, 'If we confess our sins to Him, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all wickedness.' God promises that when we ask for forgiveness, 'I'll wipe the slate clean for each of them. I'll forget they ever sinned!' Forgiveness comes by faith, not feelings. As long as you live by feelings, Satan has a weapon he can use against you at every turn. But as long as you truly repent, whatever you have done is pardonable. Once God has forgotten it, it's gone, so how can you still feel guilty about something that doesn't exist? We may feel like we're condemned, but we need to start living like we're not: 'There is no condemnation for those who belong to Christ Jesus.' If you belong to Christ Jesus then that's you!

content.title: Extraordinary Living (1)
content.introtext:
'...Building yourselves up on your...faith...' Jude 1:20 NKJ

If you're intentional about it, your faith will grow. If you're lazy, it won't! It's that simple. Like a river erodes a riverbank, your faith can wear away just from living every day. If you don't do anything to secure and strengthen your faith, it will begin to deteriorate-and you can count on that! Hebrews 11:6 NIV tells us that, 'Without faith it is impossible to please God,' so living by faith needs to be the top of our daily agenda. 'Faith is being sure of what we hope for and certain of what we do not see.' (Hebrews 11:1 NIV) It's being Godconfident: relying on God to guide you through life.

Henry Blackaby wrote: 'The kind of assignments God gives in the Bible are always God-sized. They are always beyond what people can do, because He wants to demonstrate His nature, His strength, His provision and His kindness to His people and to a watching world. That is the only way the world will come to know Him.'

God wants us to do things for Him that we can only do with His help, because only then will we experience God at work in our lives, only then will people see how great God is. Live by faith, take on God-sized jobs and God-sized challenges-do something that you can only accomplish with God's help.

Remember, your faith is like a muscle; if you don't exercise it consistently it will grow weak and powerless.



SoulFood: Jos 14-15, Luke 22:63-71, Ps 3, Pr 21:4-8

content.title: Extraordinary Living (2)
content.introtext:
'...Building yourselves up on your...faith...' Jude 1:20 NKJ

A surprising number of people go to church each week just to get a word to help them survive. They sing about faith but when you ask them, 'How are you doing?' they say, 'I'm just hanging on. I'm hoping to make it through.' If you feel like this, you need to be careful about spiritual infection. It's the contagious type of disease that weakens and waters down God's words, bringing doubts, wrong thought patterns and a misguided way to live. We need to avoid catching such infections and spreading them.

Jude, the brother of James (and possibly the brother of Jesus) was so bothered about this that he wrote a fiery letter to the church, telling them to watch out for them and fight against them. The danger is very real: there are false teachers and deceivers out there. They live pleasing themselves and encourage others to do the same. We need to live differently, Jude says: 'But you, dear friends, build yourselves up in your most holy faith and pray in the Holy Spirit. Keep yourselves in God's love...' (Jude 1:20-21 NIV)

Don't rely solely on what others say about the Bible, discover it for yourself. Let's encourage each other to live right and keep spiritual infections out of the church. Read your Bible and make a point of sharing what you discover with your friends.

content.title: Ground Control
content.introtext:
'The Lord God put the man in the Garden...to take care of it and to look after it.' Genesis 2:15 CEV

If you're still living with your family, how do you treat your home? Do you think drop your mucky trainers in the kitchen, tip your dirty washing on the bathroom floor and leave ten mouldy mugs under your bed? What about the people whose house it is-the ones who've made it a home and allowed you to live there? It's only fair you look after the place, right?

Psalm 8:6-8 NLT says God 'gave [us] charge of everything [He] made, putting all things under [their] authority...the flocks...herds...all the wild animals...birds...fish...everything.' Does that mean we can treat it however we like? Trash the place, leave it wrecked, broken and desolate? No, when God made us, He gave us the earth 'to take care of it and to look after it.' Are you doing what you can to keep God's place tidy?

We're not talking tree-hugging here, but there are plenty of things we can all do to make this world a better place. Like recycling, being careful with your rubbish, sponsoring a child in a third world country, logging on to opendoors.org.au to see what you can do to help persecuted Christians, for instance. Will you look after what God has given you?

content.title: Delivered
content.introtext:
'...They didn't even smell of smoke!' Daniel 3:27 NLT

We can't blame the devil for everything that goes wrong (we have to take responsibility for our actions) but we do need to remember that he's real and hanging around. 1 Peter 5:8 NLT says, 'Stay alert! Watch out for your great enemy, the devil. He prowls around like a roaring lion, looking for someone to devour.' Don't freak out about that, though1 John 4:4 NLT tells us: '...You have already won your fight...because the Spirit who lives in you is greater than the spirit who lives in the world.' As James 4:7 KJV says all we need to do is: 'Resist the devil, and he will flee from you.'

Have you read about those three guys who God literally delivered from the flames? They lived in a time like ours, where most people think more about themselves than they do about God. They were given a horrendous death penalty, to be burnt alive simply for believing in God. Thrown into the hottest furnace in the kingdom, they came out alive, without a scorch mark anywhere: 'They didn't even smell of smoke!' Their names are oddsounding today-Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego-but they'll always be remembered by history, their lives publicly announcing: The devil may want to destroy you but God is here to deliver you.

You can read Shadrach, Meshach and Abednego's story in Daniel 3 and be inspired by the God who delivers us from danger.



SoulFood: Jos 22-24, Luke 23:26-34, Ps 52, Pr 21:17

content.title: The Hezekiah Approach
content.introtext:
'Hezekiah...spread it out before the Lord...' 2 Kings 19:14 NLT

The sound of screeching tyres, a court date, a lump-bad news comes in all shapes and disguises. For Hezekiah it came in the form of a letter. Devastating news that left him in a hopeless situation. Bad news is no respecter of age, class or gender and can hit us at any time. So what should we do when it reaches us? How do we problem solve? We could hardly do better than to adopt the Hezekiah approach.

Hezekiah's bad news: a massive all-conquering Assyrian army was marching his way to wipe him and his city out! Straight away, 'After Hezekiah received the letter and read it, he...spread it out before the Lord. "Listen to me, O Lord, and hear! ...rescue us from his power; then all the kingdoms of the earth will know that You alone, O Lord, are God." And this is what the Lord says about the king of Assyria: "His armies will not enter Jerusalem... I will defend it."' (2 Kings 19:14-34 NLT) God kept His promise: 'That night the angel of the Lord went out to the Assyrian camp and killed 185,000 Assyrian troops. When the surviving Assyrians bbwoke up the next morning, they found corpses everywhere.' (2 Kings 19:35 NLT)

Hezekiah was a man of faith (2 Kings 18:5) and prayer. His first reaction when confronted with bad news was to bring it before God. Whether the problem was 185,000 armed and dangerous Assyrians or a painful illness (2 Kings 20:1-7), Hezekiah took it to the Lord in prayer. And when he prayed, things happened.

We should still deal with our problems or bad news the Hezekiah way: take them to God today!



SoulFood: Gen 40:1-41:43, Phil 2:5-13

content.title: We Don't Want No Drama
content.introtext:
'Hezekiah...spread it out before the Lord...' 2 Kings 19:14 NLT

There's another response to crisis, and it isn't the Hezekiah approach of yesterday's reading. It's the drama queen tactic! Ever met one? They take the smallest thing and blow it out of all proportion, bursting eardrums with their screams and soaking whole boxes of tissues with their tears. They leave their friends frustrated wanting them to sit down, calm down and just breathe. Hassle, stress, crises and problems are sadly part and parcel of life. (It's not until we get to Heaven that they'll disappear. Check out what's coming your way in Revelation 21).

Honoré de Balzac said: 'In times of crisis, the heart either breaks or boldens.' God wants you to toughen up, not break up. The best way to do that is to let God in on the action straightaway. If we don't, we can overreact. And this means we spend time making the problem worse. Instead of rushing around trying to fix everything ourselves, we need to leave room for God to help. God's not going to step in if you're busy doing it all yourself. He won't step in when He's not welcome. You need to ask for His help. God is the best problem-solver there is and He wants to teach you how to become good at it too. Will you let Him?

There is value in talking to someone you trust, who you know handles a crisis well. Ask them how they keep cool under pressure and learn from them.



SoulFood: Col 1-2, Luke 23:35-43, Ps 54, Pr 21:18-21

content.title: Running On Empty
content.introtext:
'Abraham never doubted or questioned God's promise.' Romans 4:20 CEV

A car might have a new engine, great body work, smartlooking interior...but with no fuel in the tank, no one's going to expect it to get very far. It's the fuel that allows it to reach its destination. If we want to get ahead in life, we need to spend less time on our outward appearance. We need to be more concerned with what's going on inside, making sure the tank of our lives is constantly topped up with the right fuel.

Life often doesn't turn out as we think it will; our plans sometimes fail, we don't always achieve or receive the things we wanted. So how do we keep going through disappointment and confusion? Hebrews 11:1 NLT tells us what makes life worth living is having faith in God: 'Faith is the confidence that what we hope for will actually happen; it gives us assurance about things we cannot see.'

Abraham reached a point in life where the odds were incredibly stacked against him. But he never lost hope, never gave up, he kept going. Why? Because he was full of faith in God: 'Abraham never doubted or questioned God's promise. His faith made him strong, and he gave all the credit to God. Abraham was certain that God could do what He had promised.' (Romans 4:20-21 CEV)

We can be certain too. Don't worry about the odds, be fuelled by faith.

Have a scan of Abraham's life story in Genesis 15-21 and then see what the New Testament writers say about him in Romans 4 and Hebrews 11:8-10.



SoulFood: Col 3-4, Philemon, Luke 23:44-56, Pr 21:22-27

content.title: Shift Your Focus
content.introtext:
'...May I never forget the good things He does for me.' Psalm 103:2 NLT

Do you feel the world owes you something? Do you walk around, moaning, 'I don't believe it,' about everything? Do you live your life thinking, 'if only'? 'If only I had this, if only I could do that, if only I wasn't born here, if only that didn't happen to me?' Are you grumbling your way through life and feeling hard done by?

Did you know if you close one eye and hold a dollar close enough to your other eye you can block out the light of the sun? The sunshine doesn't disappear, we just can't see it, all we can see is the dark face of the dollar. When you feel as if life only serves up misery, it's time to shift your focus! Lamentations 3:22-23 NCV is the focus shift in a book of deep pain. 'The Lord's love never ends; His mercies never stop. They are new every morning; Lord, Your loyalty is great.' Focus on all the good things God gives you every day; 'May I never forget the good things He does for me.'

Changing your computer password or the welcome message on your mobile to a promise of God will help shift your focus to an attitude of gratitude.



SoulFood: Lev 16, Lev 23:26-32, Heb 9:1-14, Heb 13:11-16

content.title: Potential Power (1)
content.introtext:
'Let's not get tired of doing what is good...' Galatians 6:9 NLT

Take your average tube of toothpaste and you will see that it is jampacked with potential. Potential to keep those pearly whites of yours from becoming deep black cavities and your gorgeous gums from becoming a bleeding mess! There on the back is displayed a list of all the good stuff it contains with instructions as to the best way to use it. Yes indeed, your average tube of toothpaste has the potential to make your visits to the dentist a genuine journey of joy, rather than a torturous trip of terror.

However, if all you ever do is leave the cap of that toothpaste tube firmly shut and the tube languishing at the back of your bathroom cabinet, then all that potential goes to waste. Potential has to be used for it to produce anything good. And it has to be used regularly, not just a oneoff. You need to open that toothpaste top, release all that toothpaste potential on to a toothbrush and brush at least twice a day in order to receive its benefits and unlock all that potential.

More importantly, you are packed with potential to do much good: 'We are...created...to do good works...' (Ephesians 2:10 NIV) So no more hiding that potential away, rather let your potential run free. Today, take those opportunities to demonstrate love, or to choose to be selfdisciplined.



SoulFood: Neh 1-4, Luke 24:1-12, Ps 91, Pr 21:28-31

content.title: Potential Power (2)
content.introtext:
'Let's not get tired of doing what is good...' Galatians 6:9 NLT

There's a legend about a soldier being court-martialled before Alexander the Great. Thinking it was all a case of mistaken identity, the soldier asked to appeal it. The conqueror informed him that there was no one he could plead his case to who was higher than him. 'In that case,' the soldier replied, 'I appeal my case from Alexander the Small, to Alexander the Great!'

In each of us there is a lesser self and a greater self struggling for supremacy. Your lesser self says, 'Not enough people believe in me. I'll never make it!' Your greater self says, 'My faith in God and His power in me is enough; I can make it.' Your lesser self says, 'It's taking too long!' Your greater self says, 'Dreams are realised one day at a time.' Your lesser self says, 'Enough is enough! I've taken too many smack-downs.' Your greater self says, 'I've come too far to give up now.' Your lesser self says, 'I don't have the strength to hold on...' Your greater self says, 'Keep on keeping on! You'll look back and wonder why you ever doubted.' After being shipwrecked, stoned, imprisoned, betrayed, hungry, thirsty, sleepless, cold and naked, Paul found it within himself to keep going. (2 Corinthians 11:24-12:5) Where does that kind of strength come from? God! The assignment God gives you will never be greater than the grace He provides. So draw on His strength, fight through for God and with God.



SoulFood: Neh 5-7, Luke 24:13-24, Ps 68:1-18, Pr 22:1-5

content.title: Anger Management
content.introtext:
'Stop being bitter and angry and mad at others...' Ephesians 4:31 CEV

When it comes to anger and bitterness, here are two things you need to keep in mind: First, it is contagious. You are a part of the body of Christ. So what happens to you, and in you, affects those you are connected to both positively and negatively. The Bible says, 'If one part suffers, every part suffers with it; if one part is honoured, every part rejoices with it.' (1 Corinthians 12:26 NIV) A snake bite doesn't just affect the body part that gets bitten; the venom spreads through the whole body. 'See to it that no one misses the grace of God and that no bitter root grows up to cause trouble and defile many.' (Hebrews 12:15 NIV) Don't get upset and leave the church God has placed you in. You need them and they need you. Secondly, it can be overcome. Here's how: (a) Acknowledge and admit it. (b) Don't rehearse it in your mind or recite it to others. (c) Repent and get rid of any attitude that's not Christ-like. (d) Ask God to give you self-control, and submit to His leadership. (e) Don't infect others and don't let them infect you. (f) Without waiting for admissions or apologies, say to yourself, God and a trusted friend, your decision to forgive all wrongs against you. 'Be kind and compassionate to one another, forgiving each other, just as in Christ God forgave you.' (Ephesians 4:32 NIV) This will set you free to enjoy your relationship with God, yourself, and others. (g) Look for practical ways to 'be kind...[and] tenderhearted' toward those who hurt you. (Ephesians 4:32 NKJV)

content.title: No One's a Super Christian
content.introtext:
'Your words...were my joy and my heart's delight...' Jeremiah 15:16 NIV

Someone who says, 'If you really love God and walk according to His Word you will never get depressed,' has clearly never read the Scriptures and never been depressed! Elijah called down fire from heaven in a spectacular victory, yet he became so depressed in the aftermath that he wanted to die. '...It is enough! Now, Lord, take my life...' (1 Kings 19:4 NKJV) That's a big-time low!

Being a Christian does not mean you've been given a jab immunising you against the viruses of life. When you try to act super-spiritual and allow people to think you never battle in areas like fear, failure, finances, family or feelings, you're living in on another planet! But when you bring the real you before God, you not only free yourself up for Him to do His work in you, you also show everyone else you're real and no Super-Christian.

God knows exactly what you're going through. So let's get real with Him. You are never more effective than when you are transparent. And Jesus has promised: '...in Me you may have peace. In the world you face persecution. But take courage; I have conquered the world!' (John 16:33 NRS)

Is there a particular issue you're struggling with at the moment? Tell God all about it. Vent. Rant, if you have to. And when you've told Him everything, ask Him what He has to say.

content.title: Temptation (1)
content.introtext:
'...We will receive...grace to help us when we need it.' Hebrews 4:16 NLT

'You deserve this. In fact, you've earned it...No one has to know. It's not harming anyone, is it? Just this once will make everything feel so much better! It's just a bit of fun. All work and no play makes you dull... Come on, if God's good, He'll want you to enjoy yourself...and besides, other people do it, don't they?'

These are the kind of things Satan will whisper to you. Whether it's pornography, alcohol or an eating disorder, your brain will seduce you with a logical argument. Then it'll invite you to have a taste of the forbidden fruit. Whether you're fourteen or forty, temptation can strike at any time.

'But it's hard, isn't it? That's why it's called temptation! I don't know what to do!' Well, first off, be honest with yourself. When exactly are you most likely to be tempted? Are stress levels rising? Feeling hurt, angry, bored, worried, alone, think you deserve 'a reward'? Work out what the patterns are of your temptation. 'God's people...protect themselves by watching where they go.' (Proverbs 16:17 CEV) Secondly, go to God in prayer: 'Call on Me when you are in trouble, and I will rescue you...' (Psalm 50:15 NLT) God's not given up on you, '...So let us come boldly to the throne of our most gracious God. There we will...find grace to help us when we need it most.' (Hebrews 4:16 NLT)

Temptation is hardest to resist when you think 'no one will know'. Many people have an accountability buddysomeone spiritually mature that you know and trust who has your permission to ask you anythingyes, anything!

content.title: Temptation (2)
content.introtext:
'...Your life is shaped by your thoughts.' Proverbs 4:23 GNT

After reading yesterday's notes, it may have sounded like it's all cut and dried: recognise when you're tempted, ask for God's help and He'll come through for you. Job done! But we all know that beating temptation is nowhere near as simple as that.

Simply repeating, 'I won't go on those websites, I won't go on those websites!' just won't cut it. Before you know it, you're back in a pool of shame eating a big slice of regret. So what do you do? Well, the battleground is your mind. Trying to fight the thought of not doing something just feeds the idea until it grows so big, it's the only thing you can think of. The answer? Replace your thoughts.

Once you focus is on something good, the dross begins to lose its grip. Positively distract yourself, '...Fix your thoughts on what is true, and honourable, and right, and pure, and lovely, and admirable. Think about things that are excellent and worthy of praise.' (Philippians 4:8 NLT) This is more than a nice verse in the Bible, it's the key to overcoming temptation. The wisdom of Solomon states: 'Your life is shaped by your thoughts.' Mind management is massive for moving mountains. Yes, it might take time, practice and God's help. However God is all about achieving the impossible.

The Psalmist prayed, 'Keep me from paying attention to what is worthless...' (Psalm 119:37 GNT) Is this easy to do? No, it takes discipline and practice. But with time, and God's grace, you can change the way you think and overcome temptation.

content.title: Prejudice
content.introtext:
'God is no respecter of persons.' Acts 10:34 KJV

Prejudice is the product of a lazy mind. It's contempt, prior to investigation. Your first impression of someone is incomplete and often inaccurate. Don't assume your first impression is right. Don't make lasting decisions based on limited insights. Your success in life will be limited by prejudice, fear and any form of discrimination you allow to colour your thinking. Jesus never measured a person's worth based on their race, gender, financial status or appearance. He was comfortable in the presence of fishermen and tax collectors. He was at ease with the rich and the poor. He knew that every person He met had potential and He never looked down on them because of their past. Born to a mother who conceived Him as a virgin, He knew what it meant to have a questionable background and be subject to the rumour mill. But He rose above it. And He broke tradition. The Samaritans were considered such a lower class of people that Jews wouldn't talk to them. But Jesus did. In fact, He went out of His way to meet with a five-times-married Samaritan woman, discussing the mysteries of worship with her and changing her life. Peter struggled with prejudice yet, once God dealt with his bias, was called to introduce the Gospel to the first group of Gentiles. He had obviously figured it out when he said, 'I perceive that God is no respecter of persons.' If 'God so loved the world' but you don't, how can you claim to be 'godly'?

content.title: Are You in a Hurry?
content.introtext:
'But Jesus often withdrew to lonely places and prayed.' Luke 5:16 NIV

If you're serious about getting serious with God, you can almost guarantee one of the battles you'll face is with hurry. In the world we live in, there tends to be two types of people: those who can be bothered, and those who can't. Those who can't suffer from apathy and those who can are usually so focussed on fighting apathy that everything has to be done at warp speed. While this supersonic way of living starts to get the job done, the pitfalls are normally as follows: (a) you get worn out (b) you get frustrated at what seems like apathy from anyone going slower than you (c) you become so focussed on getting the job done you actually forget to have a relationship with God!

Nobody was in more demand than Jesus but He always knew that there was a time for hurry and a time for rest. Have you ever noticed that despite living a hectic lifestyle Jesus never got stressed out?

The truth is, as much as we complain about it, we love hurry. It keeps the adrenaline pumping and makes us feel important. Jesus never hurried. He had time for people, His diary was flexible. Nothing was so important that He couldn't change His plans for someone. And what's the secret? Solitude. Jesus took time out, away from busyness to be with His Father.

Why not take out your diary and book in some time for God and give it the highest priority this week.

content.title: Make Today A Masterpiece!
content.introtext:
'Teach us to make the most of our time, so that we may grow in wisdom.' Psalm 90:12 NLT

Often we get very distracted worrying about things we have no control over. Worrying about the past is a waste of timewe should learn from the past and plan for the future. The Bible teaches us we reap what we sow which basically means if we work hard and are deliberate about what we're doing, our future will reflect that. If you spend your time sitting around watching TV, don't expect to do much with your life. Did you ever get given a presentation project in school? Remember the model bridge? The idea is for a bridge to hold as much weight as possible. The kids who messed around had two tubes and a piece of paper that couldn't hold anything. But those kids who put the time in, worked hard and thought through the science had bridges that could hold all the weights.

In order to plan for the future you need two thingsDecision and Discipline. (No point in making a decision unless you have the discipline to follow through!) Decide what God has called you to achieve and work until you get there! Some of us never admit that things go wrong because we didn't prepare properly. Some people give up early and others even decide not to do what's right! We know we shouldn't, but we give in to temptation. Good decisions aren't normally easy but they are essential if you want to be successful.

Plan to make today a masterpiece! Pray to God to give you the discipline to achieve the dream He's given you.

content.title: An Audience of One
content.introtext:
'Love the Lord your God with all your heart...' Deuteronomy 6:5 INV

Are you the same person at home, at work, with your mates and at church? Does your language 'loosen' up a bit when you're with your mates? Would you be comfortable if your pastor sat with you through the movies you choose? We're all good at playing the part; saying and doing the right things in right places. Sometimes we put on an act because we are afraid that if our real personality was on show people would walk out rather than applaud. Know this-your life is like a stage and loads of people may come in and out and watch for a while; but there is one person who remains a constant observer-Jesus. You should live your life performing for an audience of One. No one else's opinion matters. God doesn't see your life as a collection of separate performances. He sees you as oneas a whole person. The person you are when no one's looking is just the same to Him as the person you are when you're standing in plain view.

God asks for integrity (wholeness) in our lives. Why? Because it doesn't work any other way! He made us with one will, one mind, one heart and one spirit. It's Satan's lie that 'we can have it both ways' which leaves us fractured and paralysed. What's the answer? 'Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your strength.' (Deuteronomy 6:5 NIV) 'All' means all! One person, one life, one show!

Remember, God made you and loves you. You don't have to prove anything to anyoneyou just need to love God the Deuteronomy 6:5 way.

content.title: Control Freak?
content.introtext:
'Their loyalty is divided between God and the world...' James 1:8 NLT

Ever been called a control freak? Some people aren't happy unless they have everything under their controland that's not what God wants. If you've got a tendency to try to control situations or people just to get your own way, there's something wrong. Ever noticed that the more you try to control, the more anxiety you feel?

The Bible says, '...the mind of the flesh [which is sense and reason without the Holy Spirit] is death... But the mind of the [Holy] Spirit is life and peace...' God says, 'My thoughts and My ways are not like yours.' (Isaiah 55:8 CEV)

Let the Holy Spirit bring you in line. He may have other plans.

While it's true that God wants us to engage our brains, He also wants us to 'live by faith and not by sight'. Want everything signed, sealed, delivered? Learn to be comfortable with the unknown and you can bathe in God's pools of peace. Jesus said: 'Don't worry about tomorrow. It will take care of itself.' (Matthew 6:34 CEV)

content.title: The Revival We Need (1)
content.introtext:
'...Won't You revive us...' Psalm 85:6 NLT
And there he was, in the middle of this huge wide plain as the sun beat down. He looked to the left and then to the right, but the dry stubbly ground was covered with the ivory hue of what seemed to be bones. Yeah, bones?! 'Speak to the bones.' He recognised that voice. It was God. 'Here goes...' And as he did, and spoke what God had told him to speak, and followed His instruction, he heard a sound sweeping across the wilderness. A strange kind of rattling, a shaking. Before his very eyes the bones started to attach themselves, then muscle and sinew started to form all around, then actual flesh. But then God spoke again, 'Breathe life!' Then a howling, deafening wind came. And then he saw a huge number, a complete army in fact, rise up before his very eyes!

Ezekiel's story (found in Ezekiel 37) might seem a bit weird, but it shows us today that without the life of God, we're just like those same dry bones. Do we need reviving? It's easy to create the right impression, but are we really just becoming religious while our inner life does whatever it wants? Do we have spiritual diseases that are slowly killing our relationship with God? Or maybe we've just settled for second best? God offers us life: 'I came that they may have life, and have it abundantly.' (John 10:10 NRS)

content.title: Case Studies in Crashing (1)
content.introtext:
'A righteous man may fall seven times and rise again...' Proverbs 24:16 NKJ

Big? Big doesn't describe it! Like towers, these guys. Built like the Terminator, every one of them. They've got muscles on their muscles. There is no possible way we could fight them and live to tell the tale. You may as well shoot me here in the desert, because the only promise coming from that Promised Land is one of death and defeat.

The Israelites talked themselves into failure before they even attempted to fight. Only Joshua and Caleb had enough belief that God could help them drive out their enemy from their Promised Land. The Israelites scared themselves into losing. Instead of entering the Promised Land then and there, their fear of failure caused a 40 year delay.

Don't let fear become your excuse for failure. Don't let things in your mind grow out of proportion. Sure, your challenge may be big-but don't you have a God who is bigger? Don't dwell on the size of the task; dwell on the size of your God. Philippians 4:8 says it best: '...my friends, fill your minds with those things that are good and that deserve praise: things that are true, noble, right, pure, lovely and honourable.' Don't let fear be the reason for your failure.



SoulFood: Ezek 10-13, Luke 1:67-80, Ps 139:13-24, Pr 13:25

content.title: Turnaround
content.introtext:
'Let me...glean...after him in whose sight I may find favour.' Ruth 2:2 NKJ

Ruth: she has her own book in the Bible, her name is an important one in the family tree of Jesus, and lessons drawn from her life are taught all over the world thousands of years after she died. She must've been born with 'lucky' tattooed on her forehead, right?

Actually, no. She wasn't born into a family who worshipped God. Her husband died while she was still young. And she ends up living in a land far from home. Yet the story of Ruth shows what a hopeful turnaround God can make out of doubtful beginnings.

The opening scene sees Ruth slap-bang in the middle of a famine. No food, no hubby, no family. The only person in her life is Naomi, the mother-in-law (a woman so short on laughs she changes her name to 'Bitter'). It seems the two have little in common: Naomi was Jewish; Ruth wasn't. Naomi was old; Ruth young. Naomi thought her daughter-in-law was better off without her; Ruth wanted to stick with her mother-in-law.

In the end, despite the differences, Ruth got her way and devoted herself to the care of her mother-in-law. God's eyes, which 'range the earth' looking for a heart of faith and commitment (2 Chronicles 16:9), zoomed in on Ruth. From then on, 'blessing' was written all over Ruth. She got a new and good husband, a new home with plenty of land, and a child called Obed, who turned out to be the future granddad of David, Israel's greatest king. What a turnaround!



SoulFood: Lam 3:40-5:22, Luke 1:1-10, Ps 80:12-19, Pr 13:13-16

content.title: The Big Book
content.introtext:
'The teaching of Your Word gives light...' Psalm 119:130 NLT

Forget Google or Wikipedia, the answers you need are waiting in that big book gathering dust under your bed.

If you're clueless, that big book says, 'If you need wisdom-if you want to know what God wants you to do-ask Him, and He will gladly tell you. He will not resent your asking.' (James 1:5 NLT)

If you're tempted to take a short-cut, the big book says, 'There is a path before each person that seems right, but it ends in death.' (Proverbs 16:25 NLT)

If you're just about to sound off to someone who let you down, the big book says, 'People with good sense restrain their anger; they earn esteem by overlooking wrongs.' (Proverbs 19:11 NLT)

If you're tempted to bend the truth a little, the big book says, 'We don't use tricks, and we don't distort God's Word. As God watches, we clearly reveal the truth to everyone.' (2 Corinthians 4:2 GWT)

If your shopping list is seriously taking over your life, the big book says, 'Keep your lives free from the love of money, and be satisfied with what you have. God has said, "I will never leave you; I will never forget you."' (Hebrews 13:5 NCV)

If you're ready to tear someone to shreds, the big book says, 'If someone has done you wrong, do not repay him with a wrong... Do everything possible on your part to live in peace with everybody.' (Romans 12:17-18 GNT) Dust off the big book today-read your Bible.



SoulFood: Amos 1:1-5:17, Luke 1:11-25, Ps 73:1-16, Pr 13:17-19

content.title: Forever Young? (1)
content.introtext:
'...Let us go on...and become mature...' Hebrews 6:1 TLB

The insolence of those two brothers! Who do they think they are? Like Jesus wants to sit between that pair while they're bickering for eternity. If anyone's going to sit at His right side in His glory, it's going to be me. I'm the obvious choice. I'm laid back, quite possibly the holiest, not to mention easy on the eye. And did I say how humble I am?

Mark 10:35-45 tells the story of an argument between the disciples. James and John have clearly put everyone's back up by asking to be Jesus' wingmen in His Kingdom. Jesus tells them to grow up: '...You know that those who are regarded as rulers of the Gentiles lord it over them, and their high officials exercise authority over them. Not so with you. Instead whoever wants to become great among you must be your servant.' (Mark 10:42-43 NIV)

Growing up Jesus-style means reducing the swelling of your own head; humility is His way. Instead of clamouring for main stage like James and John, we should be turning the spotlight on others. Instead of ripping that certain someone to pieces, we should be encouraging them to keep going. Instead of being ready with our uncalled-for advice, we should be looking to learn from others. 'Let other people praise you-even strangers; never do it yourself.' (Proverbs 27:2 GNT)



SoulFood: Amos 5:18-9:15, Luke 1:26-38, Ps 73:17-28, Pr 13:20

content.title: Forever Young? (2)
content.introtext:
'...Let us go on...and become mature...' Hebrews 6:1 TLB

Ever seen a movie where two people are going at it with the trash talk? Tearing each other down by trying to come up with a bigger insult than the one they just received. Verbal attacks on the other person's looks, intelligence, parentage, or family are all par for the course. Well, unfortunately we too can be too quick with the trash talk at times. We don't want to seem small so we fire a rapid sarcastic comment back to cut the other person down to size. Peter wants us to try a new culture, swapping the trash talk for prayer talk. 'Never return...insult for insult...pray...for their welfare, happiness, and protection...that you may...inherit a blessing [from God]... Keep [your] tongue...from evil.' (1 Peter 3:9-10 AMP)

Imagine Peter's version of trash talk: Your family's so poor I'm bringing you food and clothing round tonight! I'm praying for wisdom for your dad! You may be dirty now but the blood of Jesus can wash you white as snow! Ok. So maybe that kind of talk won't catch on. But here's the challenge, why not look for the best in people, not the worst? The beauty. Not the ugliness. '...win favour and a good name in the sight of God and man.' (Proverbs 3:4 NIV)



SoulFood: Ezek 1-4, Luke 1:39-56, Ps 139:1-6, Pr 13:21-23

content.title: Forever Young? (3)
content.introtext:
'Do any of you want to live a life that is long and good?' Psalm 34:12 NLT

Being young and in a church can be a challenge. Very often young people are overlooked. More often they are underestimated.

When the church doesn't connect with youth, it's straying from the template set by Jesus. When Jesus wanted to kick off the greatest revolution ever seen in history, what did he do? He included the youth. Maybe the older generation were too set in their ways. Maybe the religious brigade had it all sussed so they weren't open to new teaching.

Whatever the reason, Jesus bypassed the holy huddle of the day and put His trust in young outsiders. Peter might have been older and married but John, the disciple Jesus loved, probably wasn't even old enough to vote.

You never hear of Jesus taking the youth 'out of the main service' because it might be a little over-their-heads. Far from it, Jesus has them casting out demons, venturing on mission trips, making supper for thousands. A gap year with Jesus would have been pretty intense. Here's what Paul says we should do about Him: '...grow up in every way into Christ, who is the head.' (Ephesians 4:15 NCV)

content.title: Through The Pain
content.introtext:
'Consider it all joy...when you encounter various trials.' James 1:2 NAS

James must've flown over the cuckoo's nest once too often! What is he talking about in today's verse? 'Consider it all joy...when you encounter various trials...' Joy?! To be sure, there's nothing like your teacher handing you a bad test result to bring a smile to your face, is there? And it's such a laugh when you're bullied just because you're a Christian, eh?

Has James lost the plot or could he be getting at something here? The rest of the verse gives us a clue: '.... knowing that the testing of your faith produces endurance...that you may be perfect and complete...' (James 1:2-4 NAS)

Trials, tests or bad times bring us back to basics: prayer. Emergencies-whether they are illnesses, break-ups, disasters or whatever-bring us to our knees. September 11 in 2001 reminded the western world that life is short. The aftermath in America saw people hit churches in record numbers. Sceptical atheists have been known to send up prayers at the deathbeds of loved ones. Bad times remind us all that life is fragile and there must be more to it all than this.

This is especially true for the Christian. Hard times force us to admit we're doomed unless God turns up. James asks us to consider tough times as joy because the pain sobers us up. The hurt draws us to the presence of God. The sting thrusts us into Godly maturity. James is NOT saying that you deserve the pain, nor that you need to sit in it helplessly (especially if it's the sort of thing you should be telling someone about). What James is saying is God is there with you in it and, even though it can be downright terrible, He can use it to change you into something beautiful and perfect. Getting closer to God can only be a joy, right?



SoulFood: Ezek 5-9, Luke 1:57-66, Ps 139:7-12, Pr 13:24

content.title: Case Studies in Crashing (2)
content.introtext:
'A righteous man may fall seven times and rise again...' Proverbs 24:16 NKJ

In the spring, at the time when kings go off to war...David remained in Jerusalem.

One evening David got up from his bed and walked around on the roof of the palace. From the roof he saw a woman bathing. The woman was very beautiful, and David sent someone to find out about her. The man said, 'She is Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam and the wife of Uriah the Hittite.' Then David sent messengers to get her. She came to him, and he slept with her. (2 Samuel 11:1-4 NIV) King David took what didn't belong to him: Bathsheba was somebody else's wife. Lust began to control his actions and suddenly David had added the murder of a good and loyal man to his sin of adultery.

For a while it was all going to plan: David had a new wife, a baby on the way, and no one else the wiser. Except the thing he did had displeased the Lord. David had to live with the consequences of his royal fall. His cosy picture of domestic life was totally shattered. Bathsheba gave birth to a son who only lived seven days. And the text suggests that, in David's case, it was in judgment for his failing. What we learn from David's failure is that sometimes we are forced to live with the consequences of a fall. When you repent of your mess-up, God always forgives. But you may still have to work through the repercussions.

content.title: The Right Thing (1)
content.introtext:
'Never let loyalty and kindness leave you!' Proverbs 3:3 NLT

If you've ever had to deal with disappointment, cope with being rejected, or experienced the pain of a broken promise, you will understand that loyalty and kindness really matter.

The Bible says, 'Never let loyalty and kindness get away from you! Wear them like a necklace.' That means all the time, in all circumstances, in every situation-not just when you feel like it. That might be easy to say, but when your friends have deserted you, your friend's just dumped you or your parents have gone back on their word, it can feel like the end of the world. We don't want to stay loyal and be kind, we want to shout and scream-we want them suffer, to hurt like we're hurting!

Shortly after mentioning the importance of loyalty and kindness, the Bible says, 'Trust in the Lord with all your heart; do not depend on your own understanding.' (Proverbs 3:5 NLT) God knows that what's good for us doesn't always come natural to us. It's at these times that we need to trust God, believing His way is better than our way. Frank Clark once said, 'Kindness makes a fellow feel good whether it's being done to him or by him.'

If you're struggling today to do the right thing, the loyal thing or the kind thing, ask God to help you, and be '...certain that God, who began the good work within you, will continue His work until it is finally finished on the day when Christ Jesus returns.' (Philippians 1:6 NLT)

content.title: Case Studies in Crashing (3)
content.introtext:
'A righteous man may fall seven times and rise again...' Proverbs 24:16 NKJ

Then Jesus told them, 'This very night you will all fall away on account of me...' Peter replied, 'Even if all fall away on account of you, I never will.' 'Truly I tell you,' Jesus answered, 'this very night, before the rooster crows, you will disown me three times.' But Peter declared, 'Even if I have to die with you, I will never disown you.' (Matthew 26:31-35 NIV)

We all let ourselves down from time to time. Simon Peter had heard three years of Jesus preaching on 'turning the other cheek'. But on the night Jesus is arrested he chops off some guy's ear and then, when his earlier bold declaration is tested, he folds and, with swearing and cursing, denies he even knows Jesus! Yep, even the best let themselves down from time to time.

Fortunately Jesus was well aware of Simon Peter's tendency for failure: '...Satan has asked for you, that he may sift you as wheat. But I have prayed for you, that your faith should not fail; and when you have returned to Me, strengthen your brethren.' (Luke 22:31-32 NKJ)

Hear that? Jesus has forgiven him well in advance of the failure. What's more, He's challenging Simon Peter to strengthen other believers when they let themselves down. The challenge, for you too, is to turn your failures into opportunities to sympathise and strengthen other victims of crashing.

content.title: Direct the Hard Questions to God
content.introtext:
'God, why have You forsaken Me?' Matthew 27:46 NKJV

At Calvary, Jesus asks one of the most heart-wrenching questions ever recorded, 'God, why have You forsaken Me?' These words are also found in Psalm 22:1, where David poured out his heart in despair. Ever felt like that? The Bible says that when Jesus was crucified, God made Jesus 'who knew no sin, to be sin...so...we might become the righteousness of God in Him.' (2 Corinthians 5:21 NAS) In order to break sin's hold on mankind and make salvation possible, Jesus went through a temporary separation from God. At that precise moment He felt 'Godforsaken'. If you've ever felt overwhelmed and abandoned, you know from experience that there's not another living soul who has a satisfactory answer to your 'Why?' With good intentions our loved ones can only go so far. Only God can pour His healing into your broken heart and help you make sense (or at least accept) what's happening. That's why you need to go to Him for your answers.

But here's the flip side of asking tough questions, you might get tough answers. Are you willing to accept His answer and do what He says? The Bible says, 'God has given us...His promise and His oath' (Hebrews 6:18 NLT), so even if you don't get the answer you want, you can trust that He's listening. Check this out: the One who makes 'everything ...work together for...good,' (Romans 8:28 NLT) always sends the answer that's in your best interests. So you can trust Him today...and the next!
