content.title: The Generous Mr Cadbury
content.introtext:
'Her children stand and bless her...' Proverbs 31:28 NLT

Dairy Milk. Freddo. Time Out. Boost. Roses (for the older generation)... What's your favourite Cadbury product?

The word Cadbury puts a smile on our face because it's the name of one of the biggest brands of the sweet brown stuff we know as chocolate. The company was founded almost 200 years ago when the founder John Cadbury opened up a shop in Bull Street, Birmingham back in 1824.

But it wasn't just the public who enjoyed the delights of the Cadbury empire. Their workers did too-because Cadbury looked after their people much better than most employers did in those days. Inspired by their Christian faith, they built houses with gardens, a swimming pool at the factory, and even set up pension plans.

John and his wife then passed on the company to their sons George and Richard. The good times continued to roll as the sons built cricket pitches and playing fields next to the chocolate factory. Sometimes, they'd knock off work early to all have a game of cricket!

Considering the only option of most other workers was probably a grimy coalmine in pitch black for 15 hours a day, this was very radical stuff. The Cadbury family was serious about the Kingdom of God coming to earth. They set in place the principle of treating their neighbour as they'd like to be treated and made sacrifices to make it happen. I'll 'Chomp' to that!



SoulFood: Ezek 22-23, Luke 2:34-40, Ps 17, Pr 14:13-16

content.title: Tough Times Ahead
content.introtext:
'...problems and trials...are good for us-they help us learn to endure.' Romans 5:3 NLT

Who wants to go through a tough time? What a stupid question! Who on earth puts up a hand, shouting, 'Yes please, pick me!'?

Actually anyone who's serious about living their life with God is signing themselves up for tough times along the way. But before you start ripping up your copy of word4U2day, know this: God will use tough times to help you, so you'll be all the better for it. God doesn't take us into deep water to drown us, but to develop us.

Some of the people you can't stand right now are the very ones God will use to help you grow spiritually. Honestly if you want to see some improvements in your character then tough times will help, not hinder. We actually need situations that make us angry if we're ever going to learn to control that temper. We need to be irritated if we're ever going to develop patience. We need to meet people we dislike if we're ever going to find the ability to love.

Today, thank God for those people in your life who bring out the worst in you, who stretch your faith and drive you crazy. God is using them to develop your character. It's thanks to them that you know how much more of God you need. So ask Him today for extra supplies of His love, patience, self control, forgiveness and understanding. Soon you'll discover those people can't bring out the worst in you because you'll be a changed character.



SoulFood: 1 Sam 25:2-42, Rom 12:14-21

content.title: Fight Night
content.introtext:
'[God] wrestled with him until...' Genesis 32:24 GNT

Have you read the account of the physical fight between Jacob and God in Genesis 32? It was a wrestling match that went on all night; if tickets could have been sold, the stadium would have been packed. Television crews would have broadcast it to the world; it would go down in history as the fight of all time: Jacob versus Almighty God. But there was no one else there. Struggling with life and scared of facing up to his past, Jacob got rid of all distractions. He left himself alone to fight it out with God. And he was determined not to give in until God answered, until God blessed him.

A few lessons for us from the big 'Fight Night':

(1) God turned up: God gives us permission to confront Him with our issues. No problem is too difficult for Him. So be real, be honest.

(2) God wrestled: He'll never leave us struggling alone.

(3) God blessed: Jacob was changed. Never bury your head in the sand. Confronting tough stuff with God always brings out the best outcome.

content.title: How to Sparkle
content.introtext:
'These trials will show that your faith is genuine...' 1 Peter 1:7 NLT

So you want to sparkle like a diamond? Well, before a stone becomes a diamond it's just a lump of carbon put under heaps of pressure.

The Bible says, 'These trials will show that your faith is genuine.' You become so engrossed with 'how you're feeling' or 'what's gone wrong' that you miss what God is up to through it all. God hasn't gone AWOL; He's allowed this trouble to happen so that your faith can shine. Hard as this might be to hear right now, there is nothing like a spot of trouble to bring your 'faith life' into the open. Singing perfect harmonies to the latest worship song doesn't impress God half as much as putting your trust in Him when your life is badly out of tune.

James knew a thing or two about sparkling: '... be very happy when you are tested in different ways. You know that such testing of your faith produces endurance. Endure until your testing is over. Then you will be mature and complete.' (James 1:2-4 GWT)

There's far more to being a Christian than singing when you're winning. There's singing when it hurts. If you want to sparkle, you first have to endure the pressure.

content.title: Step on It (1)
content.introtext:
'...Rise and go; your faith has made you well.' Luke 17:19 NIV

I could never do that, I'd be too embarrassed. What if they think I'm stupid? Who am I, anyway? Whatever reason you choose for not doing what God asks just doesn't cut it. God didn't ask Moses, a man with a proven stutter, to speak up for His people because He enjoyed watching embarrassment. He'd appointed Moses the job of 'rescuer' before time began.

Likewise, God isn't prompting you to tell your mate about Jesus because He wants you cut down by the 'in' crowd. He knows only you can connect with your friend. If you've heard from God, now is the time to step on it.

There is a story in 2 Kings 5: 1-19 about Naaman, a top general in the Syrian army. He had plenty of muscle, and plenty of respect. But Naaman had leprosy. He eventually put all his hopes in Elisha for a miracle healing. However, when God's prophet didn't wave a magic wand over him, he threw a hissy fit along these lines: 'If it was a wash I came for, I could've picked baths better than your Jewish sewers.' He didn't act upon God's Word, so he didn't get healed.

Meantime, his servant did the old 'count slowly to ten and breathe deeply' thing, before suggesting there could be something about bathing in the Jordan. Namaan did see sense, acted upon the Word of God, and wound up with skin as smooth as any you'll see in a cosmetic commercial. Lesson: When God speaks, act!



SoulFood: Ezek 31-33, Luke 3:11-20, Ps 59:9-17, Pr 14:23-24

content.title: Step on It (2)
content.introtext:
'...Rise and go; your faith has made you well.' Luke 17:19 NIV

Perhaps you've felt you've had your fair share of being an 'outsider'. But imagine being a leper in Jesus' day. Everywhere you walked you had to ring a bell, as if you were a lost cow, just to let people know you were approaching. Once the bell chimed, people would run for cover in order to get away from you. You weren't allowed into church because people, who really should've known better, believed that God had washed His hands of you.

Can you relate to that kind of treatment? You feel like God has snubbed you. Feel like people avoid you. Feel like you're never going to be back on the up and up because the people surrounding you are as messed up as you are. If so it's time to shout out for Jesus. In Luke 17, that's what the people with leprosy did. They broke the rules. Instead of ringing their usual bells and crying out, 'Unclean,' like they were supposed to, they took a chance on crying out for Jesus. And no, God didn't run for cover, He stopped to answer.

Desperate people pray desperate prayers and God responds to their prayers. James teaches us: 'When you ask, you do not receive, because you ask with wrong motives.' (James 4:3 NIV) So today, get your heart right and pray! Jesus tells us, 'So I tell you to ask, and you will receive.' (Luke 11:9 GWT)

content.title: Step on It (3)
content.introtext:
'...Rise and go; your faith has made you well.' Luke 17:19 NIV

Let's look again at the ten people with leprosy Jesus healed. Their flesh is getting worn away and yet what does Jesus do? Magic up some special kind of medicine? Snap his fingers and, voilà, skin velvety as a new born? Nope. Jesus sends them walking. There is no on-the-spot miracle for these people. He asks them to walk in faith.

Imagine as they head to the temple to show the priests that they've been cured. At first maybe there was a bit of hesitation-'But we're not even cured!' But the further they walked, the better their bodies became. Picture the scene as rotten stubs healed, wounds and sores gave way to layers of smooth skin. Can't you just hear these guys laughing all the way to the temple?

Sometimes before God will do the miraculous, He'll ask you to do the ridiculous. When God tells you something, best step on it. 'And so it was that as they went, they were cleansed.' (Luke 17:14 NKJ) Note the words, 'as they went.' The Bible says, 'The steps of a good man are ordered by the Lord...' (Psalm 37:23 NKJ) Whether it's healing, direction, forgiveness, or whatever you need, these people remind us to keep walking in faith. Maybe God doesn't want to snap His fingers over your problem; maybe He's asking you to carry on walking. Maybe the walk is the way to your wholeness.

content.title: Influence
content.introtext:
'...But who do you say I am?' Matthew 16:15 NLT

You're too tall, you're too small; you're too fat, you're too thin; you're too normal, you're too weird; you're too confident, you're too shy. People blurt out their opinions left, right and centre. If we're not careful, we can allow them to damage us-chewing us up, spitting us out and leaving us in an insecure heap on the floor.

People do the same with Jesus-voicing their opinions: He's not real, He's not God, He's not important, He doesn't matter, He's boring, He's mad, He's a conman, He's dead. If we're not careful we can allow them to nudge us into unbelief too, twisting our thoughts and words, hopes and experiences into an unrecognisable shape.

When Jesus was on earth people did the same, using their words to try and trick Him. They talked Him down to try to discourage Him. They tried to make Him look foolish to cause His followers to doubt Him.

Jesus knows the damage that people's negative opinions can have on us if we allow them to grow and fester. This is why He sat down and had a chat with His disciples: to teach them not to allow the words of others to destroy them. He asked them, 'Who do you say I am?' to teach them He was indeed the Son of God! Be confident in God, and know that He is bigger than any doubt and negativity that comes your way.

content.title: The Right Thing (2)

'...Stay away from complaining and arguing.' Philippians 2:14 TLB

The Bible encourages us to 'do everything without complaining and arguing.'

Do you need to give your mouth a closer examination today? If friends were to describe you as a character from an AA Milne book (bear with us... J) would they say you are (a) Easy-going Winnie the Pooh; (b) Thankful Piglet; (c) Bouncy-happy Tigger; or (d) Moaning and groaning Eeyore?

Kent Crockett wrote, 'A friend of mine lives on the coast of Florida a few [kilometres] from Kennedy Space Centre. I told him, "It must be fun watching the space shuttle launches and going to the beach all the time." "I never go to the beach," he replied. "I don't even go outside my house to watch the space shuttle launch." "You're kidding me. Why?" I asked. "I've seen them so many times it's no big deal." When we see the same blessings every day, we eventually stop noticing them. When we stop noticing, we quit appreciating. When we quit appreciating, we stop thanking. When we stop thanking, we start complaining.'

Are you spending more time complaining instead of appreciating? Is your first instinct to moan, or do you weigh up your words before you speak them? Remember: '...Stay away from complaining and arguing' and develop an attitude of gratitude.

content.title: A Cry For Help
content.introtext:
'Answer me when I call...Give me relief from my distress...' Psalm 4:1 NIV

It's human nature to want rid of a problem immediately. Doesn't matter if it's debt, boredom, headaches or an annoying girlfriend or boyfriend, we just want it to go away-now! And when the problem is a real one and seems too big to fix, that's when we cry out to God: Help God! Take it away! Are you listening? It's not right, not fair, I don't like it, I want it out of my life, sort it out, God-now!

These might seem like anxious, immature responses but in the Bible, David sets us an example. When life got tough he cried out to God: 'Answer me when I call...Give me relief from my distress.' When he was panicking, feeling depressed or messed up, he prayed. Many of his 'help me, God' prayers are recorded in the Psalms. In them we discover that no matter what, God always listens, and will never ever reject us.

Now when life is hunky-dory, sunshine and smiles we rarely need to hear this; but when life hits the fan and you feel as though your prayers are bouncing off the ceiling, these words of assurance can be music to our ears. Know God hears you and will answer. His answers might not be what you expect, but He is there for you.

content.title: The Fear (2)
content.introtext:
'The word of the Lord came to Abram...saying, "Do not be afraid."' Genesis 15:1 NKJ

You'd think after being told something a couple of hundred times we'd get the message. But even though that's how often the Bible gives us the 'do not fear' message things still scare us. Fear can hit us anytime and sometimes more than once a day!

All our fears basically come down to two questions: (1) 'Will God protect me?' (2) 'Is God going to provide everything I need?' When Abraham got scared, God answered these two questions for him: 'Do not be afraid...I am your shield, your very great reward.' In the same way, God answers both of our fear questions with a resounding 'Yes!' He will protect us, and He will provide all our needs.

Now this doesn't mean you can go leaping off high buildings, shouting, 'The Lord will protect me,' expecting God to swoop down and catch you just before impact. It doesn't mean you can shop till you drop, max out a credit card and never look for a job, saying, 'God will provide all I need.' You can't expect God to put money in your account to cover your reckless and selfish lifestyle.

God gives us common sense and expects us to use it. God didn't create us to live life doing whatever whenever however we feel like it, no matter how careless or life-threatening it is! God wants us to live a life of trust, listening to and following Him.

content.title: The Fear (3)
content.introtext:
'The word of the Lord came to Abram...saying, "Do not be afraid."' Genesis 15:1 NKJ

Researchers have found that about forty percent of the things we worry about never happen. Thirty percent are in the past and can't be helped. Twelve percent involve the affairs of others that are not even our business. Ten percent relate to sickness, real or imagined. That means only eight percent of the things we worry about are even likely to happen! Mark Twain once said, 'I am an old man and have known a great many troubles, but most of them never happened.'

A survey recently discovered the fear of spiders (arachnophobia) to be the biggest phobia among young people. Fear of needles (trypanophobia) was second, with fear of clowns (coulrophobia) third and fear of flying (aerophobia) fourth. But most fears are completely irrational: you would have to fly every day for 19,000 years before the probability you'd be killed in a plane crash gets anywhere close to 100%.

In Matthew 6:25-26 NLT, Jesus tells us '...not to worry about everyday life-whether you have enough food and drink, or enough clothes to wear. Isn't life more than food, and your body more than clothing? Look at the birds. They don't plant or harvest or store food in barns, for your Heavenly Father feeds them. And aren't you far more valuable to Him than they are?'

Nicknames are commonplace across the world. Sometimes, at a young age, we get given nicknames by friends or family. Do you have any? 'Without faith it is impossible to please Him...' Hebrews 11:6 NKJ

Some people use this excuse with things of God: 'I can't understand it so I don't believe it'. Do they understand how the touch screen on their smartphone works? All aspects of our life involve faith and to truly believe in God involves living by faith. It's something you do, a way of life. The Bible says that without faith, it's impossible to please God. And why? 'Because anyone who comes to Him must believe that He exists and that He rewards those who earnestly seek Him.'

If you want to know God you have to put your faith in Him. God wants you to trust His Word, His character, and His track record of faithfulness. It is impossible to please Him if you don't.

Living by faith not only pleases God but brings excitement into our lives, helps cast out our fears and gives us a guaranteed hope that when we do what we can, God will do what we can't.

content.title: Just Desserts
content.introtext:
'...We have all received...one grace after another...' John 1:16 AMP

There's an old story that goes like this: a small boy had been late again and again for dinner. One particular day, after his parents had warned him again to be on time, he arrived later than ever. He found his mum and dad seated at the table, already eating. In his place was nothing but a single slice of bread and a glass of water. He sat in silence, about to cry.

Suddenly his dad got up. The boy then watched as his father reached over, picked up his plate and set it before himself. Then his dad put his own full plate in front of his son, smiling warmly as he made the exchange. Later, as a man, he said, 'All my life I've known what God was like by what my father did that night.' What his dad had done was help his son understand God's grace.

Grace is a gift that costs everything for the giver and nothing for the recipient. It always comes free of charge, no strings attached, and on the house.

Ephesians 2:2 GWT tells us how everyone had turned their back on God: 'You followed the ways of this present world and...refused to obey God.' Yet God doesn't give us our 'just desserts'! He chooses to love us and forgive us. God is gracious-He gives us gifts we don't deserve, what we cannot earn or buy. The question is will you accept it? Will you live as God intended-not trapped in sin, but free by God's grace?

content.title: Transformers (1)
content.introtext:
'...Let God transform you into a new person...' Romans 12:2 NLT

Have you seen any of the Transformers movies or TV series? If you have, I imagine you'll have noticed that Transformers, as the name suggests, transform. No matter where they are, they are ready to transform when needed, at any given moment. God talks about the importance of always being ready to transform in today's verse: always asking, always available, always willing to 'let God transform you into a new person by changing the way you think.'

That means 24/7. Whether we're alone or in a crowd, at work or school, playing sport or hanging out with friends, at the cinema or just walking the dog, we're called to fix our attention on God.

Transformation is necessary-we're all prone to 'grace abuse'. Flick through any popular magazine and you'll see temptations everywhere that make sin look downright appealing.

But God always wants to bring out the best in you, not allow you to sink in a muddy mess. However He won't take you by force-there's no arm-twisting involved. It's your choice. When we first get to know Jesus, it's just the beginning. When we stay with Jesus we make progress. But as we choose to be transformed by him, that's when we experience success.



SoulFood: 1 Sam 20:30-23:29, Luke 8:40-56, Ps 146, Pr 16:4-5

content.title: Transformers (2)
content.introtext:
'...Let God transform you into a new person...' Romans 12:2 NLT

If you're always out to win popularity points, you could find yourself easy prey for peer pressure! If you're a people-pleaser you could be on your way to ruining your reputation! Cultivating conformity could result in a character catastrophe!

Psalm 37:5 CEV says, 'Let the Lord lead you and trust Him to help.' We're meant to be God led, not people led. We're meant to be followers of Jesus not followers of our friends. Now don't panic, thinking God doesn't want you to have friends; He's not asking you to become a loner. But He is saying: 'Don't copy the behaviour and customs of this world, but let God transform you into a new person by changing the way you think. Then you will know what God wants you to do, and you will know how good and pleasing and perfect His will really is.' (Romans 12:2 NLT)

When we are a follower of Jesus, we have God's Spirit living in us, giving the power to transform. 1 John 4:4 NLT says, 'You belong to God, my dear children...the Spirit who lives in you is greater than the spirit who lives in the world.' God doesn't ask about our ability, or our inability, but about our availability. Are you available to let God transform you?



SoulFood: 1 Sam 24-26, Luke 9:1-17, Ps 14, Pr 16:6-7

content.title: Transformers (3)
content.introtext:
'...Let God transform you into a new person...' Romans 12:2 NLT

Are you one of the crowd, or a unique individual? You might well say the second, but if we're being honest, most of us really just want to fit in.

Chuck Swindoll said, 'The truth is, we hate to appear different lest we be ostracised, branded fanatics and rejected. So, we conform. You'll see it in the child eager to please; the adolescent aligning with peer pressure; the adult breaking their back to keep up with the Joneses.'

God wants His people to be willing to be radically transformed: 'Therefore, I urge you...to offer your bodies as living sacrifices, holy and pleasing to God-this is your spiritual act of worship. Do not conform any longer to the pattern of this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind...' (Romans 12:1-2 NIV)

Here are two facts God wants you to know about being a transformer. First, it's urgent. Paul says, 'I urge you,' but words like beg and plead are used in some translations.

Secondly, you've got the Holy Spirit's help: believers are promised that 'the Spirit who lives in you is greater than the spirit who lives in the world.' (1 John 4:4 NLT) God is on your side, helping you resist the world's pressure to conform to its ways.

content.title: Transformers (4)
content.introtext:
'...Let God transform you into a new person...' Romans 12:2 NLT

There's a guy in the Bible called Hosea who helps us understand how difficult the struggle between conforming and transforming can be. His wife's actions caused Hosea to became the talk of the town-he was the centre of a scandal; everyone was gossiping about him and his wife. So the 'conform or transform' struggle began; He wanted to shame her, he wanted to forgive her. He wanted to divorce her and have nothing to do with her, he wanted to take her back and be together again. She disgraced and humiliated him but he chose not to conform. Against all the odds, he transformed to love her and keep on loving her. She made him the joke of the community, yet he allowed God to change him. He was able to give his wife a love she didn't deserve. His transformation enabled a nation back then (and millions since) to see a God who loves us unconditionally.

Be a transformer. God can take what you do and lift it off the scale. Just: 'Offer yourselves as a living sacrifice to God, dedicated to His service and pleasing to Him... Do not conform yourselves to the standards of this world, but let God transform you inwardly by a complete change of your mind. Then you will be able to know the will of God-what is good and is pleasing to Him and is perfect.' (Romans12:1-2 GNT)

content.title: Move It!
content.introtext:
'Why are you crying out to Me? Tell the Israelites to move on.' Exodus 14:15 NIV

Imagine you've been given the biggest, most important job of your life so far. Overwhelmed, you're not convinced you can do it. But remembering Philippians 4:13, 'I can do everything through Christ, who gives me strength,' you drum up confidence from the bottom of your boots, and give it a go.

Unbelievably everything goes great-everybody's impressed, you've zoomed in popularity... but then, problems and difficulties start zapping you from all directions. People who thanked you are now criticising, doubting and blaming you at every opportunity. You wish you'd never started out.

Welcome to the world of Moses! Things started off terrific for him-at least once he got over himself and agreed to follow God's lead and take a few million refugees out of Egypt. But then they find themselves trapped, with Pharaoh's crack chariot division hard on their heels. What seems to be an inescapable dead end is right in front of them. You can imagine what they said as they turned on Moses: 'You promised us freedom and you've brought us to Loserville.' Their complaining stopped Moses in his tracks, but God said, 'Why are you crying out to Me? Tell the Israelites to move on.'

So Moses kept moving forward and saw God at work in his life. God parted a whole sea, leading millions to safety, and stopped the enemy advancing. Don't stop and listen to cynics, worriers or doubters! Ask God for directions, and keep moving.

content.title: Focus
content.introtext:
'...He kept...on going...He kept his eyes on the one...' Hebrews 11:27 NLT

Two cute rabbits appear in your garden at once, and you decide you want to catch them. If you try and catch both at the same time you'll catch neither. It's only when you focus on one at a time that you'll achieve what you desired. What about the decisions you are making for your life? If you leave all your options open, you won't achieve much.

Winston Churchill once said, 'Success is the ability to go from one failure to another with no loss of enthusiasm.' We are capable of doing many things with our lives-we could become a doctor or dentist, teacher or lawyer, policeman or paramedic, actor or dancer. But if we focus on all our options at the same time, we will end up achieving none of them. Decide on one, and stick to it!

Hebrews 11 is full of men and women who achieved much in their life, overcoming many obstacles and traumas. Like Moses: 'He kept right on going because he kept his eyes on the one who is invisible.' Paul in Philippians 3:13-14 NLT tells us, 'I focus on this one thing...Jesus.'

What about you? Where is your faith focus? Is it all over the place? Jesus one minute, keeping your options open the next? Stay focused all the time! 'Let us fix our eyes on Jesus...who for the joy set before Him endured the cross...and sat down at...the throne of God. Consider Him...so that you will not grow weary and lose heart.' (Hebrews 12:2-3)

content.title: Health Warning
content.introtext:
'Turn us back to You, O Lord, and we will be restored.' Lamentations 5:21 NKJ

Lamentations is probably the saddest book in the Bible-the story of a people who refuse to change-and who pay the price in suffering. When we refuse to turn away from the things that God hates, there are always consequences. Any bad habit you cannot break or you refuse to break is a habit that has the power to break you. It's not what you go through in life that messes you up; it's what you keep going back to!

Today it's time to give yourself a 'habit health check'. How many times have you said, 'I'm not going to look at it, I'm not going to listen to it, I'm not going to do it again' only to go out and do it over and over again? Is your addiction so out of control you're heading for a damaging eating disorder, critical drink problem, drug overdose, or fatal self-harming? Do you struggle with compulsions that bring moments of pleasure followed by days of regret and disappointment?

Don't feel down and defeated! The book of Lamentations brings hope for us all. In the face of death and destruction, with life falling apart at the seams, Jeremiah turns tragedy into triumph, eventually crying out to God, 'Great is your faithfulness!' (Lamentations 3:23 NIV) He knew with God there is always hope because He can give us the power to change.

Pray: Turn me back to You, O Lord, and I will be restored. Break those bad habits for good!

content.title: BOGOF
content.introtext:
'...I insist on paying the full price...' 1 Chronicles 21:24 NIV

Everyone loves a bargain! There's a great sense of satisfaction in getting that trendy top half-price or scouring the supermarkets seeking out those BOGOF ('Buy One Get One Free') offers. That's because there's something quite satisfying about getting a genuine bargain. Some people make it a way of life, refusing to buy food that doesn't display a discount sticker or to hand over cash unless it's a knockdown offer.

Now there's nothing wrong with showing a bit of common sense when it comes to shopping. But it's a big fat no-no when it comes to your commitment to God. There's no cheap deal when it comes to faith; no BOGOF offers on church attendance, prayer times or Bible reading; no bargain basement offers on how we should love.

Commitment to God is about sacrifice, giving that costs in terms of our self, time and money. Ephesians 5:1-2 GNT tells us: 'Since you are God's dear children, you must try to be like Him. Your life must be controlled by love, just as Christ loved us and gave His life for us...'

Giving to God what costs you nothing doesn't demonstrate commitment. Like David, when it comes to serving the Lord we need to 'insist on paying the full price!'



SoulFood: 2 Sam 3:22-7:17, Luke 9:57-62, Ps 46, Pr 16:20-22

content.title: Pep Talk, Hebrews 12 Style
content.introtext:
'Let us lay aside every weight...' Hebrews 12:1 NKJ

Today is the opening ceremony for the 2012 Olympics. Imagine if every day were like this with a whopping, solid gold medal awaiting you at the podium. The crowds are chanting your name, the commentators have you picked out, the cameras are trained on you.

What do you do? You strip down, you start the race and you don't quit. You keep your eye on the finishing line, on Jesus. He's the trim, toned athlete who started this race and finished it with records, medals and victories. You get into His training regime-the highs, the lows, the cross, the shame. When your faith has a stitch or your hope pulls a hamstring, you watch the repeats of Jesus hurdling His way through insults, high-jumping hostility and setting the pace from the front in times of trouble. You let Jesus quench your thirst and rehydrate your soul.

And when you feel like you can't move another muscle, when you've hit the wall-you remember your training. Every Olympian has hit the pain barrier but run through it. Only the well-trained win gold; only the well-trained find themselves on God's podium. And the tougher the training, the holier the living. That's why we compete, isn't it? To run our best, flat-out into the arms of our living God? So no more ankle-dragging, no more tripping and traipsing. Run like every day is Olympics 2012 day!

content.title: Courage Under Fire (1)
content.introtext:
'Be strong and of good courage...' Joshua 1:6 NKJ

The Jordan River stretched out before them. Forty years of petty squabbles and backbiting. Forty years of wandering and wandering. Forty years of desert life; camping in the desert, waking early to see if God had sent manna from the skies again. Forty years. And it was all about to end.

A new life beckoned on the other side of the river. It held the promise of milk and honey and meat and homes and land fit for growing fruit. Yes, it was the promised land. One snag: it was enemy-occupied territory. Who were they to think they could go into battle and drive the current occupants out? And who was this Joshua bloke to think he could lead the battalions? He wasn't a war leader or a guerrilla commander; he was a desert nomad.

Maybe, they should just turn back and find a smaller piece of land. A land where nobody had to be evicted. Maybe. But hadn't God promised the best? A land perfect for growing a mighty nation. If they settled for less, what would that say about the Jews? What would that say about God? Is this a God who promised the best but delivered far less? As fear fluttered like birds in Joshua's insides, God spoke to him. 'Be strong and of good courage.' His spirit was immediately strengthened. God had promised to turn a crowd of past slaves into a mighty, godly nation. Joshua had to act on it.



SoulFood: 2 Sam 12:1-14:20, Luke 10:13-24, Ps 78:9-16, Pr 16:25

content.title: Courage Under Fire (2)
content.introtext:
'Be strong and of good courage...' Joshua 1:6 NKJ

All the Jews were watching Joshua. He needed to be strong, he needed to show courage. He needed to be a role model of strength and belief. It wasn't just about him, it was about those God planned to bless through him. God has told him to 'be strong and of good courage.' So his attitude mattered. His ability to demonstrate faith in the face of impossible odds needed to be seen by the Jews. His actions had to inspire courage in others.

What about you? The battles that you face in life are not just about you, you know. They're also about the people God plans to bless through you. Your friends, your family, your community-only God knows the plans He has for you and only He knows who He intends to influence through you. It's suggested that the average person influences 10 000 people in their lifetime. And, with God on your side, you're far more than 'average'.

So, in what tough areas could you inspire others to be strong? What circumstances could you show others that having faith really makes a difference? Like Joshua, take the lead. You never know who could be watching.

content.title: Courage Under Fire (3)
content.introtext:
'Be strong and of good courage...' Joshua 1:6 NKJ

So Joshua heard the words, 'I will give you every place where you set your foot... No one will be able to stand up against you all the days of your life. As I was with Moses, so I will be with you; I will never leave you or forsake you. Be strong and courageous, because you will lead these people to inherit the land I swore to their fathers to give them.' (Joshua 1:3-6 NIV) With these words God gave him the strength and reassurance he needed to lead the fight for the Promised Land.

But all this happened a long time ago, didn't it? Switch on the news now and it seems every other week soldiers are fighting for that little strip of land, all of them claiming they've got a God-given right to it. Doesn't fighting just make orphans and widows?

Joshua's fight was a just fight. His people had been slaves, and now God wanted to restore their heritage. It was a fight worth pursuing. In 1960s America there was another just fight. Dr Martin Luther King also believed in fighting for a promised land. A land where children were judged by their character, rather than the colour of their skin. He called for people to fight by using peace as a weapon. When struck, he would not strike back. An eye for an eye and the whole world goes blind, he believed. God honoured his courage. And, if He has called you to lead a just fight, He will honour yours too.

content.title: All That You Are (And Aren't)
content.introtext:
'...The Good Shepherd...lays down His life for the sheep.' John 10:11 AMP

Do you find yourself singing 'baa baa black sheep'? Do people count you and your little woolly friends when they can't get to sleep? Ever considered 'cardigan' as a career prospect?

Ok, so obviously Jesus never literally meant that we are sheep; just that our behaviour can be similar to sheep. But how? Well, firstly, we all have a tendency to ramble off on our own: 'We all, like sheep, have gone astray, each of us has turned to his own way.' (Isaiah 53:6 NIV)

Secondly, sheep aren't the smartest of animals. They can't see that far around or ahead. You may think you've got away with that sly dig or whispered put-down, but for how long? God sees everything! 'If I go up to the Heavens, You are there; if I make my bed in the depths, You are there.' (Psalm 139:8 NIV) You can fool some of the people some of the time, but you can't ever fool God.

God wants us to be honest with Him, with others and with ourselves. That means the good, the bad and the ugly. In James 5:16, we're told to own up when we get it wrong. 'Why should I?' you might retort. '...that you may be healed...' (ESV) When you give God all that you are (and aren't), He'll bless you and use you, above and beyond your sometimes sheep-like limitations!



SoulFood: 2 Sam 17:14-19:43, Luke 10:38-42, Ps 78:32-39, Pr 16:31

content.title: Giant Slayer
content.introtext:
'...Arise...go...to the land which I am giving to (you)...' Joshua 1:2 NKJ

Is God calling you into something or somewhere new? Whether it's moving to a new job, a new school, a new home or a whole new way of living, any kind of change can freak us out. A change of scenery on the stage of our lives can lead to fear creeping in, looming over us like some kind of shadowy giant. Being obedient to God's call is important so let's learn from Joshua.

God knew Joshua would get scared when he understood what He was telling him to do: 'You and all these people get ready to cross the Jordan River into the land I am about to give to them.' (Joshua 1:2 NIV) So God said three times to Joshua he would need to be strong and courageous. On the third time He said, 'Have I not commanded you? Be strong and courageous. Do not be terrified; do not be discouraged, for the Lord your God will be with you wherever you go.' (Joshua 1:9 NIV) Remember that God goes with you too. Do you have some giants of fear? With God you can do more than just disable them-you can knock them dead!

At the beginning of Joshua (1:1-9), God gives some sound advice on how to go about moving into a new home and situation. Grab your Bible and check out His advice for yourself.

content.title: Showing Honest Emotion
content.introtext:
'Jesus wept. Then the Jews said, "See how He loved him!"' John 11:35-36 NIV

Jesus wasn't interested in superficial smiles here on earth. He didn't shrink away from real emotions. Jesus allowed Himself to be real with people. When Lazarus died He wept with Lazarus' sisters, Martha and Mary.

What would you think about letting your guard down like that? Do you worry about showing people how you really feel? Do you let taunts like 'What are you crying for, boy?' or 'You're such a drama queen!' silence your legitimate emotions? The Bible says, 'For everything there is a season, a time for every activity under Heaven...A time to cry and a time to laugh. A time to grieve and a time to dance.' (Ecclesiastes 3:1-4 NLT)

If we put up a safe robotlike shell, we run the risk of coming across as thickskinned or fake. If we make out we're 'Just fine, thank you,' we could miss out on being comforted or bringing comfort to someone else.

Have you got a prayer buddy? If you haven't, ask someone you can trust, someone you feel you can let your guard down with. Do you know someone who needs some comfort and prayers? Why not offer your services!

content.title: Hidden Things
content.introtext:
'Lord, by this time he stinketh.' John 11:39 KJV

What do you keep in the dark? It's human nature to keep some things in our lives hidden, worrying that if we let them out in the open and into the light, they would let off a right old stink and pollute the fragranced atmosphere. Pride stands in the way because we fear people will look at us in a different way. So we stay in the stink.

Mary and Martha wanted to leave the stink of their dead brother in the tomb. Can you imagine the state Lazarus was in after four days in the grave? So when Jesus told them to get the stone rolled away, it's quite understandable that they didn't see the point. What was Jesus up to?

But Jesus was right when He said, 'If you [will] believe you [will] see the glory of God.' (John 11:40 NKJ) He not only went on to bring Lazarus out of the tomb, He brought him back to life! Sometimes in life there are things that just stink and we'd rather keep buried. We don't want to share our mess with other people or work through it with God.

People may give up on you but Jesus won't. Have you ever changed a baby's nappy? If anything else smelled that bad you would throw it in the trash, right? But not your child; you love them and you know that with a little help they're capable of outgrowing it and becoming something good. Like Mary and Martha, you may think it's too late for a miracle, but it's not. Your finances may stink, your relationship may stink, your prospects for the future may stink but, if you will believe, you will 'see the glory of God.'

content.title: Dad Knows Best (1)
content.introtext:
'He who observes the wind will not sow...' Ecclesiastes 11:4 NKJ

Some people suck up their food quicker than a vacuum cleaner. Others are 'savour the flavour' types who take their sweet time chewing every mouthful. Multitaskers talk while eating and let you in on the process of how exactly their food is breaking down-a delight for all at the table! And then there's the 'nibble, pick or play' sort who spend more time rearranging the food on their plate than actually eating it. They can spend ages before even moving the fork to their mouth!

We're all different in how we approach the little things in life. But we can be sure about this tasty fact-God's ways are different from ALL our ways. It's important to remember that if we're too concerned with making sure everything's right before we talk to people about Jesus, we'll never get started.

The Bible says, 'Farmers who wait for perfect weather never plant. If they watch every cloud, they never harvest.' (Ecclesiastes 11:4 NLT) If you're waiting for everything to be perfect with you or those you care about before you open your mouth and start telling people about Jesus, you'll never get round to it-or see the rewards.

So, challenge yourself. Next time you're with someone you haven't told about Jesus, pray for God to give you a way into the conversation to start sowing! See what God does!

content.title: Dad Knows Best (2)
content.introtext:
'Faith is being sure of what we hope for...' Hebrews 11:1 NIV

It's tempting to think that successful people are those who get it right first time, every time. But many of them simply see failure as a steppingstone to success. Polio was once one of the most feared diseases in the world. Jonas Salk, the developer of the vaccine which finally eliminated this deadly threat, failed many times before he succeeded. Every time his team was discouraged by something that didn't work, he'd say, 'Great, we've made a great discovery!' By learning what didn't work, they came closer to what did.

Giving up on ourselves can stem from listening to negative words spoken against us. Hopes and dreams can shatter to pieces on the sharp rocks of harsh words.

There's Someone, though, who has monumental faith in you and wants to speak better words over you. He has anchored those hopes and dreams deep in your soul. He's not in the business of making hopeless cases; He creates masterpieces. You're valuable to Him and are made for great things. To believe and hope in this, we have to have faith in Him and who He says He is. Jesus said, '...I have come that they may have life, and have it to the full.' (John 10:10 NIV)

Ask your Dad in Heaven about your hopes and dreams. Write down or draw anything He gives or reveals to you.

content.title: Dad Knows Best (3)
content.introtext:
'...He kept his eyes on the One who is invisible.' Hebrews 11:27 NLT

It starts out like this: 'We were texting loads and then, on last night's text, there were three kisses at the end! Three! Before it was two, max! Honestly, serious butterflies when I got that text. So nice having someone to make you feel special...he's my everything.'

But then, this happens: 'You will not believe this, right. I texted him three kisses, right, as usual. We always send three kisses-minimum. He texts back one, one! I felt so special before and now I just feel like old bubblegum he wants to scrape off his shoe!'

It doesn't matter how perfect you think someone is, they will eventually disappoint, upset or frustrate you. No one gets it right all the time. That's why getting your confidence and self-worth from God, and not from someone else, is so important. Your relationship with Him, the unseen, should come before anyone or anything. Loved ones can come and go, but look at God's love in comparison: '...Neither death nor life...neither height nor depth, nor anything else in all creation, will be able to separate us from the love of God that is in Christ Jesus our Lord.' (Romans 8:38-39 NIV)

Take time out to think of some things that stress or worry you, then, make a decision to 'Cast all your anxiety on Him because He cares for you.' (1 Peter 5:7) He promises He will '...quiet you with His love, He will rejoice over you with singing.' (Zephaniah 3:17)

content.title: Dad Knows Best (4)
content.introtext:
'...Faith...if it is not accompanied by action, is dead.' James 2:17 NIV

We live in a bit of a 'microwave culture' nowadays, don't we? It's all about how quickly we can have something. We want to hear that sweet 'ping' after only a couple of minutes' wait and (let's face it) very little effort from ourselves.

The reality is, however, microwave food doesn't taste that great, especially when compared to one of mum's special dishes. All the time and effort taken over a carefully-prepared home-cooked dinner becomes obvious in its taste. All that time and effort counts. It's exactly the same for most things we want in life: we have to be prepared to put in time and effort.

'For we are labourers together with God...' (1 Corinthians 3:9 KJV) Having the gift of faith in God and what He can do in our lives is an amazing, life-transforming thing. But God wants us to play our part too. You can't ask for God to help you pass all your exams without putting any work into the revision-that's not using your God-given abilities. And if we're to put time and effort in with God like Jesus, we've got to make sure that love is at the centre. Because the Bible says that if we're not love-focused in what we do, it don't mean diddly!

So put some time and effort into study time with God! Look up how to be a really good 'labourer' with Him and for Him by checking out 1 Corinthians 3:1-23 and 2 Corinthians 6:1-18.

content.title: Extra Grace Cases
content.introtext:
'He gives more grace...' James 4:6 NKJ

Attitudes can be pretty ugly things. Like, when you say hello to someone and they look you up and down with that 'Hello Declined' expression on their face. Bah. However ugly their reaction may look, there's part of you just wants to fire back the same attitude at them. Or better yet, to slap that selfrighteous pout off their face! 'For God called you to do good, even if it means suffering, just as Christ suffered for you. He is your example, and you must follow in His steps.' You can't love like Christ without His help. Pray Paul's prayer out loud for yourself, found in Ephesians 3:14-21.

content.title: Open Your Eyes
content.introtext:
'...Lord, open his eyes so he may see...' 2 Kings 6:17 NIV

The Bible records: 'When the servant of the man of God got up and went out early the next morning, an army with horses and chariots had surrounded the city. "Oh, my lord, what shall we do?" the servant asked. "Don't be afraid," the prophet answered. "Those who are with us are more than those are who are with them." And Elisha prayed, "O Lord, open his eyes so he may see." Then the Lord opened the servant's eyes, and he looked and saw the hills full of horses and chariots of fire all around Elisha.' (2 Kings 15-17 NIV) By God's power, the servant saw angels. And God can help you to see His hand at work in what you're going through today. He never promises to remove us from our struggles, but He promises to change the way we look at them. After listing many of his problems, Paul writes: 'In all these things we have complete victory through Him...' (Romans 8:37 GNT) We'd prefer Paul said 'apart from all these things,' but he actually says, 'In all these things.' The solution is not to avoid trouble, but to change the way we see it. God asks, 'Who gives a person sight?' Then answers, 'It is I, the Lord.' (Exodus 4:11 GWT) God let Elisha's servant see an army of angels, Jacob see a ladder that went into Heaven, and Saul of Tarsus (Paul) see Jesus on the road to Damascus. The blind man said to Jesus, '...I want to see,' (Mark 10:51 NIV) and he walked away with clear vision. Today ask God to let you see His hand in every circumstance.

content.introtext:
'Oh, the joys of those who are kind to the poor!...' Psalm 41:1 NLT

We may lack the latest, the biggest, the finest and the fastest, but we seldom lack the necessary, right? God doesn't 'guilt-trip' us, but He does want us to consider [remember, be mindful of] the poor. 'But if there are any poor people in your towns...do not be hard-hearted or tightfisted toward them. Instead, be generous and lend them whatever they need. Do not be mean-spirited... If you refuse to make the loan and the needy person cries out to the Lord, you will be considered guilty of sin. Give freely without begrudging it, and the Lord your God will bless you in everything you do.' (Deuteronomy 15:7-9 NLT)

You might think, 'Oh, you know I'd love to help out but, well, they don't call me "moneybags" you know.' The Bible pushes us to look deeper: 'If you have two shirts, give one to the poor. If you have food, share it with those who are hungry.' (Luke 3:11 NLT) There are always things we can do.

James 2:14-26 tells us faith and deeds go together. We've been called to feed, shelter and clothe the needy (Isaiah 58:5-12). God is compassionate and generous to the poor, and He asks us to follow His example.

content.title: Poor So We Could Be Rich (2)
content.introtext:
'He who gives to the poor will lack nothing...' Proverbs 28:27 NIV

Jesus said, 'The Spirit of the Lord is upon Me, for He has anointed Me to bring good news to the poor...' (Luke 4:18 NLT) He also said that '...anyone who believes in Me will do the same works I have done...' (John 14:12 NLT)

Let's have a look see at how the New Testament church lived that out: 'All the believers...shared everything they had. They sold their property and possessions and shared the money with those in need...' As a result, they experienced 'great joy'. (Acts 2:44-46 NLT)

Not sure you believe all that warm fuzzy joy bit? I'm sure some of them would rather have been in Toys"R"Us than this upsidedown, shareycarey Jesus"R"Us! Some people would not have been pleased with this arrangement. All that sharing meant they lost out in the long term, right? Wrong. That's not how God's Kingdom works at all.

Here's a look into the workings of God's Kingdom: 'One man gives freely, yet gains even more; another withholds unduly, but comes to poverty. A generous11 man will prosper; he who refreshes others will himself be refreshed.' (Proverbs 11:24-25 NIV) Freely give to others and the Lord will give back to you. Don't let any selfishness or fear tighten your purse or harden your heart, because '...those who trust in the Lord will lack no good thing.' (Psalm 34:10 NLT)

Next time God nudges you to show compassion and give, do it. Then when you have a need, you'll have Psalm 34 bursting from your lips like David.

content.title: Poor So We Could Be Rich (3)
content.introtext:
'...They gave themselves...to the Lord and then to us...' 2 Corinthians 8:5 NIV

It's hard to know how to best help people in need. Like homeless people, for example: 'Where's my money going, eh? Are they even homeless? They could be professional con artists for all I know. I want my money to go towards a bed for the night, not wasted on smokes or drink.' All these thoughts and fears can swim around in our brains, leaving us swept up with doubt on whether our giving actually does any good. Sometimes that means when we're walking down the street and we spot a homeless person out of the corner of our eye, we check the phone we know hasn't buzzed; we look anywhere but at them; we shut ourselves off because it feels easier that way.

But if you have a read of 2 Corinthians, you'll see that the Macedonian church went about giving in this way: 'They gave themselves first to the Lord and then to us in keeping with God's will.' It was a natural response to meeting Jesus. Giving simply flowed out as part of the purposes of God working in their lives! First give yourself to God more and more and then let His mind at work in you guide you. Because it's possible to give without loving, but you can't love without giving to those God loves.

Pray and let God's wisdom guide you next time you are asked on the street. You might just end up talking to them. Who knows, they might let you pray for them? Remember giving means more than simply dollars and cents.

content.title: Time's Up!
content.introtext:
'The time has come, He said...' Mark 1:15 NIV

Sometimes it can feel pretty daunting telling people about Jesus, even though we know the Gospel is fantastically good news. We zip up our mouths because we feel the responsibility squeezing the life out of us like a straightjacket. We can feel too small for the job: 'What if I say the wrong thing?' 'What if I put them off?' 'What if talking about God without three years of Bible College theological know-how will actually end up putting them off Jesus?'

That's a whole heap of excuses! The Gospel should be shared as simply as possible. Giving someone a load of Christianese using words like 'bloodwashed' and 'sanctification' is probably just gonna go over their heads anyway! Evangelism isn't a project or a task, it's just a natural extension of your relationship with God. What do you do when something great has happened in your life? You tell someone!

Most importantly, take off the stifling straight-jacket of responsibility and give it back to God! It's the Holy Spirit who convicts a person's heart of their need for God. He's the Saviour, not us. Jesus' delivery style went like this: 'At last the time has come!... The Kingdom of God is near! Turn from your sins and believe this Good News!'(Mark 1:15 NLT) God wants to use your style! Just be yourself!

Do you have any friends or family who don't know why you follow God? Have a think about how you might let them know, without making it a task or a project!

content.title: Shake the Salt
content.introtext:
'...This man welcomes sinners...' Luke 15:2 NIV

Jesus upset a lot of people. Mainly the self-righteous mob of Pharisees, who didn't take too kindly at the thought of prostitutes or tax collectors entering the Kingdom of Heaven before them. Read about it for yourself in Matthew 21.

Why did He love them? He said, 'Healthy people don't need a doctor-sick people do. I have come to call not those who think they are righteous, but those who know they are sinners.' (Mark 2:17 NLT) The high priests and leaders who Jesus was talking to refused to believe that He was the Son of God and rejected Him and what He said.

Meanwhile, the sinners believed, knew they needed Him and spent every minute with Him soaking up His every word. Jesus made sinners and outcasts of society welcome at the dinner table with Him. They loved being around Him and Jesus showed them that life would taste better being with Him and living like Him. He accepted invitations into their homes and got involved in their lives. Jesus says that His followers are 'the salt of the earth'. Just like Him, He wants us to be like salt shakers around the table, bringing the first flavour of a new life in Christ into everyone's lives.

If you haven't got many non-Christian friends in your life why not see what community events are going on in your church, or local area, where you could get involved.

content.title: Check Your Plank

'Who are you to judge someone else's servant?' Romans 14:4 NIV

When we judge other people, we can jump to all kinds of conclusions that can not only be just plain wrong, but potentially really harmful. Judging and gossiping often go hand in hand, making a juicy but toxic cocktail with all sorts of bad consequences. Sometimes we find ourselves mentally accusing an innocent person of all sorts of wrongdoing. We can even transfer our own motives on to other people.

content.title: Track Record for Tragedy?
content.introtext:
'...Cast me not off in the time of old age...' Psalm 71:9 NKJ

Psalm 71 was written when David was getting on a bit. He was looking back at how the Lord had helped him in the past through many trials and David had plenty of those! As the saying goes: 'You can't choose your family.' There was enough drama and devastation in the lives of David and his kids to satisfy any daytime TV addict!

Just think of it: 'Coming up on our next talk show, we'll meet the father with a track record for tragedy. A son born dead, a son who raped his own sister, a son who killed his rapist brother, a son killed in battle against him and another son who kills his brother. What gets him out of bed? His story...next!'

That's some dose of devastation for any man to take. It's clear to see through this Psalm that what got David out of bed in the morning was the Lord. 'Lord, I put my hope in You; I have trusted in You since I was young... I will always praise You. My life has been an example to many, because You have been my strong defender. All day long I praise You and proclaim Your glory.' (Psalm 71:58 GNT)

Just like David, God takes all our family issues, worries and faults in His stride. Nothing puts Him off us and nothing's too big for Him: 'His love endures forever.' (Psalm 136:1 NIV)

So, what now? Dig into the Psalms and find one that fits how you're feeling. Personalise it in prayer and worship to God!

content.title: Quick Fixes
content.introtext:
'When I am old...You shall increase my greatness, and comfort me on every side.' Psalm 71:18, 21 NKJ

You can go to all sorts of things for comfort to help you feel better, like attacking that familysized chocolate bar in the fridge. Or seeking attention from other people so you feel wanted and loved for a while. Or indulging in retail therapy.

These things, as good as they may feel at the time, can have real nasty consequences. Quick fixes don't get rid of the problem. It's like trying to jazz up a pair of shoes by customising them with stickers. Even if they make you into twinkletoes for a while, it's not long before they start peeling off and you're just back to the same shoes, only with annoying gluey bits you've got to pick off. The stickers really weren't worth it.

By giving into emotional quick fixes we can be left picking off more problems than we started with. Not gluey bits, but emotional scars and scabs. Yet God can comfort us from 'every side' of where it hurts.

We can pray for God's help to resist the quick fixes. When we have a need to feel better we should go to the Source of all comfort who never gives us nasty withdrawals, only His loving peace and security.

content.title: The Incomparable
content.introtext:
'Even to your old age...will I carry you...' Isaiah 46:4 NKJ

Isaiah was a prophet who spoke with zealous force, with both wit and the wisdom of years of experiencing the dirt of humanity firsthand. In Isaiah 46 he speaks on behalf of God, describing the stark difference between Babylon's idols and the true, real God. 'To whom will you compare Me and make Me equal? To whom will you compare Me so that we can be alike? People pour gold out of their bags and weigh silver on scales. They hire a goldsmith. He makes it into a god. They bow down and worship it. They lift it on their shoulders and carry it. They set the idol in its place, and it stands there. It doesn't move from its place. If they cry to it for help, it can't answer. It can't rescue them from their distress.' (Isaiah 46:5-7 GWT)

God is alive, not dead like a plank of wood. He is the Incomparable, and our attempts to fully understand Him will always fall short. More than that, He is real, He is powerful, and like no idol or made-up god, He offers to carry us throughout life. 'Even when you are old, I will be the same. Even when your hair has turned grey, I will take care of you. I made you and will take care of you. I will carry you and save you.' (Isaiah 46:4 NCV)

We need to get rid of any idols in our own lives. Ask yourself what they are (a good gauge is where most of your time is spent) and bring them to God. Ask Him to remove any you can't see.

content.title: Dig Deep

content.title: Crowd Control
content.introtext:
'...It would not be right for us...' Acts 6:2 NIV

We're all highly talented, unique God-created bundles with God-given gifts and abilities. It takes a lot of different skills and personality types to build God's Kingdom. Have a look at the New Testament church in Acts. The church was spreading fast and the apostles were having a tough time dealing with crowd control issues. The apostles had to listen to a lot of disgruntled talk and tutting tongues because the Grecian Jews had a major beef with the Hebraic Jews for, well, eating all the beef.

'...The Grecian Jews among them complained against the Hebraic Jews because their widows were being overlooked in the daily distribution of food.' (Acts 6:1 NIV) The apostles realised that trying to minimise the issue by ignoring it wasn't the best way forward. After all, they wanted the church to grow, not split. But they didn't want to spend all their time fixing it: '...It would not be right for us to neglect the ministry of the Word of God in order to wait on tables.'

So what did they do? They gave the responsibility over to seven others who had gifts fit for the task. Then they prayed for them. This way, 'the Word of God spread. The number of disciples in Jerusalem increased rapidly, and a large number of priests became obedient to the faith.' (Acts 6:7 NIV) Crowd control in God's Kingdom means each member using their gifts fit for the tasks given to them!

God has given you specific gifts that He wants you to use to advance His Kingdom. What are they? Ask your pastor to tell you what they think.

content.title: Transform Your Habits
content.introtext:
'...Three times a day he got down on his knees and prayed...' Daniel 6:10 NIV

You're at your home computer and you think, 'Yeah, I've got time for just one more update on Facebook.' You then hotfoot it to catch the bus, but you just miss it. Eventually you meet up with your friend who's been waiting an hour. Through gritted teeth he says, 'Don't worry about it,' but you spend the next half hour noticing he's only just keeping his cool with you. Punctuality problem?

By their nature, bad habits are lowmaintenance and easily picked up. Whether it's too much Facebook eating your time, or always being late for meetings, bad habits can really get in the way of what we want to achieve. Jesus had some subversively God-centred habits. Here are just a few: (1) Giving God the space and time to speak: 'Very early in the morning, while it was still dark, Jesus got up, left the house and went off to a solitary place, where He prayed.' (Mark 1:35 NIV) (2) Consistent prayer. The disciples might not have always been quick on the uptake but they did notice the connection of Jesus' prayer life with His authority. They wanted to learn from the best: '...Lord, teach us to pray...' (Luke 11:1 NIV) (3) Putting nothing else before God. Seek the Kingdom of God above all else, and live righteously, and He will give you everything you need.

Jesus' habits can transform not just your relationship with God but also every area of your life and peace of mind! If you pay close attention to Jesus' life in the Gospels you'll discover His good habits.

content.title: Great Balls of Faith!
content.introtext:
'We walk by faith, not by sight.' 2 Corinthians 5:7 KJV

Are you a bit like Asaph sometimes? Busy walking by sight rather than by faith? Drinking from a bottomless cup of disappointment? Jealous of people who spend their lives doing and worshipping the wrong things? Then, to top it all off they seem to be enjoying life far more than you. How's that for a cherry? Asaph walked so often with his eyes of faith shut, that in Psalm 73 he wrote, '...my feet had almost slipped; I had nearly lost my foothold. For I envied the arrogant when I saw the prosperity of the wicked.' (Psalm 73:2-3 NIV)

Asaph nearly shrugged off God because he was jealous of what he could see happening for those who didn't follow God. But as the Psalm progresses, Asaph grows in faith: 'You guide me with Your counsel, and afterward You will take me into glory. Whom have I in Heaven but You? And earth has nothing I desire besides You.' (Psalm 73:24-25 NIV) He realises any earthly gain is nothing to the guaranteed eternity with God.

There really is no accolade, thrill or relationship better than having God in your life. Why envy others who don't have God? '... those who are far from You will be lost from You forever.' (Psalm 73: 27 NIV)

When things seem too difficult for you or you doubt God, remember Asaph and feast on God's trustworthy Word!

content.title: Weigh It Up
content.introtext:
'If anyone suffers...' 1 Peter 4:16 NKJ

Check out this passage in the Bible: 'Let none of you suffer as a murderer, a thief, an evildoer, or as a busybody in other people's matters. Yet if anyone suffers as a Christian, let him not be ashamed, but let him glorify God in this matter. For the time has come for judgment to begin at the house of God...' (1 Peter 4:15-17 NKJ)

If you're enacting God's truth in your thoughts, words and deeds and getting attacked for it, it can be really tough. Whether you're encountering cruel words from others, or you feel like Satan's shredding your selfesteem, the Bible's response 'be glad for it' can seem like a bit rough. Looking deeper though, this is truly a compliment-because you're seen as a threat! Satan hates anything to do with the Kingdom of God so, if you're building it in some way, then he's gonna have a go. After all, you're an enemy!

But fear not: '...the glorious Spirit of God rests upon you.' (1 Peter 4:14 NLT) You're on the right team, so be glad! God is your shelter and your shield. You can rest under Him and He will protect you.

When it's tough and we're struggling with people, don't forget to pray for them, too. The Bible says, '...love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you.' (Matthew 5:44 NIV)

content.title: The Best of the Best
content.introtext:
'...God has appointed another [future] for me...' Genesis 4:25 NKJ

If God has closed the door on something we really want, it's because He has a much better alternative in mind. It might feel like you wanted an adventure playground complete with monkey ropes and sandpit but you got a frisbee from the Two Dollar Shop in its place. But it doesn't work that way at all.

God doesn't want less for us. He wants more. But that does mean trusting that He knows the best way to get there. The process can be painful, so it takes faith. For that we need peace: the peace of knowing that our future is in God's hands: 'And we know that in all things God works for the good of those who love Him, who have been called according to His purpose.' (Romans 8:28 NIV)

God's hands are reliable hands; they never pick up the wrong things for us to do. It's when we don't trust Him and so try to do things our own way that it all starts going shaky! 'Trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own understanding; in all your ways acknowledge Him, and He will make your paths straight.' (Proverbs 3:5-6 NIV)

Why not try writing down any worries you have? Then pray through the list and rip it up as a sign you've given it to God and it's not yours to worry about anymore.

content.title: Tough Love
content.introtext:
'The Lord disciplines those He loves...' Hebrews 12:6 NLT

Discipline is a harsh word. It probably makes you think of some form of punishment aimed at getting you to behave. So having the words discipline and love in the same sentence in the Scripture above seems like it's a contradiction, right?

Wrong! Ever heard of the phrase 'tough love'? Sometimes God has to give us a spot of it for our own good. One of the hardest things for any parent is to watch their kids make mistakes and go through the painful consequences.

Obviously God would rather keep us from the pain. And that's why the Bible is so valuable: it's God's Word and includes His precautions for us. He explains that when we face choices, following God is always the right decision.

Don't resent God's discipline, and don't resist it. Recognise that it's for your good. And one more thought: don't allow some well-meaning person to 'rescue' you from God's dealings. God's goal for us in discipline is 'that we might share in His holiness.' No discipline is enjoyable while it is happening! But afterward there will be 'a peaceful harvest of right living for those who are trained in this way.' (Hebrews 12:11 NLT)

content.title: Rahab's Story (1)
content.introtext:
'It was by faith that Rahab the prostitute was not destroyed...' Hebrews 11:31 NLT

Living in the wall of the city of Jericho thousands of years ago was Rahab, a prostitute. Fast approaching was Joshua, leading all of God's people. Under God's instructions, they were planning to demolish the entire city.

Was it staring death in the face that caused Rahab to rethink her beliefs? Was it the stories she had heard about what this Joshua bloke's God was doing in defeating any army on the other side of the Jordan that stood in their way to the Promised Land (Genesis 17:8)? Or was it when she met the spies for the first time and heard their absolute faith in their God that made her realise she needed to change her thinking? Whatever the reason, Rahab didn't just change her mind, she acted upon it. (You can read the full story in Joshua 2:1-6:25) She chose to live differently and put her faith completely in the one true God. What about you?

Have you got a big question that stops you living for God? Take time out today to talk about it to Him and seek out an answer. You might need to take a leaf out of Rahab's book and change your thinking.

content.title: Rahab's Story (2)
content.introtext:
'"I know the plans I have for you," says the Lord. "They are plans for good..."' Jeremiah 29:11 NLT

While everybody else was preparing to fight, she was preparing to surrender! Rahab had heard about the things God had done for Israel; how He'd turned the Red Sea to a red carpet, converted rocks into drinking fountains, made breakfast for them every morning in the wilderness and dried up the waters of the Jordan River.

Where Rahab lived, no one believed in God. For a long time she just went with the flow, not stopping and thinking for herself, never questioning what was best-she just tried to fit in. But then she did one very courageous thing: she stood up for what was right and put her trust in God, completely.

Rahab may not have been wise when it came to her body, but she was wiser than everybody else in town when it came to her soul. She wasn't about to fight God-she knew that was a fight you can't win! For her the path to victory was surrender! And that is the right path for you too. If only you stop trying to 'run the show' and turn your life over to Christ, He will take you to places of blessing. Perhaps they'll be places you've always dreamed of but didn't know how to reach. God had a great future for Rahab. He planned to make her not only the ancestor of King David but of Jesus Himself! How's that for restoring? And God, who loves all people from prostitutes to kings and queens, will do the same for you no matter where you've been or what you've done.

Are you going with the flow, against God? Or are you swimming against the crowd, with Him? Decide again who you are going to surrender to, today.

content.title: Rahab's Story (3)
content.introtext:
'...God paid a ransom to save you... It was the precious blood of Christ...' 1 Peter 1:18-19 NLT

What she trusted in stood, when what everybody else trusted in fell. What did Rahab trust in? Her morality? Nope, the Bible says she was a prostitute. Her nationality? Nope, she was a Gentile, not part of God's people (at least, not then). So what did she trust in? A scarlet cord! It's a picture of the blood Jesus spilt.

As a prostitute, she was probably the last person people thought would to be saved from an entire doomed city. Maybe even she thought that herself-that she was worthless and hopeless. But she trusted only in the scarlet cord to save her. And we need to do that too. If we're worried about how worthless we are, know that just like Rahab, we have to trust only on Jesus' blood. This simply means: Jesus' innocent death was a way of salvation for us. A way out from shame. When Joshua's troops saw the scarlet cord flying from the window of Rahab's home they knew it meant she was under protection. And Christ's blood does that for you.

If you struggle with the idea that you're accepted and protected by God then read 1 John 1:8-9, John 3:16 and Romans 10:9 and see what it says about what God has accomplished for you.

content.title: Rahab's Story (4)
content.introtext:
'Anyone who leaves your house will be killed, and it won't be our fault...' Joshua 2:19 CEV

She was safe as long as she stayed in the house. Before conquering Jericho, Joshua sent two spies in on a recon mission. That's when they met Rahab and she befriended them. As a result they instructed her to hang a scarlet cord from her window, marking her house as 'off limits' to the invading army. But notice the instructions that were given to her: 'If anyone goes outside your house into the street, they'll be killed!'

There's a lesson here: if you're wondering about getting off your feet and back into church, the message is: 'Get into God's house while you still have time!' If you're drifting away from God, the message is, 'Don't leave the house, guys!' When it comes to being protected, the most important thing is knowing that you're 'in' God. What does that mean? Stay in church. Stay in God's Word. Keep praying. Stay in the company of praying mates who'll build you up spiritually. 'Live under the protection of God Most High and stay in the shadow of God AllPowerful.' (Psalm 91:1 CEV)

If you need to get right with God today, don't let the day end before you do! Don't let yourself worry or procrastinatedo it now! He waits with open arms.

content.title: Pride Symptoms
content.introtext:
'...you will soon be bursting at the seams...' Isaiah 54:3 NLT

You'll rarely find pridefilled people sharing food or allowing friends to use their phone credit. However they'll often happily chomp away on their friends' chocolates or find emergency reasons to make calls on their phones. They never leave tips when out for a meal. They only buy presents for someone who will give in return, secretly hoping they get the best deal. They put loose change and never notes in the charity box or collection plate. And they always talk themselves out of sponsoring a child from a third world country-after all, their need for that extra $10 a week is always greater.

Another less obvious symptom of the prideful heart is hoarding. Every drawer, cupboard, room in the house is jampacked with stuff they 'just might need'. These people become reluctant to give anything away to help someone in need, just in case they may need it again. Lending belongings is a definite no-no, for fear things will get damaged. Their mindset is gimme-gimme, rather than give and give again. Happy to point this attitude out in other people, they're oblivious to it flourishing in their own.

Isaiah 58:10 GNT says, '...if you give food to the hungry and satisfy those who are in need, then the darkness around you will turn to the brightness of noon.' So no hoarding or stingy living for us; remember: '...you will soon be bursting at the seams...' (Isaiah 54:3 NLT)

Read 2 Corinthians 9:7-9. Think of a way to be exceptionally generous today, then do it. Surprise someone by going beyond their expectations!

'...This is what [God] requires...to do what is right...' Micah 6:8 NLT

'People, the Lord has told you what is good, and this is what He requires of you: to do what is right, to love mercy, and to walk humbly with your God.' content.title: Chosen (1)
content.introtext:
'...Don't say, "I'm too young"...go wherever I send you...' Jeremiah 1:7 NLT

God could have chosen to do His work any way He wanted, but He chose to use ordinary run-of-the-mill people. People like Moses, Isaiah and Jeremiah...and you!

God asked Moses, complete with speech impediment, to go and give orders to the ruler of Egypt. God asked Isaiah, a polished city gent, to volunteer for an important mission which would include preaching in his underwear for three years! And God asked Jeremiah, a young bloke, to go speak to a bunch of rebels and risk getting his head kicked in. Moses said, 'I won't,' Isaiah said, 'Woe is me,' and Jeremiah said, 'I can't.'

God supplied tailor-made training courses to turn their 'I won'ts' into 'I wills' and their 'I can'ts' into 'I cans', Likewise God designed you with all the built-in qualifications you need, you don't have to compromise your convictions, manipulate, drop names or do special favours. The part is yours! And don't be jealous or intimidated by anybody else no matter how talented they are. In God's eyes there are no other contenders; you're it! You're the only one who can fill the slot because He created it with you in mind. When you feel insecure and unqualified, remind yourself of that.

'...whoever humbles himself will be made great.' Matthew 23:12 GNT

'...I want to talk to You about Your justice. Why do wicked people succeed?...You know me, O Lord. You see me and test my devotion to You. ...people are wicked. They think that God doesn't know what they are doing.' (Jeremiah 12:1-4 GWT) Jeremiah wasn't the first person to ask questions like this.
