content.title: Dinner Time!
content.introtext:
'But they all...began to make excuses...' Luke 14:18 NKJ

In Luke 14, Jesus tells the parable of a man giving a great banquet. The invitation to the banquet represents the Gospel, and the man hosting the banquet represents God. Jesus says that many were invited but when party time came, those who had been invited made excuses.

'The first said... "I have just bought a field, and I must go and see it. Please excuse me."' (v18) Sounds pretty feeble, doesn't it? If you'd just bought a block of land, you'd think that you'd have had a look before buying it! When it came to it, the bloke preferred to revel in his wealth than do anything else.

This was no takeaway joint lunch he was turning his nose up at. This was food like no other, served at the Host's mansion. It's easy to laugh at this bloke who couldn't see the worth of what he was giving up. But what about us?

Even when we have seen the worth of Jesus, accepted His invitation for salvation and know what it's like to hang out with God, we frequently still make excuses for not giving Him our time when we should. Philippians 4:19 NIV says: 'And my God will meet all your needs according to His glorious riches in Christ Jesus.' God wants our time, but too often we give Him our excuses.

content.title: Keep Your Eye On The Ball
content.introtext:
'While I was busy doing something else...' 1 Kings 20:40 NLT

There are several ways we can discover that it is dangerous to jump off a ten-story building: (1) you can read about the law of gravity in a book; (2) You can learn from the sad experience of someone else who tried it; (3) You can listen to the wise counsel of a firefighter or physician who claims it would be 'hazardous to your health'; ( 4) You can jump.

Each way provides the information you are seeking; the only difference is the amount of pain involved in gaining that information. An unknown prophet had a message from God to King Ahab: it was about being busy doing his own thing. God wanted Ahab to learn that He alone is Lord over everything. God gave Ahab lots of great ways to learn this important life lesson, but Ahab chose the hardest option of all. It cost him his life. King Ahab got distracted and, as a result, he did the opposite of what God had asked him to do.

Keep your eye on the ball, don't get distracted. The Bible says, 'Stay alert! Watch out for your great enemy, the devil. He prowls around like a roaring lion, looking for someone to devour.' (1 Peter 5:8 NLT) If Satan can't 'devour' you with a frontal assault, he'll settle for diverting you with things that ultimately don't matter. Keep your eyes fixed on Jesus. Don't be distracted. Don't end up being 'busy doing something else.'



SoulFood: Jer 31-32, Mark 3:7-19, Ps 103:13-22, Pr 10:14

content.title: Finishing Strong
content.introtext:
'I have finished my course.' 2 Timothy 4:7 NAS

Right now it probably seems like you've got your whole life in front of you. The world is full of fresh opportunities, great adventures and exciting people to meet. If life was a race, you'd have kilometres of track in front of you. But here's the thing: not everybody who starts the run finishes it. If you want to stay the distance, you need to beware of potential hurdles.

At the first hurdle, you may find that close 'go-for-it' mates start to stumble. Some give up or give in to temptation; others don't like the way the Christian path is taking them. Just like in Jesus' day: 'many of His disciples went back and walked with Him no more.' (John 6:66 NKJ)

By the second hurdle, you may start to feel the burn. Running with God isn't all warm glows and praise sessions. Sometimes God purposefully takes you through tough times: 'Everyone who wants to live as God desires, in Christ Jesus, will be hurt.' (2 Timothy 3:12 NCV) All runners hit the wall at some point-the important thing is to keep on running.

Our final hurdle is opposition. People, situations, losses-opposition comes in different disguises. Often opposition is an indicator that God is about to bless you. In order to finish strong you mustn't quit: face each challenge and keep running in the face of opposition.

content.title: Your Way or God's Way?
content.introtext:
'He guides the humble in what is right.' Psalm 25:9 NIV

God can be so frustrating at times! Especially when He won't play ball. Like, you know, you'd be much happier with that girlfriend/boyfriend. You'd be really great at that high paying job and you could give more away. Like, there must be some kind of mix-up between the life you've been given and the life you want. Sure, He's the creator of the universe, the knower of all things and wears time around His wrist...but if He'd just consult you now and again, things would be just right. Is that really too much to ask?

When you don't like the way God is leading, do you pray, hoping that God will come round to your way of thinking? Praying is more about getting the mind of God rather than the things on our shopping list. Jesus said, 'I am the vine, you are the branches.' (John 15:5 NKJ) Only as you stay connected to Christ will you bear fruit. Just as the life flows from the vine into the branches, so His power flows to you. David wrote, 'The Lord is good and does what is right; He shows the proper path to those who go astray. He leads the humble in what is right, teaching them His way.' (Psalm 25:8-9 NLT)

God will show you what the 'right' direction for you is, if you look for Him. Basically, there are only two ways-God's way or the wrong way. Which way? You choose!

content.title: Promises, Promises
content.introtext:
'God has made me laugh' Genesis 21:6 NKJ

Sarah laughed twice. The first time it was in unbelief because in her old age God had promised her a child. The second time it was with joy because God had fulfilled His promise. But between these two events she went through the most wrenching experience of her life. Her husband, Abraham, betrayed her to save himself. A heathen king took her to his harem and would have violated her had God not intervened. There's a great lesson here. Between praying for a miracle and getting one, you'll be tested, you'll grow, and you'll learn to trust God more than you ever thought possible. Plus, here's something else important here too: when you share your experiences with others don't just tell the start and the finish; instead, tell them what God brought you through, because those are the very things they're struggling with too. Be honest. Tell them how your faith was tried. Don't leave them feeling a failure because they haven't yet seen God's promise like you have. The King's tent where Sarah spent that terrifying night was in a place called Gerar, which means 'the halting place'. Yes, there'll be times when you'll feel like your life has come to a screeching halt and you're getting nowhere. Maybe that's where you are today. But know this: God always comes true on His promises. Always.



SoulFood: 2 Kings 16:1-18:16, Matt 26:36-46, Ps 6, Pr 8:32-33

content.title: Into The Fire
content.introtext:
'He will sit as a refiner...of silver' Malachi 3:3 NIV

Inside a crucible, silver is heated by a refiner. The scum in the metal rises and is drawn off by the silversmith until every impurity is burnt away. Finally, the refiner's keen eye knows the silver is ready to pour when it becomes like a mirror. It is so clean he can see his own face reflected back from the surface.

Malachi hints that troubles and life's mess can be used to help us clean up our act. It's tempting to think that when the heat is turned up in our lives it's somehow punishment for some wrong we've done. However it could be exactly the opposite. We pray to be more like Jesus, so God turns up the furnace to burn away all our impurities. Often a tough time in life is followed by a great opportunity for serving God. Why? Because God has used your problem to get you ready for His service. There's nothing like a spot of trouble to draw you closer to God. The challenge is to see beyond the problem.

The worst thing the prodigal son could have done was to make his bed and draw his curtains in the pigsty. He wasn't made for life as a pig-he just had to experience life at the bottom in order to look to the top. Maybe you're in the fire now: hurting, melting, burning. The refiner's fire is not to be avoided. To escape it is to escape your destiny and to escape God. Hold on, you'll soon be reflecting the face of God with your life.

content.title: Victory
content.introtext:
'I have given you authority...to overcome...the enemy.' Luke 10:19 NIV

Now here's a picture for you: at the end of World War II, General MacArthur met the supreme commander of the beaten Japanese forces. He took the sword out of the general's arms to signal the commander's defeat. He then enforced the terms of unconditional surrender. Victory was declared publicly.

You know what? Jesus did that for you at the cross. Jesus said, 'I saw Satan fall like lightning from Heaven. I have given you authority...to overcome all the power of the enemy; nothing will harm you.' (Luke 10:18-19 NIV) Notice you haven't been called to defeat Satan; Jesus already did that 2000 years ago. You have been called to enforce His defeat each day. Jesus already disarmed and made a public spectacle of him at the cross (Colossians 2:15). That means Satan can't keep you from your destiny.

When Jesus died and rose again He stripped the devil of his power and declared, 'All [power] in Heaven and on earth has been given to Me. Therefore go.' (Matthew 28:18-19 NIV) Go in His power. Go in His strength. Go in His name. He has given you authority over the enemy-use it.

'At one time you were separated from God. You were His enemies in your minds, and the evil things you did were against God. But now God has made you His friends again. He did this through Christ's death.' (Colossians 1:21-22 NCV)

content.title: Eyes Wide Open
content.introtext:
'Lord, open my servant's eyes, and let him see.' 2 Kings 6:17 NCV

The Bible tells us the story of Elisha's servant. He got up early in the morning but when he went outside he was confronted with the sight of a huge army with horses and chariots surrounding the city. He knew they were there for Elisha. This wasn't cool-but Elisha was.

While the servant was freaking out just looking at the size of the king of Syria's army, Elisha said, 'Don't worry, those with us are more than those who are with them.'

'And Elisha prayed, and said, LORD, I pray, open his eyes that he may see. Then the LORD opened the eyes of... [Elisha's servant] and he saw. And behold, the mountain was full of horses and chariots of fire all around Elisha.' 2 Kings 6:17

Often our problem is that we, like Elisha's servant, sometimes only see the physical problems. We get thrown by money and circumstances and people. Instead we need to learn to 'open our eyes' like Elisha. We need to know that there are many more on our side than those against us.

content.title: A Lovely Day!
content.introtext:
'Love is patient and kind.' 1 Corinthians 13:4 NLT

Most of us are fond of the odd chunk or two (make that bar or two) of chocolaty loveliness. With a name like chocolate it has to be good, right?

The advertising world encourages us to 'spoil, treat, relax, indulge' with... chocolate! To attract that special someone's attention you need to 'make the face you love light up' with... chocolate! In the advertising world chocolate symbolises love. To love yourself and to love others you need... chocolate!

Truth is, chocolate, once it's out of that wrapper, doesn't last long. It satisfies only a moment- before heading straight for your hips to taunt you. Not even a whole box of the stuff can make the object of your desire fall head over heels in love with you.

If you want to know what real love is, you have to go to the main source. 1 John 4:8 tells us, 'God is love' and this is what God says real love is like: 'patient and kind...not jealous or boastful or proud or rude. It does not demand its own way. It is not irritable, and it keeps no record of being wronged. It does not rejoice about injustice but rejoices whenever the truth wins out. Love never gives up, never loses faith, is always hopeful, and endures through every circumstance.' (1 Corinthians 13:4-7 NLT)

God's love always satisfies and never disappoints. God lavishes His love on you. So indulge yourself. Know from Him what it means to love and be loved. And have a lovely day!



SoulFood: 2 Kings 24-25, Matt 26:65-75, Ps 72:12-20, Pr 9:7-9

content.title: Extreme
content.introtext:
'God will generously provide all you need.' 2 Corinthians 9:8 NLT

You've probably seen Man vs Wild the television series where Bear Grylls demonstrates his wilderness skills in some of the world's most menacing environments. Want to know how to survive the world's worst? Bear is your man! In total contrast, the MTV reality series My Super Sweet 16 documents huge coming-of-age celebrations thrown by teenagers and their (usually extremely wealthy) parents. The show has been criticised for its excesses and the effects of presenting such over-the-top parties as an inspirational norm.

Neither show gives us a picture of a good way to live: one extreme leaves us coping and struggling, grabbing what we can in order to survive; the other smothers us in self-indulgence with no real sense of value or purpose. God's way doesn't leave us wanting, wondering if we'll make it; nor does it leave us spending without any care or concern.

Let's live out God's extreme way of life, knowing that 'God will generously provide all you need. Then you will always have everything you need and plenty left over to share with others.' Living God's extreme means: (1) Trusting God to provide all you need-don't walk around struggling, feeling hopeless. When you need it, He promises you'll have it. Live like it! (2) Giving generously-this is no time for stinginess. Give with purpose what God has given you to those in need. Give and you'll be given more so you can give more. Now that's extreme!



SoulFood: Hosea 1-5, Matt 27:1-10, Ps 32, Pr 9:10-16

content.title: I Have The Power!
content.introtext:
'Love cannot be drowned by oceans or floods.' Song of Solomon 8:7 CEV

We've all seen the horrific devastation a tsunami brings. News footage has recorded how a picture-perfect coastal town can be swept away under the force of an ocean wall and homes, businesses, lives destroyed. Water is a powerful force with the ability to be so gentle young children can freely play in it or so strong it wounds, maims and breaks anything in its way.

The Bible talks of another force that can operate at both ends of the extreme-and on a much larger scale! This force is God's love, so strong it 'cannot be drowned by oceans or floods.'

It is gentle enough to heal the tenderest broken heart, it is strong enough to withstand the cruellest barrage of hate. It is full of compassion and mercy yet it is also what drove Jesus to give His life on the cross. Amazingly God's love is freely available to all-will you accept it? In a world where so many negative forces are at work it is very easy to feel unloved and unlovable. Know today that God is here and He loves you. As St Augustine wrote, 'He loves each one of us as if there were only one of us.' In a world that can be difficult and relationships damaging, use love. God's love is so powerful it changes any situation for any individual for the better.



SoulFood: Hosea 6-10, Matt 27:11-26, Ps 25:1-7, Pr 9:17-18

content.title: Never Too Old
content.introtext:
'Even in old age they will...remain vital...' Psalm 92:14 NLT

If someone were to ask you today to make a list of all the important, vital things you need in life, would the elderly be on your list? Or do you think the silver-haired brigade have no relevance to you whatsoever? If you constantly feel like you're being shot down for being young, hanging out with the oldies might be the last thing you want to do.

The older generation can get a bad press, thought of as 'past their use-by date', no longer important. But God thinks differently. In the Bible God promises many good things to those who are older, like special God-knowledge and insight into people and life.

And it's not just the youthful God uses to do the spectacular. Moses was aged 80 when he was used to free thousands of slaves. Can you imagine what it would have been like to hang out with him and watch him fight the ruler of Egypt using frogs and extreme acne? Or being there when he parted the sea with a stick? Moses actually saw God face-to-face and is the only person on record as having God as his undertaker (Deuteronomy 34 tells it all).

So show some respect and chill out with the oldies that hang out with God-you might be amazed at the difference it will make to your life.

content.title: Eye Witness
content.introtext:
'This man truly was the Son of God!' Mark 15:39 NLT

I'll never forget that day. I much prefer to remember the week before, when Jesus came to my town. Everyone was talking about Him. He was performing miracles and saying things that really challenged people's thinking. As He came through our city gates, everyone cheered, 'Hail Jesus, King of the Jews!'

But days later, He'd been arrested. I couldn't find out why, but they were going to let us choose between a thug named Barabbas and Jesus. You'd think everyone would shout to release Jesus, right? But one person shouted 'Barabbas!', then another, and soon it was everyone. Even I was shouting, 'Barabbas, free Barabbas!' I don't know why I did it. I'm not the sort to go along with the crowd. Why didn't I stop and think for myself?

The next time I saw Jesus, I hardly recognised Him. His whole face was swollen and bruised- they'd beaten Him up real bad. He had blood running down His head from where they'd stuck a crown of thorns. They laughed and said it was a joke, but it didn't look funny to me.

A soldier asked some guy to help carry Jesus' cross-I suppose that's one good thing that happened that day, but not the only good thing. When they were nailing Jesus to a cross He said, 'Father, forgive them for they don't know what they're doing.' While He was there, dying, He was thinking of us, asking God to forgive us...to forgive me.



SoulFood: Matt 27:33-56, Ps 22, Is 53 (Good Friday)

content.title: Search for the truth
content.introtext:
'I will not believe it until I...put my finger where the nails were.' John 20:25 NCV

You know the sort of person who never lets the truth spoil a good story? Some people will lie through their teeth to get people believe the ridiculous. And the story of Jesus coming back to life sounded, well, ridiculous to one of the disciples.

What could be more ridiculous than a dead man coming back to life-who's going to believe that? It's not something you see every day, is it? And how dare someone start spreading that kind of rumour? We're all just trying to come to terms with what's just happened and figure out how we're going to get by without Him.

Similar thoughts were probably running through the mind of Thomas. No matter who told him, he just wouldn't believe Jesus had come back to life again: 'I will not believe it until I...put my finger where the nails were.' Thomas needed some extra proof-positive that Jesus really had died and come back to life again.

Jesus didn't let Thomas down. He turns up and shows His scars, so Thomas can believe. If you're struggling to believe Jesus is alive and wants to have a friendship with you, don't give up: 'If...you seek the Lord your God, you will find Him if you look for Him with all your heart and with all your soul.' (Deuteronomy 4:29 NIV)

content.title: I.T. (Infallible Truth)
content.introtext:
'He...presented Himself alive...by many infallible proofs.' Acts 1:3 NKJ

Thanks to chocolate companies, Easter has become a choc fest. We enjoy it to the full, stuffing our faces with a variety of Easter egg delights. You probably know how many eggs you got, how many you've already eaten and whether there are any more still to come. But do you know why we give each other eggs?

Giving eggs at Easter celebrates new life. It's a way of remembering that Jesus, after dying on the cross, rose from the dead. In doing this, He defeated death and sin and offers us the promise of eternal life: 'Praise be to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ. In God's great mercy He has caused us to be born again into a living hope, because Jesus Christ rose from the dead. Now we hope for the blessings God has for His children. These blessings...cannot be destroyed [and]...are kept in Heaven for you.' (1 Peter 1:3-4 NCV) This is not just nice idea- this is real, infallible truth!

Scientists say that infallible proof comes from getting the same result from repeated experiments and multiple confirmations. Here are five infallible proofs that Jesus rose from the dead. One: Mary Magdalene encountered Him. Two: the women at the grave saw Him. Three: the disciples talked with Him. Four: the apostles met Him. Five: 500 people witnessed Him at one time.

Don't just munch your way through a mountain of chocolate this Easter, discover the amazing truth for your life: 'If you confess with your mouth that Jesus is Lord and believe in your heart that God raised Him from the dead, you will be saved.' (Romans 10:9 NLT)



SoulFood: 1 Cor 15, Matt 28:1-10 (Easter)

content.title: You Listening?
content.introtext:
'Pay attention to what you hear.' Luke 8:18 NLT

Most people love the sound of their own voice but it has been said that he who speaks much is much mistaken. James 1:19 NLT says we 'should be quick to listen and slow to speak.' Look through the book of Proverbs and you'll discover why: 'Anyone who answers without listening is foolish' (18:13 NCV); 'A simpleton can learn only by seeing mockers punished; a wise person learns from instruction.' (21:11 NLT); 'Intelligent people are always open to new ideas.' (18:15 NLT)

We may have the ability to hear but the art of listening is an important skill to develop, and the reason we need to develop this skill the most is found in Proverbs 3:5 NLT: 'Seek His will in all you do, and He will direct your paths.'

Three things you need to know about listening: (1) Listening doesn't happen naturally; it is a conscious choice. Choose today to improve your listening skills. Stop talking and start listening out for God's voice. (2) Listening may appear easy but it is often hard work. Don't panic if after five minutes you haven't heard God at all, it can take time to know God's voice. Enjoy the journey of discovery. (3) True listening requires you give another person your attention and possibly change your attitudes as you listen. 'Let God transform you into a new person by changing the way you think. Then you will know what God wants you to do.' (Romans 12:2 NLT) Are you listening?

content.title: Sorted
content.introtext:
'Oh, give thanks to the God of gods! For His mercy endures forever.' Psalm 136:2 NJKV

When life goes pear-shaped do you become a disgruntled wreck or are you like the missionary Paul-sorted? He wrote: 'I have learned how to be content with whatever I have...I have learned the secret of living in every situation, whether it is with a full stomach or empty, with plenty or little. For I can do everything through Christ, who gives me strength' (Philippians 4:11-13 NLT)

What if, at the age of 46, you were burned beyond recognition in a terrible motorcycle accident, and then four years later were paralysed from the waist down in an airplane crash? Can you imagine yourself becoming a millionaire, respected public speaker, happy newlywed and a successful business person? Can you see yourself going white water rafting, skydiving and becoming a politician? W. Mitchell has done all these things and more after two horrible accidents left his face a quilt of multicoloured skin grafts, his hands fingerless and his legs thin and motionless in a wheelchair. 'Before I was paralysed,' he said, 'there were 10000 things I could do. Now there are 9000. I can either dwell on the 1000 I lost or focus on the 9000 I have left.' He too had learnt the life-changing effect of being content in any situation. What about you? Take a step back. Get a wider view of your life. Look at the things holding you back, leaving you feeling angry or unsettled. Maybe they aren't so bad after all. Remember it's not what happens to you: it's what you do about it.

content.title: Love Like You Mean It
content.introtext:
'Love never gives up; and its faith, hope, and patience never fail.' 1 Corinthians 13:4 GNT

Gram Seed lay dying in a hospital. 'I'd become the tramp that nobody sees,' he recalls, 'from a broken family living in a rough part of town. A life of crime allowed me to be both rich and powerful but inside I was hurting, insecure and angry. After the confinement of prison walls I...made a public bench my home... I became so desperate I wanted to end my life, so I slashed my wrists...but I was soon back on my bench... It wasn't long after that that I collapsed and was put on a life-support machine.'

Gram's life would have ended there and then if it weren't for two young guys who acted on God's words: 'love cares more for others than of self.' Not only did they go to Gram when he lived on that bench telling him, 'Jesus loves you,' they went to visit him in hospital every day for two months. They prayed for him and read the Bible to him.

'When I got out, I gave my life to the Lord,' says Gram. 'In God's amazing providence I now head up Sowing Seeds Ministries which aims to help ex-offenders, just like me, not only to find a better way of life but to realise that true freedom can only be found through the love of a Saviour, and that Saviour is my Lord and my Friend Jesus Christ... Every time I walk past that bench I thank God that He knew my address and sent someone to tell me about Jesus.'

content.title: BFF (2)
content.introtext:
'Each part...helps the other parts grow.' Ephesians 4:16 NLT

When life goes belly up, it's then we find out who our true friends are. True friends walk in when others walk out. Real friends don't care if your socks don't match. Real friends don't walk ten steps behind you if you're having a bad hair day. Real friends are those who, when you've made a fool of yourself, don't feel that you've done a permanent job. But how do you stand by your friends when things go wrong, when situations become awkward or difficult?

God wants us to work together to bring out the best in each other as, 'each part...helps the other parts grow.' But how can you bring out the best in your friend when it feels like they're bringing out the worst in you?

When it looks like one of your friends is in serious trouble or heading that way, we can do one of five things:

(1) Ditch them-you've got plenty of other friends you don't need them; (2) Join them-you don't want anything to ruin the friendship, so you think behaving like them will help; (3) Act two-faced, being nice to their face but gossiping about them behind their back; (4) Pretend the problem will go away, carrying on as though nothing is wrong; or, the only real choice, (5) Be honest with them, tell them you're concerned and do all you can to help. Proverbs 17:17 NIV says 'a friend loves at all times.'



SoulFood: Jer 18-21, Mark 1:35-45, Ps 127, Pr 10:11

content.title: Dead Or Alive?
content.introtext:
'I have been crucified with Christ.' Galatians 2:20 NKJ

When we are under attack our survival instinct kick in. It's natural but it creates a problem. Paul says, 'I have been crucified with Christ; it is no longer I who live, but Christ lives in me.' If we default to self-preservation, we aren't free to make the right decisions. We'll do things based on what we think 'feels good', or is 'acceptable to others', rather than what God wants us to do. We've got to 'die to self': '...unless a grain of wheat falls into the earth and dies [to self], it remains alone; but if it dies, it bears much fruit.' (John 12:24 NAS)There are people in the Bible who missed out on God's best because they were looking out for their own interests rather than God's. Without considering Abraham, Lot chose the well-watered plains of Jordan, and lost his family (Genesis 13:10-11). The rich young ruler could have been numbered among Christ's disciples, but he'd too much to lose (Mark 10:22). Often, the more we have, the tighter we hold on. Jesus said, 'Whoever wishes to save his life will lose it, but whoever loses [invests] his life for My sake...will save it.' (Luke 9:24 NAS)Paul wrote, 'I consider my life worth nothing to me, if only I may finish the race and complete the task the Lord Jesus has given me...' (Acts 20:24 NIV). The safest place to be-the only place to be-is in the will of God!

content.title: BFF (1)
content.introtext:
'Each part...helps the other parts grow.' Ephesians 4:16 NLT

Mates, pals, chums, buddies, amigos, allies, your BFF, soul mate, kindred spirit-friends. When cutting up your cake of life this is one of the biggest slices of all. They make you laugh, they keep you sane and they help you pick up the pieces when it all goes wrong. You can't choose your family, but you can choose your mates, and hopefully you've made some good choices along the way.

But what do you do when your mates have gone strange on you? What's your response when they come to you, their loyal friend, to back them in a bad idea? What happens when they head down the path of doom asking you, their BFF, to support them in a nutty career? Do you just smile in agreement because you don't want to upset them? Leave them to make fools of themselves because it's their life they're ruining, not yours?

The Bible talks about God wanting us to work together to bring out the best in each other: 'As each part does its own special work, it helps the other parts grow, so that the whole body is healthy and growing and full of love.' Are you brave enough to be honest with your friends to help them make good choices? They say the best vitamin for developing friends is B1. Will you be one-the kind of friend who always brings out the best in others?

content.title: BFF (3)
content.introtext:
'Each part...helps the other parts grow.' Ephesians 4:16 NLT

They say it's smart to pick your friends-but not to pieces. So be careful when you're trying to bring out the best in your friends (like God asks us to) that you don't end up ripping them to shreds. Before you go wading in, check your motives. Do you want to correct your friend for all the right reasons-or are you trying to make yourself look good? Do you want to build them up-or are you trying to knock them down a peg or two? The world needs more warm hearts and fewer hot heads, so no bouncing in and starting a mudslinging match.

When someone accepts us as their friend it means we've earned their trust and respect. Don't be quick to spend that all at once. Proverbs 27:6 NIV says: 'wounds from a friend can be trusted.' Friendship puts us in a position where we can say things that, at times, are difficult but needed. But if we go in all-guns-blazing or with selfish or ulterior motives, then rather than help a friend we're more likely to lose a friend.

If done in the right way, a real friend will eventually thank you for pointing out where they're going wrong. They'll come to understand you had their best interests at heart. If there's a tough situation you need to confront a friend about, think about how you're going to do it first. Then ask yourself this question: if you were that friend, would you want to be friends with you?

content.title: Enjoy The Journey
content.introtext:
'I do not claim that I...have already become perfect.' Philippians 3:12 GNT

What matters most to you right now? Top exam results-anything below an A+ is not acceptable? Having that dream car, dream job and supercool friends? Do you go ape if your makeup gets smudged or a hair falls out of place? If you do, it sounds like you could be suffering from perfectionitis.

The world tells us we have to be the best and have the best, so we pressure ourselves chasing after perfection-and are often left with a big F for Failure! Pressure yourself into the world's idea of perfection and you're going to miss out on living! Think about it: for most things in life there is a perfect standard to aim for-from how we treat waiters, shop assistants, strangers or family to how we use our money, time or words and on to how compassionate, understanding, supportive or hardworking we are.

Paul had a few words to say on this kind of attitude: 'I don't mean to say that I have already achieved these things or that I have already reached perfection! But I keep working toward that day when I will finally be all that Christ Jesus saved me for and wants me to be.' (Philippians 3:12 NLT) You're not perfect yet, but you will be. So chill and enjoy the journey. Hand your life over to Jesus and live each day with Him. He'll turn your imperfections into His perfection.

content.title: Tongue-tied
content.introtext:
'I will guard my ways that I may not sin with my tongue' Psalm 39:1 NAS

You know the score: it starts off as a cosy chat between friends ('My sister's pregnant and I'm so happy; I can't wait to be an auntie...') and it's wrongly overheard; rumours are soon around the school: 'Cecilia in Year 9 is pregnant-again!'

Now this may sound funny-unless you're Cecilia. Having slanderous accusations thrown around about you is never fun. For all kind of reasons, usually insecurities, people are wrongly confronted with some outrageous untruth about themselves or their family. Our natural response is to fly off the handle and 'give the lying little brat what for!'

It's extremely difficult to keep silent when others tear us down. We want to protect our reputation. It's not easy to stay silent while others assault something so precious to us. But we don't need to lash out in revenge or justify our position; we can trust God to protect our reputation. Romans 8:31-37 NIV says: 'If God is for us who can be against us?... who will bring any charge against those whom God has chosen?... Shall trouble or hardship or persecution... No, in all these things we are more than conquerors through Him who loved us.'

Jesus was silent before His accusers (Luke 23:9). He left His case in God's hands (1 Peter 2:21-24). This is a good place to leave our case too. Don't fight slander with anger. Trust God and pray, 'guard my ways that I may not sin with my tongue.'



SoulFood: Jer 25-27, Mark 2:13-22, Ps 130, Pr 10:12

content.title: Consequences
content.introtext:
'Everyone's work will be put through the fire.' 1 Corinthians 3:13 TLB

One day an ox said to a mule, 'Let's pretend to be sick.' The mule said, 'No, we need to get this work done.' The ox feigned illness, and the farmer brought him fresh hay. When the mule came in from ploughing, the ox asked how things went. The mule said, 'All right.' The ox asked, 'What did the farmer say about me?' The mule replied, 'Nothing.' The next day the ox pretended to be ill again. When the mule came home the ox asked, 'How did it go?' The mule said, 'All right.' After a week of this, the ox asked, 'Did the farmer say anything about me today?' The mule replied, 'Well, he said nothing to me personally, but he stopped and had a long talk with the butcher!'

Are you like that ox-shirking work? Ephesians 2:10 TLB says: 'We are God's masterpiece...created...so we can do the good things He planned for us.' So we need to get on with it and forget about pulling sickies. Everything we do or don't do has consequences. The Bible tells us: 'There is going to come a time of testing at the Judgment Day to see what kind of work each...has done. Everyone's work will be put through the fire to see whether or not it keeps its value.' So 'think of ways to encourage one another to outbursts of love and good deeds.' (Hebrews 10:24 NLT)



SoulFood: Jer 28-30, Mark 2:23-3:6, Ps 103:1-12, Pr 10:13

content.title: Don't Stop Believing
content.introtext:
'You will lift up your face without shame.' Job 11:15 NIV

You know those times when nothing seems to go right and the whole world seems to tell us we're a waste of space?

No one understood this more than Job. He was one of those people who had it all. Everything you could want in life, he had it-great job, wonderful kids, stunning wife, good friends. He wanted for nothing. Then he lost the lot! Apart from his wife, that is. But going through such extreme hardship and loss didn't make that relationship easy. He couldn't make sense of it; he wished he'd never been born.

But one thing that Job never did was blame God. Sure, he questioned Him, he tried to find some understanding of why his life had turned upside down. He tried to grab some peace in the torment of each day. But he never blamed God and always clung to Him in belief and trust. Even when his friends deserted him and his health took a nosedive, he kept hanging on to God. Eventually Job came out on top. The book with his name on it says: 'If you devote your heart to [God]...you will lift up your face without shame; you will stand firm and without fear.' Don't stop believing-God will come through for you too.



SoulFood: Jer 33:1-36:26, Mark 3:20-35, Ps 16, Pr 10:15

content.title: Do The Maths
content.introtext:
'His divine power has given us everything we need for...a godly life.' 2 Peter 1:3 NLT

Have you been brushing up on your three R's lately? Reading, (w)Riting and (a)Rithmetic? How are your mathematical skills? If they've grown a little dusty then 2 Peter 1 is your dust-buster. In the space of one chapter you will learn some spiritual mathematics.

In verses 5-8, you discover seven things you need to add to your life: 'For this reason make every effort to add to your faith, goodness; and to goodness, knowledge; and to knowledge, self-control; and to self-control, perseverance; and to perseverance, godliness; and to godliness brotherly kindness; and to brotherly kindness, love. For if you possess these qualities in increasing measure they will keep you from becoming ineffective and unproductive in your knowledge of our Lord Jesus Christ.' (Write down those seven qualities so you don't forget them.)

Then it's straight onto some subtraction. 'Those who fail to develop these virtues...have already forgotten that God has cleansed them from their old life of sin.' We need to stop doing sinful things, subtract sin from our lives, stop going our own way and do life God's way. The more we add those seven qualities into our everyday lives the more we will subtract the sin. Every day, do the maths-your spiritual maths, that is!



SoulFood: Jer 36:27-40:16, Mark 4:1-12, Ps 7:1-9, Pr 10:16

content.title: Grow Up
content.introtext:
'Let us cross over to the other side.' Mark 4:35 NKJ

At times Jesus gave His disciples special inside knowledge and understanding on stuff He was saying, which gave them a buzz of excitement or a headache, like their brain couldn't develop fast enough to fit the information in. Then they had experiences like the day Jesus said to them, 'Let's cross over to the other side.' So off they sailed, but it was no easy trip: 'A fierce storm arose. High waves began to break into the boat until it was nearly full of water.' (Mark 4:37 NLT)

They were petrified; their short lives were flashing before their eyes. Jesus wasn't at all scared, though-they had to wake Him up before He saw the commotion. Then they watched in amazement as Jesus told the weather to stop playing up-and it did! But then Jesus made them realise they needed to grow up, 'Why are you so afraid? Do you still not have faith in Me?'

God wants us to be 'no longer be infants, tossed back and forth by the waves and blown here and there by every wind of teaching and the cunning and craftiness of men in their deceitful scheming. Instead...grow up.' (Ephesians 4:14-15 NIV) Jesus wants you to grow up, trusting Him in every situation no matter how stormy life gets, trusting His words no matter how many people rock the boat with their untruths, trusting Him no matter how what circumstances try to blow us off course.



SoulFood: Ruth 1:3-18, Acts 8:26-40

content.title: Run Run Run
content.introtext:
'When you are tempted, He will show you a way out.' 1 Corinthians 10:13 NLT

Excuses, excuses, excuses: we all make them when temptation strikes. We fall for it, get caught and then it's 'I've been set up, officer, honest! He made me do it! I didn't have a choice!'

They say opportunity knocks only once but temptation leans on the doorbell and often kicks the door down! We don't get tempted because we're evil; we're tempted because we're human. So expect temptation to happen-and learn how to handle it. Here are three things God wants you to know about temptation:

(1) 'The temptations in your life are no different from what others experience.' So don't kid yourself that you're different from anyone else, or that your situation makes it more difficult for you. We're all in the same boat, if one person can resist-so can you.

(2) 'God is faithful. He will not allow the temptation to be more than you can stand.' So don't fool yourself in believing that it was too hard and you had to fold under the weight of it. God never goes back on His promises; if He says you can resist it-you can.

(3) 'When you are tempted, He will show you a way out.' So refuse to believe there's no other option. Instead look around, think outside the box, ask God to show you an alternative route. If He says there's another way-there is! And once God has locked the door on your temptation, don't go climbing through the window. Run from temptation and don't leave a forwarding address.



SoulFood: Jer 41-44, Mark 4:13-25, Ps 7:10-17, Pr 10:17-18

content.title: Have Faith
content.introtext:
'The person who is put right with God through faith shall live.' Romans 1:17 GNT

We all believe in things we can't see: like oxygen! We believe it's there to breathe even though we can't see it. If we can have faith in oxygen, we can have faith in God. As 2 Corinthians 5:7 NIV says: 'we live by faith, not by sight.'

The bungee jumper hurtles from a great height with faith in the bungee cord to save him from death. We too can have faith that God will save us: John 3:16-17 NLT says 'For God so loved the world that He gave His only son, so that everyone who believes in Him will not perish but have eternal life. God did not send His Son into the world to condemn it, but to save it.'

We can't see the wind or electricity, but the effects of these make us believe it to be real. In a similar way we can see the effects God makes in people's lives and have the faith to believe He is real. John 4:39 NIV says, 'Many...believed in Him because of the woman's testimony.'

We can take a piece of cheap yellowish plastic to a shop, expecting we can exchange it for a new shirt. We've got faith that the new shirt will be ours because the cheap yellowish plastic is a $50 note with the full backing of the Reserve Bank behind it. So we can also read God's Word and have faith that He will fully back all the promises He has made (over 3000 of them). Hebrews 11:1 NIV says: 'faith is being sure of what we hope for and certain of what we do not see.'



SoulFood: Jer 45-48, Mark 4:26-41, Ps 144:1-8, Pr 10:19-21

content.title: Work It
content.introtext:
'We are God's fellow workers.' 1 Corinthians 3:9 NIV

It's been said that the only workout some folks get is jumping to conclusions, running down their friends, sidestepping their responsibility and pushing their luck! Back in the day when Paul was around, the church in Corinth was full of people like that-pulling each other to pieces, moaning, complaining and picking sides, saying one Christian leader was better than another. So Paul has a word: 'The Lord has assigned each to his task. I planted the seed, Apollos watered it, but God made it grow. So neither he who plants nor he who waters is anything, but only God, who makes things grow...we are God's fellow-workers.' (1 Corinthians 3:5-9 NIV)

Paul puts them in their place, reminding us all that we are to work together with God, not fight against each other. After all, it's God who does the miraculous, not us! Where would we be without God? What can we achieve without God? God is the amazing one; only He 'is able to do immeasurably more than all we ask or imagine.' (Ephesians 3:20 NIV)

If you lose sight of what working with God is all about, try remembering the words of J. John who, when asked what he did for a living, replied, 'WelI, I work for a global enterprise with outlets in nearly every country of the world; we've got hospitals, hospices, homeless shelters; we do justice work, reconciliation work, orphanages, marriage guidance counselling... basically we look after people from birth to death... It's called the church.'



SoulFood: Jer 49-50, Mark 5:1-10, Ps 144:9-15, Pr 10:22-23

content.title: Start Small, End Big
content.introtext:
'Do not despise...small beginnings.' Zechariah 4:10 NLT

Walking along the road you see five cents on the ground-what do you do? Walk past it, leave it where it is-after all it's only five cents, why bother? What would happen if that coin were a $50 note? Would you ignore it? You'd want to pick it up, wouldn't you? You'd want to do something about it, you couldn't just leave it lying there-it's worth enough to buy something!

In a world that constantly says, 'bigger is better,' it's easy to ignore the little things in life. It's easy to think you can't do anything because you don't have enough, aren't talented enough, or don't know enough. It's easy to get fed up, frustrated and pack it in because it's taking too long, you feel you're not getting anywhere or your efforts aren't amounting to much.

The Bible says, 'Do not despise...small beginnings, for the Lord rejoices to see the work begin.' God always sees the potential in you. So notice the small things, take care of the little things, do the tiny things you can do. You'll find they are just as valuable and just as important. All things that become great started small.

Do this for others too: start passing on small words of encouragement and compliments. Watch how attitudes change as others see you seeking to build them up, rather than trying to tear them down. Little things like a word of encouragement can help others achieve their massive potential.



SoulFood: Jer 51-52, Mark 5:11-20, Ps 94:1-11, Pr 10:24-26

content.title: Don't Give Up
content.introtext:
'Everyone...abandoned me...but the Lord stood with me.' 2 Timothy 4:16-17 NLT

If you're open and honest about your Christian faith, you will have noticed there is often someone around to 'shoot you down'. They can spring up from nowhere, sometimes appearing so knowledgeable as to make your faith in Jesus look weak and insignificant. Or they can stun you into silence so you feel unable to answer. Occasionally they're harsh critics out to humiliate whatever the cost. Then there's always some new-fangled theory, declared as a 'new truth' that hits the headlines along with a new bit of information that apparently disproves the Bible-it's mostly only those negative towards the Christian faith that become newsworthy.

Never be downhearted; instead read 2 Timothy and be encouraged. Paul wrote this letter from a Roman prison cell-unheated, underground, probably measuring only 3m by 6m and 2m high, accessible only through a hole in the ceiling. Trapped there because he wouldn't deny his faith in Jesus, he knew the harsh reality of living the Christian way of life. It's likely Paul suffered more than most of us will ever suffer for our faith, yet he endured it. Will you?

Paul writes: 'The first time I was brought before the judge, no one was with me. Everyone had abandoned me...but the Lord stood with me and gave me the strength, that I might preach the Good News in all its fullness.'



SoulFood: Joel 1-3, Mark 5:21-30, Ps 94:12-23, Pr 10:27

content.title: Confront Your Fears
content.introtext:
'God has not given us a spirit of fear, but of power and of love and of a sound mind.' 2 Timothy 1:7 NKJ

'You are the light of the world! But if that light is under a bushel, it's lost something kind of crucial. You got to stay bright to be the light of the world.'

You may not be familiar with the psychedelic 70s musical Godspell, but its lyrics are full of God's Word, based on Matthew's Gospel. The point is that if you're in the dark, you don't have a light just to hide it away. If you've been given talents (and you have), you've been given them by God to be used for His glory.

You might be familiar with the Parable of the Talents found in Matthew 25:14-30, involving three servants each given different amounts to invest wisely. When the master returns, the first two servants have doubled their investments. But the last servant, who'd only been entrusted with the least amount, had buried it. When asked what the deal was, he could only reply, 'Master, I knew that you were a hard man. You harvest things you did not plant. You gather crops where you did not sow any seed. So I was afraid and went and hid your money in the ground. Here is your bag of gold.'... The master said, 'Throw that useless servant outside.' (Matthew 25:24-25, 30 NCV)

Conquering the fear of failure begins with believing: 'If God is for us, who can ever be against us?' (Romans 8:31 NLT)



SoulFood: Deut 5-7, Mark 10:1-12, Ps 75, Pr 11:23

content.title: Happy Thoughts
content.introtext:
'Your leader will break out...He will bring you through.' Micah 2:13 NLT

What do you think about when you're not thinking about anything? What goes through your mind before you fall asleep? Where does your mind focus when you wake up? What do you think about when you get some 'head space'? Your thoughts reflect your character and reveal what you're most passionate about.

Is your mind full of doom and gloom? Or a bit like the villains of the Batman movies-like the Joker or the Penguin, daily consumed with planning more dastardly deeds? The Bible lets us know that negative thinking produces a negative result. This is why we're encouraged in Philippians 4:8 NLT: 'Fix your thoughts on what is true and honourable and right. Think about things that are pure lovely and admirable...excellent and worthy of praise.'

This is easier said than done, but well done you! By reading word4U2day today you've made a great choice! When your brain feels wired for a 24/7 worry party or comes up with a creative solution to your circumstances involving 'payback time'. Colossians 3:2 says; 'Let Heaven fill your thoughts.' When we become passionate about things of God He promises to set us straight. 'Your leader will break out...He will bring you through...Your King will lead you; the Lord Himself will guide you.'



SoulFood: Acts 1:1-3:10, Mark 5:31-43, Ps 35, Pr 10:28-29

content.title: Brave Heart?
content.introtext:
'Examine me, O God, and know my mind.' Psalm 139:23 GNT

The bravest prayer in the Bible is believed to be David's prayer in Psalm 139-is your heart brave enough to pray this? 'Examine me, O God, and know my mind; test me, and discover my thoughts. Find out if there is any evil in me and guide me in the everlasting way.'

Eek! Allowing God to have a rummage under your bed? God already knows your deepest darkest moments, what goes on in your head, what you get up to with your mates, what you do when no one is looking-but actually asking Him to fill out a feedback sheet on what He thinks? Daring to let Him compare your life, your actions and your attitudes to His? Now that's scary! No one's going to come out looking good praying a prayer like that, are they? So why pray it? Why ask to be put under a microscope?

We only really recognise where we're going wrong when God points it out. We're forever making excuses about the stuff we do wrong. We can end up believing it's ok, acceptable, even right! But when we allow God to poke around and take over our mess, something incredible happens. Romans 8: 5-6 GNT tells us, 'Those who live as the Spirit tells them to, have their minds controlled by what the Spirit wants. To be controlled by human nature results in death; to be controlled by the Spirit results in life and peace.' It's not only the bravest prayer, but the best prayer too.



SoulFood: 2 Kings 20:1-11, Heb 8:7-13

content.title: Look Out!
content.introtext:
'Old people will have dreams...young people will see visions.' Joel 2:28 GNT

Being a Christian is the best. There's nothing like it, no better way of living. Romans 10:11 NAS says, 'Anyone who trusts in Him will never be disappointed...' Plus it's available to all-God leaves no one out, not even you. Romans 10:13 NIV says, 'Everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.'

Sure, life has its moments-but knowing Jesus makes a massive difference to all the tough stuff. Romans 5:3 NLT tells us, 'We can rejoice, too, when we run into problems and trials.' And there's more! God promises to let us in on His thoughts, give us special knowledge to see what He's up to, let us in on what He's doing: 'I will pour out My Spirit on all people. Your sons and daughters will prophesy, your old men will dream dreams, your young men will see visions.'

Do you want to be in the know? Then start asking God today to give you His vision for your life. Proverbs 29:18 GWT says, 'Without prophetic vision people run wild, but blessed are those who follow [God's] teachings.' Look out! You don't want miss God's blessings and make a fool of yourself. Look up! Ask God to let you in on the bigger picture of your life. If you don't know where you're going, you'll miss it when you get there. Get in on God's action.

content.title: More Hassle Than It's Worth?
content.introtext:
'Do not despise these small beginnings, for the Lord rejoices to see the work begin...' Zechariah 4:10 NLT

Does this sound familiar? God, I'm trying to do the best thing all the time and stand up for what's right-like not picking on anyone and sticking up for them instead. Not that it seems to make any difference-people just question my motives. I'm trying to do what You say is right, but it all goes as flat as a punctured tyre. Jesus, I want to put my hope in You and soar on wings like eagles, but quite frankly I feel like I'm flapping like a finch!

Trying to make a difference can seem like more hassle than it's worth sometimes. But living by God's Word does make a difference: 'Faith is the confidence that what we hope for will actually happen; it gives us assurance about things we cannot see.' (Hebrews 11:1 NLT) We all know someone who has trouble making friends (maybe that even applies to us) and we also know that even one person standing up for us really helps.

Who you follow, how you act and what you say can give God the room to change situations, circumstances and even lives. It can feel like you're making no difference, like you're flapping like a finch following Jesus-but keep at it and eventually you'll start to soar like an eagle. Eagles definitely have a better view!

content.title: Don't Worry About It
content.introtext:
'Casting all your care upon Him, for He cares for you.' 1 Peter 5:7 NKJ

'Cheer up, it might never happen!' can be the most annoying phrase in the whole world. And 'Turn that frown upside down!' can be as helpful as dropping your ice cream on the carpet. It can feel really patronising and unhelpful when people tell you not to worry. After all, most of the time you worry about things that actually matter.

One author wrote: 'A friend came up with this novel idea: "Why don't you try this worry coupon? It entitles you to worry as much as you like, but only if it will: (a) feed and clothe you; (b) add to your life instead of taking from it; (c) make tomorrow better; (d) you don't mind acting like a non-believer! If that doesn't work make a list of all the things you're worrying about, place it in a box and put it up on a shelf where you can't see it. If God is either unwilling or unable to take care of it, you can always get the box and start worrying again but at least give Him a chance. While you are waiting for Him to answer, pray. Stand on His Word. Don't give your worries a voice."'

If you're a chronic worrier, why not make a list of the things you're worrying about, give them to God in prayer-and give Him a chance to help.

content.title: Is That All?
content.introtext:
'...With the heart one believes unto righteousness...' Romans 10:10 NKJ

'If you confess with your mouth that Jesus is Lord and believe in your heart that God raised Him from the dead, you will be saved. For it is by believing in your heart that you are made right with God, and it is by confessing with your mouth that you are saved.' (Romans 10:9-10 NLT)

Is that it? Yes! Believing in your heart that Jesus died for you to make you right with God and confessing that out loud equals one glorious badge of salvation. Actually, it's better than a badge-we are made new! 'Therefore, if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation; the old has gone, the new has come!' (2 Corinthians 5:17 NIV)

That sounds amazing but my life so far doesn't exactly look like one of Walt Disney's happily-ever-after stories. You don't know what I've done! I don't believe I could ever be righteous before God.

That's why the Gospel is 'good news'! Jesus died for every sin imaginable! The Good News doesn't come with small print or exceptions. God's not like a Facebook user who accepts or declines friend requests! He accepts every time! 'One man, Jesus Christ, took on the sin of the world.' That includes yours! '...Neither the present nor the future...nor anything else in all creation, will be able to separate us from the love of God that is in Christ Jesus...' (Romans 8:38-39 NIV)

content.title: Lessons from Lazarus (1)
content.introtext:
'Now a certain man was sick...Lazarus of Bethany...' John 11:1 NKJ

Lazarus was a man Jesus raised from the dead. It's an amazing story of the miraculous. It's a great example of how Jesus proved He was the Son of God by giving life to Lazarus' dead limbs in the tomb with the words: 'Lazarus come out!'

But there's more we can learn from this story. We learn a lot about Jesus' character too. When Lazarus' sisters sent word to Jesus that their brother was sick, Jesus knew what God was doing: 'This sickness will not end in death. No, it is for God's glory so that God's Son may be glorified through it.' (John 11:4-5 NIV)

Jesus knew from the beginning how it would end. Did Jesus rock up to Martha and Mary like a Las Vegas magician? 'Hey girls, had you going there, didn't I? Stop crying now and prepare to be amazed... Lazarus! Come on down!'

No, He did the opposite. When Jesus met with the sisters, He wept. He mourned with them. He loved them so He felt and understood what they were going through. The Bible says, 'Love must be sincere...rejoice with those who rejoice; mourn with those who mourn.' (Romans 12:9;15 NIV)



SoulFood: Acts 14-15, Mark 7:14-23, Ps 37:32-40, Pr 11:7-8

content.title: Lessons from Lazarus (2)
content.introtext:
'Now a certain man was sick...Lazarus of Bethany...' John 11:1 NKJ

Martha and Mary sent news to Jesus that their brother Lazarus was sick, and might die. What do you think Jesus did when He heard this? Well, you know Jesus loved people, so you might make an educated guess He went over to the house straight away. But no, He didn't. In fact, He waited two days before going to see them. And by that time Lazarus had died.

Funny way of showing you love someone, you might think. Doing nothing for a few days-what was Jesus thinking? But God never makes mistakes. He always knows what He's doing and He did here, too. Jesus said to His disciples, '...Lazarus is dead, and for your sake I am glad I was not there, so that you may believe...' (John 11:14-15 NIV)

Jesus wanted to instil into His disciples faith that He was who He said He was by letting them witness Lazarus come back to life. There was a purpose in His timing, not neglect. God loves us massively and because of that, no matter how bad things can be, we can trust that '...God works all things for the good of those who love Him, who have been called according to His purpose.' (Romans 8:28 NIV)



SoulFood: 1 Sam 5:1-6:16, Rev 11:15-19

content.title: Lessons from Lazarus (3)
content.introtext:
'Now a certain man was sick...Lazarus of Bethany...' John 11:1 NKJ

It must have been so difficult for Martha and Mary. They had to watch their brother die because Jesus didn't get to them in time. You wouldn't blame Martha and Mary if they felt a double dose of mourning: they'd lost their brother, and maybe they had lost hope in Jesus too.

But it didn't seem to rock Martha's faith! When Martha first saw Jesus after her brother had died she said to Him, 'Lord...if You had been here, my brother would not have died. But I know that even now God will give You whatever You ask.' (John 11:21-22 NIV)

Martha not only believed Jesus would have saved Lazarus from sickness, she still believed He could save him 'even now' in death. Mary's initial reaction to Jesus' arrival in Bethany was very different to Martha's. Mary stayed at home whereas Martha was up and out of the house straight away to find Him.

Perhaps Mary stayed because she thought Jesus would be coming to the house anyway, so there wasn't any need. But there's a sense that Martha had so much hope in Jesus that she couldn't just wait for Him to just turn up, she had to seek Him out to declare the massive faith she had in Him. Martha was right to have that kind of hope in Jesus. He was who He said He was. He is the same for you!

content.title: Keep that Heart Pumped for God!
content.introtext:
'I will give them an undivided heart...' Ezekiel 11:19 NIV

The rulers of Jerusalem had chosen to ignore God and turn away from Him by following the practices of other nations. By way of example, filling streets with dead bodies had become a regular pastime! Ezekiel was like a lifeguard being used as God's megaphone to speak to these people whom God had forced out of Israel because of their broken faith.

But through that time of judgment, God also gives words of hope to Ezekiel: '...I will give you back the land of Israel again. They will return to it and remove all its vile images and detestable idols. I will give them an undivided heart and put a new spirit in them.' (Ezekiel 11:17-18 NIV)

Jesus is the source of our hope. He took all the punishment for sin at the cross. But just like the people of Ezekiel's day who followed the practices of other nations, it's easy for our hearts to get divided. We need to focus on God rather than what our mates are doing or what society claims to be normal.

Have a fresh look at your heart for God. Would you say you're giving Him nothing but the best? Or does He get the leftovers of your life? The Bible says, 'Let us throw off everything that hinders us and the sin that so easily entangles us, and let us run with perseverance the race marked out for us.' (Hebrews 12:1 NIV)

content.title: It Happens In Stages
content.introtext:
'...First the blade, then the head, after that the full grain...' Mark 4:28 NKJ

At different times, all of us find ourselves waiting for God to make a move in our lives. If that's you right now, listen to the words of Jesus in the parable of the seed:

'The Kingdom of God is like a farmer who scatters seed on the ground. Night and day, while he's asleep or awake, the seed sprouts and grows, but he does not understand how it happens. The earth produces the crops on its own. First a leaf blade pushes through, then the heads of wheat are formed, and finally the grain ripens.' (Mark 4:26-28 NLT)

Notice how things happen in stages. First, there's the 'I don't know' stage. Your seed is in the ground but when it will produce a harvest is entirely up to God. All you have is His Word to you promising that it will (and God never breaks a promise). Next comes 'the leaf blade' stage. It's just a tiny shoot blowing in the breeze but it's enough to encourage you and let you know that He is at work. Next comes 'the head' stage. Now it's starting to look like God-given God-driven transformation. Finally the 'full grain' appears.

The point is we don't always see what God's doing on the earth, or even under the earth, of our hearts. But He is busy working. The Kingdom is growing and will eventually appear.



SoulFood: Acts 20-21, Mark 8:14-26, Ps 44:17-26, Pr 11:12-13

content.title: You're Called to Be a Servant
content.introtext:
'Paul, a bond-servant of Christ Jesus...' Romans 1:1 NAS

'Servant' is definitely a word that belongs in a history lesson! Here in the sunburnt land of Oz there are not many people today who'd admit to having servants. Those with a splash of cash might have a 'nanny' for the kids or a 'cleaner' for the house, but even the highest paid CEO probably doesn't call them 'servants'.

In Israel in Old Testament times, things were very different. There was a dignity to being a servant, especially if you were a 'bond-servant'.

In those times, servants were hired on the basis that they would work faithfully for their masters for six years. In the seventh year, the law said they had to be set free. But in many cases, the servants didn't want to go free. They had good lives; their wives and kids were happy; they loved their masters.

In that case, when it came time for a servant to be released, the master would take him before a judge and pierce his ear, signifying that he belonged to him forever. It was a sign the servant was committed to obeying him for life. It meant: 'Master, I'm not serving you because I have to but because I want to' (Exodus 21:6).

Is this your prayer today? Lord, I'm not serving You because I have to but because I want to. Pierce my ear, mark me as Yours, bond me together with You so that I can never belong to another.

It's a very powerful thing to say-can you say it and mean it?



SoulFood: Acts 22-23, Mark 8:27-38, Ps 57, Pr 11:14

content.title: Learn from the Yoke
content.introtext:
'It is good for a man to bear the yoke while he is young.' Lamentations 3:27 NIV

The Book of Lamentations is not exactly the world's most exciting read. It doesn't get a big tick for adventure either. Yep, when it comes time to choose your next book to read Lamentations probably doesn't immediately spring to mind.

However when you do take the time to read it you find it is about hope, hope and still more hope. There are five poems in Lamentations and they describe the destruction of Jerusalem and the plight of those people living with the consequences of the nation's rebellion. However woven through these poems is the thread of belief in God's mercy and faithfulness: 'The steadfast love of the Lord never ceases. His mercies never come to an end.' (Lamentations 3:22 ESV) This is true whatever you've done!

The author, even through his affliction, recognises the benefit of his 'yoke'. The yoke represents the oppression of his sin. He was glad he had learned the lesson from rebellion, with many years left to live more wisely and with God. The poems take a real journey of painful loss and shame but end in restored hope and prayer for renewal.

content.title: Far From Worthless
content.introtext:
'...Well-nurtured plants...pillars...to adorn a palace.' Psalm 144:12 NIV

The Psalmist writes: 'O Lord, what is man that You care for him?...Man is like a breath; his days are like a fleeting shadow.' (Psalm 144:3-4 NIV) As in, what's so great about us? We're here one minute, gone the next, why should God care?

God created us to have a relationship with Him, and He's planned amazing stuff for us all to do: we all have a purpose, a God-stamp of significance.

But people in our lives can make us doubt our worth: 'You're a waste of space!' 'You'll never amount to anything!' 'You'll never be good enough!'

If you hear these kinds of things enough, you can start to believe them. Sometimes we don't even need to hear them to start to believe them-it's just how we feel about ourselves.

Either way, what God says about us is very different: 'For we are God's workmanship, created in Christ Jesus to do good works, which God prepared in advance for us to do.' (Ephesians 2:10 NIV) We are God's workmanship. We are beautiful in His sight because it is He who made us and knitted us together in our mother's womb. Far from worthless, we are His children and He has plans that will give us a hope and a future.

Read His Word. When you listen to God's words about you, you'll start to believe you are priceless, not worthless!

'...You are My followers if you love each other.' John 13:35 NCV

content.title: Now That's A Staff!
content.introtext:
'...Moses...became so tired...Aaron and Hur...stood on each side...holding up his hands...' Exodus 17:11-12 NLT

Israel was up against the Amalekites. Moses ordered Joshua to choose the fighters and then went to watch from the top of a hill, the staff of God in his hands.

Do you think anyone complained about Moses being lazy or scared? 'You lot go fight, I'll just stand here with a stick!'

No, because this staff wasn't a walking stick. It was God's staff-the one that had parted the Red Sea and drawn water out of a rock.

Having the staff of God in his hand showed the Israelites that (1) Moses was chosen to lead them (2) It was the Lord's power that would lead to victory, not Moses himself. As long as Moses held up the staff the Israelites were stronger in battle. But as his arms got tired and the staff dropped, the Amalekites gained advantage.

So, 'Aaron and Hur found a stone for him to sit on. Then they stood on each side...holding up his hands.' There are times when we need friends like Aaron and Hur to join us on the hill overlooking our own battles. God didn't just lead Israel to victory that day. When Moses was at his weakest, He provided some helping hands. Are you trying to do it on your own when you could ask God for some helping hands?

'God has not given us a spirit of fear, but of power and of love and of a sound mind.' 2 Timothy 1:7 NKJ

God says we can conquer fear, worry and all other pesky anxieties, by choosing to give over all our worries and concerns to Him. content.title: In the Worship Zone
content.introtext:
'God is Spirit, and His worshippers must worship in spirit and in truth.' John 4:24 NIV

If you watch those shopping channels, you'll hear the phrase 'body, soul and spirit' a lot. But this is actually our contemporary culture's reversal of the way the Bible sees us. 1 Thessalonians 5:23 tells us that we are spirit, soul and body (look it up!) Therefore, we're not simply bodies, occasionally having spiritual experiences, but are whole beings having all of these experiences.

The life force within you came from God. When we worship our Maker, it's like going back to our origins and reconnecting with our Maker. It's the very purpose of our existence-the thing we were created to do.

Let's consider some of the amazing things that happen in worship: (1) Our deepest thirst is quenched. (2) Our wounds are healed. (3) Our strength is renewed. (4) We're placed beyond the reach of our enemy.

King David was a worship leader whose songs have lasted thousands of years. You may not be able to download his latest album directly from iTunes but his worship material has connected people to God for centuries-his songs are called Psalms and you'll find them in every copy of the Bible. You don't need to go to a special worship event or buy the latest CD to worship God-our whole lives are about worshipping Him.

content.title: Keep Your Priorities in Place
content.introtext:
'...I must be about My Father's business.' Luke 2:49 NKJ

Choices, choices: sandals or sandshoes, burger or pizza, tweet or text? Life is full of choices. Ok, so the consequences of these choices might not be earth-shattering. But some choices we make every day shape who we become. Like whom we hang around with; like what we watch on TV; like how much effort we put into our coursework.

As a boy of twelve, Jesus knew His purpose and priorities, and He lived by them: 'I must be about My Father's business.' Do you know your priorities? A clear idea of what they are will shape your choices. We all make hundreds of choices each day, but the big question is: are those choices taking you nearer to your goal or further away? If you don't understand your life's goal, you won't be able to make the right choices.

The best way to make consistently good choices is to make prayer and God's Word your top priority. Ray Ortlund said: 'We must first be fully committed to Christ, then to one another in Christ, and finally to the work of Christ in the world.' The very fact you're reading this indicates you've got an interest in what God's got for you, so why not take this opportunity to ask Him afresh what His priorities for you are-and ask Him for His help to make any necessary changes?

content.title: Faith and Fantasy (1)
content.introtext:
'...They speak a vision of their own heart, not from the mouth of the Lord.' Jeremiah 23:16 NKJ

Time travelling. Flying like a bird. Creating your very own solar system. These are three of the top ten dreams most unlikely to be fulfilled. How about yours? Most of us would love to wake up on a beach in Hawaii, but life doesn't often work like that. Do you need to wake up and smell the coffee? No doubt about it, a lottery mindset will lead you into trouble!

Consider the sad underbelly of reality TV: how many contestants go in for shows like The X Factor thinking they've 'got it', only to be told at the first hurdle that their act simply isn't good enough? Cue hissy fits, tantrums and general toys-out-of-pram behaviour. We wonder: how could they be so deluded? But maybe they're not the only ones who need a reality check.

Ralph Waldo Emerson observed: 'Shallow men believe in luck. Strong men believe in cause and effect.' When God gives you a dream, you need faith to make it materialise. But it's important to ask, 'Is my dream from God?'

David Westlake once said, 'God doesn't tell you to be great, He just asks you to do the next thing.' If you've got a big dream that you're hoping will turn into reality and not fade into fantasy, then God will give you the trustworthy test: if you can be trusted with the dull and the ordinary, maybe you can be trusted with the superstar stuff.

Jesus said, 'Ask, and it will be given to you...' (Matthew 7:7 NKJ) 'Fantastic!' says your imagination. 'I'll have a Porsche 911, a big mansion, a pony in pink and a...' Whoa there, Nelly! Before you finish off your shopping list, check the small print! It has to be in line with God's will (1 John 5:14 NIV).

Joseph was a young bloke of seventeen with a richly ornamented robe (not necessarily Technicolour). He might have been a bit of a dreamer, but his dreams came true. Read the story for yourself in Genesis 37 if you don't think the musical does it justice.

The main points of his story were: God gave him some dreams indicating he'd be a big shot. Straight away, a heap of disappointment was dished out to him , followed by a dollop of false accusation, a slice of imprisonment and a helping of more dreams. The conclusion to the story is that his dreams actually did come true-eventually.

But they came true in a different way to what he expected. God worked his circumstances out so that he became humble and merciful, not arrogant and conceited. God cares more about good character than he does about gifting and talents. Rather than worrying about things out of your control in fantasyland, base what you do on your strengths and other factors within your control. When God gives you a dream, it will play to your strengths.

content.title: Thirsty for God
content.introtext:
'...My soul thirsts for You...in a...land where there is no water.' Psalm 63:1 NAS

It's a hot summer's day. Your tongue is sticking to the roof of your mouth, you're virtually spitting feathers, so what do you do? Waltz to the kitchen, grab a glass, turn on the tap and hey presto: lovely cool drinking water. No big deal, is it? But hike up a hill on a hot summer's day without enough H2O and your body will soon let you know about it! It's a condition commonly known as 'thirst'.

David wrote about being thirsty in Psalm 63 when he was in the Desert of Judah. 'Earnestly I seek You, my soul thirsts for You, my body longs for You, in a dry and weary land where there is no water.' His enemies were pressing in on him and he cries out, 'Where are You, God?'

Ever been there? Wondering if God's taking a coffee break rather than answering your call? Just as physical thirst is your body's way of telling you that you need water, there's a spiritual thirst that only God can quench. And He will! 'You will seek Me and find Me when you seek Me with all your heart.' (Jeremiah 29:13 NIV) But you have to give God the time, space and the opportunity to do so. Half-hearted efforts won't cut it. Don't dehydrate, drink from the fountain of life!

content.title: Don't Give Up!
content.introtext:
'...There is wonderful joy ahead, even though you have to endure...trials...' 1 Peter 1:6 NLT

The film The Pursuit of Happyness tells the true story of Chris Gardner, played by Will Smith. Having invested the family's hard-earned savings into portable bone-density scanners, he begins a career as a salesman. Having little understanding of business, the whole venture goes pear-shaped and ruins the family financially. As a result his wife leaves him.

Things pick up for Chris when he gains an internship after a chance meeting with a stockbroker and some fancy moves with a Rubik's cube. However, he's dealt another blow when he and his young son are evicted from their home for unpaid taxes. He's now homeless with a demanding, low-paid job and a young son to care for.

Left with no other option but to stay in a homeless shelter that he must queue up for each day (because of the demand for limited rooms), he works as hard as he can to stay afloat, and keep his job. He pushes on to develop ways of making phone sales more efficient and remains faithful in caring for his son despite the pressure. Finally he is rewarded by a fully paid position. By the time the credits roll, we discover that Chris went on to form his own multi-million dollar brokerage firm.

There's a lesson here for us. When things get tough, keep on keeping on and don't give up! As Peter said: 'There is wonderful joy ahead!'
