'Thanks be to God who always leads us in triumph in Christ...' 2 Corinthians 2:14 NAS

Siblings! One minute you're laughing and joking, the next they're ripping your hair out. For a while you make up and everything's fine, but then they take it one step too far and suddenly blurt out the most unkind, hurtful, painful thing you've ever heard: '...You'll get no inheritance...you're the son of that other woman.' (Judges 11:2 GWT) Whoa!

This was exactly how it was for Jephthah. And what they'd said was true. He was the son of a prostitute. So they kicked him out of the family home, robbed him of his rightful inheritance only to come crawling back to him years later, asking for his help when they were in trouble. The nerve of them! But he didn't tell them to take a running jump. Instead, he swallowed his pride, trained up an army, defeated Israel's enemies and even gets a mention in the Faith Hall of Fame found in Hebrews 11, rubbing shoulders with Samson and David!

But how did he do it? Well, he didn't let his past define his future. He overcame the hurt inflicted by those who were supposed to love him and seized his chance to make a difference. You are more than the product of your environment. Leave yesterday where it belongs-in the past. 'This means that anyone who belongs to Christ has become a new person. The old life is gone; a new life has begun!' (2 Corinthians. 5:17 NLT) Live in the new and say goodbye to the old.

Have you been hoping and praying for a friend of yours to become a Christian? Invited them to church but they've informed you they're washing their hair instead? Tried to be a good witness and crowbar God in to conversation at every available opportunity, but still not even a jot of interest?

You're not alone if you're feeling the pangs of disappointment: Isaac's son Esau rejected God even though his other son Jacob surrendered to God. The prophet Samuel's sons were out for what they could get for themselves, accepting bribes and perverting justice. In fact, history is full of people sadly rejecting God's salvation plan. We can end up discouraged if we take the matter to heart too much.

So, before we get too down about it all, let's consider three important lessons about salvation. (1) God alone can save. As Jonah sat in the intestine of a large fish contemplating his own actions, he had revelation of this truth: 'Salvation comes from the Lord.' (Jonah 2:9 NIV) Don't take on guilt that isn't yours. Because God is so great, He knows exactly how and when to close the deal for your mates. (2) 'Don't worry about anything; instead, pray about everything. Tell God what you need, and thank Him for all He has done.' (Philippians 4:6 NLT) Your part is to pray and believe God for your mate's salvation, then hand over the burden to God. (3) If they're alive, there's hope! God is bigger than stubborn hearts and people's circumstances, if only you will trust Him.

content.title: Staying When You Feel Like Quitting
content.introtext:
'Love...endures through every circumstance.' 1 Corinthians 13:7 NLT

Have you ever been to an amazing conference or festival like Easterfest, Strawberry Jam or Hillsong? Was the worship tingle-inducing? Did you have an encounter with God that changed your life? Hear teaching that blew your mind? But now you look round your own church and see Aunt Ethel in the same pew as always, Bob the organist slowly decaying and a minister who just doesn't get you. Then it hits you: I'll do church my way. After all, there's teaching on the internet and I'll listen to some proper worship music! I'll see you losers later!

But that's not what God wants. The church is God's plan for you. There is no plan B. The old cliché rings true: 'If you find the perfect church, don't join it, you'll only spoil it.' Instead of asking what church can do for you, ask what you can do for your church. How about having a chat with Aunt Ethel-she might surprise you. And as for Bob the organist, why not see if you can help on the worship team? If you're really not happy, talk it through with your youth leader or someone you trust. Whinging with your mates isn't the way.

Leaving a church isn't to be taken lightly. A tree that keeps getting uprooted can't keep growing, it just slowly dies. We all need feeding and watering, and that will happen through your church. Get involved and ask God for more of Him, so that you can endure 'through every circumstance.' (1 Corinthians 13:7 NLT)

content.title: Meditate and Ruminate
content.introtext:
'...Meditate on it day and night...' Joshua 1:8 NIV

'A ruminant is a mammal that digests plant-based food by initially softening it within the animal's first stomach, then regurgitating the semi-digested mass and chewing it again. This is called "ruminating"'. Thanks, Wikipedia!

If you're wondering why we're talking about a rather unpleasant way of reviewing your lunch today, it's all to do with ruminating-or meditating.

If we want to live spiritually healthy lives, it's important that we eat right. That means healthy portions of God's Word. Yet some bits of the Bible need to be chewed rather than swallowed whole. Otherwise we suffer the spiritual equivalent of heartburn and indigestion. No matter how busy life gets, we need to make sure we're making time to process, chew and meditate on God's Word so that it can take root and become part of you.

When Joshua replaced Moses as leader of the Israelites, God told him three times to 'Be strong and very courageous.' (Joshua 1:7 NIV) It would seem God was trying to make a point. He went on to explain where that strength and courage would come from: 'Keep this Book of the Law always on your lips; meditate on it day and night, so that you may be careful to do everything written in it. Then you will be prosperous and successful.' (Joshua 1:8 NIV)

God is saying that if we take His Word to our very core, then we have a role to play in our strength and success. You wouldn't swallow a piece of steak like you would a spoonful of yoghurt. Chew on it, and keep chewing.



SoulFood: Lev 23:15-22, Acts 2:1-18 Pentecost

content.title: The Spirit of Wisdom
content.introtext:
'The Spirit of the Lord shall rest upon Him, the Spirit of wisdom...' Isaiah 11:2 NKJ

During His earthly ministry, Jesus needed the Spirit of wisdom to make all sorts of decisions. He even rebuked one of His own disciples, Peter, for getting in the way of God: 'Go away from Me, Satan! You don't care about the things of God, but only about things people think are important.' (Mark 8:33 NCV)

As followers of Jesus, that same Spirit lives in us. James points out three kinds of ungodly wisdom in James 3:15 (look it up). Firstly, earthly wisdom: this isn't always dependable because 'sometimes what seems right is really a road to death.' (Proverbs 16:25 CEV) Secondly, sensual wisdom: based on emotions which can be confusing and lead to hurt and jealousy. Thirdly, demonic wisdom which is selfish and ungodly.

But Godly wisdom is altogether different and is 'first of all pure; then peace-loving, considerate, submissive, full of mercy and good fruit, impartial and sincere.' (James 3:17 NIV) A few things to consider, then: Are your motives pure or would you be embarrassed when a bit more light is shed on the matter? Are you willing to submit to what God wants, even if it's something you desperately want? Is your conscience clear if you go ahead, or does it require deception and selfishness? Is it fair and impartial or is it favouring a particular group or person?

James says, '...if you want to know what God wants you to do-ask Him, and He will gladly tell you. He will not resent your asking.' (James 1:5 NLT)



SoulFood: Deut 32:29-34:12, Mark 12:28-44, Ps 108, Pr 12:14

content.title: How's Your Relationship with God? (1)
content.introtext:
'...I carry out the will of the One who sent Me, not My own will.' John 5:30 NLT

The relationship Jesus had with His Father is the kind of relationship that He wants you to have with Him. Jesus modelled it perfectly, and today we'll consider one aspect of that relationship: intimacy. Some people might go all red at the mention of the word-but actually it just means 'closeness'.

Jesus said, 'The Father loves the Son and shows Him everything He is doing...' (John 5:20 NLT) Now I might be able to reel off a few facts about Prince William, but I don't really know how he thinks, what makes him tick, what disappoints him. It's the same with our relationship with God. How close are you to God right now? Do you have a quick flick through word4U2day and then it's straight on with your own agenda? Are you close enough to know when you've said or done something that saddens God? Are you close enough to feel the warmth of His presence? 'Come near to God and God will come near to you' (James 4:8 NIV) never fails to be true. The truth is that you are as close to God as you desire to be, decide to be, and discipline yourself to be. So ask yourself, what are you desiring? God's Word or whatever's on TV? God's house or your mate's house? God's will or your own will? God is a gentleman-He won't force Himself on anyone, and He'll only come as close as you let Him.



SoulFood: 1 Pet 1-5, Mark 13:1-11, Ps 113, Pr 12:15-17

'...I carry out the will of the One who sent Me, not My own will.' John 5:30 NLT

Three things characterised Christ's relationship with His Father. Yesterday we looked at intimacy and today we'll look at His dependency on God. 'I tell you the truth: the Son can do nothing on His own; He does only what He sees His Father doing. What the Father does, the Son also does.' (John 5:19 GNT) Someone once said, 'Christians don't tell lies, they just sing them.' It can be easy to declare our dependence on God in the middle of amazing worship. But then walk out the door with the same prideful heart, totally unchanged. Often, if we fail at something, it's because we collapsed under the weight of a task God never gave us in the first place.

Are you struggling with insecurity or fear? Don't! Instead take strength from God's Word... 'For I am the Lord your God who takes hold of your right hand and says to you, Do not fear; I will help you.' (Isaiah 41:13 NIV) Your Heavenly Father won't ever give you something to do that won't require His wisdom and strength. It'll be designed to increase your dependence on Him, not decrease it. When you wake up each day, let your first thought be: 'God, I need You today, and there is no backup plan!'

content.title: How's Your Relationship with God? (3)
content.introtext:
'...I carry out the will of the One who sent Me, not My own will.' John 5:30 NLT

The third aspect of the relationship between Christ and the Father is obedience. Before you flick the page, assuming this is going to be a bit heavy, hang on two ticks! First, remember that God is love and that it's because of His awesome love for each one of us that He wants our best. God's not trying to cramp your style, He's looking to protect you. When you make Jesus Lord, you give up three basic rights your ego may have an issue with: (1) What it will cost you. It cost Jesus everything, namely His life. (2) Where it will take you. Jesus came from the beauty of Heaven to the rags of this world for us. (3) The amount which it will change you. Jesus went through separation from His Father to take on our sin on the cross.

Jesus said, 'I judge only as I hear, and My judgment is just, for I seek not to please Myself but Him who sent Me.' (John 5:30 NIV) Notice the bit that says, 'as I hear'. When you've heard from God, you've heard from God. End of story. It's time to get with the programme-God's programme! Don't go seeking after security, seek after God. 'In all your ways submit to Him and He will make your paths straight.' (Proverbs 3:6 NIV) Obedience is a sadly underrated virtue in our self-seeking culture. But when you walk in obedience, God's best is what you'll get. Don't settle for anything less.

content.title: God's Grace
content.introtext:
'If by grace, then it is no longer by works...' Romans 11:6 NIV

For all you theatre lovers out there, we're going to connect today's verse to 'Les Mis'. Hit musical Les Miserables tells the story of convict Jean Valjean, a lead character who finds himself offered mercy by a kind bishop. One night, while the house sleeps, Jean Valjean helps himself to the family silver and shoots through.

The next morning three policemen knock on the bishop's door with Valjean in tow. They're all for throwing him in jail. But the bishop says: 'So there you are! I'm delighted to see you. Had you forgotten I gave you the candlesticks as well? They're silver like the rest, and worth 2000 francs. Did you forget to take them?' The bishop not only gets the criminal off the hook, he sets him up for life, challenging him to use the money to become an honest man. And amidst the singing and dancing (and that special song Susan Boyle made her own) a near-perfect picture of 'grace' is drawn.

Do you see it? We are like Jean Valjean and God is like the bishop. Not only does God forgive our sins He also gives us the family silver. He wipes our slate clean with the challenge to go and make something of ourselves. And it's not something we can earn or buy; it's a gift called 'grace'. Praise God.



SoulFood: Judges 1-3, Mark 14:1-11, Ps 121, Pr 12:23-24

content.title: The Naked Truth
content.introtext:
'The Lord God called to the man, "Where are you?"' Genesis 3:9 NIV

It was the morning after. Adam's head throbbed. The place was a mess. His stomach felt like it was hurtling down a rollercoaster. Little fragments of what happened last night kept coming back to him. Did I really spend so long chatting about that snake? And why have I woken up with a half-eaten piece of fruit in my bed?

He remembered the blazing row with Eve. (Quarrelling-that was something new to Eden.) What exactly did happen last night? He felt strangely vulnerable. Naked, in fact. Best not let God find out, he thought. Just then the sound of feet rustled through the morning leaves. 'Adam, where are you?' called God. Adam had an idea: hide!

And it seems that ever since, people keep trying to hide. And God keeps asking, 'Where are you?' Maybe you're hiding beneath good grades at school and trophies and awards. You're telling the world, 'I am capable, honest.' Maybe you're hiding behind a long string of relationships; you're telling everyone, 'I am wanted, honest.' Maybe you're hiding beneath a scowl and warning the world, 'Don't mess with me or else.'

Of course God knew all along where to find Adam; He wanted Adam to find himself. Until you do that, you're truly lost. Unless you admit there's a problem, it can't be fixed. You can't be fixed. Stop hiding and ask that person in the mirror honestly, 'Where are you?' Face the naked truth.



SoulFood: Judges 4-6, Mark 14:12-26, Ps 4, Pr 12:25

content.title: Definitely Maybe (1)
content.introtext:
'...it may be that the Lord will work for us...' 1 Samuel 14:6 NKJ

Jonathan, King Saul's son, crept into enemy territory till he was right in the barracks, face to face with a swarm of armed soldiers. 'Maybe, just maybe, this wasn't such a good idea after all,' he should have thought. Maybe he should've waited until he got the go-ahead from the intelligence guys back home. Maybe he should've brought more back-up. Maybe he should've waited until all the stars lined up in the sky spelling: 'Attack now, Johnny Boy!' Maybe.

But Jonathan had more faith than that. His belief was proactive. His confidence in God was the dangerous type. '...It may be that the Lord will work for us' was his attitude. And his certainty in God started off a chain reaction in the Philistines' camp that led to victory for Israel.

The point of the story isn't that God rewards mavericks who go off and do their own thing. It's more a lesson in finding out what pleases God, then doing it. If you wait for perfect conditions you'll never achieve anything.

A lot of impressive God-go-getters haven't necessarily received clear instructions in how to change the world. They merely act on a hunch of what they believe pleases God. So you haven't specifically heard God ask you to volunteer for the coffee roster...but maybe He'd be pleased if you did. Here's the thing; you're going to face a lot more of 'maybe' than 'definitely' in life. But your faith won't grow unless you act and give God the opportunity to turn your 'maybe' into a 'definitely'.



SoulFood: Matt 28:16-20, 2 Cor 13:14, Jn 1:18, Jn 15:18-26

content.title: Definitely Maybe (2)
content.introtext:
'...it may be that the Lord will work for us...' 1 Samuel 14:6 NKJ

Go over yesterday's story again. The problem with this story is we can use it to justify what we want, in the hope that God will bless our 'maybe' with a 'definitely'. Jonathan wasn't on some killing spree for the sake of it. He had a strong understanding of God's justice.

The Philistines were violently opposed to God's people. They enslaved Jewish men and violated Jewish women. Remember Goliath? He was a mouthpiece for the Philistines-he publicly rained down curses on God. In short, Jonathan wasn't making trouble-he was seizing a chance for justice. Rule one for chancing a 'maybe' with God: make sure your motives are just.

Jonathan wasn't some opportunist who knew nothing about God. Reading our Bibles we get a picture of an upright man who cared deeply about God being glorified. He was a man of faith. Rule two: Unless you have a proven track record of stepping out in faith make sure you're getting sound advice before placing all bets on a 'maybe'.

The Bible warns of people who want something to happen, and presume God does too. Jonathan's father King Saul is led to his own downfall because he expected God to rubberstamp his own agenda. The difference with Jonathan was that his heart was right before God. Rule three: To turn your 'maybe' into a miracle takes wisdom and a desire to see God's will be done.



SoulFood: Judges 7:1-9:33, Mark 14:27-42, Ps 124, Pr 12:26-28

content.title: The Waiting Game
content.introtext:
'Let patience have its perfect work...' James 1:4 NKJ

Mike Pilavachi once wisely compared answered prayer to a tortoise. Think about it, a tortoise dawdles at an incredibly slooooow pace. Occasionally the answers to our prayers can seem a long time coming. We send one up to God and it's as if He straps the answer to the shell of a tortoise. The trouble is, often we give up waiting and so the tortoise, having only made it half way to us, turns round and heads back home.

Our culture hates waiting. We've got steam blowing out of our ears if we have to wait ten minutes in a queue. We get twitchy fingers waiting for our computers to boot up. And heaven help the fast food chain that keeps us waiting five minutes on our quarter pounder. We carry our twitching fingers and steaming ears into our prayer life.

But God just isn't in the same rush as us when it comes to relationship. '...if we look forward to something we don't have yet, we must wait patiently and confidently. And the Holy Spirit helps us in our distress.' (Romans 8:25-26 NLT)

Perhaps God sometimes keeps us waiting because He wants us to be more thankful for the giver than the gift. You wouldn't give up on your mum just because she won't give you your Christmas present in August; nor should we give up on God just because He hasn't given us an answer out of season.



SoulFood: Judges 9:34-11:40, Mark 14:43-52, Ps 129, Pr 20:25, Ecc 5:4-6

content.title: When Nobody's Looking
content.introtext:
'Glancing this way and that and seeing no one...' Exodus 2:12 NIV

Nice work, Moses. The guy was asking for it, exploiting the poor like that, striking the other bloke like a dumb animal. Slavery is evil. Who wouldn't have brought down a large boulder on his skull? One question though: if what you did was right, Moses, why are you trying to cover it up? Why are you dragging a corpse down around the back of the pyramids? Why are you looking to hide the bloodstained body?

Ever done something wrong when nobody was watching? Late-night channel hopping and you land on planet porn? Downloading that album not yet out in the shops? Sneaking into your mum's purse? Nice work. Got away with that one. Nobody has seen me. Except God, of course. God sees everything. When we know we can get away with it, but we still choose not give in to temptation, God smiles.

But what if the pull is too strong? After all we're only human. That's when we need to get some accountability. Be answerable to someone wise and trustworthy. Let them know your struggles and ask them to support you. Avoid situations that are likely to lure you. Set a curfew on your viewing habits. Allow your accountability partner access to your smartphone. Remember, 'the temptations that come into your life are no different from what others experience...' (1 Corinthians 10:13 NLT)

content.title: Just Enough
content.introtext:
'...Each family had just what it needed.' Exodus 16:18 NLT

Each day brought the same worry, the same temptation: What if God doesn't provide tomorrow? What if we wake up in the morning and there isn't a dish of manna in sight? Isn't it best we store a little away tonight just in case tomorrow the cupboard is bare? Whenever the Israelites disobeyed the commandment from God and hoarded the stuff, then maggots turned up, rats nibbled at it or the manna just turned a bit green and furry. God provided enough for one day at a time: 'Everyone had just enough. Those who gathered a lot had nothing left over, and those who gathered...a little had enough. Each family had just what it needed.'

Are you stuck out in your own wilderness? Do you worry that God might not turn up tomorrow? Are you tempted to solve your own problems, completely bypassing God in the process? Stay strong. When you're going through a 'just enough' season God is teaching you to trust Him on a daily basis. Yeah sure, sometimes it can seem like an hourly basis. He's allowing you to taste this verse for real: '...His mercies...are new every morning...' (Lamentations 3:22-23 NCV)

God never lets us gather tomorrow's manna today. Philippians 4:19 NKJ says He will 'supply all your need according to His riches in glory.' God wants you to rely on the Giver not the gift, to trust Him with your needs, and to learn that He always brings good out of bad situations.

content.title: Renovation Work (1)
content.introtext:
'And He...said, "Behold, I make all things new..."' Revelation 21:5 NKJ

You probably have a mate who bought a bomb of a car and was full of talk about how he was going to do it up and turn it into a 'show car'. But at the end of the day his lack of skill, combined with no planning and very little cash, meant that all he achieved was a more expensive old bomb of a car. He expected too much return for too little investment (and he probably never listened to the experts). Well, maybe there are warning signs there for us as we look at renovating our lives.

First, do we expect too much when investing very little? John Wesley said, 'God does nothing but by prayer, and everything with it.' We know that God works through prayer. We read or hear testimonies of people changed by the power of prayer. All of Jesus' significant moments are prepped in prayer: before He picked His disciples, He was up all night in prayer; He walked on water following a quiet prayer time; before the cross, He sweated blood through prayer. It's clear-we can't expect a great change in our lives without first investing in time alone with God.

Secondly, do we listen to the expert? Prayer can easily become a one way dialogue. We want God to bless our agenda, our shopping list. But prayer should be the moment we lock into God's will. We need to make time to listen to Him through reading our Bible and expecting to hear His voice. 'The Lord is close to all who call on Him, yes, to all who call on Him sincerely.' (Psalm 145:18 NLT)

'And He...said, "Behold, I make all things new..."' Revelation 21:5 NKJ

A classic mistake of the wannabe property developers we see on the TV 'reality' shows is they forget the original purpose of the project: to make money.

Half the budget will go on a set of Edwardian taps because one of the team simply adores the way they curve like a swan's neck. The experts will remind them that this expense will be subtracted from the profit. But by now they're more interested in period plumbing!

What can we learn from this when renovating our own lives? Purpose. Ephesians 1:11 NLT reminds us, '...because of Christ, we have received an inheritance from God, for He chose us from the beginning, and all things happen just as He decided long ago.'

It's all too easy to veer off-project and forget your original purpose. You weren't placed on this earth to get a good job or make money or become famous. You are on assignment here on this earth-your purpose, to glorify God and reflect His beauty through your relationship with Him. Everything else merely subtracts from your profit. Don't blow your budget on secondary stuff, stockpile treasure in Heaven instead. Remind yourself today, I'm here on this earth to know God and make Him known. My purpose finds meaning through God.

content.title: Renovation Work (3)
content.introtext:
'And He...said, "Behold, I make all things new..."' Revelation 21:5 NKJ

The best part of any TV home renovation show is saved until the end of the programme. Through the marvel of editing, the director switches from one shot of a run-down, dilapidated dump to the next shot of a sparkling first-time buyer's dream home, complete with new kitchen, sanded floorboards and magnolia walls. The transformation is evident. The house viewers are oblivious to the trials and tantrums and breakdowns the team sweated through to renovate their pile of bricks.

Christian biographies can sometimes use the director's clever editing trick too. We read stories of these heroes of faith who have conquered the world for Christ in their lunch hour. And we look at the pile of bricks of our lives and feel disheartened.

Well, books condense a lifetime of God's work in someone's life to dozen chapters or so. Fact is, four chapters of Billy Graham cutting his toenails or Corrie ten Boom paying the electricity bill doesn't sell books. Heroes of faith have to plod through the mundane moments and discouragements of everyday living as much as we do. They're as faithful in the small things as the public things. So you didn't raise the dead in your coffee break? But did you dare pray for your mate's headache? Honour God in the smaller things and He'll take you one step at a time to the bigger things. He'll turn your pile of bricks into something really impressive.

content.title: The Secret of My Success
content.introtext:
'For the Lord gives wisdom...' Proverbs 2:6 NKJ

Just visit any bookshop and you'll see shelves and shelves of paperbacks all promising the secret to success or the promise of a happy life. The 'Business' section promises the key to mega-wealth. 'Mind, Body and Spirit' promises the road to spiritual bliss. 'Biography' promises the hush-hush secrets to triumphant living.

Jesus warned us not to be gullible: '...the road is wide that leads to hell, and many people enter through that gate. But the...road is narrow that leads to true life. Only a few people find that road. Be careful of false prophets. They come to you looking gentle like sheep, but they are really dangerous like wolves.' (Matthew 7:13-15 NCV)

Fulfilment Jesus-style is measured in service. Over and over He said not to push yourself to the top, but instead help others there. 'Whoever wants to become great among you must serve the rest...' (Matthew 20:26 NCV)

If you want to be a success, Jesus suggested, you're going to need more help than your own brain power and muscle: 'A person cannot receive even one thing unless it is given him from Heaven.' (John 3:27 ESV) This is why prayer is a must for any wannabe success story. Prayer sketches up God's drafts for your life. Without it you're basing your living on guesswork and flukes.

Finally, keep your eyes open for the 'wise ones' God has placed in your path. Success heeds the advice of others: 'Plans fail without good advice, but they succeed with the advice of many others.' (Proverbs 15:22 NCV)



SoulFood: Gal 4-6, Mark 15:33-47, Ps 143, Pr 13:9-10

content.title: Task-Focused
content.introtext:
'...This job is too heavy...to handle...by yourself.' Exodus 18:18 NLT

There's gifted and talented, then there's Michelangelo. The ultimate Renaissance man, this guy excelled as a painter, sculptor, and architect. Jon Walker writes: 'Imagine if God created you to be the Michelangelo of this age but you stayed so busy doing all kinds of things-good things-that you never got around to painting and sculpting. You'd end up missing the best because you got distracted chasing the good. What a disappointment...for God...and all the people who would have been blessed if you'd stayed focused on your original purpose.' Likewise, imagine if Michelangelo never got round to painting the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel because he was too busy undercoating the walls of his neighbour's spare room. This isn't meant to put down generous acts (God is the proud sponsor of generosity), it's a wake-up call to staying on task with whatever God has predestined you to do.

The world is jam-packed with 'needs' and 'needy people' but God doesn't expect you to be the solution to every need. Moses learned the same lesson, when he spent every waking moment dealing with complaints from long lines of people. His father-in-law said, 'You're going to wear yourself out-and the people, too,' and advised him to appoint capable leaders to 'help...carry the load.' (Exodus 18:18;22 NLT) It was a win-win solution-the people got help faster, and Moses became a better leader. Release the load God never meant you to carry, and focus on what He called you to do.

content.title: Real Love
content.introtext:
'...sexual sin, perversion of any kind, or greed...is not appropriate behaviour for God's holy people.' Ephesians 5:3 GWT

It's hard going, this Christian commitment thing. It seems the whole world is pairing off while you're left alone with a bunch of rules for company: 'No sex outside marriage. No dating non-believers. No tempting others. No fantasising. No visiting porn websites.'

First, despite popular belief (or unbelief if you like) God is for sex. He invented it. He planned it out so intimacy feels good. Good idea, God, nice one. However, God understands (far more than we do) that relationships need to be built upon things with a little more substance than mere flesh on flesh.

Trust, unswerving love, commitment, compatibility, romance and sex all need the parameters of a long-term relationship such as marriage. Without it, we cheapen ourselves and each other. Secondly, if God really does mean the world to you, why would you want to spend all your time with someone who won't even acknowledge Him? The rule for not dating non-believers is to protect you. Sooner or later your loyalty to God or your beloved will be stretched. Who needs that brain-stretch right? So don't sell yourself short, wait and enjoy God's best-it's worth it!

content.title: Memory Verse
content.introtext:
'The word is near you, in your mouth and in your heart.' Romans 10:8 NKJ

Now be honest, how many times do you actually read the day's verse that accompanies the reading. I mean really read it? Not just catch a quick glance as you dig into the larger paragraph for a bit of direction. This isn't some kind of Christian horoscope you know-the idea is to be inspired to crack open your Bible.

word4U2day isn't God-breathed-only Scripture is. So, use this little booklet to awaken your taste buds to the real thing. In fact, why not start memorising some of the verses each day?

Here's how: choose a time when you're free from distraction. Read the verse again and again. Say it out loud because hearing your own voice will help cement it. Go away and come back to it. Try repeating it when you're waiting for a bus or going for a jog or in the shower. Write it down over and over again. Test yourself on it the next day.

Being proactive with God's Word will pay dividends. When you need direction the Holy Spirit will be able to bring it to mind. When someone asks for your help the answer they need might pop up in a verse. When you're tempted to stray the right verse may reframe your thinking. Jesus promised that whoever hears His words and puts them into action will stand strong when times of trouble come (learn it in Luke 6:46-49).



SoulFood: Ex 34:27-35, 2 Cor 3:7-18

content.title: Shipwrecked
content.introtext:
'I have faith in God that it will happen just as He told me.' Acts 27:25 NIV

It seemed like a monster was eating the ship. A violent wind pulled at the sails, lightning sizzled the mast, twenty metre high waves kept dunking the boat's bow in and out of the water. The sea thrashed across the deck, spilling men into its hungry belly. The sailors were sure they were never going to reach Rome alive. And it all could've been avoided.

Paul wasn't one for saying, 'I told you so.' He'd already warned them, 'Men, I can see that our voyage is going to be disastrous and bring great loss.' (Acts 27:9 NIV) But the majority had sided with the captain and so they set sail.

Lesson one: Listening to the majority doesn't make you right. Sometimes listening to God may go against human logic. Lesson two: God always brings good out of our mistakes. Despite Paul's warning, they ended up shipwrecked in Malta. Instead of arguing about who was to blame, Paul channelled his energy into spreading the Gospel.

When we slip up, rather than play the blame game, we'd do well to see what God is up to through our mistakes. Lesson three: Whatever we've lost, God can find again. All of Paul's belongings are forever lost at sea (or in the belly of some octopus) and yet Acts 28:10 tells us the people of Malta finally sent Paul away loaded with supplies.



SoulFood: Rev 5-9, Matt 24:15-25, Ps 116:1-11, Pr 8:8-9

content.title: Send Me-I Will Go!
content.introtext:
'Who will go for us?' Isaiah 6:8 NIV

Sitting in his office scribbling down notes for a meeting, a man looks up from his desk and glances out the window. A king whose face burns like fire appears, seated on a throne of clouds. Isaiah takes off his glasses, gives them a wipe and wonders if he's got a fever. He sees the king's robes trail down from the sky and flow into a church. He rubs his eyes and peeks out between his fingers. Angels are darting across the roof, sparkling like rainbow-coloured fireworks. A voice booms: 'Whom shall I send? Who will go for us?'

Isaiah tears himself from his desk and steps towards the light. 'Here I am. Send me.'

Isaiah chapter 6 records the details of Isaiah's full cinematic spiritual experience: visions, voices and warm glowy feelings. But he knew he couldn't stay wrapped up in the moment. Soon after saying, 'Here I am. Send me,' the prophet took his experience and went into the world outside with his message. He faced opposition, hard hearts and faith-testing times but still Isaiah had to go. What about you? So the fuzzy feelings of summer conferences have gone. You remember touching God's heart so close only a month ago. But where are your godly goosebumps now, eh?

Well, like Isaiah, now is the time to leave the cinematic stuff and step out into the hurting world with God's message. Whom shall He send? You?

content.title: Sitting on the Fence (1)
content.introtext:
'Like an ocean wave tossed around in a storm.' James 1:6 CEV

From the top of the hill the hard-talking warrior could be seen by all. His dry, rasping voice carried through the valley, bouncing off stones straight into the hearts of men, women and children. Some of these men had lost brothers, some of the women had given sons to bloodthirsty wars. But nobody had quite showed the bravery of Joshua. Like a lion protecting its cubs he'd fought for the future of his people. And they'd all reached the moment when they had to decide which way they were heading.

He urged them to ditch their useless wooden idols and godless bits of superstitious metal on the other side of the river. 'Stop running hot, then cold. Worship the living God or put your faith in superstition-but don't insult the Heavens by trying to do both. As for me and my family, we will worship God,' Joshua concludes. The crowds growl in agreement.

Do you have one foot in God's side of the fence and another in your own backyard? Chances are you feel down more than up. You feel frustrated at your lot in life. You go round in circles chasing your tail. Your life stops and starts. Unless you choose to follow God wholeheartedly like Joshua you're going to experience life like a wave tossed around in a storm. Don't be full of religious sales talk-live like you believe God is God.



SoulFood: Rev 15-18, Matt 24:36-51, Ps 13, Pr 8:14-16

content.title: Sitting on the Fence (2)
content.introtext:
'Like an ocean wave tossed around in a storm.' James 1:6 CEV

James chews on the end of his pen. His mind tries its hardest to reach for the perfect image. He needs to find a way of describing a problem with these early Christians. He scratches his beard and mutters to himself, 'What good is a truth if they don't know how to live it? What good is an intention if they can't follow it through?'

The trouble is they have the right words, they know all the jargon, they've passed the theory but they keep flunking the practical. They say one thing and then do the other. They're as consistent as ocean waves in a storm, hurling themselves one way, raging themselves the other. 'Wait! That's it!' He scribbles: '...a doubtful mind is as unsettled as a wave of the sea that is driven and tossed by the wind.' (James 1:6 NLT)

Lots of us are up and down like wind-whipped waves, furiously trying to do things our way, trying to have the casting vote. But didn't Jesus teach us to pray, 'Your will be done'? Shouldn't God have the controls, not us? Grasping and holding tight to things makes us look like toddlers pulling tantrums. The mature believer recognises that 'if you try to keep your life for yourself, you will lose it. But if you give up your life for [Jesus], you will find true life.' (Matthew 16:25 NLT) So stop behaving like a wave blown about on the ocean and start trusting God.



SoulFood: Rev 19-22, Matt 25:1-13, Ps 55:1-11, Pr 8:17-18

content.title: What Sank The Titanic?
content.introtext:
'These things happened...as...warnings for us.' 1 Corinthians 10:11 NIV

Contrary to popular belief it wasn't Celine Dion's My Heart Will Go On that sank the Titanic. The 270m ocean liner went down in 1912 on its first voyage from England to New York, sunk by an iceberg. Recently, scientists used sound waves to probe through the wreckage, which is buried in mud four kilometres underwater. Here's what they were surprised to discover: the damage was surprisingly small. Instead of a huge gash, they found six relatively narrow slits across the six watertight holds. 'Everything that could go wrong, did,' said William Garzke Jr, a naval architect who helped the team with their analysis.

So, what sank the Titanic? Four things-things that could sink you too! First, they thought they were immune, that it couldn't happen to them. Secondly, they were 'asleep at the wheel' and failed to heed five different warnings. Thirdly, it wasn't one big thing, but a series of small things that took them under. Finally, the problem that finally destroyed them was hidden beneath the waterline, out of sight. The Bible says, 'These things happened to them as examples and were written down as warnings for us... So, if you think you are standing firm, be careful that you don't fall!' (1 Corinthians 10:11-12 NIV) Not one of us, however strong, wise, successful or good, is immune to failure. Staying close to God will help make sure the iceberg of a mistake won't sink you.



SoulFood: 2 Kings 1:1-4:17, Matt 25:14-30, Ps 55:12-23, Pr 8:19-21

content.title: Seeing Sense
content.introtext:
'When he came to his senses...' Luke 15:17 NIV

The parable of the prodigal son is a stark reminder that actually we don't always know best. '...a man had two sons. The younger one said...Father, give me my share... Not long after...[he]...set off for a distant country and there squandered his wealth in wild living. After he had spent everything, there was a severe famine...and he began to be in need. So he went and hired himself out...to feed pigs. He longed to fill his stomach with the pods that the pigs were eating, but no one gave him anything.' (Luke HYPERLINK "http://biblia.com/bible/niv/Luke 15.11-16"15:11-16 NIV) When God says 'no', He has a very good reason. When He pulls back on your reins, listen. It's better to be alone and walk with God than be surrounded by people but away from God. If you are waiting for things to improve start doing things God's way! Are you willing to repent and come back home? In three back-to-back parables in Luke 15, Jesus points out that the shepherd went looking for his lost sheep, the woman went looking for her lost silver, but nobody went looking for the lost son. That's because he knew the way back. And it happened when 'he came to his senses'. The rebel who left dad saying, 'Give me,' humbled himself and came back saying, 'Forgive me.' When he did, his dad embraced him and said, 'This son of mine was...lost and is found...' (Luke 15:24 NIV) Your Heavenly Father is waiting to welcome you home too.

content.title: Be the Right Stuff
content.introtext:
'To Philemon our beloved friend and fellow labourer.' Philemon 1:1 NKJ

Paul called Philemon 'our beloved friend and fellow labourer.' Obviously Paul had found a guy with the right stuff. How do you become 'the right stuff'?

First, have the right frame of mind. Life has a funny habit of throwing mud against your window to see what sticks. Well, refuse to become a prisoner of circumstances. You can't control what happens to you but you can control how you react. 'Don't worry about anything; instead, pray about everything. Tell God what you need, and thank Him for all he has done. If you do this, you will experience God's peace, which is far more wonderful than the human mind can understand.' (Philippians 4:6-7 NLT) Secondly, accept forgiveness. Don't let past failures haunt you. Don't rummage around your old sin-bin looking for excuses for failure. Admit them. Learn from them. And move on. 'Your sins have been forgiven because of Jesus.' (1 John 2:12 NLT)

Thirdly, be grateful. The day is too short to waste hours of it in self-pity, worry or boredom. This is the day that the Lord has made. Enjoy it like a child, use it to break records and write history. When tomorrow comes, today will be gone forever. So while it's still alive use it for loving, living and giving to God. 'I know the Lord is always with me. I will not be shaken, for He is right beside me. No wonder my heart is filled with joy, and my mouth shouts His praises! My body rests in safety.' (Psalm 16:8-9 NLT)



SoulFood: Joshua 6:1-25, Lk 7:36-50

content.title: Help
content.introtext:
'My help comes from the Lord...' Psalm 121:2 NKJ

Did you hear about the guy who prayed, 'Lord, so far today I've done all right. I haven't gossiped, lost my temper, been nasty, greedy or grumpy. But in a few minutes I'm gonna have to get out of bed, then I'm gonna need all the help I can get.'

We smile, but the truth is, we need God more than we let on. Sure, prayer comes in handy when we've got that exam coming up or that relationship to mend, but we can blank God out when it comes to irritable parts of our behaviour. Like when we lose our cool, or we come across that bit of juicy goss about that semi-friend that we've just got to post on Facebook? Well, we could always pray for more patience or that God will give us the strength to do what's right. When things seem so rotten we think we may as well bring the whole world down with us, maybe we could look for ways to bring God's goodness into the situation.

God's help doesn't have to be reserved solely for all the crisis situations in your life. You can ask for help in your everyday stresses and strains, you can ask for help in gently refining your character, you can even ask for help on behalf of others.

content.title: For Things To Go Well
content.introtext:
'...that it might go well with [you].' Deuteronomy 5:29 NIV

When God tells you to do something that seems difficult or unpleasant, He's not trying to make your life hard or put you in a straitjacket. Often He's just getting you to a place where He can bless you: 'Oh, that...[they]...would...keep all My commands always, so that it might go well with them.'

Everything God asks you to do carries this thought with it: that it might go well with you. Living in peace, instead of going to pieces, is easier when you learn to respond to God immediately. Don't hesitate. Don't negotiate. Don't rationalise. And whatever you do, don't run. The only thing that's worse than running away from God is living with the painful aftermath. Your disobedience can take you all the way to the bottom. If you doubt that, stop and read the story of Jonah.

The prophet Samuel said, 'to obey is better than sacrifice.' (1 Samuel 15:22 NIV) The truth is, sometimes you'll have to sacrifice certain things in order to obey God. But it's better to do that than to ignore His voice, live stressed out, forfeit His blessings, and end up getting nowhere.

Sometimes God will require things of you that He doesn't seem to require of others; things that He won't explain, and you can't understand; even things that when you've obeyed them, you won't immediately see the benefits of. But if you're convinced that He loves you and has a plan for your life, you'll surrender to Him in trust, knowing that in the end it will indeed go well with you.



SoulFood: Num 25-26, Matt 17:1-13, Ps 36, Pr 5:21-23

content.title: Job
content.introtext:
'You shall remember it as waters that pass away.' Job 11:16 AMP

Job had an exemplary track record and still he was knocked down. Some people live fast and play loose with the rules and get what they deserve. Not Job: he got a large portion of undeserved suffering. He lost children through natural disasters. He lost everything he ever worked for through unforeseen circumstances. His marriage took the strain of his faith. And to top it all: the doctor's results came in, and it wasn't good news at all.

Job's 'ad-man's dream life' was flushed away and he was left with lots of questions-questions he may never have found answers for, this side of Heaven anyway. Job was bewildered; Job was outraged; Job eventually protested to God. But still the pain ate away at his heart. And in the midst of his suffering his pain was hammered home daily by his 'friends'.

Ever notice how some people slow down to look at a car crash? Well, that's Job's 'I told you so' mates. They showed up hourly trying to identify and fix Job's problems. They reduced God's invitation to follow Him into sure-fire formulas of 'do this and don't do that', 'think this and don't think that'. Hey presto, life is bound to be rosy again. Zophar even went as far as to suggest: 'You will forget your trouble and darkness will seem like morning.' (Job 11:16 NCV) To Job's credit, he rejects all the glib answers and stays honest in the face of old clich. His persistence allows God, in time, to talk through the troubles.



SoulFood: Num 27-29, Matt 17:14-27, Ps 40:1-8, Pr 6:1-5

content.title: One For All
content.introtext:
'But Christ gave Himself...one sacrifice for all time.' Hebrews 10:12 TLB

The lamb struggled as the priest wrestled it to the altar. With one firm hand on its writhing body, he brought the blade down onto the innocent animal. Its blood was poured out for the sins of many. Soon smoke would rise to the heavens and, as a sign that sins were forgiven, the priest would stand on the remaining ashes sprinkled to the ground.

The picture for burning up sin in the Old Testament was a gruesome one. And yet every year the same picture was re-enacted: sin had to paid for again and again. The New Testament would draw an even bloodier picture. Replace the innocent lamb with an innocent man. With one firm hand on His body, a soldier brought down a hammer onto His hands. His blood was poured out for the sins of many. A cross was pointed to the heavens and, as a sign that sins were forgiven, a man died in between two criminals.

Every year around autumn that picture is remembered as the one-off payment for sins forever-Easter. If you've been struggling with what you've done or what you keep doing, don't beat yourself up-your one-off forever payment has already been made. 'Your sins have been forgiven because of Jesus.' (1 John 2:12 NLT)

content.introtext:
'I am still confident of this: I will see the goodness of the Lord...' Psalm 27:13 NIV

Feel like there's always some bruiser of a situation rugby-tackling you from behind? When the hard times throw you to the ground, you're not alone. Check out Paul's 'tough time' catalogue!

'I have...been in danger from rivers, thieves, my own people, the Jews, and those who are not Jews. I have been in danger in cities...and on the sea and...with false Christians. I have done hard and tiring work, and many times I did not sleep. I have been hungry and thirsty...without food...cold and without clothes. Besides all this, there is on me every day the load of my concern for all the churches.' (2 Corinthians 11:26-28 NCV) Phew! Had he handed in a 'Please excuse Paul from anything churchy' note from his mum, you'd have understood!

How did Paul handle these experiences? By 'forgetting the past and looking forward to what lies ahead.' (Philippians 3:13 NLT) Now, Paul didn't actually forget any of it-he could remember names, places and faces-but here's the difference: he refused to let all the trouble of the past influence him. He turned history into destiny. That's the kind of brainwave you need to surf as well. Press 'Delete' on the past and hit 'Enter' on your future. Have the faith that saw the Psalmist through: 'I am still confident of this: I will see the goodness of the Lord in the land of the living.'

content.title: Blow It!
content.introtext:
'To the Lord I cry aloud, and He answers me...' Psalm 3:4 NIV

It was as if the words just flooded into his mind at the right time... He opened his mouth and verses of Scripture he never realised he knew so well just spilled out. And as he spoke (well, shouted really) he could feel the crowd hanging on to every syllable; he could see their belated realisation of the truth. Now was the moment to ask if anyone would like to give their lives to Christ. To his amazement three thousand hands rose into the air. Not a bad preaching debut for Peter. And he wasn't even using notes!

Acts 2 is a real high point for Peter, a far cry from only a month or so before when he'd disgracefully disowned Jesus in His hour of need. Thankfully for us, God is brimming over with second chances. Here was a man who had slipped up big time and yet God used him as the groundwork for His church. You see when you slip up, all God requires is a dose of honesty and apology to get you in line with His will again. After denying Jesus, Peter is quick with the tears and quick to correct his mistake. (Jesus asks him three times if he loves Him; three times Peter utters a big 'I sure do'.)

So you blew it and everyone is only too keen to remind you? Well the Psalmist has been there too: 'Many are saying... God will not deliver him. But...to the Lord I cry aloud, and He answers me.' (Psalm 3:2-4 NIV)

content.title: Heartbreaker
content.introtext:
'When I heard these things, I sat down and wept.' Nehemiah 1:4 NIV

Nehemiah is far from home when he receives the bad news from his brother Hanani: Jerusalem has become a joke. Her very walls are stripped and looted to the bare bones. Once the most beautiful and godly city in the world, now Jerusalem looks like a condemned shack with boarded-up windows. Thieves raided her daily, neighbours spat on her; Jerusalem was treated like a dirty, smelly beggNehemiah's heart was broken. He had to do something about it.

Any work of God starts with weeping. Before laying a single brick, Nehemiah had to be broken. And there's a lesson for us there: passionate talks at summer festivals or heart-wrenching images of the poor may be enough to get us out of the blocks but only tears will sustain us. Unless God's broken us, it's all too easy to give up when the going gets tough. We're distracted by next year's bright idea, we forget why we signed up or we feel let down because it's all too hard.

The thorn that God places in your heart is the best motivation you'll ever need to keep going when the going gets tough. Nehemiah weeps, fasts and prays for days before making his first move to rebuild Jerusalem. Are you in two minds about your calling? Ask God to break your heart with what breaks His. Spend time in solid prayer. Deprive yourself of something time-consuming in order to focus on God.



SoulFood: Jonah 1-4, Matt 19:1-14, Ps 61, Pr 6:16-19

content.title: Rainy Days and Mondays
content.introtext:
'Our light affliction...is working for us.' 2 Corinthians 4:17 NKJ

in Oz we'd like nothing more than sun-and-surf weather 24/7, 365. Being burnt like overdone toast is what we Aussies do best! Yet the wheat in the fields, the cotton in the country and the spuds in the ground wouldn't be too glad of all sunshine and no rain. To get the best out of God's creation it's essential there are other seasons besides the sunny one.

The same is true of the seasons in your faith life. If everything you touched turned to sunshiny gold, it wouldn't be too long before head-swell set in. That's why God also allows us to go through rainy seasons and tough times to grow us. There's nothing quite as ugly as arrogance and God didn't build us to be self-sufficient but God-sufficient. The storms of life lead us to shelter under God's wings, and getting closer to Him can only be a good thing.

Today's verse can seem back-to-front because Paul is saying the misery he's facing works to his advantage. Paul is wise enough to recognise that his weakness is bringing out God's strength: with less of him there is more room for God. What a great way of thinking! Perhaps that's why he could write from experience, 'This foolish plan of God is far wiser than the wisest of human plans, and God's weakness is far stronger than the greatest of human strength.' (1 Corinthians 1:25 NLT)



SoulFood: Titus 1-3, Matt 19:15-30, Ps 66:1-12, Pr 6:20-22

content.title: Trouble At Sea
content.introtext:
'Pharaoh's chariots and his army He has cast into the sea.' Exodus 15:4 NKJ

Pharaoh did not want to be seen as a weak king amongst the nations, folding like a house of cards under the pressure. For 400 years his predecessors had kept the Hebrew people in slavery.

Ok, swarms of locusts had devoured the crops, the Nile had turned blood red and there had been the death of all the firstborn. But as Pharaoh's officials had pointed out, these things were mere coincidences, surely? Now he had to enslave them once more-for his own dignity, at least. So, as the Israelites hurried between the walls of sea, Pharaoh and his men stormed after them like bounty hunters on a mission.

For generations, the Jews would remember how those deafening waves came rolling down on Pharaoh and his armies. And as they sang, 'Pharaoh's chariots and his army He cast into the sea' they would remind themselves of God's intervention in their troubles. They would recall the dividing line between their past and their future. God had saved them when all looked hopeless.

The story reminds us that if God did it for them, He'll do it for us too. Whatever circumstance has you enslaved, God can break through it. He will provide a passage through your sea of trouble and step by step you'll be able to walk in faith into a new future. Meanwhile your haunted past will be drowned for good in the tumbling waves.



SoulFood: Heb 1-4, Matt 20:1-16, Ps 66:13-20, Pr 6:23-25

content.title: Anon
content.introtext:
'[The] parts...that seem...least important are...most necessary.' 1 Corinthians 12:22 NLT

Paul massages his fingers into his temples. Maybe it's because he hasn't eaten or drunk water for days. He must be dehydrated. Or perhaps it's the lack of daylight in this damp, dank, dark jail. Or the lack of oxygen in the two by two metre cell. Or the stress of not knowing whether tomorrow he lives or dies. Perhaps he feels homesick for his Christian brothers and sisters around the world: the wild bunch in Corinth, the joy brigade in Philippi, the bedrock foundation in Jerusalem. Whatever the reason, Paul feels another headache coming on.

He's at a real low. When he hears the footsteps on hard ground down the corridor, he hopes with all his heart it's Onesiphorus. The wild-eyed former slave has visited him most days this past year. Each day he comes with a smile and a hungry heart. His growing faith has been a much-needed source of encouragement for Paul in prison.

Onesiphorus who? Ok, so his name doesn't trip off the tongue quite as easily as Peter or Paul. He's only mentioned twice in the entire Bible. And yet this unknown hero of the faith is a source of strength to an incarcerated Paul. Don't bother asking why God makes some names known and others not-so-known. The point is that everyone, whether named or unnamed, contributes to God's Kingdom. So be encouraged-you may be anonymous but you're essential to the great plan.



SoulFood: Heb 5-8, Matt 20:17-28, Ps 70, Pr 6:26-28

content.title: Super Size Me
content.introtext:
'The pure in heart...shall see God.' Matthew 5:8 NKJ

There's this film called Super Size Me where documentary filmmaker Morgan Spurlock conducts his own dietary experiment. Every meal for a whole month he eats only food from burger chain McDonald's. Surprise, surprise, by the end of his junk food binge we've learned that a regime of Big Mac and fries is not the best idea for your arteries. Likewise, the Bible teaches us that unconfessed sin is not great for your spiritual arteries.

The Psalmist writes, 'Who may stand in [Your] holy place? He who has clean hands and a pure heart... He will receive blessing from the Lord.' (Psalm 24:3-5 NIV) If we want 'God's go-ahead' stamped over our lives we need a healthy heart-none of this sin-junk congealing at the core of us.

Jesus said, 'Blessed are the pure in heart: for they shall see God.' The problem is not God's inability to be seen, but our inability to see Him. No wonder David prayed, 'Create in me a pure heart.' (Psalm 51:10 NIV) This word pure is from the Greek word katharos, which means 'to clean out'. Maybe you don't want to hear it but perhaps your heart needs a spiritual cleansing. Through prayer and fasting, flush out all those nasty sin toxins and clean out your clogged saintly arteries.



SoulFood: Heb 9:1-11:16, Matt 20:29-34, Ps 77, Pr 6:29

content.title: Old School Rules
content.introtext:
'Christ has set us free.' Galatians 5:1 NIV

Moses has got so much to answer for! First there were voices from smouldering shrubbery, then there came frogs and locusts on the weather report and before long there was a whole set of instructions...

The Ten Commandments arrived on blocks of stone but Moses cracked the first set in a rage. So, God carved some more-the trouble is nobody (but Jesus) has cracked how to keep them since. All these rules and regulations have a funny way of highlighting how far we have missed the mark. For all of us who've drooled in envy over next door's new car, mobile phone or sheer good looks, there's a rule: 'Do not covet.' For all of us who've daydreamed about peeking in the dressing room of the opposite sex, there's a rule: 'No lusting.' And for all us best mates who've dared to utter the immortal words, 'No, I never told anyone!' there's a rule: 'Quit with the lies.'

All in all, the standard is so high we'd be doing pretty well if we managed to peel ourselves out of bed before breaking one of these rules. If our salvation depended on us keeping every letter of God's law we'd have no chance. Thankfully, God made a way for us even though we don't live up to perfect standards-He sent His Son Jesus to make us right with Him. Now the rule is to do what Jesus instructed His disciples: 'Follow Me.'



SoulFood: Deut 10:12-21, Col 2:9-15

content.title: Respect The Elect
content.introtext:
'Pray for...all who have authority.' 1 Timothy 2:2 NCV

Maybe your grandad was right when he said, 'Kids of today-they've got no respect!' We've no respect for the Government: 'This Prime Minister is running the country into the ground...' We've no respect for the Police: 'They should be out catching real criminals!' And we've very little respect for the older generation.

1 Timothy reminds us to respect those who have been elected: 'Pray for...all who have authority.' It's easy to jump on the media bandwagon and slate all those in government but not quite so easy to humble yourself and pray for their strength of character. And for the police- maybe instead of muttering about unsolved crime, pray for discernment in law enforcement, thanking God that we're not a lawless nation. As for older people, some cultures have it sorted: the oldest in the community are given a rightful place at the top of the pecking order.

It pleases God when we pray for those in authority. When our prayers allow God to influence the influencers of our world it has to be win/win right? James 1:5 NLT says, 'If you need wisdom, ask...God, and He will give it to you.' Don't we want our leaders to have the wisdom of God? Well then, call out to God for them. Our world is plagued with war, economic crises, trafficking, terrorism-our leaders need the advice of God more than the moaning of men.

content.title: Bright New Seasons
content.introtext:
'To everything there is a season...' Ecclesiastes 3:1 NKJ

No matter how hard you pray, you can't pray your life's seasons away. There are some situations you aren't meant to change-you're just meant to survive! Paul calls these times, '...light and momentary troubles...' (2 Corinthians 4:17 NIV) When you can't change your circumstances you've just got to learn to grow through them.

In winter, trees take advantage of the season to rebuild their strength and prepare to be fruitful next season. Their sap and substance goes underground. Then in the spring it pushes its way back up again in the form of new growth. Looking back over your life you'll find that your achievements are seasonal. Growth comes, then struggle, and so on. Each season has its purpose. God has a reason for not wanting you to be productive all the time. When He allows wintry weather to blow through your life He's getting you ready for spring. One of the issues you'll struggle with through a winter waiting time is the urge to hurry, to make big permanent decisions based on circumstances that are about to change. Don't do it! Every situation doesn't need immediate action. Remember, patience comes from trust, and you can't trust a God you don't know. That's why you need to spend more time getting chilling out with Him and reading His instruction manual.

content.title: The Calling
content.introtext:
'...whatever you do, do it all for the glory of God.' (1 Corinthians 10:31 NIV)

David knew that God had called him before he went to work for King Saul! That's important! You've got to know who you are, not just what you do; otherwise you'll end up working harder at being appreciated than you will at doing your job. That not only sends the wrong signal to your work-mates and supervisors, it also robs you of the solid foundation of security, peacefulness and joy your job provides. God has called you by name, so don't let your self-worth swing like a politician's popularity in an election year, up one day and down the next. You'll end up riding a roller coaster of moodiness and unexpected disappointments. Occasionally you'll enjoy moments of praise, but they may not be sincere, for once others learn you thrive on recognition, they hold the key to manipulating you for their own purposes. So trust your calling, not their opinions.

Thirsting for recognition gives others power over you. That's dangerous! It's hard to hear God's voice when you have tuned your ears to respond to your peer group. Listen: '...whatever you do, do it all for the glory of God.' (1 Corinthians 10:31 NIV) So strive for God's pleasure in everything you do. Put your heart into your work today, doing it all for the glory of God!



SoulFood: 1 Kings 3-5, Matt 21:18-32, Ps 106:1-23, Pr 7:1-2

content.title: 'Fess Up
content.introtext:
'Confess your faults one to another.' James 5:16 KJV

Sometimes God asks us to do things that can seem stupid or scary, like this for example: 'Confess your faults one to another.' How stupid does that sound? No one in their right mind wants their bad behaviour made front page news! How scary would it be letting someone know the stuff you spend all your time trying to hide? Why would God ask us to do this?

With God there is always a good reason. When we try and hide bad habits, we give them a stronger hold on us. They become harder to stop and difficult to break. But the moment we tell someone it begins to lose its power. The Bible says, 'Pity the man who falls and has no one to help him up! ...Though one may be overpowered, two can defend themselves.' (Ecclesiastes 4:10-12 NIV) God never intended us to go through life dealing with the tough stuff alone which is why He says, 'Confess your faults one to another and pray one for another, that you may be healed.'

If there's something in your life that you're keeping secret, if you are struggling to break a habit that's trying to break you, talk to someone about it today. But who? Tell who? Someone you can trust, maybe someone who's been through what you're going through, but definitely someone who's compassionate, someone who'll pray with you, someone who'll hold you accountable, someone who'll keep your confidence. Ask God to help find you the right person and then confess your faults, and let God heal you.



SoulFood: 1 Kings 6-7, Matt 21:33-46, Ps 106:24-48, Pr 7:3-5

content.title: Running the race
content.introtext:
'One thing I do...' Philippians 3:13 NKJ

Many Christians look more like a kid in the egg and spoon race than a sleek, speedy Kenyan in a marathon. We stumble and fumble in our Christian race trying to balance the egg on the spoon, not really running in a straight line-whereas we should be taking elegant stride after stride, steady and focused, running with sustained stamina.

Kenya has a rich tradition of producing the world's best endurance runners. Their athletes tend to run from the front in threes. They work as a team, setting the pace together and taking it in turns to do the hard bit in leading. If we're going to do the hard bit of leading we would do well to surround ourselves with like-minded, spiritually-fit Christians to urge us on in our running.

Kenyan athletes tend to make distant running look like poetry, gliding round the track with presence and purpose. We'd do well to command an authority like theirs in our circles; to move with a similar determination in our run with God. Kenyan athletes tend to save fuel for a final burst in the last lap. We should be so built up in prayer reserves that we can surprise any opposition with a sudden kick when needed.



SoulFood: 1 Kings 8-9, Matt 22:1-14, Ps 112, Pr 7:6-9

content.title: That's Not My Name!
content.introtext:
'His father called him Benjamin.' Genesis 35:18 NKJ

You could have heard the screams right across the camp. Long into the night the woman tossed and turned on her bed. The midwife mopped the sweat from the woman's forehead. Each pain, each contraction made Jacob wince. This was hard labour. Hard, hard labour. And there were no epidurals, no gas and air, no nothing out there in the desert. The woman strained to push, colour drained from her face-the unborn child was taking the very life from Rachel. She was barely conscious as she gasped these last words: 'Name the child Ben-oni, for he is the son of my pain.'

Moments later Jacob cradled his newborn son, taken from the lifeless arms of his deceased wife. From that moment on, every time Jacob looked into the eyes of his son he saw the eyes of his wife. He would remember the pain and the way life seemed to drift out of her eyes at the very moment he held his son for the first time. And so son of my pain seemed an apt name. Yet Jacob renamed the child 'Benjamin', son of my right hand. Benjamin would not be a reminder of pain but of God's sovereign power.

So hear this: you are who God says you are, not who otherssay you are! Only believe what God says about you.

content.title: Lessons From The Liberator
content.introtext:
'God has appointed...teachers...' 1 Corinthians 12:28 NKJ

So what do you remember teachers for? Their talent for steaming at the ears over a forgotten set of PE gear? Their gift for sending students to sleep? No doubt you've had many good teachers growing up.

The best teachers seem to have an effortless knack of drawing you into their world. They don't so much pass on information as make it come to life. They have the power to inspire and motivate. They help you see the planet at an entire new tilt.

Take Jesus. He was a young, magnetic teacher with the skill to make fishermen put down their nets and walk away from their jobs for unpaid employment. He was such a fascinating speaker he could bring a whole working city to a standstill just to hear one of his lectures. His teachings are so compelling they can still draw millions of people around the globe to hear them on a Sunday two thousand years after He first taught them.

Real teaching doesn't stay in a textbook-it writes itself into the lives of its students. Jesus taught about justice and so William Wilberforce determined to abolish the slave trade. Jesus taught about poverty and so William Booth opened hostels, hospitals, schools and soup kitchens. Jesus taught wherever He went and so John Wesley covered over twelve thousand kilometres a year by horseback in order to preach. Take a class from history's most inspirational teacher and then write His lessons into the world around you.



SoulFood: Phil 4:4-13, Gen 11:1-9

content.title: Pray Today
content.introtext:
'Noah, warned by God...[saved] his household.' Hebrews 11:7 NRS

The sales assistant sniggered when he sold the old man such a large amount of wood. 'A boat! You're going to build a boat in the outback. Good luck!' Then he added, 'Oh, and the wood is non-returnable.'

The neighbours complained to the local council; the thing was so big it blocked the view from their windows. And finally, when the animals started arriving, so did the animal rights protesters. They objected to the dark, cramped conditions the poor critters were subjected to by this religious nutter. What had possessed Noah to take up the world's craziest woodwork project in the first place?

The answer was faith. All the doubters and gripers could see with their own eyes was what a ludicrous thing Noah was attempting. But Noah had heard from God. He must've been really close to God to hear such a thing. Nobody else was busy boat-building. Everybody else was oblivious to the approaching danger. Noah must've had some pretty interesting prayer-journal entries going in order to decide to act upon what he heard. Nobody builds a massive boat in the middle of nowhere. Not unless you distinctly hear God, anyway.

Noah saved his family and, ultimately, humankind through his act of faith. God has some saving assignments for you too-but unless you stay close, you'll never hear the instructions.

content.title: Youth of Today, Tsch!
content.introtext:
'Don't let anyone look down on you because you are young.' 1 Timothy 4:12 NIV

A kid sits staring out a classroom window. The sun is shining on the sports field, some kids in PE gear are playing cricket. 'And here am I stuck in RE learning nothing,' he thinks to himself. But as he looks at the bright clear skies, something amazing happens. A face seems to appear like lightning in the blue cloudless heavens. The sun is sparkling all around and yet there is lightning. And a voice cracks open the earth, louder than a volcano erupting at the next desk.

Yet the kids still chase a ball on the field, classmates keep their heads in textbooks. A finger like a flaming torch shoots through the window and touches the kid's lips. 'Before you even made an appearance on your mum's first baby scan, I'd singled you out. I'm giving you the job of my top spokesperson for the world.'

Jeremiah looks around. The teacher takes a swig of coffee and continues with his marking. 'Me? A spokes-what? But I'm just a kid. I haven't even taken my final exams yet!'

The kid next to him covers his answers. 'Never believe the I'm too young thing.'

And with that, Jeremiah shot across the room with the sheer power of the words he was given. Youth and inexperience do not disqualify when God calls. The beginning of Jeremiah's story shows that God always equips and supports those He appoints despite their lack of years or job history.



SoulFood: 1 Kings 16:1-18:15, Matt 23:1-12, Ps 26, Pr 7:26-27

content.title: Bless You, Bless Me
content.introtext:
'The Lord has blessed me for your sake.' Genesis 30:27 NKJ

Jacob: 'I want to go back home. Let me take my wives and children...and let me be on my way. You know I have fully paid for them with my service to you.' (Genesis 30:25-26 NLT)

Laban had to think fast. He knew how things had improved ever since Jacob had arrived. A few straggly animals had turned to fields of grazing cattle under Jacob's care. Sheep were producing knitwear, cows were manufacturing milkshake and the goats' cheese never tasted so good. What with all the free home-help supplied by Jacob's ever-expanding family tree, Laban would have been a fool to let him up and off without trying to change his mind. So that very same day Jacob's father-in-law plotted and schemed to keep his good thing going. He might have been a schemer but the old fella knew a thing or two: 'Please stay. I know the Lord has blessed me because of you.' (Genesis 30:27 NCV)

If you want to get God's best for your life, stick like Velcro to someone or something He's blessing. Proverbs 13:20 NLT puts it like this: 'Whoever walks with the wise will become wise.' And if you really, really want God's good stuff, take the reins yourself and do for them what you want done for you: 'Those who help others will themselves be helped.' (Proverbs 11:25 NCV) Learn to recognise what and where God blesses and throw your best into the mix.



SoulFood: 1 Kings 18:16-20:43, Matt 23:13-22, Ps 115, Pr 8:1-3

content.title: Big
content.introtext:
'First sit down and estimate the cost...' Luke 14:28 NIV

Big is the story of a twelve year old kid catapulted into an adult world. Thanks to a spooky attraction at a funfair a school kid becomes trapped inside the body of an adult (played by Tom Hanks). For the first time in his life he finds himself with a job and more money than he knows what to spend it on. He buys himself giant trampolines and every gadget going, and feasts on milkshakes and squirty cream for tea. But eventually he's confronted with complex relationships, backstabbing business colleagues and tight work deadlines. The kid realises he's just not ready for life as an adult and so another wish propels him back to life as a twelve year old.

Maybe you have a touch of this kind of impatience yourself. You think you're ready to take on the world.

You may be big enough but are you mature enough? If God has planned stuff for you, don't be in a rush to receive it before its time. 'Wait for it; because it will surely come.' (Habakkuk 2:3 NKJ) Are you ready to pay the price? Are you able to pay the price? Stick it out and stay in God's timing.



SoulFood: 1 Kings 21-22, Matt 23:23-39, Ps 11, Pr 8:4-5

content.title: Second, Third, Fourth Chances
content.introtext:
'How often shall...I forgive him?' Matthew 18:21 NKJ

You have to wonder why Peter asked Jesus this question. Maybe he was angry, and the 'taking deep breaths and doing the count-to-ten' thing hadn't helped at all. 'Jesus-how many times do I forgive someone who hurts me?' he asked, staring at the back of the person who hurt him.

Probably there was an answer already playing around in Peter's head. And if there was you can bet it involved Peter coming out on top, looking righteous and superior and the other guy getting his just deserts. But all done in good Christian 'love' of course! - yeah right! Surely Jesus would confirm to him that forgiving seven times was incredibly gracious!

Jesus' actual answer suggests you shouldn't try to put a number on how many times you should forgive. Whether you think it or not, people always deserve a second chance. And a third chance. And a fourth-you get the idea. Where would we all be without second chances? After all, Jesus taught us to pray: 'forgive us as we forgive...' (Luke 11:4 GWT)

content.title: Walk The Walk (1)
content.introtext:
'Follow my example, as I follow the example of Christ.' 1 Corinthians 11:1 NIV

Corinth was a place that really mixed it up when it came to different cultures and religions. Loads of different gods were thrown together in that place, a bit like a salad with 'a bit of this, and a bit of that' (only not quite so healthy).

Paul brought the Gospel of Jesus Christ into this mixed-up place and soon a church was established. Later Paul wrote passionately to the church about how to live among unbelievers: 'I have become a servant of everyone so that I can bring them to Christ...I fit in with [different people] as much as I can. In this way, I gain their confidence and bring them to Christ. But I do not discard the law of God; I obey the law of Christ...I try to find common ground with everyone so that I might bring them to Christ. I do all this to spread the Good News, and in doing so I enjoy its blessings.' (1 Corinthians 9:19-23 NLT)

Are you enjoying its blessings too? It's so important to not be cooped up in a bubble with just you and your Christian mates. Paul would tell you to pop that bubble and open your life to those around you who need Jesus.



SoulFood: Num 14-15, Matt 15:15-28, Ps 5, Pr 5:1-2
