content.title: Walk The Walk (2)
content.introtext:
'Follow my example, as I follow the example of Christ.' 1 Corinthians 11:1 NIV

Paul wasn't a bloke who just talked the talk. He didn't do anything by halves. He fully invested in walking the walk-living rightly as well as preaching the Gospel. His passion-fuelled letters encouraged the church in Corinth to follow his example. He said things like: 'Get your joggers on and really run the life you've been given to glorify Him!'

Here he is again in chapter 9 of 1 Corinthians: 'Do you not know that in a race all the runners compete, but only one receives the prize? So run your race that you may lay hold of the prize and make it yours. Now every athlete who goes into training conducts himself temperately and restricts himself in all things. They do it to win a wreath that will soon wither, but we do it to receive a crown of eternal blessedness that cannot wither. Therefore I do not run uncertainly. I do not box like one beating the air and striking without an adversary. But like a boxer I buffet my body and subdue it.' (1 Corinthians 9:24-27 AMP)

Paul packs a punch, eh? Whether he inspires you or makes you twitch coz he reminds you of your whistle-blowing PE teacher, he does make a good point. Make your life count. Invest in eternity!

content.title: Teamwork
content.introtext:
'A dinner was prepared in Jesus' honour. Martha served, and Lazarus sat...with Him.' John 12:2 NLT

Pots and pans clattered in the kitchen. Martha couldn't believe her sister was sitting doing nothing. There were guests to be fed, tables to be set, drinks to be served. And there was Mary-dearest, all gooey-eyed at Jesus' feet.

Mary, on the other hand, couldn't believe the fuss her sister was making. If looks could kill, Martha would be up for triple homicide. Couldn't she understand that Jesus was here? Spreading fish paste on sandwiches could wait-this was a once-in-forever opportunity; the Son of God was in full flow on their sofa!

Lazarus had no time for the disagreement. Sure, his sisters were having a bit of a hissy fit, but things would turn out right. They always did. That was Lazarus' take on life ever since he was saved from the clutches of death. Nothing like a near-death experience to give you a fresh 'life is too short' outlook on things!

Which are you? Marthas tend to prioritise mission over the master. Marys need to realise that service is worship too. Lazaruses could do with checking in with the everyday world now and again. And yet, without Martha, practicalities are missed. Without Mary, passion in worship is lacking. Without Lazarus, we're deprived of amazing testimonies. Truth is they all have their place at the table. And if they can see past the squabbles-as a unit they're one dynamic team not to be messed with.



SoulFood: Exod 16:1-35, Jn 6:30-40

content.title: The Petrol of Purpose
content.introtext:
'You, Lord, give perfect peace to those who keep their purpose firm...' Isaiah 26:3 GNT

What is it with some people? Their DNA seems to be made up of moans, groans and complaints. They expect the world to entertain and pamper them and when the world fails to comply, they act like a two-year old! Problems arise when you run your engine on premium tantrums. But find your purpose in life and your ride will be a whole load smoother.

For instance, ever noticed how some people seemed to have meetings dead-locking their diary but never seem to be actually achieving anything? Being busy doesn't necessarily mean you're being effective. When you're not clear about your purpose, you'll try to do too much. The reality is you'll only ever have enough time and energy to do God's will. Jesus was able to say, 'It is finished' after just thirty-three years because He never strayed from His purpose.

Know your purpose and you'll know peace: 'You, Lord, give perfect peace to those who keep their purpose firm.' Knowing your purpose gives you momentum. Instead of scratching around in the dark trying to figure out how you could make a name for yourself, pray. God created you for His purposes-why not download your destiny direct from Heaven? Your momentum, your drive, your energy should all come from your prayer life. Trying to change the world through sheer muscle and brain cells is always going to be second best to impacting the planet God's way.



SoulFood: Num 19-21, Matt 16:1-12, Ps 33:1-12, Pr 5:7-14

content.title: Lord of the Work
content.introtext:
'Come to Me, all of you who are tired and have heavy loads, and I will give you rest.' Matthew 11:28 NCV

Oldies can be goldies. Think about this little gem: 'It's easy to get caught up in the work of the Lord, and miss out on the Lord of the work.'

Yep, it's dead easy to get caught in the trap of doing-'evangelising your mates', 'looking after kids in Sunday school', 'planning a youth outreach event'-and all the while missing out on just being. While you're keeping your fingers crossed that God will smile down on all your good works, you're missing out on precious 'you and God' time.

God isn't a hobby, a side-project or a hard task. When we treat Him like that we're on the slippery slope to burnout. Without God's love to motivate us, needy people become just pains in the neck; Sunday school kids become a bit of free babysitting; youth outreach events become another hectic date in the diary.

Without God we lose the focus of why we do what we do. So how do we get our eye back on the ball? What is the antidote to burnout? Matthew 11:28-30 NCV has the answer: 'Come to Me, all of you who are tired and have heavy loads, and I will give you rest. Accept My teachings and learn from Me, because I am gentle and humble in spirit, and you will find rest for your lives. The teaching that I ask you to accept is easy; the load I give you to carry is light.'



SoulFood: Num 22-24, Matt 16:13-28, Ps 33:13-22, Pr 5:15-20

content.title: Who Are You Really?
content.introtext:
'He...laid aside His garments.' John 13:3-4 NKJ

In John 13 we read how after supper, Jesus took off His outer garments and filled a bowl of water to wash His disciples' feet...

'Errr, sit down, Jesus! Washing smelly feet's not your business! And anyway you've got the timing all wrong for it. You know, when we've just come in from journeying down those dusty roads, kicked off our sandals and our feet are revealed in all their dirty glory, that's when they need a good washin'! Anyway, more to the point, in case you haven't noticed, Jesus, you're Jewish! Business with feet is for non-Jewish slaves! Sit down, you're better than all that.'

That's what the disciples were probably thinking even if they didn't say it. With His crucifixion imminent, Jesus washes their feet as a final outpouring of His love for them. It's a real example of humility and what it means to be servant-hearted.

It's an example of how we should be with our mates and family-not seeing ourselves above anyone or anything, but as willing to serve one another. It's also a reminder of how we are called to love our enemies: Jesus washed all of His disciples' feet, including those of Judas-who He knew would soon betray Him. By Jesus taking off His outer garments to do this also brought a sense of vulnerability. We can learn from this too. Don't cover up who you are!


SoulFood: Num 11-13, Matt 15:1-14, Ps 149, Pr 4:25-27

content.title: How To Be A Great Lover!
content.introtext:
'Be kind to one another, tender hearted...' Ephesians 4:32 NKJ

Jesus is crystal clear that the greatest commandment is: Love God with everything you've got. He doesn't leave us guessing about the second either: Love people the way you'd like to be loved.

The key word here is 'commandment'. A command is an order-not a nice idea, an order. Nazi Germany wasn't defeated in the Second World War because somebody had a nice idea; success came from scores of obedient men and women following strict orders. Likewise, God's Kingdom won't be made visible if we pick and choose Jesus' 'nice ideas'. Loving people is an order of the highest importance if we're serious in making God known.

Loving people means being quick to forgive. So many of us have got 'Don't double-cross me' tattooed on our hearts-which only adds to all that's wrong in our world. Forgiveness releases our grip around someone's neck.

Loving people means serving. Jesus washed His disciples' grubby smelly feet. If the King of the Heavens can do that, then surely we can put the jug on for a mate.

Loving people means practicing kindness. A kind word, a friendly smile, an unexpected email, a surprise gift through the post-they're all small ways of revealing God's Kingdom. But don't just take our word for it: 'The command that Christ has given us is this: whoever loves God must love others also.' (1 John 4:21 GNT)

content.title: Slumps (2)
content.introtext:
'Jacob set up a pillar in the place where He talked with [God]...' Genesis 35:14 NKJ

Do you like looking at your holiday pics to remember the good times you've had away from home? It's great to look back and remember, especially when it's one of those 'miserable Mondays'. Looking back and remembering good times can really cheer us up-laughing at the clothes we used to wear; seeing our mates being silly; remembering all the different places we've been and experiences we've had.

Did you know that words for 'remember' are mentioned well over 200 times in the Bible? It is important to God that we 'remember the days of long ago.' (Deuteronomy 32:7 NLT)

They didn't have photographs in Bible times so they used other things to help them remember good times. For example, 'Jacob set up a stone pillar to mark the place where God had spoken' (Genesis 35:14 NLT); 'The people of Reuben and Gad named the altar "Witness", for they said, "It is a witness between us and them that the Lord is our God, too."' (Joshua 22:34 NLT); 'Samuel took a stone...set it up...and called [it]...Ebenezer, saying, "Thus far the Lord has helped us."' (1 Samuel 7:12 NKJ); 'Jacob presented a sacrifice to God and invited everyone to a feast.' (Genesis 31:54 NLT)

When we're in a spiritual slump it helps us get back on track when we look back and remember all the great things God has done. Remembering God's promises (over 3000 of them) fills us with hope again. God's promises are like the stars-the darker the night, the brighter they shine.



SoulFood: Lev 23:26-25:55, Matt 11:1-9, Ps 107:1-9, Pr 3:13-18

content.title: Know Jesus
content.introtext:
'For this reason I was born, and for this I came into the world...' John 18:37 NIV

Jim Peterson writes, 'Three elements of personality are involved in making a decision to become a Christian, or in making any significant decision for that matter. They are the emotions, the intellect, and the will.

'For example, a young man meets a young woman. They are immediately attracted to one another. They both say to themselves, "Now there is someone I'd like to marry." At that point, if the emotions had their way, there would be a wedding. But the intellect intervenes, questioning the impulsive emotional response. Would we be compatible? What is she really like? Can I afford to support her? Both conclude it would be better to take some more time and answer a few questions before they proceed.

'So the two begin spending more time with each other. He eventually concludes that she is as beautiful on the inside as she is on the outside. Now his intellect has sided with the emotions on the idea of marriage. But the final and heaviest vote remains to be cast-that of the will. It stops the march toward the altar with the questions, "Am I willing to give up this lifestyle for another? What about my freedom, is it worth the trade? Am I willing to assume the added responsibility?" The marriage will occur only when the will finally agrees with the emotions and the intellect.'*

Let your will, intellect and emotions agree to follow Jesus.

(*Credit: Jim Peterson, Living Proof, NavPress, 1989, p. 170.)

content.title: What Matters Most?
content.introtext:
'I don't care what happens to me...' Acts 20:24 CEV

Paul writes, 'I don't know what will happen to me...I don't care...as long as I finish the work that the Lord Jesus gave me to do.'

Paul wasn't wishing his life away, far from it. Instead he had realised that he had taken hold of something much, much, more valuable: Jesus. Paul may have seemed like a sold-out radical to people around him, maybe even suicidal, because of his insistence on walking into pretty nasty situations carrying Jesus' name and message high. He may have looked like he'd completely lost the plot, but he was working to a different set of priorities: 'For me, to live is Christ, and to die is gain.' (Philippians 1:21 NIV)

What about that new mp3 player? That new phone? That new pair of jeans or accessory that you have to get your hands on as soon as you get the chance? What about that boy or girl you've had your eye on? While these things can be harmless in themselves, sometimes they feel like they're all that life's about. Paul didn't take any half-measures with distractions-he let that kind of life die in him. Instead he lived completely to do Jesus' work, and looked forward to an eternity with Him when it was all over. What matters most to you?



SoulFood: Lev 26-27, Matt 11:10-19, Ps 107:10-16, Pr 3:19-20

content.title: Impressive
content.introtext:
'...the Lord God appeared as a blazing fire in a bush.' Exodus 3:2 NLT

Moses must have been totally impressed when God appeared to Him in a burning bush that didn't burn up. Things that leave a lasting impression are not always found where you'd expect.

Here's some questions based on the philosophy of Charles Schulz, the creator of the Peanuts comic strip. 1. Name the five wealthiest people in the world. 2. Name the last five Australian cricket captains. 3. Name the last five winners of Miss Australia. 4 Name ten people who have won the Nobel Prize. 5. Name the last 5 Academy Award winners for best actor or actress. 6. Name the last 5 World Cup winners.

The point is, none of us remember all the headliners of yesterday. These were no second-rate achievers-they were the best in their fields-in their day. But the applause dies, awards tarnish, achievements are forgotten.

Here's anotherbetter-quiz: 1. List a few teachers who really helped you through school. 2. Name three friends who were there for you in a difficult time. 3. Name five people who have taught you something worthwhile. 4. Think of three people who have made you feel appreciated and special. 5. Think of five people you enjoy spending time with.

I bet you found that easier. The lesson is clear: the people who make a difference in your life are not the ones with the most credentials, the most money or the most awards. They simply are the ones who care the most. Do you leave a lasting impression?

content.title: Bring Out The Best In Others (1)
content.introtext:
'Be strong and courageous.' Deuteronomy 31:6 NIV

The Bible's full of stories of God telling people not to be afraid: 'Be courageous! Don't chicken out! Stand firm!' We all find ourselves in situations that make us feel like a wimp sandwich with a side serve of limp fries. That's not God's plan for us! Sometimes we've got to be courageous about our own potential-and helping other people with theirs too.

We might be familiar with the idea that each one of us is 'fearfully and wonderfully made' with huge amounts of potential packed inside. But it's often only when someone else spots that potential and draws it out that we actually start to live out our lives based on this powerful truth.

To make sure a person's potential doesn't remain under wraps, we've got to be on the look-out for their strengths and God-given giftings. The words we speak create an environment in which people not only see for themselves they've got gifts, but are also encouraged to grow and develop them. Everyone's been implanted with a God-given purpose in life and we can play a key part in inspiring them to achieve it. If you show you believe in someone's future, then who knows what can happen?

Jesus said, 'With God everything is possible.' (Matthew 19:26 NLT) The question is, do we believe it?

content.title: Bring Out The Best In Others (2)
content.introtext:
'Be strong and courageous.' Deuteronomy 31:6 NIV

Simon the Galilean fisherman didn't audition for a role as one of Jesus' disciples. Jesus didn't wow the audience by presenting Simon on a glitzy, high-octane TV show while announcing His plans for the future of the church. Instead, when Simon said Jesus was the Saviour that God had promised, Jesus told him: 'On this rock I will build My church.' (Matthew 16:18 NIV) Jesus also gave Simon a new name and a fresh purpose. Jesus took a lumpy old bit of coal called Simon and turned him into Peter, the rough diamond.

The thing about diamonds is (grab your lab coat, here comes the science bit) they can only be formed if carbon is subjected to specific and intense pressure. None of us is the finished article and God wants to make us more like Christ. This often means we have to go through some pressure-cooker times for those diamonds to be produced. God accepts us just the way we are but He loves us way too much to leave us that way.

If God has something for you to do that makes your fearful just thinking about it, it'll be accompanied with this message: Be strong and courageous. 'I am holding you by your right hand-I, the Lord your God. And I say to you, Do not be afraid. I am here to help you.' (Isaiah 41:13 NLT)

content.title: Bring Out The Best In Others (3)
content.introtext:
'Be strong and courageous.' Deuteronomy 31:6 NIV

Halfway up one of the mountains in the Swiss Alps there's a little caf. The mountain itself takes a full day to climb from the bottom to the top but you can usually get to the caf by lunchtime, and that's where the men get separated from the boys. When some amateur climbers feel the warmth of the fire and smell the good cooking they say to their mates, 'I'll just wait here while you go to the top. When you come back down I'll join you and we'll go to the base together.' Relaxation washes over them as they sit by the fire, sipping the strong coffee. But about 3:30 in the afternoon everything changes; they start looking toward the mountaintop as their friends reach it. Suddenly the atmosphere in the caf changes and they think: 'If only I'd kept climbing!'

So what factors decide whether you end up in the caf or on the mountaintop? There are at least three things: (1) TIREDNESS: Jesus told Peter, 'I have prayed for you...that your faith may not fail.' (Luke 22:31-32 NIV) We all have to find strength in Jesus to overcome times of failing faith. (2) FEAR: Some days it seems like vertigo strikes our souls. We can't cope with the height of the mountain and we're tempted to give up. Then a voice whispers, 'Be strong and courageous...for the Lord your God will be with you.' (Joshua 1:9 NIV) (3) COMFORT: Conflict and hard times keep us on our toes-and on our knees-but having it easy all the time can con us into settling down short of our goal. So keep climbing!

content.title: Bring Out The Best In Others (4)
content.introtext:
'Be strong and courageous.' Deuteronomy 31:6 NIV

'Can we fix it? Yes we can!' The producers of Bob the Builder had a pretty good understanding that a positive attitude to a problem is the first step towards solving it. But they weren't the first to hit on the idea. Jesus is the Master when it comes to dealing with sticky situations and turning them on their head.

John 8 tells the story of a woman caught in the act of adultery. Not good. Checking their law books, the religious people suggested stoning her to death. But Jesus stepped in with immense compassion and handed her a lifeline: 'I do not condemn you either. Go, but do not sin again.' (John 8:11 GNT) It's likely she'd have gone on from that point trying to live up to Jesus' view of her. The New Testament is full of the idea we should breathe life into people and situations.

So what stops us from sharing the love? Could it be the lure of laziness? Or are we seduced by selfishness? Do we fall down by taking people for granted? Perhaps we're concerned if we say a few nice words, they'll take a rocket ride to Superiority Central. But that wasn't Jesus' concern when He praised Nathanael: 'Now here is a genuine son of Israel-a man of complete integrity.' (John 1:47 NLT) What an amazing compliment! The sad truth is more people die of broken hearts than swelled heads. Ask God today for an opportunity to be a life-breather.

content.title: Your Best Days Are Still Ahead
content.introtext:
'Don't call me Naomi...call me Mara...' Ruth 1:20 NLT

Ask any new parent about the importance of a name and they'll probably gush with the story of how they picked out what to call their little bundle of joy. Throughout the Bible, names are super-significant. They usually tell us about that person's character and identity, with Jesus Christ being the best example: Jesus-'God is our Saviour'; Christ'the Anointed One'.

But in Ruth, we read about a woman who decided on a name change for the . Naomi lost her husband and, later on, both of her sons. She went from Naomi, meaning 'my joy' or 'pleasant' to Mara, meaning 'bitter'. She let her circumstances define her when in reality there were still loads of things in store for Naomi-including mentoring Ruth who would ultimately become an ancestor of Jesus Christ himself!

Sadly, Naomi let pessimism into the driver's seat of her life. It strangled hope within her. Don't let that happen to you. If things around you are changing, embrace the change and roll with it. God's still in control and still has things in store for you too. We might think we've got our life nailed down but God's got an uncanny way of surprising us with what we never thought possible.

So instead of having a Mara mentality, let God have His way: 'By His mighty power at work within us, He is able to accomplish infinitely more than we would ever dare to ask or hope.' (Ephesians 3:20-21 NLT)

content.title: Don't Be Afraid, Put God First
content.introtext:
'I have instructed a widow there to feed you.' 1 Kings 17:9 NLT

Times are tough. The economy's come to an all-time slump. No one even knows where their next meal's coming from. These were the circumstances facing Elijah, but he didn't lose hope. Elijah knew God, and he knew God's voice when he heard it: 'Go to Zarephath. I have instructed a widow there to feed you.' So Elijah set off to find the woman and invite himself to dinner.

It soon turned out God was going to have to perform a major miracle if Elijah was going to get fed that night. The widow let him know: 'I don't have a single piece of bread.' (1 Kings 17:12 NLT) But Elijah wasn't put off. He delivered God's Word: 'There will always be plenty of flour and oil left in your containers until the time when the Lord sends rain and the crops grow again!' (v14) Sure enough, God fulfilled His promise to provide.

Here are three powerful lessons in provision: (1) When you need it, God's provision is in place; (2) The people God uses might surprise you; (3) Our bad time is God's opportune moment. This lady was all set to savour her last meal on earth.

When God's work has a need, He looks for someone with a seed, stretches their faith, and both the giver and God's work are blessed. You see, one of God's names is Yahweh-Yireh, which means 'God will provide'. He will provide, it's in His DNA. But He'll often wait till we are totally dependent on Him, before we see Him come through for us.



SoulFood: Dan 11-12, Matt 13:1-9, Ps 120, Pr 3:33-35

content.title: You've Got To Work For It!
content.introtext:
'Though a righteous man falls seven times, he rises again...' Proverbs 24:16 NIV

Stand up and take a bow, Winston Churchill. Prime Minister of the United Kingdom during World War II, Nobel Prize winner and patron of bow ties and bowler hats (ok, the last bit's not actually true). Yet when asked what prepared him best for the pressures of leading a country to war, he remembered the time he was made to repeat a year of school: 'You failed a year at school?' quizzed the interviewer. 'I never failed anything,' he replied. 'I was given a second opportunity to get it right.'

Our attitude and response to failure is crucial in deciding what we make of our lives. Failing isn't falling down, it's staying down. With God's help, we can keep on getting back up again. Still, it takes guts. Before Jonas Salk developed a vaccine for polio that finally worked, he tried 200 unsuccessful ones. He didn't even use the word 'failure' when talking about that journey of discovery, but instead boldly stated, 'I just discovered 200 ways how not to vaccinate polio.'

Mistakes and 'failures' are part of daring to live the kind of life Jesus lived on earth-full of excitement and even potential danger. The other option is to drift through life, living a 'safe existence' and never taking a single risk. The choice is ours.

So, ask yourself: Is failure when things don't work out the way we hoped or expected? Or is failure not having the courage to risk living out our dreams?



SoulFood: Jm 1-2, Matt 13:10-23, Ps 67, Pr 4:1-2

content.title: He's Got A Better View!
content.introtext:
'But I know that even now God will give You whatever You ask.' John 11:22 NIV

'Take off those grave clothes and let him go,' Jesus said. (John 11:44 NIV) Well, it wouldn't really be appropriate for Lazarus to go freaking out the good folk of Bethany looking like a zombie, would it?

Lazarus was Mary and Martha's brother. He'd been dead for four days when Jesus raised him from the dead... In fact, Jesus had received a message from Mary and Martha that Lazarus was sick, but He had delayed coming to help. Delayed? To say they were disappointed in Jesus is a bit of an understatement.

It's easy to forget that before Jesus performed this amazing miracle, they were in full mourning. Filled with grief, Mary and Martha both questioned Jesus' timing when He finally arrived. 'Lord,' Martha said, 'if You had been here, my brother would not have died.' (John 11:21 NIV)

Are you questioning God's timing or His involvement in a problem or circumstances you're dealing with? Maybe you think that God doesn't seem to be doing anything at all? Even through Martha's pain and confusion, she still didn't deny who Jesus was. She said: 'But I know that even now God will give You whatever You ask.' (John 11:22)

If you're having a 'What are You doing, God?' moment, remember God says, 'My thoughts are not your thoughts, neither are your ways My ways ... As the Heavens are higher than the earth, so are My ways higher than your ways.' (Isaiah 55:8-9 NIV) God's always got your best at heart.

content.title: There's Something About Mary
content.introtext:
'She poured it on Jesus' feet...' John 12:3 NIV

It would be nice to feel that once in a while there'd be a day where you could just cruise along without a care in the world, wouldn't it? But there are days when you feel that all you've got to give God are the tail ends of your time-nothing but the scraps. You know you haven't worshipped God with the best you've got to give. Let's look at the way Mary worshipped Jesus: 'Mary took...expensive perfume; she poured it on Jesus' feet and wiped His feet with her hair.'

We see Mary's character in this. Washing Jesus' feet shows how servant-hearted and humble she was. She poured out her expensive perfume on Him. We're not talking dropper quantities here-it was enough to perfume the whole house. She wanted to give the God the best of all she had.

Also remember this took place at a banquet, with lots of people watching. She didn't let other people intimidate and divert her from worshipping Jesus. And the fact she used her hair to wipe Jesus' feet was amazing, as Jewish women rarely let their hair down in public. It shows how personal she was with Jesus and how little she cared about what other people thought.

Let's go all out for God like Mary! Let's seek to please God rather than people. Don't worry what you look like being caught with your Bible! Let yourself be Spirit-guided in a chat about your relationship with God instead! Give God the best. 'It is good to sing praise to our God; it is pleasant and right to praise Him.' (Psalm 147:1 GNT)



SoulFood: Num 1-2, Matt 13:36-46, Ps 134, Pr 4:5-13

'All these are the work of...the same Spirit.' 1 Corinthians 12:11 NIV

Nothing like a good pick 'n'mix, is there? Coming up with your own yummy blend of choccies and lollies, lovingly arranged to suit your taste buds and yours alone!

content.title: The Stink or the Storm?
content.introtext:
'Let my prayer be...as incense.' Psalm 141:2 NKJ

Noah's ark is a picture of your church. It wasn't a luxury liner... can you imagine spending a year in that ark with all those animals and just one window? No thanks! But Noah had only two options-the stink or the storm.

So what's the point here? That there are no perfect churches. We all love to talk about the power of the New Testament church, but what about its problems? They had hypocrites. They had financial scandals (Acts 5). They had doctrinal differences that almost split the church down the middle (Acts 15). And they had moral problems-they actually had a man in the Corinthian church who was sleeping with his stepmother (1 Corinthians 5).

So what should you do when there's a big stink in your church? First, don't spread it: 'And above all things have fervent love for one another, for love will cover over a multitude of sins.' (1 Peter 4:8 NKJ) Second, work for reconciliation: 'If someone is caught in a sin...restore him gently.' (Galatians 6:1 NIV) Don't be discouraged when 'flesh acts like flesh'. And don't be part of the problem by being immature; instead, be part of the solution.

The Psalmist said, 'Let my prayer be set before You as incense.' When problems arise in your church, you should pray, walk according to God's Word, and trust Him to bring good out of the situation.

content.title: Limping Your Way Through
content.introtext:
'The socket of Jacob's thigh was out of joint...' Genesis 32:25 NKJ

The Bible isn't full of stories of squeaky clean people with superhero strength and nobility. Nor does it have endless tales of perfect specimens of humanity used to fulfil all of God's purposes on planet Earth. The New Testament doesn't look anything like the adventures of Jesus and the twelve Gummy Bears!

Nope, the Bible is about regular Waynes and Waynettas like you and me. In fact God's preference seems to be to use the least likely people. Throughout Scripture, He seems to be on the look-out for the kind of people considered least worthy by human standards. And guess what? He hasn't changed.

The truth is it's not about us; it's about Him. It's not about what we have done and can do; it's about what God has done and what He can do through us. It can be hard feeling totally out of your depth. Maybe you feel like you're struggling through a situation like Jacob trying to walk with his dodgy hip.

God often uses difficult situations and difficult people to grow us and make us rely on Him. So instead of thinking about how unfair or difficult a situation feels, take the time to consider what God is trying to teach you through it.

Here's some really great news: we don't have to struggle on in our own strength and capabilities. God says, 'My grace is sufficient for you, for My strength is made perfect in weakness.' (2 Corinthians 12:9 NKJ)

content.title: God of the Give and Take Away
content.introtext:
'Abraham...was called God's friend.' James 2:23 NIV

Friendships don't seem to work when they're all one-sided. They tend to end in angry words: 'Know what? I'm what's called a giver-you on the other hand just take, take, take!'

God is definitely a giver. He wants to give us more than we could ever dream or imagine. And boy, do we wanna grab hold of those B-for-blessings: 'Thanks very much Lord, don't mind if I do! Yep, God's a great mate!'

But what about when God takes away? What's up with that? We don't wear our God Squad badges with quite such a big smile then, do we?

Let's have a look at God's friend Abraham. God stripped a lot away from him: 'Leave your country, your relatives, and your father's family, and go to the land I will show you.' (Genesis 12:1 NCV) Abraham had to leave everything he knew and loved in order to gain something that he hadn't even seen-and didn't even know if he wanted.

But Abraham knew he could trust God. He knew that God knew him better than anyone and he knew that he would want what God wanted him to have. It's hard to see blessings when God takes things away. It's hard to have faith in the unseen but, 'Trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own understanding. In all your ways acknowledge Him and He will make your paths straight.' (Proverbs 3:5-6 NIV)

content.title: Wedding Bells (3)
content.introtext:
'Marriage should be honoured by all.' Hebrews 13:4 NIV

If Christianity would just let go of its hang-ups about sex, people wouldn't be so put off the church, right? We've ditched the organ for the electric guitar, so why not click the refresh button on our attitudes to sex too? Why won't the church give us the green light to play around a bit? The answer is God.

Sex and God: the two are connected. God made us and God made sex. And because we are spirit and God is spirit, there is a lot more than just the physical happening in the marriage bed. Something spiritual is going on. And if God carefully designed the act of intimacy, doesn't it follow that He would know when to use it?

1 Corinthians 6:15-16 NLT says, 'Don't you realise that your bodies are actually parts of Christ? Should a man take his body, which belongs to Christ, and join it to a prostitute? Never! And don't you know that if a man joins himself to a prostitute, he becomes one body with her? For the Scriptures say, "The two are united into one."' Avoiding commitment avoids the beauty of relationships. We miss out on God if we're only interested in what we can get from Him; likewise we miss out on love if we're only interested in flesh on flesh. God draws a firm line on sex outside the commitment of marriage.

content.title: A Slap In The Face!
content.introtext:
'[Your] steps...are ordered by the Lord.' Psalm 37:23 NKJ

The sun is shining, the birds are singing a happy tune and you're feeling tip-top, looking hot and it promises to be a great day. You get to school, college or the office doing your best swagger down the corridor and... Slam! The door crashes right in your face as the person in front glides on through.

OK, so that was annoying... but you're in a good mood and you're not gonna let a little door incident steal your joy, right? You carry on and then... Slam! It happens again. You're determined to keep upbeat but you mutter loud enough to be heard and your carefree swagger has morphed into a walk with that 'I'm a bit annoyed with you' edge. You turn the corner, relieved this is the last set of doors before your destination, aaand... SLAM! Farewell joy.

Do you ever feel like God is distant? And like that rude dude in front of you, He's not seeing or caring you're there? Do you ever wonder where He is when doors of opportunity slam in your face? Well, 'we can make our plans, but the Lord determines our steps.' (Proverbs 16:9 NLT) It's hard when doors close on us but God wants you to know, 'For I know the plans I have for you...They are plans for good and not for disaster, to give you a future and a hope.' (Jeremiah 29:11 NLT)

content.title: Becoming God's Friend (5)
content.introtext:
'...I have called you friends...' John 15:15 NKJ

On an all-day bricklayer's practical test, each student was given a drawing and a labourer who would prepare bricks and mortar for them as they built the item from the drawing supplied. One of the students appeared to know what he was doing. He started well while the others stood around watching.

Once he was well on his way, the other students simply followed his design. (In an open workshop it was impossible to stop anyone from cheating.) After several hours the inspired brickie stopped and looked at his drawing very carefully. Then he folded the drawing and kicked the project down! You could have heard a pin drop. They all needed help now, but no one knew what to do. They all failed.

It's good that life isn't like that. We are not left to our own devices with only each other as inspiration. We can be friends with God Himself and have His inspiration. In John 15: 9-10 GWT, Jesus says, 'I have loved you the same way the Father has loved Me. So live in My love. you obey My commandments, you will live in My love. I have obeyed My Father's commandments, and in that way I live in His love.'

When we are friends of God, we want to obey Him because we know His way is best. Rely on God for your inspiration, follow His way and stay wrapped up in His love.

content.title: Becoming God's Friend (6)
content.introtext:
'...I have called you friends...' John 15:15 NKJ

Friends: we text them, call them, leave silly messages on their Facebook wall, meet up and chat all night, go here there and everywhere. We make time for friends, put the effort in, and we make sure they know they're important to us. What about God? Does He know you're His friend? Do you make sure you spend time with Him, put the effort in getting to know Him? Is God your number one friend?

David desired to know God above all else. He used words like longing, yearning, thirsting and hungering: 'I ask only one thing of the Lord. This is what I want: Let me live in the Lord's house all my life.' (Psalm 27:4 NCV) He even said, 'Your love means more than life to me...' (Psalm 63:3 CEV)

Jacob's desire was so intense that he wrestled with God all night, saying, 'I will not let You go unless You bless me.' (Genesis 32:26 NIV) Paul was another man who was passionate about his friendship with God. 'My determined purpose is that I may...become more deeply and intimately acquainted with Him...' (Philippians 3:10 AMP) Can the same be said about you?

Are you willing to say, 'Lord, more than anything else, I want to know You'? God's answer to that prayer has always been: 'You will...find Me when you search for Me with all your heart.' (Jeremiah 29:13-14 NKJ)

content.title: HELP!
content.introtext:
'Why...have You laid the burden...on me?' Numbers 11:11 NKJ

Are you in a Moses Mess? Moses was asked by God to lead the people of Israel but at one point found himself completely overwhelmed-it all got too much for him: 'Why...have You laid the burden of all these people on me?' He couldn't cope and so he blamed God. Recognise that feeling?

But God answers back: 'I didn't, you took it on yourself,' and Moses quickly realises that there were actually plenty of people around to help him-he'd just not bothered to ask. We need to learn from Moses: God wants us to ask for help when we need it too. And not only from Him, but also from those He puts around us too.

There are lots of reasons we don't ask for help: because we want to be independent, we're afraid or we think we're being weak. Instead of the benefits, most of us see only negative consequences to asking for help. But good things are waiting to be had if we get over our fears and ask for the help we need.

Asking for help is a good thing-it's a sign of strength, not of weakness. It gets us the right kind of help at the right time, stops us getting overwhelmed or exhausted, and makes our life easier. It can even make someone else feel good (have you noticed how good you feel when you can help someone who asks for it?)

content.title: Good Grief!
content.introtext:
'No one can serve two masters...' Matthew 6:24 NIV

'Good grief' is an example of an oxymoron, a phrase containing words that contradict each other. Here are some more: Jumbo Shrimp, Numb Feeling, Plastic Glasses, Fresh Frozen, Fine Mess, Working Vacation, Bigger Half, Oddly Appropriate and Clearly Misunderstood.

There are also religious oxymorons like Pure Evil but the most common is 'Lukewarm Christian'. These are two words that just don't go together.

In the book of Revelation 3:16 NIV we read what Jesus said to the church in Laodicea: 'Because you are lukewarm-neither hot nor cold-I am about to spit you out of my mouth.' Jesus also said, 'No one can serve two masters. Either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will be devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve both God and Money.' (Matthew 6:24 NIV)

This doesn't mean that we have to be perfect before we can call ourselves a Christian (in fact 'perfect Christian' is an oxymoron too!) It just means that when we come to Christ, we must be willing to give Him our whole selves, not just part of ourselves. When Jesus comes into your life He can't become 'just one more thing'. Instead, He wants to take over. As the apostle Paul wrote in 2 Corinthians 5:17 NIV, 'If anyone is in Christ he is a new creation-the old has gone, the new has come!' Jesus lived to please God, not to impress people, and we need to follow that example.



SoulFood: 2 Sam 17:14-19:43, John 3:22-36, Ps 89:38-52, Pr 23:19-21

content.title: Rep it Right (1)
content.introtext:
'...win favour and a good name in the sight of God and man.' Proverbs 3:4 NIV

You already know that elephants are one of the most powerful land animals in the world. So how do people train them to perform in circuses?

The first rule for training an elephant is making it believe that it can't run away. So elephant trainers will start working with elephants as babies by tying them to heavy-duty steel stakes in the ground. Over and over again, the elephant will try to pull free, but it won't be able to. Having learned that the boundary is solid and immovable the elephant will eventually stop trying to escape. The Bible tells us to, '...win favour and a good name in the sight of God and man.' This means we need to start training ourselves up in our youth and-importantly-we need a 'stake in the ground' to show us where the limits are, the difference between right and wrong for our lives.

That 'stake' is the Word of God. The only way you can become an obedient follower of Jesus is to submit yourself to the authority of the Word of God. If you discipline yourself now you will be able to control yourself when difficult times of temptation come your way.

content.title: Rep it Right (2)
content.introtext:
'...win favour and a good name in the sight of God and man.' Proverbs 3:4 NIV

Which are you more bothered about: what your friends think of you, what your family thinks of you, or what God thinks of you?

You probably know what the right answer should be, but is what God thinks about you actually most important to you? When your mates invite you to a drinking session, what do you do? When your boyfriend or girlfriend pressures you to have sex, what do you do? When your family tells you that going to church is for losers, what do you do? Are you saying one thing but doing another?

The Bible says, 'Never let loyalty and kindness get away from you! Wear them like a necklace; write them deep within your heart. Then you will find favour with both God and people, and you will gain a good reputation.' (Proverbs 3: 3-4 NLT) Loyalty and kindness are important character qualities which both involve action as well as attitude. Thoughts and words aren't enough-our lives reveal whether we are truly loyal to God and act in His kindness towards everyone.

In Luke 15, you can read Jesus' story of the prodigal son. The older son appears to have the right attitude, staying home to work with his father. But his actions don't match up. Because when the younger son returns, the older son refuses to forgive him and refuses to celebrate his return with his dad. Make sure your actions measure up to your attitude!



SoulFood: Exod 34:29-35, Mk 9:2-27, 2 Cor 3:7-18

content.title: Rep it Right (3)
content.introtext:
'...win favour and a good name in the sight of God and man.' Proverbs 3:4 NIV

Did you know that God can help you earn a good reputation? Even when people and events are set against you, God can and will come through for you. All you need to do is, 'Never let loyalty and kindness get away from you! Wear them like a necklace; write them deep within your heart. Then you will find favour with both God and people, and you will gain a good reputation.' (Proverbs 3: 3-4 NLT)

Imagine a guy who gets beaten within an inch of his life by his brothers. They then decide to earn a few bucks selling him as a slave. Just when he thinks he's doing ok again, he's wrongly accused of rape and gets thrown into prison. You can't exactly see him becoming the next Prime Minister, can you?

But when God is writing your story anything is possible. The story above is exactly what happened to Joseph. His reputation is in tatters but God totally turns things around. God brings a butler into Joseph's life and as a result of helping him, Joseph is released from prison to help Pharaoh understand his crazy dreams. Joseph ends up as Pharaoh's right hand man, ruling all of Egypt. Talk about building a reputation up from nothing!

Keep your mind open and stay sensitive to God, for He will give you favour in the most unusual places and through the most unlikely people.



SoulFood: 2 Sam 22:31-24:25, John 4:13-26, Ps 32, Pr 23:29-35

content.title: Take the First Step
content.introtext:
'Jesus said...Get up!' John 5:8 NIV

Jesus met a man who'd been unable to walk for 38 years, because he thought there was nothing he could do about it: 'Jesus said, Get up! Pick up your mat and walk.'

How do you see yourself? As a helpless victim? Wendy Blight says, 'I lived like that...for a decade. At 21 I was raped by a masked stranger hiding in my apartment. Before that I loved life. I'd just completed college...graduated with honours...become engaged to a wonderful man...and had an amazing job waiting for me... My attacker's...act shattered my hopes and dreams. I lived in a prison of fear and despair. Then I encountered Christ...the words He spoke...pierced my soul. I...was the man on that mat...accustomed to my place of sorrow... I enjoyed being the victim... I was comfortable. The Bible says, The Word of God is living and active...it judges the thoughts and attitudes of the heart (Hebrews 4:12 NIV) and it spoke personally to me. I knew I needed to take the first step. I surrendered my fear, pity, and grief... I learned God had a plan for my life and a purpose for my pain. However, I'd never see it until I had the courage to get up and walk. If you're on the mat...open God's Word. Let Him speak...promises of hope and healing. Before you can get off the mat, you must surrender your fear, self-pity, and despair. Will you do it?'

content.title: When the Going Gets Tough
content.introtext:
'...Gideon...crossed over, exhausted but still in pursuit.' Judges 8:4 NKJ

Are you thinking of quitting? Thinking of giving up? You were doing ok, you believed you could make a difference, believed you could do it...until they poured criticism and cold water on you, laughed at you and knocked you down.

We all have times when we feel like throwing in the towel. When Gideon fought the Midianites we read that he 'came to the Jordan, he and the three hundred men who were with him crossed over, exhausted but still in pursuit.' He was completely done in, but Gideon kept on going, refusing to let the river intimidate him, or tiredness stop him. So God gave him a great victory! God can do the same for you.

In 2 Corinthians 4 NLT, Paul reminds us we may think we are at the end of the rope, but we are never at the end of hope: 'We are pressed on every side by troubles, but we are not crushed and broken. We are perplexed, but we don't give up and quit. We are hunted down, but God never abandons us. We get knocked down, but we get up again and keep going ...our present troubles are quite small and won't last very long. Yet they produce for us an immeasurably great glory that will last forever! So we don't look at the troubles we can see right now; rather, we look forward to what we have not yet seen. For the troubles we see will soon be over, but the joys to come will last forever.' (vv.7-9, 16-18)

content.title: How Big is your God?
content.introtext:
'...the Lord your God is among you, and He is a great and awesome God.' Deuteronomy 7:21 NLT

In his book, Living the Good Life, John Ortberg writes: 'A friend and I were going to spend two weeks preaching in Ethiopia when it was still under Marxist rule. The underground churches there asked if I would bring 50 study Bibles. I had reservations about smuggling Bibles, but we decided to give it a shot. Sure enough, the customs agent opened the suitcases and confiscated the Bibles. A few days later we received a call that the head customs official wanted an interview with the leaders of the churches. We feared the worst-church leaders in Ethiopia spent so much time in prison, they referred to it as 'The University'. (This is where God would send His leaders when He really wanted them to grow. Like the Biblical Joseph, some of them would actually be put in charge by the guards, when the guards wanted to go on break. They would take the bullets out of their rifles and hand them to the Christian prisoners to stand watch until they got back!) Imagine our surprise when the official said, 'These Bibles are illegal. You may keep them on one condition-you must tell no one. I want one for myself.' Ortberg says, 'That day my God got a little larger!'

Every time you step out in faith, you see that God is bigger than you thought and you realise the truth of Paul's words: '...His power at work in us can do far more than we dare ask or imagine...' (Ephesians 3:20 CEV)

content.title: Your 'EXPLAIN BY' date
content.introtext:
'...I am the way...the truth and the life...' John 14:6 NIV

Why do we pretend we have all the answers when we don't? When Paul wrote, '...we know in part...' (1 Corinthians 13:9 NIV) he wasn't having a crisis of faith. He was just being honest. It's as if some things in life are labelled by God just like products in a supermarket-with an 'EXPLAIN BY' date. Thomas may not have arrived at the truth of the resurrection when the others did; but he got it soon enough!

A Christian broadcaster said: 'I find airtight conclusions mainly in people who have not hurt much. They're usually people who have become tightly wired, rigid and isolated from the real world. They're closed...unwilling to be vulnerable. Suddenly a divorce comes. Or someone dies in a tragic set of circumstances or loses his job. Reality hits and a storm blows in that threatens their once tranquil existence. Their emotional explosion results in more questions than answers. They discover things they didn't really know. They are in the vortex of dilemmas they cannot solve. At that point simplistic solutions are replaced with realistic reflections, and the deep things of God begin to emerge, eclipsing shallow answers.' That explains why Jesus didn't have a go at Thomas and say, 'Are you just going to diss me to my face by saying I'm a ghost?' No, Jesus didn't push Thomas away because of his doubts, He called him closer, close enough to touch Him. Thomas knew stuff in his head, Jesus had said to him earlier, 'I am the way and the truth and the life' but it had not entered his heart. However, when Jesus appeared to him, that changed. Jesus knew the EXPLAIN BY date for Thomas and He knows it for you too.



SoulFood: 1 Tim 1-3, John 5:16-30, Ps 5, Pr 24:8-9

content.title: The disease to please
content.introtext:
'...I'm not trying to be a people pleaser...I am trying to please God...' Galatians 1:10 NLT

A talented young musician studied under a famous violin teacher. Now it was time for his first public performance. He played amazingly and a huge chorus of 'Bravos!' came from the audience. Strangely he seemed not to hear them, but kept glancing nervously at the front row. It wasn't until a white-haired man stood up and nodded graciously, that the young violinist started to smile. His master had praised his work! He'd received the only approval that mattered.

Whose approval do you look for? Be honest! It's important to get real about how much of what you do is just to win the favour of other people. Paul said, '...we speak as messengers...approved by God... Our purpose is to please God, not people.' (1 Thessalonians 2:4 NLT) He also said, '...I'm not trying to be a people pleaser...If I were...I would not be Christ's servant.' (Galatians 1:10 NLT) You really need to watch out for the people-pleaser trap. Don't be like the people in the Bible who '...loved human praise more than the praise of God.' (John 12:43 NLT)

Remember, any time you set new goals, establish new boundaries, or change old patterns, you're going to get flak from people who are used to you behaving in a certain way. Have the courage of your convictions. Don't stop doing what you know is right!



SoulFood: 1 Tim 4-6, John 5:31-47, Ps 126, Pr 24:10

content.title: Spiritual Diet
content.introtext:
'This is the day the Lord has made...' Psalm 118:24 NKJ

What's your diet like? Do you look after yourself by eating regular, healthy meals? Or do you pig out on junk food most days? Imagine if, when you went to have your tea tonight, you were told, 'This is your last meal for a week!' How would you feel? Would it make you stuff your face, trying to eat as much as you could in the hope you'll last the week? Would you start feeling hungry as soon as you finished because you know you can't have any more food for six more days? You'd begin by feeling bloated, followed by a blinding headache and by mid-week, hunger pains would start, lasting through to your next meal. No one would choose to live on one meal a week-it's ludicrous. We'd become ill and weak, unable to concentrate.

Did you ever stop and think that what you would never tolerate for your body is often the 'standard fare' for your spirit? A Sunday 'feast' of Bible study, prayer and worship followed by six days of 'famine'. Psalm 118 says, 'This is the day the Lord has made. We will rejoice and be glad in it.' That means every day we're meant to be praising God, thanking Him-after all it's only because of His great power that this day is here at all.

Check up on your own spiritual diet! Is it properly balanced, with proper amounts of prayer, praise and Bible study every day?



SoulFood: Exodus 20:1-17, Matt 5:1-12

content.title: Go For It!
content.introtext:
'Serve the Lord with gladness...' Psalm 100:2 NKJ

'I can't do anything'; 'I'm rubbish'; 'I'm useless'; 'I've messed up big time.' The Bible may tell us to serve the Lord with gladness but how can we do that if we think we're useless, rubbish, can't do anything, or just too bad?

It's easy to compare ourselves to other people and think we're not good enough to serve God. But think again. The Bible is full of people God chose to use who weren't exactly perfect: Moses stuttered, David's armour didn't fit him, John Mark was undependable, Jacob was a liar, Abraham was too old, Joseph was a nuisance, Peter was a coward, Jonah was disobedient, Jeremiah was suicidal, Elijah suffered from depression, Moses and David committed murder, Zacchaeus was very short, Timothy had ulcers, Lazarus was dead, Miriam was a gossip, Gideon and Thomas were doubters, John the Baptist dressed funny, Mary, Daniel and so many others were only teenagers...

God doesn't do job interviews or background checks or ask for references. He doesn't care what your qualifications are-He chooses to use you, just as you are.

Hudson Taylor, founder of the China Inland Mission, said, 'I used to ask God to help me. Then I asked if I might help Him. Finally I ended up asking Him to do His work through me.' When you come to believe, really believe, that serving is all about God working through you, you'll be able to 'serve the Lord with gladness' everywhere and anywhere.



SoulFood: Zeph 1-3, John 6:1-24, Ps 85, Pr 24:11-14

content.title: Ride the Waves (1)
content.introtext:
'Peter...walked on the water toward Jesus.' Matthew 14:29 NLT

When things get tough how do you cope? When you get scared, worried or stressed, what or who do you turn to for help? We all develop coping mechanisms when life becomes difficult-some of them helpful, some of them not. Sometimes we can use unhealthy or dangerous coping mechanisms like drugs or alcohol, even eating disorders or self-harming.

It must have been so exciting being a disciple of Jesus-no two days the same, impossible to second-guess Jesus; every moment wondering what He was going to say or do next. But all the disciples found that even when hanging out with Jesus 24/7 there were still times when life got a bit scary and stressful.

One time in particular lets us in on the best coping mechanism of all, one we all need to use, one that will never harm us. The disciples were in a boat, awake because they 'were in trouble... a strong wind had risen and they were fighting heavy waves.' (Matthew 14:24 NLT) Then, out of the darkness, appeared Jesus walking on the water. They all freaked out, thinking He was a ghost! 'But Jesus was quick to comfort them: 'It's all right...I am here. Don't be afraid.' (v27) In this scary, stressy situation all but one disciple chose to stay in the boat. The boat was their coping mechanism. They felt safer there. But 'Peter...walked on the water toward Jesus.' (v29) He knew when life gets scary, tough and stressy, the best thing to do is walk toward Jesus.



SoulFood: Ezra 1-2, John 6:25-34, Ps 98, Pr 24:15-18

content.title: Ride the Waves (2)
content.introtext:
'Peter...walked on the water toward Jesus.' Matthew 14:29 NLT

Perhaps you've been there-you're in church, the music's pumpin', the rooms rockin', God's presence is electric and you're up for doing anything and everything God asks. You feel God's power inside you-nothing is going to stop you now! But then, moments later, you feel helpless, alone, powerless. You're surrounded by temptation again, doubts creep in and you want to give in or give up.

Peter felt exactly the same way. At three o'clock in the morning on a choppy sea he was totally trusting Jesus, and when Jesus asks Him to walk on water-he does! Moments later though, he's lost the plot. He starts to look at the water and the waves and doubts started creeping in: What do you think you're doing? You can't do that, you can't walk on water, no one can! Look at the size of those waves-they're going to swallow you up!

One minute Peter was doing incredible super-hero stuff; the next he was literally drowning, fighting for his life: 'But when he looked around at the high waves, he was terrified and began to sink. Save me, Lord! he shouted.' (Matthew 14:30 NLT) Did Jesus laugh at him, punish him or get angry with him for messing up? No! 'Jesus reached out His hand and grabbed him.' (v31) Did you get that? Instantly! Straight away, Jesus helped him back on his feet when he cried for help-and He will do the same for you.

content.title: Ride the Waves (3)
content.introtext:
'Peter...walked on the water toward Jesus.' Matthew 14:29 NLT

Imagine you're one of the disciples who stayed in the boat and watched Peter walk on the water to Jesus. Then you saw him sink. Would you be laughing at him, shouting 'loser'? Or would you be thinking, 'Did you see that? He just walked on water!' When Jesus helped Peter back in the boat, would you get stuck into him for failing? Or would you be asking, 'What did it feel like to walk on water?' Ok, you could say Peter failed-after all he didn't succeed in what he set out to do because he dropped out half-way and sank! But for a short time, Peter walked on water. He may have crashed and burned publicly, but he experienced the euphoria of walking on water.

He alone knew how it felt to be empowered by God to do what he could never have done by himself. Once you've walked on water you are never the same. So surely the only way Peter could have really failed is if he'd never tried at all?

Winston Churchill said, 'I've never failed at anything in my life. I was simply given another opportunity to get it right.' That's the winning spirit! Just because you sink doesn't mean you're sunk. Failure doesn't come from sinking-it comes when you stop trying. No one gets it right first time every time. So when things go wrong, know you've just been given another chance to get it right-keep on going and you will succeed.



SoulFood: Ezra 6-8, John 6:52-71, Ps 114, Pr 24:23-25

content.title: Ride the Waves (4)

'Peter...walked on the water toward Jesus.' Matthew 14:29 NLT

How boring would it be to go to Dreamworld and not go on any of the rollercoasters? The whole point of going is to scare yourself senseless on the excited thrill of the rides! You might have to stand in a queue for hours before climbing aboard the ride of a lifetime, but aren't you buzzin' when it's all over? content.title: Are you in a hurry?
content.introtext:
'But Jesus often withdrew to lonely places and prayed.' Luke 5:16 NIV

If you're serious about getting serious with God, you can almost guarantee one of the battles you'll face is with hurry. In the world where we live you tend to find two types of people: those who can be bothered, and those who can't. Those who can't suffer from what's called apathy and those who can are usually so focussed on fighting apathy that everything has to be done at warp speed. While this super-sonic way of living starts to get the job done, the pit-falls are normally as follows: (a) you get worn out (b) you get frustrated at what seems like apathy from anyone going slower than you (c) you become so focussed on getting the job done you actually forget to have a relationship with God!

Nobody was in more demand than Jesus but He always knew that there was a time for hurry and a time for rest. Have you ever noticed that despite living a hectic lifestyle Jesus never got stressed out? In those three years he never even felt the need for a little holiday!

The truth is, as much as we complain about it, we love hurry. It keeps the adrenaline pumping and makes us feel important. Jesus never hurried. He had time for people, his diary was flexible. Nothing was so important that he couldn't change his plans for someone. And what's the secret? Solitude. Jesus took time out, away from busyness to be with His Father. Make sure booking time-out for God has the highest priority in your diary this week.



SoulFood: 1 John 1:1-3:10, John 7:14-24, Ps 104:19-26, Pr 24:28

content.title: Take God with you
content.introtext:
'The Lord Himself goes before you and will be with you...' Deuteronomy 31:8 NIV

Surely God would only send those He could trust into enemy territory. Understand this: God cares about where you are. He has selected you for your school, college or work environment. He has already equipped you, or is currently doing so. Your parents wouldn't send you off on a school camp without giving you what you would need while you're away. And God wouldn't either. Sometimes nasty environments can be overwhelming; but by God's grace we can thrive in them! If you'll take God with you and keep your identity in one piece, the enemy will lose ground. Don't let him keep you focused on everything that will do your head in: gossip, peer pressure, being bullied, friends falling out, mountains of homework or nasty people. The danger is that you'll focus on the discomfort of the moment and miss the blessings that lie beyond it. While you're praying for God to change your circumstances and take away your problems, He's saying, 'If only you knew what was waiting for you. Your purpose and destiny are only moments away, and, though not wrapped in shiny paper, they contain all you'll ever need to reach your goal and bring Me glory.' God understands us so well. He knows all about our desire to stay in one place when things become so comfortable, that we just don't want to move! Often He has to trouble the waters so that we'll reach out to Him in desperation, and as a result, tap into strength and success we never knew possible.

content.title: A laugh or a danger?

The shops are full of Halloween masks, costumes, blood and other 'fun' items for little kids. Some Christians will be having meetings to declare 'victory over the darkness' and others will be taking their kids out 'trick or treating'. Whatever you think about Halloween there is no question that it's a night of celebration for Satan and, 'fun' as it may be, it is a very important night for those involved with witchcraft and the occult.

How about a party to celebrate Jesus, dress the kids as angels and things from the Bible (Jesus, an ark, a whale, a dove, a fish etc!)? Let's not teach people what we're against but show them what we have-a magnificent, glorious and beautiful God who has totally beaten Satan already! Harry Potter may be able to manage a few magic tricks but our God can heal the sick, cast out demons, raise the dead to life, give us eternal life AND He's not a made-up character from a fantasy book-He's alive and with us right now!

content.title: Hannah's Prayer
content.introtext:
'The Lord...closed her womb.' 1 Samuel 1:5 NKJ

Poor Hannah-her medical records are known to billions of people throughout history. Her story of not being able to conceive is there for all to read in the book of 1 Samuel. More than anything, this God-fearing woman wanted a child, but the story says: 'The Lord...closed her womb.' We get the sense that Hannah would have made the best, most devoted mother going-so why didn't God give her the desire of her heart? Well, because Hannah wanted a son but God wanted a prophet.

It's almost as if God used Hannah's desperation in order to get her attention and draw her closer into His plans. Through those tough times, Hannah found herself uttering words that locked into God's will: 'If You...give me a son, I will give him back to You all his life.' (1 Samuel 1:11 NCV) By surrendering her greatest desire to God, a whole chain of blessings began to open up. Yes, Hannah got her son, and six more children too (1 Samuel 2:5). And the nation got one of its greatest prophets.

Often the picture is so much bigger than us. Is your heart longing for something or someone but the door seems tightly shut? You have two choices: (1) Allow your frustration to drive you away from God; or (2) Allow your situation to draw you closer to God. Which will it be?

'Be hospitable to one another without grumbling.' 1 Peter 4:9 NKJ

Mother Teresa of Calcutta said this: 'I think the world today is upside down and is suffering so much because there is so very little love in the homes and in family life. We have no time for our children, we have no time for each other; there is no time to enjoy each other...Love begins at home; love lives in homes, and that is why there is so much unhappiness in the world today. If we listen to Jesus He will tell us what He said before: "Love one another, as I have loved you."...If we are to bring that love into life again, we have to begin at home.'

If we don't have time for the people God has chosen to be closest to us, we'll never have time for strangers. And that is where we should be heading in our journey: 'Be hospitable...with brotherly affection for...unknown guests...foreigners, the poor, and all others.' (1 Peter 4:9 AMP)

If we treat our own mum like an unknown guest in our lives, what hope is there for the poor? Let's put the world the right side up, starting in our own homes. Pray for opportunities to serve your parents. Ask God to help you see your annoying little brother through His eyes. Go out on a limb to make your sister's friends welcome. Imagine everyone that steps foot in your house is Jesus and seek to make Him feel at home.

content.title: Wedding Bells (1)
content.introtext:
'Marriage should be honoured by all.' Hebrews 13:4 NIV

Ok, let's run down the list. The invitations, seating plan, dress, shoes, flowers, photographer, venue, menu, cake, rings, bridesmaid, best man, minister...and that's even before we given any thought to the honeymoon! Weddings can be so complex, it's no wonder some of us need wedding planners to ensure the 'perfect' day. If only as much thought went into the marriage as the wedding ceremony.

There are more than 500 references to marriage in the Bible; clearly God thinks we need to treat the subject with a great deal of respect. There aren't too many articles in the Old Testament about choosing the right song for your first dance, or whether your napkins should match the colour of your bridesmaids' outfits. The Bible focuses on the theme of relationships. The Christian story is all about God winning back the relationship His people whipped away from Him. It's all about God restoring our messed-up relationships with each other. Fine-tuning our thoughts on marriage fine-tunes our thoughts on God.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 1-2, John 7:45-53, Ps 9, Pr 24:30-34

content.title: Wedding Bells (2)
content.introtext:
'Marriage should be honoured by all.' Hebrews 13:4 NIV

OK, so your mates file Christian teaching on marriage somewhere in between mum's easy listening CD and dad's cardigan collection: boring and outdated. The idea of not sleeping with someone until public vows have been made before God seems straight out of the Dark Ages.

But the Bible is big on relationships. It teaches that there is more to intimacy than gooey feelings, pretty people and happy times. The core of love is commitment. Gooey feelings and good times were not enough to lead Jesus to the cross. Commitment paved the way for Calvary. God was so committed to restoring our relationships He poured himself out to death, even death on a cross, in order to win us back. A ring on the finger gives us a physical reminder that we are committed to this person in a special way.

Beautiful skin shrivels to wrinkles. Fluttering butterflies in the tummy fly away in the grind of everyday life. That ever-dependable spouse will hurt you at some point. But love remains committed even when you're not 'feeling it'. Paul's letter to Titus groups the word love with respect, self-control, faith and endurance. Not a mention of whether someone sets your pulse racing. Love doesn't pack its suitcase when the birds aren't singing; love chooses to keep committed till the very end.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 3-5, John 8:1-20, Ps 96, Pr 25:1-7

content.title: Wedding Bells (4)
content.introtext:
'Marriage should be honoured by all.' Hebrews 13:4 NIV

If you think marriage looks more like a field of battle than a bed of roses, then you're not far from the truth. Even Jesus spells out the 'rough' over the 'romance'. So did Paul. Listen: '...those who marry will have trouble in this life...' (1 Corinthians 7:28 NCV)

Yet marriage is also an opportunity to learn about love and grace. Its lessons in loving others are about growing as a God-loving person.

See, no matter what your relationship status on Facebook says, you are still called to give out love to everyone. 1 Peter 4:8 GWT says, 'Above all, love each other warmly, because love covers many sins.'

When two people live together, they're face to face with all the peculiarities and downright unlovable stuff about each other. Without a large dose of grace and a quickness of apology the two will end up throwing kitchen appliances at one another. Love always looks for the best even when the best seems to have gone AWOL. Inspired by God's love for us we too should look for the best in others. All relationships have the capacity for love, hate, excitement, disappointment, passion, boredom, healing, hurt, selfishness, selflessness. The largeness of love asks you to look for the best-always.



SoulFood: Gen 5:22-24, Heb 11:5, 2 Kings 2:1-12, Acts 1:9-11

content.title: Successful Failures
content.introtext:
'These things happened...as examples...' 1 Corinthians 10:11 NKJ

The politician caught taking 'gifts' from business colleagues... The trader giving his friends insider tips... Life has a funny way of highlighting hypocrisy, doesn't it? Even the greatest heroes of the Bible had their 'caught with their hands in the till' moments.

Abraham, the 'friend of God', lied about Sarah being his wife. (Genesis 12:10-20) Moses, the mighty leader, got angry and disobeyed God. David, a man after God's heart, committed adultery and then tried to cover his tracks with murder. (2 Samuel 11:15) Peter, leader in the church, denied Jesus not once, but three times (Luke 22:54-62), and John Mark gave up and went home during a missionary trip. (Acts 15:38) They're all in there, warts and all, and as Paul says, '...you, too, may fall into the same sin.' (1 Corinthians 10:12 NLT)

So don't get discouraged when you stumble. Admit your mistake, apologise to the people involved, ask God for forgiveness, forgive yourself, learn from what happened, and move on. Abraham cleaned his slate with all parties and ended up with descendants more numerous than the sands. David repented and is remembered as Israel's greatest king. John Mark is believed to be the writer behind one of only four completely trusted accounts about Jesus: Mark's Gospel. Tripping up doesn't have to stop you from running all-out for Jesus.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 7:20-9:44, John 8:31-41, Ps 30, Pr 25:13-17

content.title: Saltshaker
content.introtext:
'You are the salt of the earth.' Matthew 5:13 AMP

You know those chips where you add your own salt? Well have you ever tried munching before shaking the little sachet? They taste a bit bland and dull, don't they? It's the shake of the salt which kicks your taste-buds into party mode. As friends of Jesus, we're asked to shake our salt to kick life into the world. Jesus said, 'You are the salt of the earth, but if salt has lost its taste...it is not good for anything but to be thrown out.'

It's the strength and quality of salt which brings the flavour out of food. If we're going to flavour this tired, dull life we need the strength and qualities of God: 'the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self-control.' (Galatians 5:22-23 NIV)

So when you choose to love, you're shaking your salt. When you choose to wear a smile despite the tough stuff you're facing, you're shaking your salt. When you choose not to rise to Mr. Angry's threats, you're shaking your salt. When you choose to be patient with that doddering old ditherer at the bus-stop... well, you get the idea.

Love for God is the root; love for others is the fruit. We've all met religious types who can quote whole passages of the Bible, but are sadly lacking in love. They leave a taste like dud salt, only good for throwing out.

content.title: Switching Flanks
content.introtext:
'On the left hand...I cannot see Him.' Job 23:9 AMP

OK, so your right foot can thunder a ball between the goalposts from fifty metres out, but chances are, your left foot couldn't even drop a clanger into the crowd. The best wingers are trained to play on either flank in order to surprise their opponents. And God? Well, He's the best two-footed winger around. God never fails to surprise us when He switches from flank to flank.

Genesis 28 tells the story of God switching flank on Jacob. You see, Jacob was sent away from home to find a wife. God showed up on the journey and revealed there was more at stake than spotting the future Mrs Jacob. Through a dream, Jacob was shown his part in the Bible's big picture.

With God, you can try to second-guess what flank He's on, but it's likely He'll be coming at you from another direction entirely.

Sometimes not knowing how God is going to show up can leave us feeling deserted. During his darkest hours, Job said, 'I go forward...but He is not there; I go backward...but I cannot perceive Him; on the left hand...where He works...I cannot see Him.' (Job 23:8-9 AMP)

Seeing God move in our lives reassures us in our faith, but when He's switched flanks on us, we need not worry that He's forgotten us-we can trust He's working us into the bigger picture.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 10:1-12:22, John 8:42-59, Ps 123, Pr 25:18-20

content.title: Mudguard Your Mouth!
content.introtext:
'Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus...have been a wonderful encouragement to me.' 1 Corinthians 16:17-18 TLB

Read today's verse again. Stephanas who? Fortunatus what? And as for the third bloke-how do you even pronounce his name? We know little about them and yet here they are in the cast list of the biggest-selling book of all time. Most encouragers don't want to be the centre of attention: they're happy playing Mr and Mrs Anonymous. Still this otherwise unknown trio played their role in spurring Paul on in his mission.

Want to be a Stephanas? Someone whose words are like energy food to others' souls? The flipside of encouragement is discouragement. Paul warns us to wash our mouths out of discouragement: 'Do not let any unwholesome talk come out of your mouths, but only what is helpful for building others up...that it may benefit those who listen.' (Ephesians 4:29 NIV)

A word is a weapon. Used carelessly, it can cut deep scars into people's self esteem. Used expertly, it can sharpen the edges of someone's character. A snide remark may get a quick laugh, but it may leave its mark on someone's make-up for a lifetime. Put a mudguard around your mouth and protect those nearest to you from getting a splatter of your muck. Choose words that will encourage slackers and put the exhausted back on their feet. Just as God injects us with confidence, boost others with the same.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 12:23-15:29, John 9:1-12, Ps 15, Pr 25:21-22

content.title: Be What You Believe
content.introtext:
'Be...doers of the word, and not hearers only...' James 1:22 NKJ

Don't think your Geography teacher could teach what he teaches if he believed the world is flat. Or that Muhammad Ali was able to throw a left jab without pounding a lot of punch-bags first. Similarly, you can't really claim to be on first name terms with God if you never do what He says. Your teacher knows what he believes before he opens his mouth. Ali put in the practice before he went toe to toe with the world's best fighters. So should you.

Know what you believe. Get familiar with God and His Word before you talk to others. Then practice what it says before trying to take on the whole world in a fight. If your Bible says, 'Father, hallowed be Your name, Your Kingdom come' (Luke 11:2 NIV), then start practicing it. Start praying like God is someone hallowed, holy and sacred-not your own personal vending machine! Start living like 'Your Kingdom come' means something to you. Letting God have first dibs on your choices allows His Kingdom to come (and not your will be done). If you really believe Jesus meant, 'Give us each day our daily bread,' (Luke 11:3) stop asking for the lifetime loaf. Winning the lottery won't make you happier; chances are it will drive you further from God. So be thankful that God gives you what you need when you need it.

The Bible: don't just read it-live it!



SoulFood: 1 Chron 16-18, John 9:13-23, Ps 105:1-15, Pr 25:23-25
