content.title: Blessings In Struggles
content.introtext:
'That you may be...fully developed...' James 1:4 AMP

Paul kicks off the book of 2 Corinthians with some advice on how to survive life's struggles. The reason his words carry so much weight is because Paul has been there himself. He's not writing this book from the poolside of his holiday home on the Gold Coast, he wrote it from the heat of frontline mission. He faced the missiles from the crowd, saliva in the face, beatings to his body, the lock and key of jails, hostility, suspicion, the lot. Here's a man with a PhD in suffering for the Gospel. So when he advices us to set our hope on God, we know this isn't some sort of fluffy 'warm fuzzy' encouragement, this is advice learned in the pit of suffering itself.

One of the blessings God can pull out of our suffering is that our troubles qualify us to help others facing the same: 'He comforts us every time we have trouble, so when others have trouble, we can comfort them with the same comfort God gives us.' (2 Corinthians 1:4 NCV)

Another blessing pulled out of suffering is that we always find God right in the heart of it. Anything that turns us to God has to be an asset, not a liability. It's when we lose a friend, our health or find ourselves stuck in the desert that we hear God's whisper calling across the wilderness. Hard times help us develop a fine ear for God.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 19:1-23:20, John 9:24-41, Ps 115, Pr 25:26-28

content.title: Badly Burned Boy
content.introtext:
'Watch out that no [bitter] root...grows up [among] you.' Hebrews 12:15 NLT

Remember that bit of childhood wisdom, 'never play with matches'? Only when you clutched that short burnt stick next to a towering inferno could you clearly see why. Bitterness is like that tiny matchstick. The smallest hint of it has the potential to spark a wildfire throughout your life. So how do you throw the water on bitterness before you go up in the flames?

First, forgive. Forgiveness isn't based on an emotion. Don't wait until you 'feel' like it; decide today to free yourself of the crime. When you forgive you open the door for God to heal you. Jesus said, 'Blessed are the merciful: for they shall obtain mercy.' (Matthew 5:7 NIV) Since you yourself will always need to make withdrawals, God calls you to keep making 'mercy deposits'.

Secondly, pray about it. The moment you sense resentment, turn to God and He will give you the strength to act in love rather than react in anger. When you commit to living this way He promises to give you 'power to keep [yourself] calm in the days of adversity.' (Psalm 94:13 AMP)

Thirdly, think Scripturally. Look up every verse you can find on showing forgiveness and meditate on them. Remember, each time you choose to do the right thing, a little more of the 'old you' dies, and the 'new you' develops. Call 000 on bitterness before you end up badly burned.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 23:21-26:19, John 10:1-10, Ps 99, Pr 26:1-6

content.title: Grace For The Pastor
content.introtext:
'Every high priest is selected from among men.' Hebrews 5:1 NIV

A military man wears a combat uniform, designed to shield him from danger. An American footballer is kitted out in protective padding to safeguard him from numerous blows. But what sort of defensive gear does the average minister wear in the spiritual battle?

Your minister or pastor or youth-leader faces the same trials and temptations as you.

Often the reason they can talk about the tough stuff from the front is because they have faced that tough stuff in their lives. Your church leaders have scars and scrapes from life which you can learn from. Don't think just because they look like they have God on speed-dial, that they don't struggle with thoughts, doubts and failures.

So instead of writing them off as people you can't relate to, listen and learn. In fact, instead of jumping straight on what they are and what they're not, hold that critical tongue, and let rip with some serious prayer for them. Your leaders didn't choose this job-God chose them (and you don't want to be caught badmouthing God's choices, right?) So bless your pastor with a kind word, a 'thank you' card and a prayer.

content.title: Elijah (1)
content.introtext:
'There is the sound...of rain.' 1 Kings 18:41 NKJ

So is it going to be sunglasses today or is it going to be umbrella time? The weathermen say one thing, the weather itself says another.

Sometimes when life's getting too hot we need to shut out the weather reports and focus on God-like Elijah did. First, he's part of an impressive 'calling fire down from Heaven' miracle. Then, right after a starring role in the supernatural event of the year, Elijah was plonked straight into a famine. Every bit of human resource had dried up. So what does he do? 'He bowed down on the ground, and put his face between his knees.' (1 Kings 18:42 NKJ)

Good move. Elijah shuts out his surroundings, focuses on God, and keeps praying for an answer. The answer comes as 'a sound of abundance of rain'. There's that contrasting weather report again: Elijah sees famine and dry land, but his spirit senses rain. Even before a drop falls, Elijah senses the solution to drought-a downpour of rain.

There's an important lesson here. When God speaks to your spirit He may go against what circumstances and situations are saying. Your age may be saying, 'you're too young', your bank might be saying, 'you haven't got enough money', your mates might laugh, 'as if!' But if God is asking you to do something, follow Elijah's example-shut out the world and focus on God.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 26:20-29:30, John 10:11-21, Ps 133, Pr 26:7-12

content.title: Elijah (2)
content.introtext:
'Go up now, look toward the sea.' 1 Kings 18:43 NKJ

So here's our prophet, head between his knees, silencing out the world's noise, tuning his thoughts to God FM. And yet there's no sign whatsoever of the rain God promised to end the drought. Six times a rain-spotter is sent on the hunt for a raindrop, and yet six times the rain-spotter comes back dry as a bone. Did Elijah hold his hands up and say, 'Maybe I got my forecast a little confused?' No way. He kept believing, shutting out all the signs and circumstances and holding tightly to God's promiseBy the seventh trip to the seaside, the rain-spotter reports seeing a cloud the size of a small fist. Well, a 15 centimetre cloud is hardly going to rain down the heavens. Yet Elijah took this as a sign for action, basically telling people to prepare for the downpour. We desperately need Elijah-sized faith. Faith which is not disheartened by what we hear or see, but chooses to wear God-goggles throughout the dry times.

Notice that Elijah was getting the same old negative reports: 'Not a drop of rain, mate,' 'Not a cloud in the sky, the sun is shimmering off the sea, Granddad.' But Elijah wasn't influenced by the doom and gloom reports; and nor should we be. The newspapers tell us the world's sick, that we live in a moral drought. But we know we're just getting ready for God's reign.



SoulFood: 2 Chron 1-4, John 10:22-42, Ps 83:1-8, Pr 26:13-16

content.title: Elijah (3)
content.introtext:
'There is a cloud, as small as a man's hand, rising...' 1 Kings 18:44 NKJ

After a long season of drought, God promises Elijah rain. Just before the downpour, there are no looming angry clouds, no ferocious thunder or violent lightning. There's just the smallest, least significant vapour of a cloud-the size of a man's fist.

With God, everything big starts with something small. In fact, if you're not willing to start small, you can't start at all. The servant who kept telling Elijah nothing was happening, finally saw something. It was just a tiny cloud, but it had great potential. God loves to use things we think are insignificant. He used a kid's lunch-box to feed thousands, a catapult to bring down a giant, and a handful of clay to restore a blind man's sight.

He can choose to bless a little job, a little money or a little idea. So little clouds can be indicators of what's coming-when God promises you something, He doesn't need anything big to make it happen. He doesn't look for the brightest idea or the most gifted person to change the world; God looks for someone with a thirst for Him. 'For the eyes of the Lord range throughout the earth to strengthen those whose hearts are fully committed to Him.' (2 Chronicles 16:9 NIV)

Whether it's an Esther or a Paul or a Mother Teresa, a Billy Graham or little old you, God needs only one small committed heart to do massive things.

content.title: Property Boom
content.introtext:
'If you have not been trustworthy with someone else's property...' Luke 16:12 NIV

The grown-ups are off for a weekend at the coast, which means you're in charge-so what do you do? (A) Invite your mates around for a party. (B) Head off to Auntie Pam's for the next 48 hours-that way you won't have to wash up. Or (C) Surprise mum and dad by sweeping out the garage, mowing the lawns and doing the painting that dad never quite got finished.

Those entrepreneurs who answered C get a 'well done good and faithful servant'! Luke 19:20-27 tells the story of a business man who entrusted his wealth to his servants. The slacker is rewarded with a ticking off, whereas the entrepreneurs are given a promotion. Jesus seems to be saying that when you make the most of what you've been given, you are rewarded. First, you'll be given commendation: 'Well done, good and faithful servant!' Next, you'll receive promotion: 'I will put you in charge of many things.' Finally, you'll be honoured with a celebration: 'Come and share your master's happiness.'

God doesn't want us trashing His planet with our careless living. Jesus said, 'And if you have not been trustworthy with someone else's property, who will give you property of your own?' (Luke 16:12 NIV) Bottom line: you won't get what you want until you've learned to use what you've already got.



SoulFood: 2 Chron 8-11, John 11:17-27, Ps 8, Pr 26:23-26

content.title: The Heart of Worship
content.introtext:
'The Father seeks...worshippers.' John 4:23 NAS

It's easier to throw your arms up and abandon your heart to God if the guitar player is in tune and the singer's voice can melt butter, right? Actually, worshipping God doesn't have to involve music at all. So when we catch ourselves thinking 'this song doesn't really do it for me' or 'I'm not really feeling it today' or 'I'm not getting anything out of worship,' we need an urgent rethink.

Paul reminds us what real worship sounds like: '...offer your lives as a living sacrifice... Your offering must be only for God and pleasing to Him, which is the spiritual way for you to worship.' (Romans 12:1 NCV)

When you fall in love with someone, you probably don't treat life like a musical, breaking out into song about your beloved every two minutes. You love someone by spending quality time together, by taking an interest, by sharing secrets, desires, ups and downs, right? Falling in love with God is the same; with the added extra of being assured that God will never do the dirty on you. Worshipping is about giving your heart over to God.

So if a certain song helps lead you into the presence of God, great. But don't leave your heart strapped to a guitar fret board; work the song into your life. Make your own sweet music through your everyday, ordinary life. Make worship a lifestyle; not a track on your iPod.



SoulFood: 2 Chron 12-15, John 11:28-37, Ps 50, Pr 26:27-28

content.title: 'At Ease!'
content.introtext:
'I will walk at liberty and at ease...' Psalm 119:45 AMP

Maths! What a brain-melter! You think you're just getting the hang of trigonometry, when along comes Pythagoras wearing a smug grin. Sometimes life seems like a never-ending maths textbook: you solve one problem when along comes a newer, meatier one. Only life won't allow you a sneak peek at the answers at the back of the book. Unless, of course, the textbook is the Bible.

Jesus said, 'These things I have spoken to you, that in Me you may have peace. In the world you will have tribulation; but be of good cheer, I have overcome the world.' (John 16:33 NKJ) The world promises trouble, but Jesus promises peace: '...learn from Me, because I am gentle and humble. Then you will find rest for yourselves.' (Matthew 11:29 GWT)

How did Jesus manage to keep His cool during the stresses and strains of His hectic life? Crowds draining Him, opposition accusing Him, disciples thirsty for Him; and not once did Jesus pull a sickie. How? Well Jesus lived as much in solitude as He did in the limelight: 'Very early in the morning, while it was still dark, Jesus got up, left the house and went off to a solitary place, where He prayed.' (Mark 1:35 NIV) Spending alone time with God is your essential prescription against stress. Spend double the time with God you'd normally spend stressing and you'll learn to live lightly. That's the kind of maths that does you good.

content.title: A Dark Pull
content.introtext:
'We are not wrestling with flesh and blood...' Ephesians 6:12 AMP

Now it's true that some people use Satan as a kind of 'Get out of jail free' card for their own stupid mistakes. They blame their own lapse in morals on a 'spiritual attack' rather than take responsibility for what's happened. However we should not downplay the fact that there is definitely a 'dark pull' in this world.

When Jesus speaks of fulfilling God's plan on the cross, Peter succumbs to the 'dark pull' and rebukes Him. Jesus sharply replies, 'Get behind Me, Satan! You are in My way...' (Matthew 16:23 AMP) Jesus isn't dissing Peter; he's addressing the real source of the problem. It's almost as if Jesus looks straight through Peter and is talking directly to Satan. We know it's spiritual warfare when the pull in us drags us away from God and His plans.

At the cross Jesus prayed, 'Father, forgive them, for they do not know what they do.' (Luke 23:34 NKJ) Again, Jesus hints that there's more going on here than the people know about. A 'dark pull' has incited the crowds to scream, 'Crucify! Crucify!' Satan manipulates people to tear you away from God. Your battle is therefore not with people but 'against the powers of this dark world' (Ephesians 6:12 NIV), which is why forgiveness is so important. Satan wants you bound by resentment and revenge, but forgiveness leaves you and the other person in God's hand.



SoulFood: Josh 1, Ps 27:11-14, 2 Tim 2:1-13

content.title: One Direction
content.introtext:
'I require your...firstfruits...' Ezekiel 20:40 AMP

Jesus must have been a top story teller-why else would crowds hang on His every word? He could have turned the stories into a five-book publishing contract, sold the rights to Hollywood and made mega-bucks.

Or perhaps He would've been more suited to medical school; after all He had a good eye for identifying diseases and then putting them right. He could have lived a comfortable life on a doctor's salary. He could have stuck with carpentry, making fitted wardrobes and chests of drawers on the side. Jesus didn't ask God to bless His comfortable middle class agenda. He sought God's agenda: 'I always do what pleases Him.' (John 8:29 NIV)

Can you think of any story where Jesus seems stressed out and confused? Nope. That's because He daily sought out God's plan and stuck to it, without swerving left or right.

Feeling pulled in 101 different directions right now? Ask God for His one direction. Jesus rose early in the morning to give God the first part of each day. So often we give God the scraps of our day, barely able to concentrate or keep our eyes open, yet we expect to be able to listen. God requires your first-fruits. If rising with the rooster is not your thing, then choose a time of day that is. When your brain is best in gear, accelerate towards God's direction.

content.title: God guaranteed
content.introtext:
'I will remember My covenant...' Genesis 9:15 NIV

We can get so carried away with the Dr Doolittle aspect of the Noah story, we overlook the happy ending. After the flood proclaimed God's verdict on wickedness, a rainbow was painted across the sky as a promise that no deluge would ever devastate the entire world again. God says to Noah, 'I will remember My covenant which is between Me and you.'

God remembers all the promises He's spoken to you too. Perhaps you were once convinced God had given you a word but now you doubt it. You've little evidence to see that promise coming true. Well, God isn't some wheeler-dealer who'll fob you off with 'the cheque's in the mail.' Hebrews 10:23 GNT says, 'Let us hold on firmly to the hope we profess, because we can trust God to keep His promise.'

Life has a nasty habit of trying to contradict God's promises. One minute you're on a high from God's Word; the next life will spring something on you which is completely in opposite of what you heard. Often, this is a case of 'if you want to see the rainbow, you have to put up with the rain.' The pain of hard times causes a passion to lean more on God, which provides an opening for more blessing. So, if you've scrunched up your promise into a paper ball, remember '...no matter how many promises God has made, they are "Yes" in Christ.' (2 Corinthians 1:20 NIV)

content.title: Be a Barnabas (1)
content.introtext:
'Barnabas...encouraged them all...' Acts 11:22-23 NIV

Being a Christian isn't always happy-clappy, warm, fuzzy feelings. Sometimes people see Jesus in you and get uncomfortable. They single you out for 'freak or unique' treatment. Having Jesus' name stamped on your passport doesn't guarantee you free passage to easy street; in fact, Jesus promises that life will be bumpy if you choose to go His way.

It's always been like that. Never mind 'Christianity: boring, untrue or irrelevant?' Early church Alpha courses would've had sessions entitled, 'Martyrdom: stoning, beheading or crucifixion?'! The first Christians were under so much pressure God had to send them the best encouragers.

One of them-Joseph-was so good at it he was nicknamed Barnabas, 'Son of Encouragement'. He had a special knack for helping people back on their feet when they were feeling the pinch. Acts 11 tells us Barnabas encouraged many to remain true to the Lord, and as the church grew he took a step back to let Paul lead from the front. What an attitude! Barnabas saw the value of stepping out of the limelight in order to best cheer on those up front.

Could you be a Barnabas? '...let us pursue what makes for peace and for mutual upbuilding.' (Romans 14:19 ESV)

content.title: Be a Barnabas (2)
content.introtext:
'Barnabas...encouraged them all...' Acts 11:22-23 NIV

What nickname should your church give you? Motor-mouth? Whinge-bucket? Absent-without-leave? Or 'Son of Encouragement'? When the Bible writers recorded stories involving Joseph of Cyprus, they always used his nickname: Barnabas (which means 'Son of Encouragement'). What a compliment for Joseph, eh?

Examples of his constant source of support are: (1) He put his money where his mouth was. Acts 4 introduces Barnabas as someone who sold a field in order to give money to mission. These aren't just shallow compliments Barnabas is spouting; he's backing his words up with action. (2) He was consistent. Acts 14 tells us that Barnabas accompanied Paul on loads of missionary trips and wherever he went, he'd strengthen Christians. (3) He believed in people. Paul felt let down by John Mark when the kid went AWOL on mission. Barnabas gave him a second chance. Looks like Barnabas was proved right to believe in John Mark, as that same kid seems to have eventually written Mark's Gospel.

Could you be a Barnabas? 'We who are strong in faith should help the weak with their weaknesses, and not please only ourselves.' (Romans 15:1 NCV) Challenge yourself to see others through God's eyes. What inventive ways can you dream up to strengthen and encourage them? Go on, be a Barnabas.

content.title: Learning To Focus On Jesus
content.introtext:
'I have set the Lord always before me...' Psalm 16:8 NKJ

We're quick at checking Facebook and we don't it like when we forget to charge our phone. Why? Because we want to be easy to contact and to stay 'in the loop' at all times. It's a shame we don't quite have that same urgency with God. Be honest, if God were a friend on Facebook, how often would you write on His wall? If Jesus was a contact in your phone, how often would you ring?

Any second of any day, without internet connection or top-up credit, you are able to contact God. All the evidence of history shows how important prayer is. So why do we exercise our fingers on Facebook chat but doze when it comes to clasping them in prayer?

Frank Laubach suggested that you'll think more clearly by including God. At mealtime put an extra chair at the table to remind you He's always present. Set a picture of Jesus or a Scripture where you'll see it as you're falling asleep and waking up. Count on it-this will set the tone for your day.

Nobody's saying you have to become technological, but how about diverting some of that Facebook devotion God's way? How about staying in regular contact with your Creator? Update your God status, write on His wall today and 'know the Lord is always with [you].' (Psalm 16:8 NLT)

content.title: God the Builder
content.introtext:
'I will heal your wounds...' Jeremiah 30:17 AMP

The Great Wall of China is thought to stretch nearly 9,000 km. Built originally to keep out the threat of invaders, that's a whole lot of protection!

Some of us can rival the Great Wall's scale and strength by the invisible barriers we build to keep others out. We think if we don't let anybody in we'll be safe from heartbreak. But in the process of barricading others out, we fence ourselves in, creating a prison cell for our hearts. Rather than rely on our own emotional tactics to keep our hearts a disaster-free zone, why not allow the Lord to be our protector?

Now God doesn't promise we'll never get hurt but He does guarantee healing. Jeremiah 30:17 AMP tells us: 'For I will restore health to you, and I will heal your wounds, says the Lord.' Following Jesus means following love, because 'God is love'. Whenever we enter the territory of love we expose our hearts to potential hurt. God put His heart up for pain when He gave up His Son in sacrificial death. 1 John 4:21 GNT tells us that '...whoever loves God must love others also.'

Are you ready to be susceptible to pain? Now is the time to start removing brick-by-brick the wall you've constructed to keep others out. Yes, you'll feel vulnerable but God is with you. God your perfect builder will take great care putting you back together.



SoulFood: Eccl 11:7-12:1, Ps 39:4-13, 2 Tim 4:6-8

content.title: The Next Generation
content.introtext:
'Let the little children come to Me...' Mark 10:14 NKJ

You could change somebody's life forever right now. And all it would take is volunteering to help out with next week's Sunday school. Today's children really are tomorrow's future. By the time a child is five they've learned 75 percent of everything they'll know in life. So if you want to make an impression, that's the time to do it.

In Mark 10 we read about the know-it-all disciples wafting the children away like a bad smell, but Jesus wasn't too happy with this. He says 'let the little children come to me.' Jesus admires the innocent, unwavering trust children have and challenges us to learn from them. Perhaps, if we took God's hand more often across the road, we'd find ourselves in more playful adventures.

Jesus loved and encouraged children: 'He took them up in His arms, laid His hands on them, and blessed them.' Wow! Those children would never forget that experience. Imagine looking back to a moment in your life when the Lord picked you up, held you in His arms, laid His hands on you and blessed you!

Well, in years to come, wouldn't it be fantastic to be remembered as the person who excited some great Christian leaders about God when they were kids? Do something beautiful today-invest in a child's tomorrow.

content.title: Unyielding For God
content.introtext:
'Blessed is the man...whose confidence is in [God].' Jeremiah 17:7 NIV

Remember Jesus on tour of His hometown? There was no grand reception or 'welcome home' banners strung around the place. His childhood neighbours sneered, 'Isn't this the carpenter's son?' (Matthew 13:55 NIV) They might as well have spat in his tea and scoffed, 'Who do you think you are?' In their heads Jesus should get back to hammers and chisels and stop with this 'ministry' nonsense.

Have you ever been there? God has done a beautiful work in you and all people can say is: 'Who do you think you are?' Next time, tell them straight: '...because of Christ, we have received an inheritance from God, for He chose us from the beginning, and all things happen just as He decided long ago.' (Ephesians 1:11 NLT)

Don't let other people's opinions and expectations shackle your feet. 'Blessed is the man who trusts in the Lord, whose confidence is in Him.' Only one opinion matters: God's. And He's already given you the seal of approval. 'Be humble under God's powerful hand so He will lift you up when the right time comes. Give all your worries to Him, because He cares about you.' (1 Peter 5:6-7 NCV) With God shouting in your corner you're capable of writing history, and don't let anyone tell you otherwise.

content.title: What Goes Around Comes Around
content.introtext:
'The deeds of a man's hands will return to him.' Proverbs 12:14 NAS

A woman noticed an old man struggling to fix his flat tyre in the midday sun. She hoped someone would stop and help but when nobody did, she went back and found the old man weak and perspiring. 'Thanks,' he gasped. 'I prayed somebody would stop.'

The man introduced himself as Bill Krumweide; he talked about his family and his hobby of collecting antique farm equipment. He offered to pay her but the Good Samaritan said, 'Just knowing I was an answer to prayer is enough.' Ten years later the same lady was worried about her aging father, who could no longer take care of the family farm. When she called in a volunteer organisation for help, one of the volunteers looked familiar, and when he introduced himself she realised why. It turned out he was the elderly man's son, Bill Krumweide Jr. 'Thank you for helping my dad all those years ago,' he said. 'I'm the one who owes you,' the woman replied. 'It's amazing how one kindness followed another and connected our families in a bond of gratitude. And it started...with an old man's prayer.'

What goes around comes around: 'The deeds of a man's hands will return to him.' God rewards us 'according to [our] work.' (Proverbs 24:12 NAS) The Bible says, 'knowing that whatever good anyone does, he will receive the same from the Lord...' (Ephesians 6:8 NKJ)

content.title: Getting Along With Each Other (1)
content.introtext:
'Be of one mind, united in thought and purpose...' 1 Corinthians 1:10 NLT

If you keep bailing out of relationships every time they hit troubled waters, you'd better get used to your own company-it's the only company you'll have! Relationships can't be based on seeing eye-to-eye on all points, but on a commitment to love each other and a willingness to work for peace. Jesus said, 'God blesses those who work for peace.' (Matthew 5:9 NLT) Notice, peacemaking is 'work', but the rewards are worth it.

Relationships are always worth restoring. God wants us to value our relationships instead of discarding them every time a problem comes along. Paul wrote, 'Does your life in Christ give you strength? Does His love comfort you? ...If so, make me very happy by...sharing the same love, and having one mind and purpose.' (Philippians 2:1-2 NCV)

God wants His family to be known for their love. Strife and bickering send the wrong message to a watching world. Paul was embarrassed when the church in Corinth started splitting into warring factions and taking each other to court. 'Surely there is at least one wise person...who can settle a dispute between fellow Christians.' (1 Corinthians 6:5 GNT) He was shocked and disappointed that nobody was mature enough to resolve conflict peacefully. So he wrote, '...be of one mind, united in thought and purpose...'

'Be of one mind, united in thought and purpose...' 1 Corinthians 1:10 NLT

It isn't easy approaching the person with whom you've had a 'friendship malfunction' or 'relationship meltdown'. Sometimes to apologise can seem as appealing as sucking up a sand milkshake. But God wants what's best for you. He doesn't want you to keep a cocktail of resentment, bitterness, hurt and anger emotions in your system. He wants us to 'go and be reconciled to that person.' (Matthew 5:24 NLT) It's not a sign of weakness to be willing to forgive someone who's hurt you; it's a sign of strength. You're choosing not to be beaten by leaving yourself stuck with hate, but to instead overcome it and move on with peace.

Running to God when we're finding someone difficult and trying to do things Jesus-style will not only help us with our own feelings and circumstances, but it can also enable us to become better friends. Take this little gem: 'Be quick to listen, slow to speak and slow to get angry.' (James 1:19-20 NLT) Let's be honest, we'd all like to receive a bit of that, especially when trying to get our point across. Take a leaf out of James' book!

Loving can cost. Loving can even feel unjust. But remember what Jesus did for you on the cross. He died for us when we were His enemies; He died a sinless man for our sin. The Bible says that if we humble ourselves before the Lord and obey Him, He will hear and forgive us (2 Chronicles 7:14). Fixing something actually takes effort. When we really care about something, we have to think about the best way to do it properly! Uh-oh! Hello, brain ache! What can be even more work for the old greymatter is when you're trying to fix something more precious than your Aunt Vera's favourite teapot. It's a lot harder to fix a friendship. Oops, here comes a migraine!

Fortunately, we're not alone. God has given us lots of help in the Bible on the issue of fixing broken relationships. Here are some top tips: 'If another believer sins against you, go privately and point out the fault.' (Matthew 18:15 NLT) 'A gentle answer will calm a person's anger, but an unkind answer will cause more anger.' (Proverbs 15:1 NCV) If you go in with a mindset to listen and respond in a calm way, it will help your temper! 'Use...only helpful words...so that what you say will do good to those who hear you.' (Ephesians 4:29 GNT)

People's reactions to us can very often become easier to accept or understand when we resist hurtling straight in with how wrong they've been, and instead, hold back, listen and take on board how someone else feels about what we've said or done. So keep away from the 'Blame Game'. You're trying to move on and become friends again, remember, not to stay stuck in your own muddy pride puddle!

content.title: Your Faith On Trial

'Do not think it strange...' 1 Peter 4:12 NKJ

Do you just skip through life with the Lord, while kittens and lambs dance around your feet? Nah. Sometimes it can seem like you're being beaten up by circumstances and situations. And there are moments that can really shake your faith.

God never said we wouldn't face tough times, but He does promise to keep hold of us and help us through to the other side. 'People who do what is right may have many problems, but the Lord will solve them all.' (Psalm 34:19 NCV) We often learn and grow more as a person when we're going through challenges than we do when life is all hunky-dory. This is mainly because when things seem way too big for us, we finally decide to put more faith in what God can do for us and through us, rather than depending on what we can do on our own.

God didn't make us to be like androids-to never feel or grow. Through tough times we can develop characteristics such as compassion and patience and grow in our relationship with God.

God really wants us to come to Him with all things, not just the hard bits; that's when we really start to shine in who we are in Christ: 'I can do everything with the help of Christ, who gives me the strength I need.' (Philippians 4:13 NLT)

content.title: Denominationalism
content.introtext:
'That all of them may be one...' John 17:21 NIV

In Heaven there will be no religious labels. If someone has the right to call Jesus 'Lord', you must treat them as your brother or sister regardless of which church they attend. We're all related by blood-the blood of Jesus! The Bible tells us to 'preserve the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace.' (Ephesians 4:3 NAS) Notice, God doesn't tell us to create unity, He tells us to preserve it.

Comedian Elmo Phillips used to tell this story: 'In a conversation I had recently, I asked, "Are you a Protestant or a Catholic?" My new acquaintance replied, "Protestant." I said, "Me too!" I asked, "What franchise?" He answered, "Baptist." "Me too!" I said. "Northern Baptist or Southern Baptist?" "Northern Baptist," he replied. "Me too!" Finally I asked, "Northern Conservative Fundamentalist Baptist, Great Lakes Region, Council of 1879, or Northern Conservative Fundamentalist Baptist, Great Lakes Region, Council of 1912?" He replied, "'Northern Conservative Fundamentalist Baptist, Great Lakes Region, Council of 1912." I said, "Die, heretic!"'

Seriously, do you know what Jesus prayed for? 'That all of them may be one...so that the world may believe.' A divided church is a wounded and weak church. What would happen if we downplayed our labels and put our contents on display instead? Maybe we wouldn't need signs outside our door to attract people, because they'd be drawn by the love of those inside. Worth thinking about, isn't it?



SoulFood: Jos 19:24-21:45, John 16:12-18, Ps 2, Pr 28:25-28

Do you love those bits in films when you see a character's dream scenario acted out? Chick-flicks always seem to have one. The scene opens with Crystal the Cheerleader, opening her mouth around a cheeseburger bigger than her head. Suddenly the shot changes to the school bell ringing; it's dream over and back to class for Crystal and her half-eaten celery stick.

Would the film of your dream look like this? Your exam questions fly around you, while you furiously write an essay with one hand, stop your little brother sticking a biro in his ear with the other and let your heartbroken friend squeeze you like her teddy bear, as you give her the same advice you did yesterday.

But then you stop it all by yelling, 'Enough!' they all vanish and, behold, you're on a beach chilling out under a palm tree.

You might love your family and friends and want to help them, but sometimes it can get a bit much. Don't suffer in silence: it's ok to ask for help too, you know. The Bible says: 'A person standing alone can be...defeated, but two can stand back-to-back and conquer. Three are even better.' (Ecclesiastes 4:12 NLT) Also, drinking up truth from God's Word can relax and revitalise you like nothing else: 'Come to me, all of you who are tired from carrying heavy loads, and I will give you rest.' (Matthew 11:28 GNT)

content.title: To Infinity and Beyond!
content.introtext:
'We were bold in our God...' 1 Thessalonians 2:2 NKJ

The thing all those Christian heroes you read about in books have in common is boldness. You know the type-at the age of 17, our protagonist saves an entire tribe of pygmies armed only with a Gideon's Bible and a dose of courage to rival Buzz Lightyear.

Have you ever dared believe that tomorrow's Christian hero biography could be yours? Seriously! The same Spirit that lives in Nicky Cruz, Brother Andrew and Jackie Pullinger lives in you. In fact, here's a mind-blowing thought: Jesus (He who walked on water and raised people from the dead) says 'anyone who has faith in Me will do what I have been doing. He will do even greater things than these...' (John 14:12 NIV)

What?! It seems Jesus is encouraging anyone with enough confidence in God to go on a history-changing, law-of-nature-defying, adventure of a lifetime. But in order to do it, you're going to need to be brave. We're not talking the kind of bravery needed for Tower of Terror II at Dreamworld; we're talking about an audacious confidence in God. We're talking about the ability, to not just study God's Word, but to act upon it. Moses didn't hang about in discussion groups arguing about whether God could part the sea; he took God at His word and placed his feet into the Red Sea. Go on, be brave-have the boldness to take God at His word.



SoulFood: Col 1-2, John 17:1-12, Ps 147:12-20, Pr 29:6-10

content.title: Esau and Jacob (1)
content.introtext:
'Isaac...loved Esau, but Rebekah loved Jacob.' Genesis 25:28 NIV

Esau and Jacob had issues, to say the least. Seriously, these guys put the 'fun' in 'family dysfunction'. From birth there was trouble. Esau was the first to be born, and so the story goes, Jacob was not far behind, snatching the ankle of his twin brother. A severe case of sibling rivalry was not helped by Mum and Dad. Daddy Isaac unashamedly loved Esau more, whereas Mummy Rebekah was biased towards Jacob.

These were pre-Supernanny days, so with no helping hand to give a few lessons in parenting, the boys were allowed to tear the family apart. Esau comes across as a man's man-a hairy, rugged caveman who worked with his hands in the outdoors, always muddying mum's freshly mopped floor. Jacob is classic mummy's boy material; the indoors type, good in the kitchen, perhaps he was even an embarrassment to dad and bro's testosterone-fuelled culture.

It seems neither boy completely matched up to both parents' expectations. And because the brothers weren't loved unconditionally, division occurred. Esau lived separated from his brother, without the blessing of his father; whereas Jacob left the family home and lived like a wanderer. Do you feel like you've failed your parents' expectations? Maybe your parents have failed you too. But remember God loves you for who you are, not what you can do.



SoulFood: Col 3-4, Philemon, John 17:13-26, Ps 148:1-6, Pr 29:11-15

content.title: Esau and Jacob (2)
content.introtext:
'Isaac...loved Esau, but Rebekah loved Jacob.' Genesis 25:28 NIV

Rebekah favoured Jacob and schemed to steal her eldest son's blessing from her husband. She sent Jacob into his dad's tent armed with a bowl of the latest Masterchef recipe and a full-on Esau disguise (there was probably at least one chest wig involved). Old nearly-blind Isaac, who should've gone to Specsavers, fell for the whole swindle.

From that moment on, the warring brothers became estranged from each other. Jacob began a lifetime on the run, fearful that big bro would kick every lungful of conniving, ankle-grabbing, birthright-stealing breath out of him. Could it have been that Isaac's blatant favouritism for an all-action, sporty man's man left Jacob with deep psychological scars? Perhaps Jacob was uncomfortable in his own skin and running away from home was as much about him running away from himself.

Jacob's pivotal moment occurred when he was on the run. Face to face with an angel, he got asked, 'Who are you?' By that time, Jacob was done pretending-he knew he'd never be Esau. The struggling, broken young man answered, 'I'm Jacob'. He started to become comfortable in his own skin. Today's word: Stop pretending to be what you're not and start appreciating yourself for who you are.



SoulFood: Neh 1-4, John 18:1-11, Ps 148:7-14, Pr 29:16-21

content.title: Esau and Jacob (3)
content.introtext:
'Isaac...loved Esau, but Rebekah loved Jacob.' Genesis 25:28 NIV

So we saw what became of Jacob, but whatever happened to Esau? 'When Esau was forty years old, he married Judith, daughter of Beeri the Hittite, and also Basemath daughter of Elon the Hittite. They were a source of grief to Isaac and Rebekah.' (Genesis 26:34-35 NIV)

So why all the misery? Well, Esau went against the family way here: Hittite or Canaanite women would've been a serious no-no when it came to a bride. By marrying them he went against his parents' wishes and opened himself up to the influence of ungodly customs and practices. No wonder Mum and Dad were upset. Genesis 27:46 says that Rebekah wasn't just grieved, she was 'disgusted with living because of [Esau's] Hittite women.'

Perhaps Esau felt it was payback time for after all those years of bad parenting. After all, why should he respect his mother's choice of suitable women for marriage, when he's hardly been shown any respect from her? Maybe you too have had your Esau moments: 'My best is never good enough, so why bother?' or 'You say one thing and do another. So why should I listen?' or 'So I can't do this? I'll show you!'

The 'I'll show you!' attitude will bite you on the backside. Don't chuck your life away just to make a point. 'The way of the guilty is devious, but the conduct of the innocent is upright.' (Proverbs 21:8 NIV) Make your decisions from a pure heart, not a spiteful one.



SoulFood: Jos 1:7-8, 2 Tim 3:14-17, Ps 119:1-16

content.title: Esau and Jacob (4)
content.introtext:
'Isaac...loved Esau, but Rebekah loved Jacob.' Genesis 25:28 NIV

Those eight long 'Esau versus Jacob' chapters in Genesis could have looked so different had that earlier verse read, 'Isaac and Rebekah loved the twins both unconditionally' (Genesis 25:28 The Revised 'If only' Version). Unbeknown to them, Isaac and Rebekah were creating a family environment ripe for rivalry, mistrust, bitterness and betrayal.

As Rebekah sets about dressing Jacob as Esau, we are given a living metaphor for identity crisis. Not only was Jacob played off against his brother, he was at that point literally pretending to be him. Perhaps you've known something similar as your own mother has said, 'Why can't you be more like your brother (or sister, or best friend)?' Whenever you're compared to someone else, it's simply not fair. The reason you don't quite have as neat handwriting as the guy next to you or you don't kick a ball as skilfully as the kid from down the road is because you are unique. And that's a good thing.

Nobody on this planet has the same mix of genetic DNA, life experiences, gifts and talents, strengths and weaknesses, personality and character traits, understanding and expressions, as you. You are a one-off priceless masterpiece, carefully knitted together by a Creator who doesn't make mistakes. Comparing you to your neighbour is like comparing a Van Gogh to a Picasso; you're both works of genius. '...it is when the Lord thinks well of us that we are really approved...' (2 Corinthians 10:18 GNT)



SoulFood: Neh 5-7, John 18:12-24, Ps 150, Pr 29:22-27

content.title: First Steps
content.introtext:
'Be transformed by the renewing of your mind...' Romans 12:2 NKJ

Imagine a one-year-old child is taking his first footsteps. He feels for his balance, steadies his arms, places one foot in front of the other and then crashes down on his nappy. Now imagine his dad rushes straight over, steam hissing out of his ears, and barks in his face, 'Pathetic! That's the second time you've failed this morning! Will you ever learn? It's easy-just place one foot in front of the other. Oh, and another thing; stop pooping in your pants. It's so immature!'

There's something wrong with the picture, isn't there? What father would dismiss a learning child like this? Well, perhaps some of us need to repaint our mental picture of God as our loving Father. Some of us get so frustrated when we fall on our spiritual backsides; we think God is steaming at the ears with us. We convince ourselves that God must've lost patience with us by now. We believe that we've somehow made ourselves unlovable and that God is either blanking us, or at the very least, just humouring us.

Your heavenly dad isn't fuming that you've fell over; He's proud that you tried a few steps. So rather than fixing your eyes on everything that you can't do, everything you can't seem to change, '...let God transform you into a new person by changing the way you think.' (Romans 12:2 NLT)



SoulFood: Neh 8-10, John 18:25-40, Ps 105:1-7, Pr 30:1-4

content.title: Playing Happy Families (1)
content.introtext:
'My conduct will be faultless...in my house...' Psalm 101:2 GNT

When two people get married, they usually expect a Hollywood happy ending. But life isn't always holding hands on the beach and picnics on mountaintops. Sometimes people decide to divorce, even when they have children together whom they both love. Divorce is painful for everybody, and never an easy decision. The upshot is that a high percentage of children today are brought up in homes with two adults who aren't both their biological parents.

If this is about to be your story, it's completely ok if you're feeling sad or scared. It may take a long time to feel comfortable with this new family unit, so don't feel guilty if you're not quite feeling your parent's new-found zest for life. Suddenly having a new adult in your life can be very disorientating. You may wonder what to call them (sometimes it's easier to call them by their first name, rather than 'mum' or 'dad'.) You might feel awkward that you quite like this new person, worried that you are somehow betraying your real mum or dad.

Chances are this is really about feeling the loss of what you once had. Well, don't deny your feelings. Jesus says, 'Those...who grieve...will find comfort!' (Matthew 5:4 CEV) It therefore follows that those who pretend everything's fine may not. In short, it's ok to lament the past before rolling into the future.



SoulFood: Neh 11-13, John 19:1-16, Ps 105:8-15, Pr 30:5-9

content.title: Playing Happy Families (2)
content.introtext:
'My conduct will be faultless...in my house...' Psalm 101:2 GNT

So we're dealing with our feelings when it comes to living with a new step-parent or being part of what's called a 'blended family'. Having no previous history with this new adult in your life, you may be left wondering about new rules and whether you have to listen to your new step-parent. Hopefully, this new adult is someone else looking after your interests and welfare, so it's a good idea to afford them the same level of respect you'd offer your mum, dad or teacher.

You might worry about school holidays or Christmas time; where will you be when presents are handed out? Any worry is a legitimate worry. You might want to talk it through with a parent alone or call a family meeting; whatever way best suits you. Getting used to this other person watching TV shows that you never watch, taking extra-long baths when you want a shower, or laughing at jokes which just aren't funny, can take some effort.

It's not easy adapting to a new way of life. Sharing mum or dad with a new person definitely takes some getting used to. So don't bottle your feelings up or deliberately try and make life difficult. Let your mum or dad know what's going on with you. Understand yourself and each other. After all, 'It takes wisdom to have a good family, and it takes understanding to make it strong.' (Proverbs 24:3 NCV)



SoulFood: Micah 1-4, John 19:17-30, Ps 105:16-22, Pr 30:10-14

content.title: Heavenly Dad (1)
content.introtext:
'For He is always thinking about you.' 1 Peter 5:7 TLB

In the introduction to his book The Father Heart of God, Floyd McClung writes about a painting by artist Karel Appel. He describes the painting: a tall, stick-like, lifeless monster with dark harsh colours. The writer is saddened to learn the original title of the artist's work: My Father. He says, 'What kind of relationship did Karel Appel have with his father? Even more important, how [did] that affect his view of God? If Karel Appel believed in God...did he believe Him to be a loving Father?'

Perhaps some of us suffer from Karel Appel's artistic eye. Bad experiences of unreliable parenting, scary father figures or absent dads leave their mark on us. They make it hard for us to accept God as a perfect, loving Father. Too many of us imagine a monstrous overbearing father, short on patience, looking down on us.

Jesus didn't just call God His Father, He called God 'Abba'. Now, 'Abba' doesn't translate perfectly into English, but to get a feel for the meaning of the word, imagine a small child, looking up with love and saying 'Dada'. Jesus often advises us to behave like kids when it comes to trusting in God, because he understands how much God loves us unconditionally, like a proud dad to a newborn baby. All theology and bad experiences aside, today Dada God wants to lift you off your feet with His big, heavenly bear-hugs.



SoulFood: Micah 5-7, John 19:31-42, Ps 105:23-36, Pr 30:15-19

content.title: Heavenly Dad (2)
content.introtext:
'For He is always thinking about you.' 1 Peter 5:7 TLB

The problem with language and God is that eventually our language lets us down. We desperately want to understand that God is warm and loving and approachable, so our language comes up with ways to say this. We start to describe God as a dad.

The problems start because the word 'dad' conjures up all kinds of ideas and images for different people. Dad might be chained to his work office for most of the week. So, because dad is never around, we get the idea that God is somehow distant, too busy for us. Dad might be tired and grumpy. So, because we're made to feel like a nuisance around our dad, we picture God as angry and quick to jump on us. Dad may not have been around for years. So it becomes hard to relate to God the Father, as we don't really know what it's like to have a dad in our lives.

Our minds try to paint a picture of God, but the image becomes hopelessly distorted because of our flawed experiences. Jesus once said, 'He who has seen Me has seen the Father.' (John 14:9 RSV) The qualities of Jesus point us to the qualities of our heavenly Father: forgiving and merciful, loving and patient, inclusive and accepting. Through Jesus' love and concern for people we see what God the Father really looks like.



SoulFood: 2 Tim 1-4, John 20:1-9, Ps 105:37-45, Pr 30:20-23

content.title: Heavenly Dad (4)
content.introtext:
'For He is always thinking about you.' 1 Peter 5:7 TLB

The baby left whimpering in a cot, tired of crying and nobody coming. The young child shushed in front of the TV so as not to disturb dad. The girl singing solo in the school show with no mum or dad to clap on the night. It's no wonder we struggle to completely trust God the Father when we've been let down by our earthly parents.

If our minds are wrestling to think of a time when God has ever shown He loved us, it's because those who should have loved us have let us down. God's love should be modelled through the arms, hearts and voices of those nearest to us in our lives. Your heavenly Father stored away each tear as you whimpered in your cot. Your heavenly Father pulled up a seat next to you as you were silenced, alone in front of the television. Your heavenly Father was the first on His feet applauding as you sang your heart out at the school concert.

If you've reached today without experiencing God's love for you, then know this: God hasn't let you down, people have. Your family home should have been four walls of love, acceptance, forgiveness and security-a place to experience God's love. No matter who you are, or where you're from, God your loving Father awaits you today with two outstretched arms ready to hug away those hurts from now into eternity.



SoulFood: Zech 1-4, John 20:10-18, Ps 57, Pr 30:24-28

content.title: God-guided (1)
content.introtext:
'Led by the Spirit of God...' Romans 8:14 NKJ

Have you ever had the idea God was asking you to do something but you make the fatal error of broadcasting it? Suddenly, everybody has to give you their ten cents worth. Mum says one thing, your mates say another and even one or two people with 'I've got a word from God...' which is a Bible verse that leaves you scratching your head wondering whether it has anything to do with your idea at all.

It's always a good idea to test an idea with people who have a good track record for godly wisdom, but when all's said and done, it's up to you to hear from God about your own life. The responsibility is all yours. If you're not careful you can be pulled in all sorts of directions and end up absolutely nowhere. 'The Lord is good and does what is right; He shows the proper path to those who go astray.' (Psalm 25:8 NLT)

So how can you make sure where God is leading? Honest prayer. God doesn't get cross when we present our confusion to Him. Hold your hands up and speak what's on your heart. For example: 'God, I'm confused right now. I think I'm hearing you but I need to make sure. Please make it clear to me-what should I do?'

When we spend enough time listening, soon a peace will silence all the other voices and you'll gain the confidence to step out.



SoulFood: Zech 5-8, John 20:19-31, Ps 67, Pr 30:29-33

content.title: God-guided (2)
content.introtext:
'Led by the Spirit of God...' Romans 8:14 NKJ

There's a warning in the Old Testament to listen to God rather than the voices of men. God's people are told to take hold of the Promised Land for themselves but everybody, except Joshua and Caleb, listens to the voice of fear. Reports become so exaggerated people are too scared to hear the voice of God.

If you really believe God has tasked you an assignment, get on with it. There'll always be the Pessimism Pack telling you it can't be done. There'll always seem to be others off on exciting adventures that will make you feel like small fish. And there's bound to be butterflies criss-crossing your stomach. Listen for God's guidance then throw yourself off the high board. 'I am Your servant; give me understanding, so that I may know Your teachings... The explanation of Your teachings gives light and brings wisdom to the ignorant.' (Psalm 119:125, 130 GNT)

The key is to focus on your potential, not your limitations. We all have limitations, so it's good to learn to accept them. In fact, it's our limitations that stop us from running away with ourselves thinking it's our job to save the world. It's not our job, it's God's job. Our limits will take us to our knees and draw on His strength. 'Even the foolishness of God is wiser than human wisdom, and the weakness of God is stronger than human strength.' (1 Corinthians 1:25 NCV)



SoulFood: Zech 9-11, John 21:1-14, Ps 12, Pr 31:1-5

content.title: Kingdom First (1)
content.introtext:
'Seek the Kingdom of God above all else...' Matthew 6:33 NLT

You know when you read a word over and over (and over and over again) it begins to lose its meaning? It can be the same with God's Word. We study it over and over (and over and over again) until we lose what it's really saying to us.

Like, 'Our Father in Heaven, hallowed be Your name, Your kingdom come, Your will be done...' (Matthew 6:9-10 NIV) We can repeat those words so many times parrot-fashion that we lose what they mean. We can rattle them off like a spiritual good luck charm without stopping to think about the meaning. If we're really serious about God's Kingdom coming, and His will being done, then we give God permission to have His way in our lives. Did you get that? His way-not ours. When God says stop, we stop. When God says go, we go.

'...it is not merely knowing the law that brings God's approval. Those who obey the law will be declared right in God's sight.' (Romans 2:13 NLT) So when God says we should love our enemies, what do we do? Deconstruct it as a line of poetry or actually do it? Actively care for our rivals? When Jesus tells us to give a gift to those in need, what do we do? Nod along in agreement to this lofty ideal, or do we actually hit our pockets where it hurts and bless the poor?

content.title: Kingdom First (2)
content.introtext:
'Seek the Kingdom of God above all else...' Matthew 6:33 NLT

Yesterday we started to look at the difference between knowing what the ink in your Bible says and knowing what the ink in your heart does. Matthew 12:50 NCV says, 'My true brother and sister and mother are those who do what my Father in Heaven wants.'

Jesus says we should be compassionate, and yet how many times do we walk straight past the guy collecting for charity as if he were a ghost? Jesus says we should patch up with friends who've hurt us. He doesn't mention anything about revenge. He doesn't say we should cheer when that friend comes a cropper. Jesus says we should surrender ourselves: 'If any of you wants to be My follower, you must put aside your selfish ambition, shoulder your cross, and follow Me.' (Matthew 16:24 NLT) Notice He doesn't say, 'Pray, pray and pray again until God changes His mind and follows your plans.' Jesus says we should think like a servant, not elbow our way to the front or hoist ourselves to the top.

We should use our talent and muscle to help others rise to the top. Putting the Kingdom of God above all else isn't in line with the 'I, me, mine' disease of modern life. 'You can enter God's Kingdom only through the narrow gate. The highway to hell is broad, and its gate is wide for the many who choose the easy way.' (Matthew 7:13 NLT)

content.title: Reasons for wrapping
content.introtext:
'Don't do your good deeds publicly, to be admired by others...' Matthew 6:1 NLT

It's Christmas Eve. If what's on your mind most is: 'What will I get?', you need to start thinking about Christmas the right way up! Christmas is all about giving, not getting.

How did you decide who to give pressies to this Christmas? Do you only give presents to those who will give one back? Are you good at guesstimating how much someone will spend on you so you don't spend more on them? Are some crossed off your Christmas list because you don't like them, don't know them or think they deserve nothing from you? What are your reasons for wrapping? What are your motives for giving?

The Bible says, 'Be careful not to do your good works in public in order to attract attention. If you do, your Father in Heaven will not reward you.' (Matthew 6:1 GWT)

Look how God gives: He gave the most precious thing He had to everyone. He didn't pick favourites, He gave to all; He didn't scrimp on the budget, He gave the most valuable thing He had; He didn't give because we'd done so well and deserved such a gift, He gave because He wanted us to have what we needed. He didn't give His gift under certain contractual conditions, He gave freely, knowing we would destroy His priceless gift: 'For God loved the world so much that He gave His one and only Son, so that everyone who believes in Him will not perish but have eternal life.' (John 3:16 NLT)

content.title: The camels are coming
content.introtext:
'They entered the house... they...worshipped Him...and gave Him gifts.' Matthew 2:11 NLT

Living the Christian life isn't exactly the easiest. But it is definitely the most exciting and best. Take Mary and Joseph. Getting pregnant when you're an unmarried teenager is hard enough today. Back then it was much tougher. But this is what God asked Mary to do. He worked one of His fantastic-but freaky-miracles so she would conceive a baby, leaving her to explain her innocence to her fianc, Joseph. He, of course, was confused. Come on, put yourself in his shoes. He hadn't slept with her but she was pregnant, supposedly with the Son of God!

Joseph wasn't at all convinced until God turned up in his dreams. Then he chose to obey. Still, it wasn't easy-imagine the gossip, the back-stabbing, the parties they weren't invited to. Then there was that torturous journey to Bethlehem, giving birth in the cold and putting the baby in an animal trough-disgusting just doesn't cut it.

Mary and Joseph just went were God placed them and did what He asked. Result: God brought to them everything they needed. They never went out or sent messages asking for presents on that first Christmas Day. And later, God sent them wise men on camels loaded with gifts. God will provide for you too-the camels are coming-so hang in there.

content.title: Post-Christmas blues
content.introtext:
'The Lord is close to the brokenhearted...' Psalm 34:18 NIV

Have you got the post-Christmas blues? The excitement of yesterday's pressies and partying has worn off. You've OD'd on chocolate and TV Christmas specials; Christmas carols have turned into Christmas quarrels and you really can't face a visit to Grandma and her sloppy kisses.

Perhaps Christmas is something you dread-there's no festive jolly joy for you. 'Here it is, Merry Christmas, everybody's having fun,' blasts out on the radio for the umpteenth time and you want to scream at it, 'Not everyone's having fun!' You're right, just because it's Christmas doesn't mean all our problems disappear or we have a break from our struggles-but Christmas is the solution, not the salt in the wound.

Christina Rossetti wrote, 'What can I give Him, Poor as I am? If I were a shepherd I would bring a lamb, If I were a wise man I would do my part, Yet what I can I give Him, Give my heart.' If your heart is breaking, broken or shattered, give it to Jesus. He'll mend you up, put you straight and fit you back together, better than you were before.

'The Lord is close to the brokenhearted.' He never leaves us; He chooses to help us, to put things right-that's why He sent Jesus. Jesus said: 'I have come in order that you might have life-life in all its fullness.' (John 10:10 GNT)

content.title: Samson
content.introtext:
'Samson went down...' Judges 14:1 NKJ

Samson is a classic case of brawn over brains. He could rip the roar from a lion's throat or grab the growl from a grizzly's gullet but he couldn't tame his temptation for the wrong sort of woman. The story says that three times 'Samson went down' to see a Philistine woman. So the man who could reach bare-arm into a bee's nest for something sweet finds himself stung by the wrong girl.

The Philistines were enemies of God. Remember Goliath the giant, shouting abuse at David about his shabby little God-well, he was a Philistine. So what was God's chosen, Samson, doing sniffing around the enemy? Well he was clearly thinking about giving into temptation, not holding onto his faith.

Can you relate to this? Times when you choose sensation over sanctification? Pleasure over purity? Indulgence over innocence? Samson chose a path which led him to become a blind prisoner shorn of all his strengths. When God says 'no' to a relationship, or a habit or a lifestyle, He's not being a killjoy, He's protecting you. God sees where the road leads; you don't. 'Some people ruin themselves by their own stupid actions and then blame the Lord.' (Proverbs 19:3 GNT)



SoulFood: 1 Cor 7-9, Matt 2:9-12, Ps 97, Pr 31:22-24

content.title: God Will Surprise You
content.introtext:
'See, I am doing a new thing...' Isaiah 43:19 NIV

We try and pin down God in the silence of a cathedral. Or we somehow think burning a candle will woo Him down from Heaven; as if the real problem is He's got lost in the dark trying to find us!

But sometimes God surprises us. Sometimes He turns up as a voice in a burning bush. Sometimes He shrinks down to a foetus in the womb of an unmarried Jewish girl. And sometimes He's found hanging from a tree in between two common criminals. God will not be pinned down by our thin expectations. God shocks us in many guises, always announcing, 'See, I am doing a new thing! Now it springs up, do you not perceive it?'

There's the challenge, right there-our perceptions. We fail to recognise God at work. Ever been frustrated? You've prayed until your brain is asking for mercy, you've had enough of God's promises to hang your hat on, and still seen nothing? Well, try this for size: 'For the Lord is a God of justice; blessed are all who wait for Him.' (Isaiah 30:18 NIV)

You might have your timetables sketched out, but the Lord says 'wait'. 'Many are the plans in a man's heart, but it is the Lord's purpose that prevails.' (Proverbs 19:21 NIV) Time is on your side because the one who wears eternity around his wrist says 'wait'. Stay alert-tomorrow could be the new thing.

content.title: Send Revival, Start With Me (1)
content.introtext:
'Revive us, and we will call upon Your name.' Psalm 80:18 NKJ

'Revival' seems like one of those Christian jargon words that gets aired so often, you're almost too embarrassed to ask, 'What does it actually mean?'

The last two great revivals to hit Britain happened in the Scottish islands and Wales. Both saw massive changes in culture. In the Outer Hebrides of Scotland, the islands stopped-people put down their drinks and their work tools to go to church. They just felt compelled to meet God, whether they'd thought of themselves as Christians or not. The islands reported no more crime. The revival seemed to turn life the right way up.

In Wales, crowds normally reserved for footie grand finals were seen swarming into church. If you wanted to be baptised, you'd have to join the back of a queue which was 100000 people long. Swear words were swapped for worship songs. The whole place felt so different that even animals no longer recognised their owners.

Revival is like God breathing fresh air into the lungs of the dead. Revival is God resuscitating our lives back in order. Matt Redman wrote a powerful song called, 'Send revival, start with me' The song nails it. If we want to see our city put back on its feet, we need to make sure we're on our knees first. In prayer.



SoulFood: 1 Cor 12-14, Matt 2:19-23, Ps 139:13-24, Pr 31:28-29

'We become more and more like Him...' 2 Corinthians 3:18 TLB

'HAPPY NEW YEAR!' is what most of us will be shouting at midnight tonight. New Year's resolutions will be made, hoping a new 'thinner, fitter, healthier me' will emerge in 2012. The Bible says, 'become more and more like Him.' So how about we make this our New Year's resolution-everyday choosing to become more and more like Jesus?

'we will hold to the truth in love, becoming more and more in every way like Christ... Under His direction, the whole body is fitted together perfectly. content.title: New Year's reso-vision?
content.introtext:
'Write the vision and make it plain...' Habakkuk 2:2 NKJ

HAPPY NEW YEAR! So-are you the kind of person who makes hundreds of New Year's resolutions every year, and then come Jan 4, you've already gone and broken most of them? Have you made any yet this year? How long do you think they'll last?!

Well, how about this year, instead of the normal routine, you make a resolution to check out God's vision for your life, and see what you can do about it?

What actually is a 'vision'? Is it some weird hallucination thing that'll hover in front of your eyes, making you wonder if it really was a good idea to munch out on the whole of that cold pizza? If that's the case, I can understand you thinking: 'No thanks, I'll pass on a vision this year!'

But that's not the kind of vision we're talking about here. What we're talking about is more like a plan, or a dream. It's about what God can do, and wants to do, through you and your life. Maybe that still sounds a bit scary to you-but don't panic! God won't ask you to do anything you can't do. In fact, He'll ask you to do something only you can do. You'll be the perfect person for the job. Sounds pretty good to me. What better New Year's resolution could there be than getting really stuck into God's plan for your life?

content.title: Fearless (1)
content.introtext:
'Elijah was afraid and fled for his life...' 1 Kings 19:3 NIV

Read up on Elijah, and you'll discover he led an incredible life for God: He was a prophet, meaning God gave him knowledge of future events (1 Kings 17); he was given supernatural running strength that would have had Olympic gold medallists eating his dust (1 Kings 18:46); he was the first recorded person in the Bible to raise someone from the dead (1 Kings 17:22); he divided a river with his coat (2 Kings 2:8); he once braved odds of 450 to 1 challenging the prophets of Baal to prove that his God was more powerful than theirs-and of course he won (1 Kings 18:22-24).

These are just a few highlights in the life of Elijah. You'd think he'd be a fearless, confident, impressive guy 100% of the time. But truth is, even Elijah had times when he let fear rule. Once, when threatened by a queen, 'Elijah was afraid and fled for his life.'

Words can have a powerful effect on us. If we're not careful then, just like Elijah, we can become gripped with fear, thrown into depression, and feel totally intimidated and worthless.

Don't listen to the voice of fear; listen to the voice of God. He will make you fearless. 2 Timothy 1:7 NLT says, 'God has not given us a spirit of fear and timidity, but of power, love, and self-discipline.'



SoulFood: Job 1-4, Matt 3:11-17, Ps 90:1-6, Pr 1:1-4

content.title: Fearless (2)
content.introtext:
'He will work for you today...' Exodus 14:13 AMP

Paul Parker once said, 'Fear is the most devastating of all human emotions. Man has no trouble like the paralysing effects of fear.' Florence Nightingale once said, 'How very little can be done under the spirit of fear.' And they're right-fear stops us from living fully. We stop doing things, afraid it might go wrong; we don't speak up, afraid someone might laugh at us, not believe us or make us look a fool; we don't use our talents, afraid we won't be good enough; we don't try, afraid we might fail.

It has been said that fear is like the darkroom where the devil takes you to develop your negatives. But fear and faith can't live together-when one enters the other leaves. So the way to get rid of your fears, the way to become fearless, is to let God into your life. 1 John 4:18 NIV says, '...perfect love drives out fear...'

If life for you is scary, stop and remind yourself whose company you're in. Deuteronomy 31:8 NLT says; 'Do not be afraid or discouraged, for the Lord will personally go ahead of you. He will be with you; He will neither fail you nor abandon you.' Courage is fear that has said its prayers, so feed your faith and your fears will starve to death. When fear knocks at your door, answer with faith and you'll discover there's no one there.



SoulFood: Job 5-7, Matt 4:1-11, Ps 90:7-17, Pr 1:5-9

content.title: I Don't Know!
content.introtext:
'He knows where I am going.' Job 23:10 NLT

Do you get fed up with people asking you things like: 'What are you going to do when you grow up? Are you going to university? What career path are you taking?' Do you feel pressured into having to answer when all you want is to shout back, 'I don't know, please stop asking me!'

Do you feel pressured by your boyfriend or girlfriend who wants you to 'prove' your love by having sex; your friends who want you to solve your 'down' feeling by taking drugs or getting drunk; or others who say you have to stick up for yourself by using your fists?

Does life sometimes get a bit too much? Do you get confused, does your head hurt and do your insides scream: 'Leave me alone! I just don't know!'?

There's a book in the Bible named after a man called Job, whose life became unbearable: 'Darkness is all around me; thick, impenetrable darkness is everywhere.' (Job 23:17 NLT) His mind was confused by circumstances and his friends' opinions. But Job knew in this muddled mess that he could completely trust God. 'He knows where I am going,' Job said. He knew he could trust God to help him out of his muddled mess. He just had to stick with God, living life His way. The same is true for you today.

content.title: Sort It Out!

'If you are displeased, I will go back.' Numbers 22:34 NIV

Not many can resist the adorable Donkey from the Shrek movies. But did you know that Shrek wasn't the first to hear a talking donkey? That privilege was given to Balaam. He was a prophet who told people what God said. He believed that he must obey God, no matter what.

One time, people from a country called Moab asked Balaam for help. God made it very clear that what they were asking wasn't right, so at first Balaam sent them away. But the Moabites kept offering bigger and better bribes. Balaam began to struggle to put into practice what he knew in theory. When he went wrong, God used his donkey to show him: 'Then the Lord opened the donkey's mouth, and she said to Balaam, "What have I done...to make you beat me...three times?" ...The angel of the Lord asked him, "Why have you beaten your donkey...? I have come here to oppose you because your path is a reckless one..." Balaam said, "I have sinned. ... if you are displeased, I will go back."' (Numbers 22:28-34 NIV)

Doing what you know is right can be hard at times. And when we make a mistake and don't correct it, we end up making another mistake. Ask God if there is something you need to put right today and go sort it out. God may not tell you through a donkey-but He will let you know.

content.title: Chip On Your Shoulder?
content.introtext:
'I will give [you] favour...' Exodus 3:21 NKJ

There are so many people who don't expect anything good in life. They don't expect to get breaks, they don't expect good grades or to get a job they really want. They don't expect anything positive. Are you one of them? Do you think you'll always be 'the bridesmaid, never the bride' or always 'the friend, never the boyfriend'? Do you go around thinking people have 'got it in for you' and your family is the worst ever?

Could this be your attitude towards God too? Do you think that God's got it in for you? Do you say things like, 'God would never want to do anything good for me and I've got a whole lifetime of events to prove it'? If you've got a big chip on your shoulder, now's the time to knock it off.

Listen! What God said to the Israelites thousands of years ago He says to you today: 'I will give [you] favour.' The Israelites were hostages, slaves trapped inside the enemy's camp and so they prayed for freedom. They asked God for favour and He gave it them. He did it in the most unexpected ways-using frogs, boils, locusts to name just a few (read Exodus to find out more). Proverbs 16:3 NLT says 'Commit your actions to the Lord, and your plans will succeed.' He will 'give you favour' in the most unexpected ways.

content.title: Competing and Comparing
content.introtext:
'A man must be content to receive the gift...given him from Heaven...' John 3:27 AMP

Have you ever ruined something by trying to use it for something it wasn't designed for? Like using your bed as a trampoline? Or using your shoe as a hammer, turning high heels into flatties? Or using the garage door as a goal and it still has the dents to prove it?

Ephesians 2:10 NIV tells us, 'we are God's handiwork, created...to do good works, which God prepared in advance for us to do.' Notice that it doesn't say we were all created identically to do exactly the same things. So it's really important we find out what we're good at-what God prepared for us-and get on with it. We mustn't allow jealousy to creep in and ruin what we have.

Disciples of John the Baptist became nervous when Jesus arrived in town because people began to follow Jesus and not John. But John replied, 'A man must be content to receive the gift...given him from Heaven... I am not the Christ... I have [only] been sent before Him...to be His appointed forerunner, His messenger.' (John 3:27-28 AMP) John knew there is no sense in competing and comparing yourself to others, we are simply to do what we've been created to do. Simply be you!

Corrie ten Boom, a Dutch Christian holocaust survivor who helped many Jews escape the Nazis during World War II, said this: 'Don't bother to give God instructions; just report for duty.'

content.title: K.I.S.S.
content.introtext:
'Forgiveness...in accordance with the riches of...grace.' Ephesians 1:7 NIV

If you speak to anyone who has done some sales training they'll tell you one of the first things they learn is the acronym 'K.I.S.S.' It means 'Keep It Simple, Stupid' and it's a reminder to deliver every sales presentation in such a simple way that the listener understands straight away.

Sometimes we can overcomplicate the things God says to us too. The verse today is about how much God lavishly loves and forgives us. God tells us His love and forgiveness is unconditional-we don't get it because we earn it or deserve it, but because He chooses to pile it on us by the bucket load.

But He also tells us He wants us to do the same to others. This is where it can get a little more complicated. It's easy to accept God's forgiveness for ourselves, but nowhere near as easy to give it to others. Love and forgive those who don't deserve it? Those we don't like very much? Strangers? Those we've already given 10 chances too? But that doesn't seem fair! It doesn't seem right! You see, we make it complicated.

At times like this we need to hear God whispering in our ear, 'Keep It Simple ,Stupid!' When we overcomplicate the simplest of instructions from God it makes a mess of our lives. Nothing fits right, relationships break down, life becomes a hassle. By making God's love complicated, we miss out on it and make others miss out on it too. So, every day remember to K.I.S.S!



SoulFood: Ex 17:8-16, Eph 3:14-21

'Like the blind we grope...feeling our way like men without eyes...' Isaiah 59:10 NIV

Have you noticed how small children have a tendency to bump into things, fall off seats, tumble down stairs, or trip over the most obvious of objects in their way? You can quite often hear their parents shouting, 'Watch where you're going! Watch what you're doing!' Perhaps you remember your parents saying that to you (perhaps they still do?). Parents aren't saying those things to be spoilsports; they're saying it to try and protect the children they love from a nasty fall.

Romans 3:23 NLT tells us, 'Everyone has sinned; we all fall short of God's glorious standard.' Everyone has tripped up, messed up and fallen away from God. When we do, the Bible says, 'Like the blind we grope...feeling our way like men without eyes.'

God, our heavenly Father, doesn't want us to live like this so He tells us to watch where we're going. He's not criticising your clumsiness, He is saying: look up, look out, look ahead never lose sight of all I am, what I can do and will do-so don't be tempted to turn away from Me.

Let Psalm 119:10-11 be your prayer today: 'I seek You with all my heart; do not let me stray from Your commands. I have hidden Your word in my heart that I might not sin against You.'
