content.title: Surrender (1)
content.introtext:
'...because You say so, I will...' Luke 5:5 NIV

Know what the ultimate test is? The Lordship test. Simon Peter passed this test by obeying a command that seemed to make no sense at all. Jesus said to him, 'Put out into deep water, and let down the nets for a catch. Simon answered, Master, we've worked hard all night and haven't caught anything. But because You say so, I will let down the nets. When they had done so, they caught such a large number of fish that their nets began to break.' (Luke 5:4-6 NIV).

Even though we've seen God do so much in our lives, it's still so easy to catch ourselves thinking that we know best. Especially when we think experience has proved us right. For example, when we've tried something time and time again and feel like giving up. When Jesus says 'stick at it', it's easy to think: 'Haven't you seen what happened? It's just not working!'

This was early days in Jesus and Peter's relationship. It would have been easy for Peter to think: 'Hang on, I've been a fisherman all my life. What can this preaching carpenter teach me about catching fish?' But he didn't. He said: 'Because you say so...' First Peter tried fishing alone and failed. Next he tried it with Jesus and succeeded. Same fisherman. Same boat. Same nets. What changed? He was willing to do it God's way! Passing the Lordship test means trusting that Jesus knows best even when your experiences or circumstances say otherwise.



SoulFood: Josh 2:1-24, Acts 9:20-30

content.title: Surrender (2)
content.introtext:
'...Because You say so, I will...' Luke 5:5 NIV

You don't imagine Mal Meninga's half-time talks sound much like this: 'We're 22-14 down, boys. So we may as well give up. Let's admit defeat and we can all go grab a latte.' Yeah right!

Winners never give in, right? Wrong. God asks us to give in. God asks us to lay down our dreams and ambitions to Him. If we want to make our life count we must first submit ourselves to God. William Booth made his life count-he started a worldwide movement drumming up Christians to love and live with the poorest people. It became The Salvation Army. He said, 'The greatness of a man's power is in the measure of his surrender.' In other words, the most important step of his life was not opening his first church or setting foot abroad, it was the moment he chose, in the quiet of his heart, to give up his own plans for his life and take up God's plans instead.

Eventually we all surrender to something. Some surrender to God; others surrender to money. Some give in to God; others give in to fear. Some submit to God; others submit to lust. Some hold out for God; others hold onto their ego. You're free to choose who or what you will lay down. But only Christ will bring true freedom in exchange for your surrender.



SoulFood: Judges 7:1-9:33, Matt 16:13-28, Ps 119:65-72, Pr 17:23-26

content.title: Surrender (3)
content.introtext:
'...Because You say so, I will...' Luke 5:5 NIV

Have you ever tried to hold on to something really wriggly-like a hyperactive hamster? Or slippery-like a frightened frog? It's practically impossible! So why do you think you can keep the people or circumstances of your life tightly in your grip? LET GO! Really, go ahead: surrender it to God. You'll be amazed at how much more energy you'll have, and how much simpler life will be. Once you make the choice to surrender it to God, those difficult days will soon seem like a distant memory. A Bible expert called Tozer once wrote: 'Father, my cowardly heart fears to give up its toys. I cannot part with them without inward bleeding, and I do not try to hide from You my terror of the parting. I come trembling, but I do come. Please root from my heart those things which I have cherished so long and which have become a very part of my living self, so that You may enter and dwell there without a rival.' So, you say, 'Surrender what?'

(1) Your reputation! What good is 'street cred' compared to 'God cred'? Find your security and your identity in Him.

(2) Your plans! Sure, think ahead, but be ready for God to rearrange things and take you along a new path. Nothing this side of Heaven is permanent, including relationships. Enjoy the time you have with your mates and your loved ones, but avoid the temptation to get clingy.

(3) Your stuff! If your attention is occupied with the stuff you own, you aren't fully available for God. No, you're still clinging to minor things. Stop. Let go! You're cluttering the awesome life God has made possible for you.



SoulFood: Judges 9:34-11:40, Matt 17:1-13, Ps 119:73-80, Pr 20:25, Ecc 5:4-6

content.title: Kid's Stuff
content.introtext:
'God, You have taught me since I was young.' Psalm 71:17 NCV

'God, You have taught me since I was young. To this day I tell about the miracles You do.' (Psalm 71:17 NCV) When God created a movement to tell the world about His wonders, you know who He chose to kick it all off? Youth.

Yes, God chose young people, like you, to do the most important job ever-tell the world about Jesus. Some of the disciples were raggedy kids from poor backgrounds. All were inexperienced and uncultured. Few had travelled beyond their own country. They lived in an insignificant part of the world under a corrupt government. They argued and bickered about trivial things. Most of them had jobs that didn't pay well. Some worked like corrupt gangsters, one was even a terrorist. Finally, they took off when the going got tough-not the best ending to three years of on-the-job training. Hardly the types to start a major world revolution, are they? And yet these inconsistent, bickering, shallow kids grew up to change the world. They became wise, loving and deeply committed followers of God.

Never let anyone say you're 'just a kid'. You're key personnel in the formation of God's movement.



SoulFood: Judges 12-15, Matt 17:14-27, Ps 119:81-88, Pr 17:27-28

content.title: Pressure points
content.introtext:
'Someone with a quick temper does foolish things...' Proverbs 14:17 NCV

Pulsing veins in the neck, red mist in front of the eyes: pressure points, we all have them. Detentions after school. Late buses. Annoying little brothers. Unreliable friends. You-must-be-joking homework. Those are pressure points. Stuff that knots up your muscles and turns your hands into fists.

There's no point trying to pretend we're always 100% 'harmony, hippy Harry'. In fact, anger is a natural emotion. Uncontrolled fury, however, is not. We need to find ways of managing our anger healthily.

1 Samuel 25 tells a story of David and his quick temper. Nabal, unreasonably, refuses to feed David and his soldiers. Something about the unfairness of the situation rattles David's insides, and he's all set for revenge. Only Abigail, Nabal's wife, saves the men from full-on bloodshed. Her reasoning, thankfully, speaks louder than heated emotions.

We too could do with a dose of sensible reasoning over bloodshed and carnage when it comes to our own pressure points. When a new top shrinks in the wash or a favourite game is crushed by a clumsy foot, then flying off the handle with harsh words will only explode the situation. Someone with a quick temper does foolish things. Don't be a fool for fights. Use your brain not your brawn. Think two steps ahead. Think about the consequences of uncontrolled anger.



SoulFood: Judges 16:1-19:15, Matt 18:1-9, Ps 119:89-96, Pr 18:1-5

content.title: When the Whistle Blows
content.introtext:
'You will...be led...with peace...' Isaiah 55:12 NAS

'Trust the Lord with all your heart, and don't depend on your own understanding. Remember the Lord in all you do, and He will give you success. Don't depend on your own wisdom. Respect the Lord and refuse to do wrong.' (Proverbs 3:5-7 NCV)

Ever had that twinge of conscience when you were about to do something that it isn't quite right? Well, maybe it was the voice of God speaking deep down into you. Psalm 32:8 NCV backs this up: 'I will make you wise...show you where to go...and watch over you.' Left to our own devices, we'd choose the path that looks nicest, but sometimes isn't the best: 'There is a way that seems right...but its end is...death.' (Proverbs 14:12 ESV)

What does it look like? Having a drink? Getting into that car? It may all seem harmless enough, but what's it going to lead to? That uncertain feeling might not be nerves or weakness-it could be God grabbing your attention to danger.

Think of it like a footy match. When the players stay within the boundaries of the game, they're free to move about. But when there's trouble, or the ball goes out of play, the referee blows the whistle. A lack of peace could mean God is blowing the whistle on your boundaries.

content.title: Desert Panoramic
content.introtext:
'Let your eyes look straight ahead...' Proverbs 4:25 NKJ

You can understand why the Complain Brigade was moaning. It was hot-sizzling, in fact. You could fry eggs on your forehead in those temperatures! And it was dangerous: wild animals, predators, snakes. Did I mention how hot it was? At times it seemed they were destined to die out in that vast desert.

It seemed like they were getting nowhere. Hadn't they passed this particular rock two years ago? Were they just going round in circles? And the food! What they would give to feel a cool cucumber on their parched tongues. Or a bit of a change from the same old dish they'd been served for the last four decades. Did I mention how hot it was?

Only the old guy at the front, leading the way, seemed to be striding with any purpose; the rest dragged their feet, kicking at the sharp stones in the scorched sand. The Complain Brigade saw wilderness upon wilderness; whereas Moses saw a promised land. What's your perspective through the tough times? Do you see a wilderness-dry, vast and empty? Or do you see a promise from God?

Proverbs 4:25 NCV says, 'Keep your eyes focussed on what is right, and look straight ahead to what is good.' Take your eyes off the desert panoramic and fix them tunnel-vision on God's promises.



SoulFood: Gal 1-3, Matt 18:21-35, Ps 119:105-112, Pr 18:9

content.title: Think About What You Think About (1)
content.introtext:
'What I feared has come upon me...' Job 3:25 NIV

Nick was a tough guy with a bad outlook. He worked on the railways. One night after all his fellow workers had gone home he accidentally locked himself in a refrigerated carriage. Worried that the temperature was below freezing, he yelled for help, but to no avail. The more he thought about his situation the colder he felt, until eventually he started shivering uncontrollably. Convinced he was dying, he wrote a letter to his family outlining what had happened. The next morning they found Nick's body. An autopsy revealed that he had indeed frozen to death. But the investigators discovered something puzzling. The carriage in which Nick was trapped was out of order and had been disconnected. The night he froze to death, the temperature in the boxcar was 16.1 degrees-just below room temperature. But because he expected to die, he lost the battle in his mind.

What you believe about your life is more important than what anyone else believes. Job said, 'What I feared has come upon me.' Be careful what you anticipate because negative expectations can become self-fulfilling prophecies.

God has promised to help you, but you get the deciding vote. Jesus said, 'Let it happen...just as you believe!' (Matthew 9:29 GNT) So get into agreement with God's Word and focus on His promises instead of your problems. 'Let us hold on firmly to the hope we profess, because we can trust God to keep His promise.' (Hebrews 10:23 GNT)



SoulFood: Gen 6:9-8:4, Matt 24:37-51

content.title: Think About What You Think About (2)
content.introtext:
'...He is able to accomplish infinitely more than we would ever dare to ask or hope...' Ephesians 3:20 NLT

The story goes that the king of Saudi Arabia met up with a famous golfer. Before the man returned home the king said, 'I'd like to give you a gift. Anything you want; name it.' Politely, the golfer said he didn't need anything. But because the king insisted, he gave in: 'Well, Your Highness, I collect golf clubs.' He imagined unwrapping a gold putter or a diamond-studded driver. Imagine his shock weeks later when he got a letter containing the deed to an 800-hectare golf club!

Paul says, 'God...is able to accomplish infinitely more than we would ever dare ask or hope...' Kings don't think like we do. They don't bust a blood vessel over what's in the treasure chest, because the treasure chest has more than you could ever imagine. Of course, you know Jesus' nickname, don't you? That would be 'King of Kings'-which means He has the treasure chests of all treasure chests. And because He's your friend, He wants to share the loot.

God's plan for you far outweighs owning your own personal golf course. So go on, what kind of good things can you imagine? (We're not talking here about winning the lottery or X Factor or anything that could drive a huge wedge between you and God.) Now double them, quadruple them, and you're still not close to what God has for you-if you'll believe. Expect the best and you'll get the best, and more.



SoulFood: Gal 4-6, Matt 19:1-14, Ps 119:113-120, Pr 18:10-12

content.title: Practice of Patience
content.introtext:
'Let ...patience...do a thorough work...' James 1:4 AMP

There's a joke about a man on death row. The prison warden asks him what he'd like for his last meal. He says, 'A huge piece of watermelon.' The warden goes, 'You must be joking! Watermelons aren't in season till summer and it's only just winter.' The inmate replies, 'That's okay, I don't mind waiting.' I bet he doesn't!

But here's the question: do you mind waiting? How do you act when things don't move fast enough? Are you a pin up saint of patience or do you seethe with annoyance?

A well-known minister writes, 'I happened to be in a store and had waited a long time in a slow-moving line to pay for one little item. The people in front of me had stacks of items. Then I was overlooked while somebody else was served ahead of me. When it was finally my turn, the sales assistant looked at me and said, Thank you for waiting. Are you who I think you are-that preacher on TV? I knew the minute you walked in that it was you. I thought to myself, What if I'd been angry and mouthing off because I wasn't served in the proper order?' See, you never know who is watching. When you're shooting your mouth off, you're not being a good rep for Jesus. So watch your mouth because you never know who else is watching it too.



SoulFood: Lam 1:1-3:39, Matt 19:15-30, Ps 119:121-128, Pr 18:13-20

content.title: Speak Up!
content.introtext:
'...encourage the fainthearted, help the weak...' 1 Thessalonians 5:14 NAS

OK, so your heart works overtime when somebody asks you what you did on the weekend and you mumble: 'Erm...actually...I...er...went to church.' Nobody wants to get the third degree just because they think what Jesus said makes sense. Nor do you want to get singled out just because you don't believe life is the end-result of some random explosion billions of years ago.

But imagine if you walked out your door this morning and got whisked off to jail just for wearing a WWJD wristband. Right now millions of Christians around the world face prison and sometimes death simply because they believe the same stuff as you. Pretty tough, huh?

Your God says, 'Encourage the fainthearted, help the weak.' It only takes one thing to be an encourager: a willingness to 'bear the weaknesses of those without strength.' (Romans 15:1 NAS) Check out www.myheartbleeds.com.au for inspiring ways to encourage those who are persecuted for what they believe. And before you say, 'What have somebody else's problems got to do with me?' then read this: 'If one member suffers, all the members suffer.' (1 Corinthians 12:26 NKJ) You wouldn't stay quiet if your sister was being bashed, would you? Guess what, that is your sister (and your brother) that is getting bashed around the world-your sister and brother in Christ. For their sake, don't stay silent.



SoulFood: Lam 3:40-5:22, Matt 20:1-16, Ps 119:129-136, Pr 18:21

content.title: God Gives the Green Light (1)
content.introtext:
'The Lord...loves to see His servants do well.' Psalm 35:27 NCV

Ah, remember Sports Day? Embarrassing parents shouting at the top of their tonsils at their 'little cherub' who is obviously the fastest, bestest, most talented kid ever to balance an egg on a spoon. A bit 'biased', perhaps?

Know what? God is a bit 'biased' about you. Jesus said, 'If you then, being evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your Father who is in Heaven give good things...' (Matthew 7:11 NKJ) In other words, if you think you want good stuff for your kids, you can't even imagine what good stuff God wants for them.

Do you have this wild-eyed idea about how to bring a bit of God's Kingdom to your mates? So wild that, quite frankly, your pastor nearly choked when you told him? So out-there that your best mates booked a van to take you to the place with soft walls and rubber cutlery? So crazy, your own brain feels sore whenever you try to think about it?

If you keep coming back to this big idea and every time you do, those little hairs on the back of your neck do star-jumps, perhaps it's a prompting from the Holy Spirit in you. Why not step out and see if God comes through and surprises everyone?

content.title: God Gives the Green Light (2)
content.introtext:
'The Lord...loves to see His servants do well.' Psalm 35:27 NCV

Whoaaa! Stop that horse! Yesterday we galloped straight ahead into the sunset because God was giving us the green light. Adrenalin and excitement are great for getting us out of the starting blocks but what if we're about to join a long distance race rather than a fast sprint? Perhaps, our wild-eyed idea needs some thinking if it's going to go the distance.

First, let's think about what our idea will cost us. Sure, we'll gain a whole load of God's Kingdom, but, realistically, we'll lose something of ourselves. What are you going to give up? Some of your 'you time', a bit of your 'head space', a slice of your pride? Maybe, you'll need to give up 'sole ownership' or 'copyright' on your idea- it's amazing how much further your dream will go when you're not bothered about who gets the credit.

Secondly, fill in the detail. Get precise with the do's and don'ts; set yourself deadlines, goals, targets; make the most of your gifts, talents, time and energy. Get others to help you flesh out the dream; write lists for what needs to be done, run with your idea.

Thirdly, see it! Imagine the idea on its feet; see yourself running with it, working it, doing it. Romans 4:17 NKJ says that God 'calls those things which do not exist as though they did.' Now, are you ready? The lights are turning green...



SoulFood: Amos 5:18-9:15, Matt 20:29-34, Ps 119:145-160, Pr 19:1-2

content.title: Motives in Money
content.introtext:
'Do not do your charitable deeds...to be seen.' Matthew 6:1 NKJ

What would you think if your mate had a chicken and you were partial to scrambled eggs? You'd hope he'd share the wealth and pass a few free eggs your way, right? If he forced you to cough up every time you got a bit peckish-you'd think he was Scrooge Junior, wouldn't you?

A world famous preacher called Charles Spurgeon did just that. No way did old Charles give away free eggs. Friends and family alike were told to splash the cash. The old fella must've been a right tight wad, don't you think? Everybody else did. Until the full story finally came out.

What he didn't tell anyone was that all the profits from his sales were given to two old widows. If only Charles would've just said so, he could've avoided all the goss that he was 'greedy'. But you see Charles Spurgeon took Jesus' words literally: 'But when you help a needy person, do it in such a way that even your closest friend will not know about it. Then it will be a private matter. And your Father, who sees what you do in private, will reward you.' (Matthew 6:3-4 GNT)

Do you fan yourself down with your crisp note, bite it and then cough loudly as you place it in the church collection? Do you smile for the CCTV camera when you're about to help an old lady across the road? What's today's verse again...?



SoulFood: Ezek 1-4, Matt 21:1-11, Ps 119:161-168, Pr 19:3-8

content.title: Growing in God (1): Purpose
content.introtext:
'...God chose us to be His own people in union with Christ...' Ephesians 1:11 GNT

For squillions of years, people with clever-sounding names have wrinkled the muscles of their foreheads struggling to come up with an answer to all this 'life' business. And here's little old you, barely a high school certificate to your name, with the problem sussed!

Without God, life has no meaning. It's all about Him. 'He created all things in Heaven and on earth, visible and invisible. Whether they are kings or lords, rulers or powers-everything has been created through Him and for Him.' (Colossians 1:16 GWT) If we're going to grow in God, we need to stop thinking about ourselves all the time. What should I do with my life? What are my dreams? What does the future have for me? 'If you try to keep your life for yourself, you will lose it. But if you give up your life for me, you will find true life.' (Matthew 16:25 NLT)

Even before you were a thought in your mum's head, God dreamed up amazing stuff for you to do. He has custom-built assignments only you can undertake. The trouble is you can waste time trying to fit into the world's mould rather stretch out in God's freedom. Some people make life about accumulating things-good job, piles of money, nice house, fancy car, latest fashion. Others make it about show business; they want the world to pick them up in a planet-sized spotlight. But life only comes into sharp focus when you connect yourself to God's purpose. Without God, life is meaningless.



SoulFood: 2 Kings 4:42-44, Mark 6:30-44

content.title: Growing in God (2): Worship
content.introtext:
'Don't just pretend that you love others... Stand on the side of the good.' Romans 12:9 NLT

What makes a normally sane and sensible mum suddenly scream like a wild-eyed, giggling teenager at an Andr Rieu concert? What makes a usually quiet, grumpy dad high-five a complete stranger at the sight of Steve Waugh's double-century comeback? What possesses you to plaster posters all over your bedroom wall?

The answer is adoration. It's as if something in us wants to throw our hearts at something out of our reach. Could it be that we're built with a default setting to worship and adore someone greater than ourselves? Whether we choose to worship God or not, our heart will always find something to love (even if it's ourselves).

Growing in God means loving God. Jesus said it is the most important thing we can do: 'You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your mind. This is the great and first commandment.' (Matthew 22: 37-38 ESV)

When you fall big-time for Mr or Miss Heart-throb, you can't stop thinking of them, right? You've got one topic of conversation, right? You try to hang out where they hang out, right? This is what our worship of God should look like. We sing songs because we're mad about God. We talk about God a lot because we're one-track-minded. We want to do certain things just to get a glimpse of God.



SoulFood: Ezek 5-9, Matt 21:12-17, Ps 119:169-176, Pr 19: 9-10

content.title: Growing in God (3): Friendship
content.introtext:
'The Lord shares His plans with those who have respect for Him...' Psalm 25:14 NIV

You wouldn't have much of a mate if you only saw them once a week and if they had one eye on the clock the whole time because they had somewhere better to go afterwards. Likewise, you won't grow a close friendship with God just by attending church once a week.

Best mates phone each other up, constantly comment on Facebook updates, chill in each other's rooms, hang out, share secrets, laugh together, cry on each other's shoulders. Friendships grow close through the ups and downs of each and every day.

Jesus didn't die just so you could have a moral code to live by. Jesus died so that you can call God your friend: '...now we can rejoice in our wonderful new relationship with God-all because of what our Lord Jesus Christ has done for us in making us friends of God.' (Romans 5:11 NLT)

Don't miss out on the closeness of God-your relationship can be so much more than an appointment in your diary. Every conversation, every problem, every thought, can involve God, if you choose. 1 Thessalonians 5:17 calls it, 'praying without ceasing' and it means an open-ended conversation whilst you shop, in school, at work, in the shower or on your bike! It's not about making time for God; it's about being with Him. Share every waking, living moment with God and become best friends with Him.



SoulFood: Ezek 10-13, Matt 21:18-32, Ps 84, Pr 19:11

content.title: Growing in God (4): Christ-like
content.introtext:
'This life that I live now, I live by faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave His life for me.' Galatians 2:20 GNT

It's tempting to think it's all glamour and fun when you see someone accept their award for Best Leading Actor at the Oscars. What you haven't seen, though, is the blood, sweat and tears that have gone before. Nobody drags themselves onto a film set and puts in a winning performance without a lot of hard work and dedication.

The best actors submerge themselves in the lives of the character they're playing. They ask themselves: what makes this character tick? What's their back-story? What drives them on? So-called 'method actors' even begin to live like their character in order to portray them as accurately as possible.

Being a Christian is a bit like being a 'method actor'. We try to live like Jesus in order to portray Him accurately. We submerge ourselves into the role of Christ. If we're serious about becoming Christ-like we start acting like Him. We ask what makes Jesus tick; we study His actions in the Bible; we develop His habits. Philippians 2:5 NIV says, 'Your attitude should be the same as that of Christ Jesus.'

What does this mean? If we start practicing being kind, we get good at being kind. If we rehearse being loving, loving becomes our second nature. If we act thoughtfully, we develop into a thoughtful person. We don't play-act being Christ to become a fake, shallow Christian who's only interested in looking good; we genuinely want to imitate Christ to become like Him.



SoulFood: Ezek 14:1-16:52, Matt 21:33-46, Ps 103:1-12, Pr 19:12-16

content.title: The Bless-fest Song
content.introtext:
'You prepare a table before me in the presence of my enemies...' Psalm 23:5 NKJ

David wasn't some singer-songwriter wannabe on the sniff of a number one when he wrote Psalm 23; he knew what opposition looked like. This is the guy who spent years in the wilderness dodging King Saul's sword, living off his wits to stay alive. So how can a man pushed to the edge write such upbeat lyrics? 'You prepare a table before me in the presence of my enemies; You anoint my head with oil; my cup runs over. Surely goodness and mercy shall follow me all the days of my life...' (vv 5-6 NKJ)

That word 'surely'. Underline it. It's God's guarantee. If a man who didn't even know if he'd live to see the next day can write 'surely' goodness will follow me wherever I go, shouldn't we be able to grab ourselves a big bag of God's 'surely' too? And what about that bit where David's enemies get ringside seats at his bless-fest? He's saying God chooses to bless you in face of any tough opposition. He's saying that God will strengthen you when you most need it. Years later, Paul agreed: 'Because when I am weak, then I am truly strong.' (2 Corinthians 12:10 NCV)

Whether your enemy is a person or a situation, Psalm 23 gives us the confidence to know that as long as we don't take matters into our own hands, good stuff is 'surely' about to be served up.



SoulFood: Obadiah, 2 John, Matt 15:1-14, Ps 119:33-40, Pr 17:16

content.title: Armed with apology
content.introtext:
'...As...Peter was standing by the fire...' John 18:25 NLT

What's with Simon Peter? One minute he's swearing he'll go to the death with Jesus; the next he's swearing he doesn't even know Jesus. Just hours after waving his sword about trying to defend Jesus, Simon Peter is asked, 'You are not one of His disciples, are you?' He denies it, saying, 'I am not.' (John 18:18, 25 NIV)

Do you have your own wavering moments? One moment you're promising to win all your friends for Christ but a few weeks on, you're keeping your 'Christian life' well and truly hidden? See, under pressure we can trip ourselves up. But how do we find our feet again? Simple: we come back to Jesus armed with our apologies. You can pretend your mistake is no big deal or you can point the finger at others, but you can't pull the wool over God's eyes. Hebrews 4:13 NLT says, 'Nothing in all creation is hidden from God. Everything is naked and exposed before His eyes, and He is the one to whom we are accountable.' God already knows your trip-up; He's waiting for you to admit you've done wrong and ask for forgiveness.

Simon Peter denied Jesus to a huddle of men gathered by a fire. Days later, around another fire, Peter acknowledged Jesus as Lord. Peter put right his wrong. Jesus forgave and restored. Put your wrong right.



SoulFood: Ruth 1-4, Matt 15:15-28, Ps 119:41-48, Pr 17:17

content.title: On a Whinge Binge?
content.introtext:
'Let us examine our ways and test them...' Lamentations 3:40 NIV

Whether you've got a brain-box like Einstein or a mind like a muddle-headed wombat, the book of Proverbs is for you! '...even smart people can find good advice in these words.' (Proverbs 1:5 NCV) Try this one: 'Stone is heavy, and sand is weighty, but a complaining fool is worse than either.' (Proverbs 27:3 NCV) There's nothing like a gripe to bring everybody down, is there? When you're complaining, you can be sure your heart (and that of everyone else around you) will feel as heavy as stone.

That's why Philippians 2:14 NCV tells us to: 'Do everything without complaining or arguing.' Going on a 'whinge binge' won't change a situation; only taking positive action will. Fact is, if you screw up your face in a grumbling mess, you're not going to remove the situation from your life. Tackling it head on is the only way to see change.

So, how can we mute the volume of the moan? Be honest with yourself-is there something you're doing wrong? Instead of pointing the finger at the whole world, take a look in the mirror. What needs to change? Is that mixture of sarcasm and sulk bringing about results? So what will change things, and what stuff is best left in God's hands?



SoulFood: Judges 1-3, Matt 15:29-39, Ps 119:49-56, Pr 17:18-21

content.title: God-gloss (3)
content.introtext:
'The lips of the godly speak helpful words...' Proverbs 10:32 NLT

'Careless talk cost lives' was a famous poster campaign in Britain during the Second World War. See, if G.I. Joe was impressing the girls at the bar saying, 'I fly to Berlin tomorrow to wipe off the moustache from under Hitler's nose,' guess who was going to be shot down once the German spy got on the blower?


Perhaps we'd benefit from wearing that slogan next to our WWJD wristbands. Getting stuck into somebody with slanderous words makes us look unattractive. Who knows who could be listening to our cruel words, thinking, 'Well, if that's what Christians do, you can forget it.' Our careless words could dishonour Christ.


So how do you keep your God-gloss from going all goss-gloss on you? (1) Facts not fiction. Let's not even begin to snowball the story when it could all be pure fiction. (2) Mind your own business. Even if it is true, does it directly affect you? Should you be talking about it? Chances are if it's sensitive, then it should be private. You're not doing anybody any favours, especially God, if you're broadcasting secrets all over the airwaves. (3) Helpful or hurtful? Do you help the situation by plastering it on Facebook or does that end up hurting people? Help or hurt-the choice is yours.


SoulFood: 1 Pet 1-5, Matt 14:22-36, Ps 119:25-32, Pr 17:11-15
